Justification: From Medieval Greek φαρδύς < Ancient (εὐ-)φραδής 'wise; linguistically correct', with metathesis /fra-/ > /far-/ ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1523), further a derivative from the same root as Ancient Greek φράζομαι 'to consider, think (up), perceive', but with no known etymology outside of Greek (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1588).

No certain etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1063-1064, {ref Beekes 2010}:1413-1414);  {ref LIV²} 603 mechanically reconstructs ?*strebʰ-, but ?*stregʷʰ- also remains theoretically possible.

Apparently related to tʿacʿ- the aorist stem of Classical Armenian tʿanam 'to (become) wet, to moisten, drench' (cf. {ref HAB} II:150-151), further to PIE *teh₂- 'to thaw, melt' ({ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:113-114, {ref LIV²} 616).

Comment: Loanword from Persian.
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3945; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

Justification: Etymology uncertain. Traditionally derived to PIE *melh₂- 'to grind' (cf. {ref Karulis 1992} I:580, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:403). [Not in {ref Derksen 2015}; not in {ref IEW}].
No certain etymology ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
Root etymology disputed, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:388, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:994-995 for various proposals.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:297 no. 5385.
Loanword from Persian سرخ / sorx 'red'.
Parallel loans from Saṇu-viri: Wâmâ ẓ′oːk

Comment: Gharib (1995: 429 #10568) suggests a connection with Av. vǝrǝzra, which is not attested in Bartholomae (1904)

Justification: Derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'be warm, hot' ({ref Lucht 2007}:376, {ref Matasović 2009}:147, {ref NIL} 196-199).
Hellenic lexemes as though from PIE *skl̥h₁-ró-, an derived adjective to PIE *(s)kelh₁- 'to dry out, dry up' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1012-1013, {ref Beekes 2010}:1345-1346, cf. {ref LIV²} 553).
Cognacy in this class for the verb is coded for NHG -legen (cf. NHG überlegen 'to consider, reflect, think'); cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:939 for the history of the formation.

Comment: Bailey (1979: 440) < *an-āmara-ka- ‘not sour’, as the reverse, Khotan Saka āhvarai ‘sour’, is ‘not sweet’. Reference to Pokorny om- and Old Indic amlá-, amblá- 'sour; sorrel'.

Justification: Classical Armenian tʿakʿowcʿanem, secondarily derived from Classical Armenian tʻakʻcʻi- 'hide oneself' as though from PIE *pth₂k-eh₁-sk̑e/o- (cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:79, 262; {ref LIV²} 495).
Parallel loans into Modern Indic from Persian برف / barf 'snow' (cf. /cognate/126/).
Loanword from Calabrian Italian culírcia 'winged / reddish ant'.
Loanword from Early Scandinavian, cf. Old Icelandic leggr 'leg' ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Comment: Original meaning "to observe".
Justification: Ultimately a derivative of PIE 1. *ser- to look after, protect' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:10, {ref Cheung 2007}:129, cf. {ref LIV²} 534).
Probably from a compound containing *h₁en- 'in' + temh₁- 'cut off' ({ref Adams 2013}:92-93).
Loanword from Latin numerāre 'to count, enumerate' ({ref Orel 1998}:291).
Loanword from Middle English putten 'to push' ((ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:284, cf. {ref Broaderick 1984b}:356).
Loan from Old French songer (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:677).

Comment: Cognate class A should be reserved for borrowings from Persian, not for Persian itself.

Justification: Parallel loans from from Old French fruit.

The etymology in this cognate set is tentatively assigned to PIE *h₃rei̯H- following {ref Orel 1998}:366, {ref Holm 2011}:56, but cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:344, {ref Holm 2011}:56 for discussion of alternative etymologies.

Italic lexemes continuing a derivative of PIE *dʰeh₁-k- 'to make, produce' ({ref LIV²} 139-140), widely considered to be connected to PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to put, place, to set up; to do' ({ref LIV²} 136-138), but the origins of the k-element on the root remain obscure (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:198-199).
Cf. Swedish slå ihjäl 'beat to death'

Comment: perhaps from PIE *sek- 'to cut'

Justification: North Germanic lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *spurda- (cf. Middle High German sporte 'tail', without attestation in East Germanic). Cf. {ref Orel 2003}:367, {ref de Vries 1977}:537 for uncertain attempts at an etymology outside of Germanic. [Not in {ref Kroonen 2013}].

Comment: cf. Turkish kuyruk "tail"

Justification: Slavic lexemes of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Boryś 2005}:422, 424, {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1189. For a proposed comparison to Latin pānus 'tumour' see {ref Derksen 2008}:416 (but cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:444).

Ancient Greek (ἀπο-)κτείνω 'to kill, put to death', derived from PIE *t⁽k̑⁾én-i̯e/o-, a derivative of the root *t⁽k̑⁾en- 'to injure' ({ref LIV²} 645-646, {ref Beekes 2010}:789-790, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:591).
Generally considered a derivative of a PIE *bel- ({ref Derksen 2008}:52, {ref ESSJa} 2:193-194, {ref Vasmer 1953-1958} I:105).
Root ref. form follows {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:564-566 to *meu̯h₁- 'to move (oneself), but cf. {ref LIV²} 445-446 reconstructing *mi̯eu̯h₁-.
Possibly from Proto-Iranic *safša- ({ref Bailey 1979}:416-417); {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:340 also considers the possibility of a loanword from Turkic sač, čač 'hair (on the head of a person)'

Comment: maybe identical with 1584 *sem-; Nyberg "Manual" (1974: 93) derives this word from *hama-van- without indicating the meaning of the elements. (There is only van "tree" in his word list.)

Justification: Etymology outside of Greek uncertain (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:243-244, {ref Beekes 2010}:289-290, 293).
From Old Breton sco 'stroke, blow', further etymology obscure ({ref Deshayes 2003}:666).
Originally a loanword into Middle English from Old French cunter, conter ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Parallel loans from Persian کوه / kūh 'mountain'.
Parallel loans from Low German.
Parallel loans from English breast.
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *ugʷ-ro- 'wet', a Caland adjective in *-ro- to *u̯egʷ- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1525-1526).
Anatolian lexemes derived from PIE *nei̯H- 'to lead' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:598-600, {ref LIV²} 450-451).
Etymology uncertain, possibly to PIE *dʰeu̯b- 'deep' if from *dʰēubotyo- (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:296-297).
No certain etymology (cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:167).
Etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Korn 2005}:319).
Loanword from Hattic eštan-, aštan- 'sun(god)' ({ref Tischler 1983}:428-430, {ref HED A+E/I}:465-468, cf. {ref Laroche 1947}).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:524, {ref de Vries 1977}:624 for further discussion.

Comment: Bailey (1979: 153) suggests a derivation from the verb dar- "to split"

Justification: Tsakonian (ι)κ̔άρα < Ancient Greek ἐσχάρα ‘hearth’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). No certain etymology outside of Greek (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:379-380, {ref Beekes 2010}:472).

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed; likely to be of onomatopoeic origin. Cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:257-258, {ref Lehmann 1986}:185, and {ref Kroonen 2013}:228 for various proposals and references to further literature.

Modern Greek forms in this class continue Ancient Greek ἀκοντίζω 'hurl a javelin' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), a derivative to Ancient Greek ἄκων, -οντος 'javelin, dart', in turn derived from the PIE root *h₂ek̑- 'sharp, point' ({ref Beekes 2010}:59).
An early loanword into West Germanic from Latin curtus 'short' (cf. {ref EWA 5}:927-929, {ref Kluge 2011}:551).
Loanword from dialectal Swedish snafsa 'to snap; get dirty' ({ref Den Danske Ordbog}).

A verbal adjective from the strong verb *grōan- 'grow', cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:260-261, {ref Kluge 2011}:378, {ref Kroonen 2013}:191-192. Extra-Germanic connections unclear, but perhaps further connected to Lat. grāmen 'grass', but the latter may also be connected with IE *gras- 'fressen' (cf. discussion in /cognate/8369/, and in {ref Seebold 1970}:242-243, {ref Kroonen 2013}:191-192.
Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)keu̯h₁- 'to perceive, see' (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:86-88, {ref Vasmer 1953-1958} III:253, {ref LIV²} 561).
Loan from Old French grif 'claw' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:663).
Root only attested in Indo-Iranic, further IE connections uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} I:153, {ref Cheung 2007}:153, {ref LIV²} 222).

North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse keppr 'cudgel, club', further from Proto-Germanic *kip(p)a-, related with Germanic to the weak verb *kippōn- 'to chop(?)', but without any certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. {ref Orel 2003}:289, {ref Kroonen 2013}:289)

Comment: Loan from West Caucasian

Justification: Originally an agent noun to the same root as OHG slingan ({ref Kluge 2011:808}, {ref Kroonen 2013}:453). The Germanic forms must continue a Verner variant *-gʷ- (cf. {ref LIV²} s.v. *slenkʷ-, n1).
Friulian vaî is from Latin uagiō, -īre 'to cry' (G. Cadorini, p.c.), further etymology unclear ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:711, {ref de Vaan 2008}:651).

Etymology outside Germanic disputed; either (1) to PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- ({ref Lehmann 1986}:55-56, {ref Orel 2003}:32, 39; for the root cf. {ref LIV²} 98-100); or (2) to PIE *bʰeh₂g̑ʰ- and related to the IE word for 'upper-arm' *bʰeh₂g̑ʰ-u- ({ref Kroonen 2013}:47).
Generally derived from a PIE s-stem *h₁regʷ-os- ({ref Olsen 1999}:203, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:259-261).

Balto-Slavic and Germanic lexemes generally connected to a common IE root *gleh₂dʰ- ({ref ALEW} 345, {ref Derksen 2008}:162-163, {ref Derksen 2015}:183, {ref Kluge 2011}:361, {ref EWA 4}:478-480, {ref Orel 2003}:135), but cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:179 who prefers an alternative etymology.
Possibly a variant to the more widely attested root *terh₁- 'bore, rub' ({ref LIV²} 632), cf. {ref LIV²} 647 s.v. ?*treh₁-, {ref Kroonen 2013}:546, {ref Seebold 1970}:519.
No certain cognates outside of Germanic, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:381; {ref Orel 2003}:303. No lemma in {ref Kroonen 2013}.

Etymology disputed ({ref Kluge 2011}:498; {ref EWA 5}:581-584). According to {ref Heidermanns 1993}:322-323, followed by {ref Kroonen 2013}:290, to the root underlying OIr. glenaid 'adhere, stick' and also in Gk. γλίνη 'sticky substance', OCS glьna 'mud, clay', to PIE *g̑lei̯- / *glei̯- 'smear, stick' (cf. {ref LIV²} 190 s.v. *gleiH- 'bestreichen, kleben bleiben').
Proto-Germanic *singwan- 'to sing', probably from PIE *sengʷʰ- 'to sing, proclaim' ({ref IEW} 906-7, {ref LIV²} 532, {ref Kroonen 2013}:437, {ref Seebold 1970}:392-393).

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁em- 'to take' ({ref LIV²} 236, cf. {ref ALEW} 395-397, {ref Derksen 2015}:200-201, {ref ESSJa} 6:71, {ref Derksen 2008}:158, 533). The cognacy in this class follows {ref LIV²} 236 s.v. *h₁em-, but cf. also {ref LIV²} 453 s.v. 1. *nem-; it is possible that these two roots formed a rhyming pair in PIE.
Continuing Vedic tr̥prá-, originally an epithet of soma of debated semantics. Further etymology obscure ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:338-339 no. 5934, {ref EWAia} I:666).
Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *ret- 'to run' ({ref LIV²} 507, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:23, {ref Schumacher 2004}:538-543, {ref Matasović 2009}:310).
Lit. 'to break (open)'.
No consensus on an IE root etymology outside of Albanian, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:99, {ref Holm 2011}:80, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:973-974 for various proposals.
Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *čāt⁽ʰ⁾- ({ref ESIJa} II:252-253, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:285), on the connection of Khowar čhat to this class, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1936}:660.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. discussion in {ref EWA 5}:1172-1175.

Comment: <*čid-t-.The word is a compound 'not-clean'.

Justification: Adjective derived from Old Irish don 'misfortune', further etymology obscure ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:169).
For the interpretation of the Hittite and Luvian forms underlying the Sumerogram ᵈEN.ZU and Akkadogram ᵈSÎN, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:206-207.
Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *bʰendʰ- 'to bind' ({ref LIV²} 75, {ref EWAia} II:208, {ref Cheung 2007}:4-6, {ref Kroonen 2013}:64).
Loanword from Latin viridis 'green' ({ref Meyer 1891}:466, {ref Orel 1998}:499).
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. {ref EWA 5} s.v. OHG jagôn with extensive discussion of previous proposals.
Lexemes as though continuing Proto-Iranic *dau̯č- 'to sew', a root restricted to West Iranic and possibly substratum loanword ({ref Cheung 2007}:67).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *blōda- 'blood'. The further root etymology remains uncertain, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:76-77, {ref Kluge 2011}:135-136, {ref Kroonen 2013}:68-70 for various proposals.
Probable loan from Old French (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:226).
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:79, {ref EWAia} I:756 for further discussion.
Germanic lexemes, generally considered derivatives of PIE *pek̄- 'to pull hair, fight' ({ref LIV²} 467, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:190-191, {ref EWA 3}:108-112, {ref Kroonen 2013}:134).

A denominative verb formed to Danish skjul 'hide, cover', further to Old Norse skjól 'cover, shelter', probably to the same root as Danish sky 'cloud' ({ref Den Danske Ordbog}), but further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:495-496, {ref Orel 2003} 339, 347, {ref Kroonen 2013}:442, 452 for various hypotheses).
Germanic lexemes continuing denominal verbal formations from Proto-Germanic Proto-Germanic *spila- 'play, game', further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:867, {ref Kroonen 2013}:467).

Probably a derivative of PIE *h₃er- 'to set oneself (forward) in motion' ({ref Orel 1998}:371, {ref Holm 2011}:73; cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:251, 344 without attempting to assign a root etymology). For the root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV²} 299-301.

Baltic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE 2. *sekʷ- 'to say' ({ref LIV²} 526-527, cf. {ref ALEW} 884-886, {ref Derksen 2015}:387, {ref Kroonen 2013}:420, {ref Schumacher 2004}:565-568, {ref Matasović 2009}:328).
Loans from Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit samudra- 'the sea, ocean' ({ref Adams 2013}:739).

Comment: etymology unknown.
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:462 for various proposals.

Etymology uncertain; occasionally attempted to be derived from the root *u̯ed- underlying the IE word for 'water' (cf. /cognate/335/, {ref Kroonen 2013}:575), but such a secondary formation does not easily explain the strong stem formation in Germanic ({ref Seebold 1970}:539, {ref Kluge 2011}:972).
Lexemes from Proto-Slavic *slabъ 'weak', as though from PIE *slob-o- ({ref Derksen 2008}:452-453, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} s.v. *(s)leb- ‘schlaff werden’).

Comment: Uncertain etymology.
Justification: Albanian forms derived from verbal kalb 'to let rot', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Orel 1998}:165, 355 for various proposals).
No clear etymology outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:794).

Latin currere 'to run' and Romance lexemes continuing a PIE zero-grade thematic present stem *⁽k̑⁾r̥s-e/o-, derived from PIE *⁽k̑⁾ers- 'to run' ({ref LIV²} 355, {ref de Vaan 2008}:157-158, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:224 no. 2415).

Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *baka-, possibly to a root *bʰeg- 'to bend, arch', but there are no certain cognates outside of Germanic ({ref EWA 1}:418, {ref Kroonen 2013}:48, {ref Kluge 2011}:80-81).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ 'black', further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾r̥s-nó- ({ref ESSJa} 4:155-157, {ref Derksen 2008}:92).

The reconstruction of the Proto-Germanic form of this adjective is problematic, therefore connections outside of Germanic are difficult to ascertain (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:157-158, 162-163; {ref Kroonen 2013}:100).
No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:287, {ref KEWA} II:540-542). For the Modern Indic forms, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:554 no. 9696.
Loanword from Arabic اسم / aism 'name'.
Parallel loans from Turkic *küčik

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *alda- '(grown) old', further from PIE *h₂el-tó-, a verbal adjective to PIE *h₂el- 'to nourish, rear' ({ref Lehmann 1986}:29-30, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:97-98, {ref Kroonen 2013}:20, cf. {ref LIV²} 262).

Lexemes from Proto-Germanic *brinnan- 'to burn'. The Indo-European root etymology remains unclear: either to (1) PIE *bʰrei̯H- 'to cut' ({ref LIV²} 92-93, {ref IEW} 166-7) or (2) *gʷʰer- 'to become warm' ({ref LIV²} 219-220, {ref IEW} 493-5); cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:77-78; {ref Seebold 1970}:137-138, {ref EWA 2}:342-345.
Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:127-128 for various proposals.

The only extra-Germanic correspondences are found in Baltic (cf. Lith. sver̃ti 'to weigh') which could go back to an original IE root *su̯er(H)- (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:578-579, {ref Kroonen 2013}:499, {ref ALEW}:998-999).

Comment: basic meaning "radiant, shiny" etc.

Justification: Etymology in this class follows {ref Orel 1998}:515, {ref Matzinger 2005}:99, but cf. {ref Holm 2011}:68 for further discussion.
Generally considered a loanword from Albanian lule 'flower' (cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:791-792), although the possibility of a Wanderwort is probably also not to be excluded.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ({ref Kroonen 2013}:445, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:417-418 for older proposals).
A loanword from Latin intelligere 'to perceive' ({ref Orel 1998}:62, cf. {ref Holm 2011}:66).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:229-230, {ref Orel 1998}:210, 221 for various suggestions and further discussion.
Loanword from Latin largus 'big, large, great (of distances)' ({ref Huld 1984}:85, {ref Orel 1998}:214).
Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *karš-/*xrah- 'to draw, plough', further to PIE *kʷels- 'to draw a furrow' ({ref Cheung 2007}:241-243, {ref EWAia} I:319-320, {ref LIV²} 388-389).
Loan from Latin pōmum 'fruit tree; fruit' ({ref Meyer 1891}:326, {ref Orel 1998}:314, {ref Holm 2011}:85-86).

Origin and structure uncertain, cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:419, {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 4:255, {ref Rejzek 2001}:455-456, {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1053-1054, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:186 for various proposals.
Manx fliaghey continuing Old Irish flechud ({ref Broaderick 1984b}:168).
Etymology disputed, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:36, {ref Demiraj 1997}:70-71, {ref Orel 1998}:1-2 for discussion of various proposals.
Etymology disputed, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:246-247, {ref Orel 1998}:219, 234 for various proposals and further discussion.
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:15.
Etymology outside of Greek unclear ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:979-980, {ref Beekes 2010}:1294-1295). For older hypotheses, cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:665-666, {ref IEW} 1004.

Comment: derivation of verbal root *dai̯H "to see" of cognate set 2012

Justification: Loan from Iranic (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1936}:671).

Comment: Loan from Romance.
Justification: Loan from Late Latin cocceus 'red, scarlet' ({ref Meyer 1891}:210, {ref Huld 1984}:84, {ref Orel 1998}:205, {ref Holm 2011}:75).

Generally compared with Vedic ándhas- 'sprout of the soma plant' which can be accounted for via an s-stem *h₂éndʰ-os- from which Greek ἄνθος would also be a regular reflex ({ref Beekes 2010}:104-105, {ref LIV²} 266, cf. {ref EWAia} I:79). See, however, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:89-90 with some reservations.
Hellenic and Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *selk- 'to pull' ({ref LIV²} 530-531, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:753, {ref Beekes 2010}:412).
Loanword from Latin venīre 'to come' ({ref Orel 1998}:508).
Etymology uncertain, possibly to be connected Gk. ὄρμενος 'shoot, sprout, stem, stalk' (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:337). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.
Loanword into Brythonic from Latin piscis 'fish' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:574, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} s.v. Welsh pysg 'fish').
Tocharian lexemes continuing PIE *kʷolh₁-o- 'turning point' ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:126, {ref Adams 2013}:211), a derivative of PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, to turn' ({ref LIV²} 386-388).

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed, cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:562-563, {ref Orel 2003}:383, {ref Kluge 2011}:887, {ref Kroonen 2013}:476, 487 for various proposals and references to further literature.
Probably a loanword from Italian milza 'spleen' ({ref Orel 1998}:259), but possibly even earlier from Gothic *milti-, cf. Catalan melsa 'spleen' ({ref Holm 2011}:69-70).
Hellenic and Armenian lexemes from PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ({ref LIV²} 487-488, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1212, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1115, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:316).
Etymology outside of (East) Baltic uncertain, cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007}:568, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:819-820 for further discussion.
Root ref. form in this class follows {ref LIV²} 243 s.v. *h₁eu̯-, but cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:227-229 reconstructing *h₂eu̯-.

Comment: s, not š, in Nuristani.
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *dau̯šā́- 'evening; night', no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} I:750, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:376 no. 6590).
Etymology here tentatively follows {ref Orel 1998}:16-17, {ref de Vaan 2008}:201-202, but cf. the objections and further discussion of {ref Demiraj 1997}:89-90).
Etymology outside of Albanian unclear, cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:274, {ref Jokl 1911}:58, {ref Demiraj 1997}:277, {ref Orel 1998}:274, {ref Holm 2011}:70} for various proposals.
Generally derived from *du̯eh₂ró- or *duh₂ró- to √*du̯eh₂- ({ref Olsen 1999}:198-199, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:266-267).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes backformed from the Old Indic suppletive aorist √dr̥ś- and replacing the inherited present stem paśya- (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:371, no. 6507). Ultimately to be derived from PIE *derk̑- 'to see' ({ref EWAia} I:704-706, {ref LIV²} 122-123).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:427-428, {ref Orel 1998}:524, {ref Holm 2011}:53 for discussion of various proposals.
Probably a loanword from Iranic, cf. Wakhi ṣ̌ʉw 'black' ({ref Morgenstierne 1936}:669).
Connections outside of Tocharian unclear ({ref Adams 2013}:478).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:483 for discussion of various proposals.
Armenian forms generally derived from PIE 2. *h₂eg̑- 'to say' (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:117-118, {ref LIV²} 256).
Etymology uncertain ({ref Kluge 2011}:536).
Loanword from Old French sentir 'to perceive' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:643).
Italic and Romance lexemes continuing Latin dormīre 'to sleep', further derived from PIE 2. *drem- 'to sleep' ({ref LIV²} 128, {ref de Vaan 2008}:179-180, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:247).
A Wanderwort of obscure origin, cf. {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 1:123-124, {ref Rejzek 2001}:701, {ref Skok 1971-1974} 3:569, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 1:279 for various proposals.
Connections outside of Albanian uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:89, {ref Demiraj 1997}:254-256, {ref Orel 1998}:243, {ref Holm 2011}:72 for various proposals and further discussion.
Loanword from Syriac ṭarpā 'leaf' ({ref Olsen 1999}:933, {ref HAB} IV:398, {ref Hübschmann 1897}:317). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tereu̯-o-].

Denominal to Armenian kap 'bond, fetter'. Further etymology uncertain, possibly an Iranian loanword ({ref Olsen 1999}:16, 887, cf. {ref HAB} II:519-521). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kap-].
NB: {ref Turner 1962–1966}:351 no. 6145 compares Iranic forms which {ref Cheung 2007}:48 assumes to be a separate root of onomatopoeic origin.
A denominal formation from Breton kaw 'hollow', originally a borrowing from Latin cavus 'hollow, excavated' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:377).
Loan from Latin *camba ~ gamba 'leg' ({ref Huld 1984}:80, {ref Orel 1998}:177, {ref Holm 2011}:63).
No clear etymology outside of Celtic ({ref Matasović 2009}:152, cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:266).

Etymology disputed. Either to the Germanic word for 'hide, skin' in /cognate/820/ or to Celtic words for 'hide' from PIE *keu̯dʰ- in /cognate/8434/ (cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}, {ref Orel 2003}:196). Not in {ref Kroonen 2013} or {ref Seebold 1970}.
Loan from Calabrian ad(d)urare, -ari 'to smell' with apheresis, cf. Sandard Italian odorare < Lat. odōrāre.
Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Abkhaz ləgaž 'old man' from *ləg 'person' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:19-21).
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1506-1507, {ref LIV²} 154). For the Tsakonian lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Andriotis 1974}:556-557.
Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic kurkurá- 'dog', probably imitative after the sound of a dog barking 'kur-kur' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:172, no. 3329; {ref EWAia} I:372).
No known etymology; perhaps a substratum loanword (cf. {ref Lucht 2007}:397).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3949, Mayrhofer KEWA I, p. 314

Justification: Of unknown etymology ({ref Olsen 1999}:941, cf. {ref HAB} III:348-349). [MM: Proto-Armenian *mortʰ-o-].
Loanword from Slavic *goditi ({ref Meyer 1891}:126, {ref Orel 1998}:119).

A unique Greco-Armenian isogloss ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:214, {ref Beekes 2010}:264-265, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:336-337, 340-341, {ref LIV²} 162; cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:126-131 for extensive discussion of the various reflexes and derivatives from this root).
Hellenic, Armenian, and Baltic lexemes from PIE *dʰg̑ʰuH- 'fish' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:474, {ref Beekes 2010}:1331-1332, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:439-440, {ref ALEW} 1331-1332).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *sterban- 'to become stiff, die', further to PIE *(s)dʰerbʰ- 'to become stiff, firm' ({ref LIV²} 512; cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:477 reconstructing *(s)terbʰ- with the same basic comparanda). For older comparisons cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:472-473.

Possibly, but not certainly, to be connected with Latv. diêt, in turn from PIE *dei̯h₁- 'dahinjagen' ({ref LIV²} 107), cf. {ref ALEW} 169, {ref Derksen 2015}:112), alternatively to Lith. dejà 'Wehklage', without certain etymology (cf. {ref ALEW} 189).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit saṁkula- 'crowded together, dense, disordered' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:744 no. 12828). further etymology unclear, cf. {ref KEWA} I:211, III:416 for further discussion.
No certain etymology outside of East Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 720-721).
Borrowing from Romance (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:289, {ref Orel 1998}:277).
Romance lexemes continuing Latin grandis 'full-grown, large, great', further etymology obscure ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:327 no. 3842, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:281, {ref de Vaan 2008}:270).
Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑i̯eh₁- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:661).
Germanic lexemes reflecting PIE *h₁eh₁t-mon- ({ref Kroonen 2013}:119-120, {ref EWA 1}:393-394, {ref Kluge 2011}:67, cf. {ref EWAia} I:164).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kap/f- 'to (be)fall, strike down' and further to PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, chop' ({ref Cheung 2007}:234-235, cf. {ref LIV²} 555).
Proto-Celtic reconstruction uncertain; no etymology outside of Celtic (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} O:2, {ref Matasović 2009}:49).

Comment: dy-bod (GPC)
*su̯elk̑s- cf. Middle Persian xwaš, Parthian wxaš

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:227). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:523, no. 9250.
Cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:390.
Lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit haḍḍa- 'bone', only attested in lexicographical works. Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:807 no. 13952; {ref KEWA} III:573).
Loanword from Anglo-Norman carier ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

The Bulgarian form goes back to the *korkŭ variant. The etymology of the Slavic lexeme and its further IE cognates are not entirely clear. Lithuanian kárka is rather a cognate but the other words linked to PS *korkŭ not.
Loanword from Italian, either directly from macinare 'to grind', or a denominal formation to a loan from macina 'mill, millstone, grinder'.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯afra- 'snow', derivatives of an Indo-Iranic root *u̯ap- 'to disperse, scatter' to which there are no certain connections outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:418-419,{ref Bailey 1979}:305-306, {ref EWAia} II:503-505, {ref KEWA} III:145).
Two possibilities for a root etymology: Either to *ser- ({ref LIV²} 534) or to *u̯er- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1095-1097, cf. {ref LIV²} 3. *u̯er- 'to observe, perceive', {ref IEW} 1164).
Probably a loanword, cf. Saṇu-viri istˈã 'star' ({ref Morgenstierne 1936}:666).
Connected with Avestan raočah- 'light', Old Persian raučah- 'day' ({ref Korn 2005}), further from PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:463-464).

Comment: possibly a Turkish loan word: kol "arm", if it was used for all extremities

Justification: No known etymology outside of Celtic ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:65-66, {ref Matasović 2009}:177).
Catalan lexemes from Latin labor 'work, labour' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:391), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:320).
No certain etymology outside of Indic (cf. {ref EWAia} II:811-812). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:811, no. 14021.
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *gȏdъ 'right time' < PIE *gʰodʰ-o- ({ref Derksen 2008}:172-173, {ref ESSJa} 6:189-192, cf. {ref LIV²} 195).
Slavic lexemes generally connected to PIE *u̯elH- 'to be strong, have power' ({ref Derksen 2008}:514).
Further etymology outside of (East) Baltic uncertain, cf. {ref ALEW} 469-470, 486, {ref Derksen 2015}:234, 243, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:282 for various proposals and further discussion.
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:139-140 for various suggestions.

Old Prussian tiēnstwei (inf.) may be derived from PIE *tens- 'to pull' ({ref LIV²} 629, cf. {Ref Smoczyński 2005}:366-367, {ref Derksen 2015}:464, {ref ALEW} 1095). This root could well be secondary neo-root abstracted from a desiderative formation to *ten- 'to pull' already in PIE (cf. {ref LIV²} 629).
Etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:163 no. 3193, {ref EWAia} I:355-356).
Derived from PIE 2. *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:353-355, {ref LIV²} 293-294).

According to {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:254 a derivative of Proto-Iranic *barz- 'high', cf. Av. bərəzant-, Ved. br̥hant- 'tall' etc., further to PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'to become tall; raise oneself' (cf. {ref LIV²} 78-79).
Of unknown origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:963, cf. {ref HAB} II:510-511). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kanatʃʰ-].
Ossetic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *taxma-, cf. Avestan taxma- 'mighty', Old Persian taxma- 'id.' (cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:306).
An early borrowing from Iranic ({ref Morgenstierne 1936}:669).
Etymology disputed, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:497, {ref ESIJa} III:49-51 for various proposals.

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Italic Lexemes from PIE *u̯emh₁- 'to vomit' ({ref LIV²} 680, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:416-417, {ref Andriotis 1974}:245, {ref EWAia} II:534-535, {ref Cheung 2007}:417, {ref ALEW} 1216, {ref Derksen 2015}:497, {ref de Vaan 2008}:690).

Comment: from Sanskrit ḍayanam (lex.), cf. Turner 1962-66, 5535

Justification: No certain etymology; cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:14 for a survey of various hypotheses.
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯elH- 'to roll' ({ref ALEW} 52, {ref ESSJa} 31:124-126, {ref Derksen 2015}:58-59, 497; cf. {ref LIV²} 677).
Root etymology in this class follows {ref de Vaan 2008}:99, but cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:106. For Romance lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:170-171.

Comment: Buck gives Grk. KYLLOS 'crooked' as a cognate (1949: 194)
etym. dub. (Buck 1949: 64)

Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin focus 'hearth, fireplace' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:292-293). Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:243, {ref de Vaan 2008}:228-229 for further discussion).
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰu̯es- 'to breathe (in, out)' ({ref LIV²} 160, {ref ALEW} 252-253, {ref Derksen 2008}:124, 131-132, {ref ESSJa} 5:151, 153).

Cognacy in this class follows {ref Matasović 2009}:317 in treating the lexemes as inherited, but note that the possibility of some borrowing or loan-adaptation between Brythonic and Goidelic and/or early Romance may still be possible (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:54).

Italic lexemes from Latin frīgidus 'cold' (adj.), a derivative of Latin frīgus 'cold, frost' (n.) < PIE *sriHg̑-e/os- ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:254, {ref de Vaan 2008}:243, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:301 no. 3512; cf. {ref LIV²} 587)

Iranic lexemes as though from PIE *k̑r-uH- to the same root *k̑er- underlying various derived lexemes in the meaning 'horn' ({ref EWAia} II:653, {ref Sims-Williams 2007}:285, cf. 'horn' in /cognate/2457/ for further etymological discussion).
From Early Modern Dutch vijs; further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref EWNl} for discussion.
Baltic lexemes continuing *gʷerh₃- 'to devour' ({ref LIV²} 211-212, cf. {ref ALEW} 315-316, {ref Derksen 2015}:172).
Etymology disputed, cf. {ref Henning 1947}:47, {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:73, {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:242.

Comment: Turner 1931: 128
Justification: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:205 no. 3881 *khiñc- 'to drag, pull'. No further etymology.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *nēan- 'to sew', a strong verb continuing PIE *sneh₁- 'to spin (wool, etc.)' ({ref Kluge 2011}:647, {ref Kroonen 2013}:385, {ref LIV²} 571-572, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:447).
No clear etymology outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:427-428); cf. {ref HED K}:14-15 for unconvincing attempts to relate to Old English hōc 'hook', etc.

Comment: This could be related to zānū: zırānü < *zızānū < *zānū, maybe following the pattern dɨdan "tooth" (though this derives from dandān).

Justification: From PIE *telH- 'become quiet' ({ref Matasović 2009}:382-383; {ref LIV²} 621). NB: {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:170 conflated two roots *tel- now reconstructed separately as *telH- ({ref LIV²} 621) and *telh₂- ({ref LIV²} 622); {ref LIV²} 621 s.v. *telH- does not connect the Germanic lexemes connected to OHG stillen as {ref Matasović 2009}.
Slavic lexemes to be derived from PIE *gʰlend⁽ʰ⁾- 'to look at, see, shine' ({ref Derksen 2008}:164, {ref ESSJa} 6:122-124, cf. {ref LIV²} 200).

Comment: fr. CeltLat. *VIRARE, cf. Gael. gwyro 'turn away, make a detour, remove' (Spanish dictionary online)

Justification: Modern Greek lexemes derived to the root of Ancient Greek ζέω 'boil, seethe' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:530-531), further to PIE *i̯es- 'to boil, foam' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:399-400, {ref Beekes 2010}:499-500, {ref LIV²} 312-313).

Comment: cf. Skt. dhávati 'cleans' (Turner 1931: 329)
Cognate with Gothic 'lasiws'.

Justification: Ossetic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *uz-maisa-, a derivative to PIE *mei̯k̑- 'to mix' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:281-282, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:261, {ref LIV²} 428-429).

Comment: cf. Turkish fena “bad” < Arabic faniya “vernichten” (fanāˀ) ?
Formally unclear whether the etymology goes back to *Hoi̯-no- or *sem-.
Justification: The etymological handbooks differ on whether Alb. një 'one' should be assigned to PIE *sem- (Gk. εἷς, Arm. mi, etc.) /cognate/6066/ or *Hoi̯-no- (Lat. ūnus, Goth. ains, etc.) /cognate/91/ (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:101, {ref Demiraj 1997}:207, {ref Orel 1998}:304-305, {ref Holm 2011}:74 for various assessments).  Consequently the Albanian numeral '1' has therefore been placed in its own cognate set reflecting this etymological uncertainty.
Brythonic lexemes of obscure origin (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:476).
Iranic lexemes derived from a Proto-Indo-Iranic root noun *tau̯k- 'progeny, children', without certain correspondences outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:651, 670).
Exact origin uncertain, probably a Wanderwort (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:588).
Loanword from Slavic *o-met- 'swept snow; snowdrift' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:124).

Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek γεμᾶτος 'full', a derivative of Ancient Greek γέμω 'to be full' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:292), further derived from PIE *gem- 'to press, press together' ({ref LIV²} 186, {ref Beekes 2010}:265; cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:215).
Possibly related to English 'cut' in /cognate/2579/, but further etymology uncertain; cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:286.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fraiwa- 'seed', further etymology disputed (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:123, {ref Kroonen 2013}:152).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *magino- 'stone, place'. Further connections not fully certain, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:9, {ref Matasović 2009}:252-253 for further discussion.
From Proto-Celtic *kʷello-,; perhaps further to PIE *kʷel(h₁)- 'turn' (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:176, {ref LIPP 2} 490).
No certain etymology outside of Italic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:573, {ref de Vaan 2008}:522). For the Romance lexemes attached to this set cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:603-604.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ({ref Lehmann 1986}:247, {ref Orel 2003}:264). {ref Kroonen 2013}:358 suggests a comparison with Ru. motýl' 'maggot'.
Parallel loans from Persian راست / rāst 'right'.
Etymology uncertain ({ref Deshayes 2003}:669).
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:177-178, {ref Matasović 2009}:108-109).
Continuing a causative stem formation *tu̯orH-éi̯e- to PIE *tu̯erH- 'to grasp' ({ref LIV²} 656, {ref Derksen 2008}:501).
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain (cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:186-187, {ref Adams 2013}:263 for various proposals).

According to {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:37-39, the Ossetic lexemes in this class continue an East Iranic root *rap- also found in Pamir languages (cf. Ormuri we-raf-s-, Shughni wi-ruv-d-). [Not in {ref Cheung 2007}].
Loanword from Turkish čök 'knee' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:242-243).

Italic and Romance lexemes typically compared to Proto-Indo-Iranic *pazdu- 'beetle, maggot'. If so we may consider a root *pesd-, perhaps identical with PIE *pesd- 'to fart quietly', although it may well be we are dealing with an independent onomatopoeic formation within PIE as *pesdu- 'annoying insect' vel sim. (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:493, {ref de Vaan 2008}:454, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:523-524).

Comment: This word is most likely related to the armpit, cf. Av. kaša-, with suffix -ka- and a modern diminutive (?) suffix -ıḷa.

Justification: No clear etymology outside of Celtic, cf. {ref Delamarre 2003}:320-321, {ref Lucht 2007}:430 for various proposals. See also ({ref Matasović 2009}:423.
No certain etymology outside of Indic (cf. {ref EWAia} II:294).

Comment: There is a second lexeme for small, PCL. *leg-o, lag-o 'small', from PIE  *h₁le(n)gʷʰ-'small, light' (IEW: 661) Matasović (2009, 236). Does not seem to be the Swadesh term in Brittonic, because of its pejorative connotations, cf. MW 'law 'small, sad', OBr. lau gl. petusculum 'small, bad', MoBret. law 'miserable, bad'.
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Celtic ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:24, {ref Lucht 2007}:355), cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:60-61 for a derivation from *bʰeg-ko-, although Matasović admits that this proposal is formally difficult and speculative.

Celtic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *mati- 'good', a derivative of PIE *meh₂- 'good; at the right time' ({ref Lucht 2007}:181-182, {ref Matasović 2009}:259-260, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:12-13).

Anatolian, Hellenic, and Indo-Iranic lexemes reflecting an original athematic root-present to PIE *h₁eh₁s- 'to sit' ({ref LIV²} 232, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:252-255, {ref Beekes 2010}:518, {ref EWAia} I:181).
Loanword from Germanic *hūsa- ({ref ESSJa} 8:159-160, cf. {ref Snoj 1997-2016}).
Cf. Old Irish uisce 'water' derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well, to spring' (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} U:21, {ref Matasović 2009}:394, {ref NIL} 706-715).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *ryba 'fish', further etymology obscure (cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} III:525-526, {ref Rejzek 2001}:552, {ref Boryś 2005}:528-529, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 3:177).

From Latin pulsāre 'to strike, beat' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:566-567), secondary from Latin pellere 'beat against, push, strike', further to PIE *pelh₂- 'to approach' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:455-456, {ref LIV²} 470-471).

Comment: cf. Avestan xšuuiptauuaṇt- "mit Melkmilch versehen"; *xšu̯iptī̆ka- (?)

Justification: Derived from IE *gʷou̯- 'cow' ({ref Bailey 1979}:89, cf. {ref EWAia} I:478-480).

Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain; cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:187-188, {ref Lucht 2007}:295-296 for a survey of various proposals. The Proto-Celtic root reference form given for this cognate set provisionally follows {ref Matasović 2009}:352-353.
No etymology outside of Iranic (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:445-446).
Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰrem- 'to buzz, to bellow' ({ref Cheung 2007}:24, {ref LIV²} 94).

Comment: zāk could represent a nasalised zãk (?) < *zank- (?) < *zang-a-k, cf. Av. zaṇga- „ankle“, alternatively one would have to assume zāk < *zaγ-k < *zaγ-ak < *zaga- < *j́nͅgʰ-

Justification: Germanic lexemes generally connected to Latin sordēs 'dirt' and derivatives (cf. {ref IEW} 1052, {ref Lehmann 1986}:333, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:574-575, {ref Orel 2003}:392; tentatively {ref Kluge 2011}:833; cf. also {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:637, {ref de Vaan 2008}:576 cited in /cognate/4865/) as though from a PIE o-stem adjective *su̯ordo-. If these lexemes go back to the same source, then they may be a post-PIE innovation in Germanic and Italic. [Not {ref Kroonen 2013}].
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ({ref Lehmann 1986}:247, {ref Kroonen 2013}:358).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *kerla- ~ *karla- 'man, freeman', a derivative of PIE *g̑erh₂- 'to wear down, make old' ({ref de Vries 1977}:301, {ref Orel 2003}:210, {ref Kroonen 2013}:285, cf. {ref LIV²} 165-166).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃er- 'to set in motion; rise' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:826, {ref Beekes 2010}:1109-1110; cf. {ref LIV²} 299-300).

Comment: etym. dub. CHECK VGK I, 66
Justification: A Brythonic word of uncertain origin ({ref Deshayes 2003}:197).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰlei̯g̑- 'to beat' ({ref Derksen 2008}:45-46, {ref ESSJa} 2:121-123, cf. {ref LIV²} 88-89).

Of obscure origin, probably a prehistoric loanword (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:420, {ref Beekes 2010}:530 for discussion of various hypotheses). The different dialectal forms point to either a Proto-Greek or borrowed source form *tʰalak⁽ʰ⁾i̯a (vel sim.).
Originally 'fresh', a transferred epithet from the phrase νηρόν ὕδωρ 'fresh water' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:915-196), further to PIE *neu̯- 'new, fresh' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1018).
Loan from Spanish empujar 'to push'.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66 s.v. khalla m., no. 3848: "connexion with challi <-> and of both with skhádate ʻcutsʼ Dhātup. [...] doubtful"?

Justification: Loan from Lat. ponderis 'of weight' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:596).

Traditionally connected to IE 1. *sekʷ- 'follow' (cf. {ref Orel 1998}:425-426, {ref LIV²} 525), but this etymology is unclear on phonological grounds; cf. {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:996, {ref LIV²} 525-526.
There are no certain cognates beyond Balto-Slavic ({ref Derksen 2008}:322, {ref Smoczyński 2007}: 369-370), cf. also {ref ESSJa} 19:144-147, {ref Beekes 2010}: 893.

Extra-Germanic connections uncertain. Traditionally connected to a root *mer(ə)- with various root extensions (cf. {ref IEW} 739-740, {ref Seebold 1970}:352, {ref de Vries 1977}:393). {ref Heidermanns 1993}:417 does not propose an updated etymology. No lemmata in {ref Orel 2003}, {ref Kroonen 2013}.
Of uncertain etymology, it is doubtful that the lexemes may be derived from Latin cossus 'a kind of larva' as previously supposed ({ref DCECH} III:287-290, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:211).
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kʷei̯t- 'to perceive, to recognise' ({ref LIV²} 382-383, {ref ALEW} 919-920, {ref Derksen 2015}:401, {ref ESSJa} 4:119, {ref Derksen 2008}:89-90).
Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑ad- 'to fall' ({ref LIV²} 318, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:78-79, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:134 no. 1451).

Comment: There is mrγ “pasture”, which is given in Sogdian for “forest”, formally *ati-margā- would work, but does it make sense?

Justification: Cf. Old Irish folach 'hiding'. For various etymological proposals, cf. {ref Bergin 1938}:220-222.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *tungla- 'star, celestial body(?)', further connections outside Germanic uncertain ({ref Lehmann 1986}:348, {ref Kroonen 2013}:526).
Continuing a derivative of PIE *tu̯em- 'to swell up' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:663, {ref LIV²} 654).
Romance lexemes based on a stem *pīkk-, probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:536)

Etymology uncertain. Traditionally considered to be from PIE *(s)lei̯b- 'drag, glide' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:131, cf. {ref LIV² 566 s.v. ?*(s)lei̯b-, {ref IEW} 663) via an original meaning '(slippery) slope', but {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} finds this development semantically dubious.
No clear etymology outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:515-516, cf. also {ref HED L}:40-44).

Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin lārgus 'generous, bountiful' ({ref DCECH} III:586-587, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:399), further etymology uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:342, {ref de Vaan 2008}:327).
No certain etymology outside of Italic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:30); possibly to *h₃emh₃- 'to grab' according to {ref de Vaan 2008}:40.

A derived adjective from Hellenistic Greek κίτρον 'fruit of the citrus tree', a loanword from Late Latin citrium, cf. Classical Latin citrus 'citrus tree' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:667-668, {ref Beekes 2010}:705).
Old English tígan is a denominal formation as though from earlier *téag-jan 'to bind', based on OE téag 'rope', to be connected with ON taug 'rope', probably from Germanic *taug-.

Perhaps further from PIE *koi̯(H)lo- if connected with Latvian kaîls 'naked, bald', but the comparative semantics are rather remote (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:6, {ref Matasović 2009}:220).

Comment: Bartholomae (1904: 1523) quotes the reconstruction *srān°. In Ossetic also "belt".

Justification: Loanword from Lat. asper 'rough' as a transferred adjective in the phrase nummi aspri 'rough coins', the original semantic development to 'white' appears to have been '(rough) silver' → 'silver-white' → 'white', cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:223-224, {ref Beekes 2010}:154.
Either a loanword from West Caucasian or a nursery word (cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:362).
Same as 'fly_V' in /cognate/9512/?
Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes derived to PIE *h₁egʷʰ- 'to drink' ({ref LIV²} 231; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:236-237, {ref Malzahn 2010}:810-811, {ref Adams 2013}:551-552).
Ossetic lexemes, probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:14).
As though from Iranic *padakā- according to {ref Humbach 1989}:194, cf. {ref Henning 1955}:43, {ref Benzing 1983}:540), further etymology uncertain.
No clear etymology outside of Celtic, cf. {ref Delamarre 2003}:453, {ref Matasović 2009}:231 for various suggestions.
There is no certain etymology. The relationship to PS *prętati and Russian prygat' is dubious. Cf. /cognate/5208/.

Cognate with Lithuanian peldė́ti 'to swim'. Further etymology uncertain. Traditionally assigned to PIE *pelǝ-, *plē- 'to fill' (now reconstructed as *pleh₁-, cf. {ref LIV²} 482-483) with a root extension in *-d- ({ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:565, {ref IEW} 800-801, cf. {ref Karulis 1992} II:34-35). Not in {ref LIV²}, {ref Derksen 2015}, or {ref ALEW}.

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vālukā- 'sand' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:675, no. 11580). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref KEWA} III:196, {ref EWAia} II:547 for discussion of various conjectures.

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek σκέπτομαι 'I look about carefully, examine' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1279-1280), further derived from PIE *spek̑-, with metathesis *sp…k > sk…p ({ref Beekes 2010}:1347-1348, {ref LIV²} 575-576).
Loan from Arabic, cf. Standard Arabic دِمَاغ / dimāḡ 'brain'.
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *smei̯- 'to smile, laugh' ({ref LIV²} 568-569, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:456-457, {ref Derksen 2015}:550-551).
Modern Hellenic lexemes derived from Ancient Greek κόκκος 'kernel', further etymology unknown ({ref Babinotis 2010}:694-695, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:553, {ref Beekes 2010}:733}).
Etymology uncertain, cf. Ved. dhánu- 'dry land', dhánvan- 'desert'(?) ({ref EWAia} I:774, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:384 no. 6724)
As though continuing Sanskrit *skambha- 'shoulderblade, wing, plumage' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:786 no. 13640). Further etymology uncertain.
From Proto-Slavic *rъvati 'to tear' and further derived from PIE *reu̯H- 'to tear (up)' ({ref Vasmer 1986-1987} III:452, {ref Derksen 2008}:441-442, {ref Boryś 2005}:528, {ref LIV²} 510).
Identical to Khwarazmian 'long' in /cognate/3381/, further to PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- (cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:299, {ref EWAia} II:232).
West Germanic lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *uba-eta- 'side dish', the lexical root of *eta- corresponds to PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat' (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:2, 665; {ref EWNl} 3:463).
As though from an Indic stem *muṭṭa- 'heart', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:587 no. 10188).

Proposed to Sanskrit nudati (otherwise isolated, cf. {ref KEWA} II:176, {ref LIV²} 456 s.v. ?2. *neu̯d- 'stoßen') by {ref Jasanoff 1978b}:39 via a pre-form *nud-sk̑e/o-, but this connection is formally difficult from a Tocharian perspective (cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:682-683, {ref Adams 2013}:356-357 for further discussion).
Loanword from Italian destra 'right'.
Iranic lexemes derived from a Proto-Indo-Iranic root noun *tau̯k- 'progeny, children', without certain correspondences outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:651, 670).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *telamon- 'earth, ground', a derivative to PIE *telh₂- 'to raise, support' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:22-23, {ref Delamarre 2003}:288-289, {ref Matasović 2009}:366, cf. {ref LIV² 622-623).
Root cognacy outside of Slavic uncertain ({ref Derksen 2008}:494, cf. {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 4:183, {ref Boryś 2005}:77, 84 for various proposals.
Loan into Romance from Old Low Franconian ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 15/1:210-229, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:109).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *rokъ, derived from the same root as Proto-Slavic *rekti 'speak, say' < PIE *rek- ({ref Derksen 2008}:433, 438; {ref Boryś 2005}:517, 532; cf. {ref LIV²} 506).
Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *mai̯θā-, cf. Avestan maēθā- 'change, evolution' ({ref Morgenstierne 1974}:45-46, {ref MacKenzie 1990}:116).
Cf. Sanskrit gaḍa- 'young of the fish Ophiocephalus lata or Cyprinus garra' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:212 no. 3970), only attested by lexicographers. Further etymology uncertain.
As though continuing an Indic stem *ḍoka- (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:313 no. 5566). No further etymology.
It's disputable if the Slavic word belongs to PIE ?*dʰreb- or *dʰrebʰ-. The majority view is adopted here.
Denominal formation from Old Breton sco 'strike, blow', further etymology obscure ({ref Deshayes 2003}:666).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *bōan- ~ *būan- 'to live, dwell', further derived from PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'to grow, emerge, become' ({ref Seebold 1970}:124-126, {ref Kroonen 2013}:71, {ref LIV²} 98-101).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *dʰeu̯- (cf. {ref EWAia} I:789-790, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:389 no.6802, {ref Cheung 2007}:65-66, {ref LIV²} 147-148).
Parallel loans from Persian پوزه / pōz(e) 'muzzle, snout' (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:68).
The Latin and Romance forms are based on a reduplicated formation *pró-pro with dissimilation of the second *-r- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:492-493, {ref LIPP 2}:641).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *derb- 'to join, tie, sew (together)', and further to PIE ?*derbʰ- 'to bind together, braid' (cf. {ref LIV²} 121).
Latin abscondere 'to hide', unprefixed verb -dō, -dere from PIE *dʰeh₁- 'put, place; do' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:175-176, {ref LIV²} 136-138). For the Romance lexemes, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:4.
Perhaps to PIE ?*leu̯p- '(ab)schälen' ({ref LIV²} 420, {ref IEW} 690-1), cf. {ref EWA 5}:1454-1457; otherwise obscure (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:328).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:357 for a summary of various proposals.

Perhaps to be connected with Balto-Slavic forms (Latv. merguôt 'rain slowly', merga 'soft rain', Ru. morositь) to a root *mergʰ- (with Greek forms reflecting a Schwebeablaut variant *mregʰ-), but this etymology is uncertain (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:195, {ref Beekes 2010}:238; not in {ref LIV²}).
The root is ideophonic. Any further etymology (as *(s)kreb-, cf. {ref ESSJa}) is speculative.
Loanword from Middle Low German made 'worm' ({ref Polański 1962-1994} III:388).
Breton lexemes, first attested in Middle Breton, but further origins obscure ({ref Deshayes 2003}:669).

Comment: probably simply „what is to be eaten“

Justification: Generally assumed to be connected with Proto-Germanic *sehwan- 'see' (cf. /cognate/288/) from PIE 1. *sekʷ- 'follow' ({ref LIV²} 525-526), cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:704-706 (rejected, however, by {ref HED SA}:50-57 on the grounds that the etymology contravenes Sturtevant's Rule).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin concha 'shell, seashell' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:199), an old loanword, already attested in Plautus, from Ancient Greek κόγχη, κόγχᾱ 'mussel' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:136).
North Germanic lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *skenþan- ({ref Orel 2003}:338, cf. {ref de Vries 1961}:493). Further etymology uncertain. [Not in {ref Kroonen 2013}].

Welsh lexemes, which along with Old Cornish trein and Gaulish *trugna- (implied through Romance, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:744 no. 8947) appear to reflect Proto-Celtic *trugnV- ({ref Schrijver 1995}:442n2, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Matasović 2009}:353).

Generally connected with PIE *h₃bʰreu̯H- 'eyebrow' ({ref Demiraj 1997}:67, {ref Holm 2011}:67), cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:48, {ref Orel 1998}:36-37 for a more tenuous comparison to a Messapic gloss in Hesychius and the Etymologicum Magnum.
Etymology uncertain, perhaps of onomatopoeic origin? (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:6).

Comment: < Lat. PILA 'bundle (of hair)'? (Dietz 1864:342)

Justification: Further connections uncertain. Perhaps to be connected with the complex of 'white' words from PGmc. *blank- but due to the difference in semantics this connection remains unclear, cf. OED, {ref EWA 2}.
Probably a loan from Old French diguer ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Generally derived from a basic PIE root *bʰel- 'to blow, swell' ({ref Olsen 1999}:525, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:178-179).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:133-134, {ref Rejzek 2001}:220, 231-232, 305; {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:398 for further discussion).
No certain etymology outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:666).

Probably a formation derived from TochAB kät- 'strew (on purpose); sow (seeds)' ({ref Adams 2013}:686), further to PIE *(s)kedh₂- 'shatter, disperse' ({ref Malzahn 2010}:564-565, {ref Adams 2013}:166-167, cf. {ref LIV²} 550-551).
Extra-Tocharian connections unclear ({ref Adams 2013}:68)

Comment: lit. "cutting"

Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *māro- from PIE *meh₁-ro- ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:18, {ref Matasović 2009}:258).
Of onomatopoeic origin. No certain etymology outside of Slavic ({ref ESSJa} 8:18-19, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:202).
Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split' ({ref Derksen 2008}:99, 507; {ref LIV²} 119-121).

Lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *lagja- 'leg; hollow bone, stalk'. Attestation is restricted to North Germanic and there are no certain cognates outside of Germanic ({ref Kroonen 2013}:321-322).
Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *kelH- 'to rise up, to tower' ({ref ALEW} 441-442, 475-476, {ref Derksen 2015}:221, 236, cf. {ref LIV²} 349).
Loanword from Iranic, cf. Wakhi pʉz 'chest', Sarikoli puz 'id.', etc. ({ref Morgenstierne 1936}:662).

Comment: Also Welsh 'cig', Breten 'kik', both meaning 'flesh' Buck (p249)

Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:65, {ref Orel 1998}:103 for various proposals and further discussion.
Derived from Middle Breton liam, a borrowing from Old French liem ({ref Deshayes 2003}:463).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:244, {ref ESSJa} 12:70-74, {ref Snoj 1997-2016} for further discussion.

A denominative verb to Gk. κυνηγός 'hound-leader, huntsman'. The lexical root for the 'leader' element of the verbal governing compound is from PIE *h₂eg̑- 'drive' (cf. {ref LIV²} 255f.), compounded with *k̑un- 'dog' (cf. {ref NIL} 436-440 s.v. *k̑u̯ón-, *k̑un-, *k̑u̯n̥- 'Hund' cf. /cognate/21/).
Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯g̑- 'to belch, to vomit' (cf. {ref ALEW} 848-849, 877-878, {ref Derksen 2015}:385, {ref Karulis 1992} II:134, {ref LIV²} 509).
Root ref. form follows {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}, but note that the Proto-Luwic form this class represents may also formally represent *gʷelH-. Cf. {ref LIV²} 679.
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *leg̑- 'to collect, to pick up' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:625-626, {ref Beekes 2010}:841-842, {ref LIV²} 397).
Lexemes as though continuing Old Indic latā- 'creeper, vine' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:633 no. 10928). Further etymology uncertain ({ref KEWA} III:88).

Etymology outside Tocharian uncertain. {ref Adams 2013}:23 proposes a connection to Hittite ḫaḫ(a)ri- 'lung(s), midriff' (but this Hittite form remains of obscure etymology according to {ref HED H}:7).

North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *nabja- 'beak', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref de Vries 1977}:406, {ref Kroonen 2013}:380). Cf. however {ref Orel 2003}:279 and others attempting to connect to Proto-Germanic *nabō- 'nave' via a meaning 'protuberance, knob'.

Goidelic lexemes probably continuing a compound containing Proto-Celtic *retu- 'course', and ultimately a derivative of PIE *ret- 'to run' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:112, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:310).
No certain etymology outside of Germanic, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:522, {ref Kroonen 2011}:333, {ref Kroonen 2013}:460-461 for further discussion.

Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish tút, túth 'smell, stench' (cf. {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:371). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:189 for references to an uncertain proposal to OHG stiuz.

Comment: fr. the notion of 'quick, swift' (Buck 1949: 896)
= Lat. CRATIS 'wickerwork, hurdle', Gr. KARTALOS 'basket', SKT> KṚT- 'twist thread together, spin' (Buck 1949: 668)

Justification: No certain etymology outside of North Germanic; traditionally considered a derivative of PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow' ({ref de Vries 1977}:671 citing {ref IEW} 81ff. *u̯ē-; not in {ref Orel 2003}, {ref Kroonen 2013}).
Loanword from Latin piscem 'fish' ({ref Meyer 1891}:329, {ref Huld 1984}:103, {ref Orel 1998}:316-317, {ref Holm 2011}:63)
See also {ref Smoczyński 2007}: 668-669.
No certain connections outside of Celtic ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:123-124, {ref Matasović 2009}:210).
Hellenic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *h₂rei̯- 'to count, reckon' ({ref Beekes 2010}:131, {ref Lehmann 1986}:281-282, {ref Matasović 2009}:313).
No certain etymology outside of Germanic (pace {ref Kluge 2011}:768, cf. {ref EWAia} II:434).

Comment: *grilla- 'wet, damp', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 235, no. 4386; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ἀμαυρός 'dim, faint' ({ref Andriotis 1999}:828-829). No further etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:71-72, {ref Beekes 2010}:84).
Etymology uncertain. Loanword from Bulgar? (cf. {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 2:633
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Turner 1931}:241, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:330 no. 5803.
Etymologically isolated, the proposed connection with Lithuanian girià 'forest, wilderness' remains doubtful ({ref ALEW} 332). For older proposals cf. {ref Karulis 1992} I:291-292.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)} for further discussion.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kau̯fa-, perhaps originally 'hump', without certain cognates outside of Iranic ({ref Schmitt 2014}:202-203).
It is related to PS *golŭ ['naked']. The original meaning was thus 'stick without twigs, naked stick' {ref Rejzek 2001}: 218.
Latin flūmen and Romance lexemes from PIE *bʰleu̯H-mn̥- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:228, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:292, {ref LIV²} 90).
Probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:389 for similar Romance lexemes in the same meaning).

Comment: Could skarəna- be derived from *kʷelh₁-? *s-kr̩H-na- > skarna-

Justification: No consensus etymology; cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972}:585, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:384, and {ref Beekes 2010}:478 for various proposals.
No known etymology ({ref Adams 2013}:401).

Comment: < 'excrement'

Justification: Loan from (Low) German voll 'full' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:1095).
Romance lexemes as though from Latin *tīrāre, of uncertain origin (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:725, {ref DCECH} V:505-508 for further discussion).

Comment: Origin unclear, l can derive from *rd/rz if this verb had originally a prefix. It is also possible that there is a kind of r/l alternation. Then it could be related to cognate set 6659 *Hrab/f-: raw- > *rū- (?), though this is pretty wanted.

Justification: Cf. MIr. cethramthu 'quarter, fourth part' in the sense of 'quartered human body; thigh' ({ref Electronic Dictionary of the Irish Language (eDIL)}), further to OIr. cethair 'four' from PIE *kʷetu̯or- 'four' (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:179).
Uncertain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic, cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:1131-1132, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:691 for further discussion. [Not in {ref ALEW}, {ref Derksen 2015}].
Loan from Finnic, cf. Livonian puk'k' (cf. {ref Karulis 1992} II:85).
Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'to stick; be pointy' ({ref Kluge 2011}:879, {ref EWNl} 4:272-273, {ref Kroonen 2013}:476, {ref LIV²} 592-593).
Anatolian lexemes continuing PIE *di̯eu̯-ot-, further derived from PIE *dei̯- '(to be) bright, to shine' ({ref NIL} 69-81, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:766-767).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *belgan- 'to swell', further derived from PIE *bʰelg̑ʰ- 'to swell' ({ref Seebold 1970}:99-100, {ref Kroonen 2013}:73-74, cf. {ref LIV²} 73-74).
Slavic lexemes as though from PIE ?*pel- 'to flame up, blaze up' ({ref LIV²} 469, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:390, {ref Boryś 2005}:409).

Romance lexemes from Latin tūtāre, tūtārī ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 13/2:446-449). Further root etymology disputed: Either to ?*teu̯H- '(freundlich) beachten, betrachten; schützen' ({ref LIV²} 639-640) or to* teu̯h₂- 'to be strong' > 'keeps strong, protects' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:632-633).
IE root etymology disputed, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:493-494 for a critical discussion of competing alternatives; see also {ref HED K} 245-248.
Derived from Old Irish cengal 'link, belt, tie', a loanword from Latin cingulum 'belt' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:65).

Comment: comp. NPers. GŌŠĀ 'edge, corner'. Rather not: NP gušād is from Middle Persian wišād! MJK

Justification: No known etymology ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:980).

Comment: Initial H may be either *h₁ or *h₃ (Kloekhorst 2008:167-168).
Justification: A root restricted to Anatolian. {ref LIV²} 234-235 mechanically reconstructs ?*h₁e⁽k̑⁾- 'to die'; {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:167-168 assumes *Hók- / *Hk- with indeterminable laryngeal under the assumption that laryngeals merged with *h₁ before *o in Anatolian (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2006}).

Adjective derived from Latin sordēs 'dirt, filth, stain', generally further connected to Proto-Germanic *swarta- 'black' appearing to reflect an adjective *su̯ordo- 'black, dirt-colour' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:637, {ref de Vaan 2008}:576, cf. {ref IEW} 1052, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:574-575, {ref Orel 2003}:392).
Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *keh₂u̯l(o)-, further analysis of the word formation within Indo-European is unclear (cf. {ref ALEW} 467-469, {ref Derksen 2015}:233).
Loanword from German schmutzig 'dirty' ({ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok}).
Of uncertain etymology, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:408-409 for various proposals.
Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *u̯ei̯s- 'to sprout, thrive' ({ref ALEW} 1170-1171, {ref Derksen 2015}:485, 495; cf. {ref LIV²} 671).
An intensive formation to Swedish skrata 'scare, chase away', of onomatopoeic/imitative origin ({ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok}).
Romance lexemes from Latin bastum 'stick' as a secondary n-stem *bastō, -ōnis. No further etymology ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 1:279, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:83, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:67).

Literally a participle to the verbal root ā(i)- 'to be hot'; further etymology uncertain. For competing IE root analyses cf. {ref LIV²} 229, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:164-166, with references to further literature.
No certain etymology outside of Italic (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:642-643, {ref de Vaan 2008}:581).

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:434-435, {ref Kroonen 2013}:453-454. Perhaps to an IE root *sleh₁b- 'be slack'(?) if to be connected with Lith. slobstù, slõbti 'be weak' (cf. {ref LIV²} 565).

Derived from Middle Welsh bwyd 'food' (cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}), further from Proto-Celtic *bēto- < PIE *gʷei̯h₃-to- ({ref Matasović 2009}:64), cf. PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'live' ({ref LIV²} 215-216).
Generally connected to PIE *(s)teu̯d- 'hit, beat' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:177-180, {ref Schumacher 2004}:642-646, {ref Matasović 2009}:393; cf. {ref LIV² 601).
Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *kret- 'to shake' ({ref ALEW} 524, 527; {ref LIV²} 370-371).
Etymology outside of Celtic disputed, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} O:22, {ref Delamarre 2003}:170, {ref Matasović 2009}:295-296, for various proposals.
Parallel loans from Arabic علف / ʿalf 'feed, fodder'.

Etymological connections outside of Baltic uncertain, traditionally compared to Proto-Indo-Iranic *sau̯- 'to press, squeeze' but this etymological proposal is no longer widely accepted ({ref ALEW} 908, {ref Derksen 2015}:396, cf. {ref EWAia} II:713-714, {ref LIV²} 537-538).
Celtic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *mīlo- 'animal' continuing PIE *meh₁lo- 'small animal' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:51, {ref Matasović 2009}:271-272).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2368 and ff.

Justification: No certain etymology outside of (East) Baltic (cf. Latv. juõds 'demon, evil spirit'). See {ref ALEW} 419-420, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:238 for further discussion.

Comment: Parallel loans from Arabic

Justification: From Ancient Greek συλλογίζομαι 'reckon, compute' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:526), from συν- 'with' + λογίζομαι 'count, reckon' a denominal verb in -ιζω from Ancient Greek λόγος 'computation, reckoning', and o-grade noun from PIE *leg̑- 'collect' ({ref Beekes 2010}:841, cf. {ref LIV²} 397, {ref IEW} 658).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *preh₁- 'to blow on; stoke up' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1192, {ref LIV²} 489, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1153).
Loanword, but precise source uncertain. Either from Romance rombulus or from Greek ῥύμβος.
Derived from Ancient Greek θεωρέω 'to view, look, behold' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), no certain etymology outside of Greek: for further etymological details cf. 'see' in /cognate/8257/.
The ablaut and morphology of related vocabulary within Greek suggest a root *h₂u̯ei̯d-, but there are no known cognates outside of Greek (cf. {ref LIV²} 288, {ref Beekes 2010}:23).
Derivative to Proto-Germanic *drita- 'shit, dirt' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:103-104, {ref Seebold 1970}:164-165).
As though from Proto-Iranic *u̯azi̯ā̆-u̯ant- 'possessing weight', cf. Avestan uaziia- 'weight, load' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:105).

Iranic lexemes, as though continuing a prefix *ka- + PIE *ml̥h₃dʰ-, cf. Vedic mūrdhán- 'forehead, head, top part', Ancient Greek βλωθρός 'grown high', Old English molda 'top of head' ({ref EWAia} II:368, {ref Bailey 1979}:52).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *stinkwan- 'to thrust, to clash; to stink', a derivative of PIE *stengʷ- 'to thrust, push' ({ref LIV²} 596-597, {ref Seebold 1970}:471-472, {ref Kroonen 2013}:480-481).
Extra-Tocharian connections unclear, possibly to be connected within Tocharian to Tocharian A kāts, B kātse 'belly', cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:112, {ref Adams 2013}:165-166 for further discussion.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *gau̯b- 'to say (positively/negatively)', no certain etymology outside of Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:113-114).

Comment: From Old Irish gar 'short; near'

Justification: Derived from Lithuanian gìrti 'to praise', further derived from PIE *gʷerH- 'to express agreement' ({ref ALEW} 335-336, {ref Derksen 2015}:171, 178-179, cf. {ref LIV²} 210-211).
Extra-Tocharian connections are uncertain (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:504-505 for various suggestions).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from derived from Vedic √cet- 'to recognise' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:261, no. 4815), ultimately from PIE *kʷei̯t- 'to observe, recognise', traditionally analysed as a root-extended form *kʷei̯-t- to a more basic root *kʷei̯- (cf. {ref EWAia} I:547-548, {ref LIV²} 382-383).

Comment: from *u̯ert- 'turn, roll, spin', Vedic vartáyati (RV), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11356
could this be identical with Kumzari bidrit?

Justification: Parallel loans from Arabic عورة ˁawra 'flaw, blemish', pl. عورات ˁawrāt 'pudency, pubic area'.

Etymology uncertain. According to {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:148, to be connected to lexemes from PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, chop' in /cognate/697/; {ref Cheung 2007}:442 hesitates between etymologies to either Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike, thresh' or Proto-Iranic *xa(m)p/b- 'to dismount, descend, move away'.

The Germanic and Celtic forms in this class reflect a derived stem *kh₂p-no- or *kap-no- (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:261-262, {ref Matasović 2009}:197, {ref Kroonen 2013}:196-197}), for the reconstruction of the IE root as either *keh₂p- or *kap- cf. {ref LIV²} 345n1.
Connections outside of Tocharian uncertain; cf. {ref Adams 2013}:9-10 for various proposals.

Comment: North Germanic only.
Justification: Possibly to be connected to the verbal root underlying Ved. √śak- ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:264-265, 301-302), but the etymology is not fully certain; cf. {ref EWAia} II:600-601.
No clear etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:975-976, {ref Beekes 2010}:1288).
Etymology outside of Slavic uncertain (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:83-84, 123; {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:176, {ref Rejzek 2001}:230).

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *lě̀to 'summer', as though an o-stem derived from PIE *leh₁t-. Alternatively, an analysis as a secondary derivative to an original t-stem from a hypothetical root *leh₁- remains possible; cf. note by Scarborough in the cognate class citations for further discussion.

Comment: Loan from East Caucasian
Justification: Loanword from East Caucasian ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:333-334).
Parallel loans from Middle Low German trecken 'to pull' (cf. {ref Den Danske Ordbog}).

Comment: < AOIS  'age'

Justification: Parallel loans from Middle Low German glatt 'smooth'.
From PIE *treb- 'dwell', a Western Indo-European isogloss common to Celtic, Italic, Germanic, and Baltic ({ref Untermann 2000}:765-766, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:388-389, {ref ALEW} 1126).
No certain etymology outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:267-268).
Etymology outside of Anatolian debated, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:645-646, {ref HED PA} 168-170, Tischler, Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar Vol. 2, 446-447 for various proposals.
Root ref. form follows {ref LIV²} 421, {ref Kluge 2011}:590, but cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:350.
Loanword from Latin coccum 'berry' ({ref Orel 1998}:189, {ref Holm 2011}:65-66).
No certain etymology outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:267-268, cf. {ref Melchert 1993a}:45).
Iranic lexemes continuing a PIE stem *pitu- ~ *pei̯tu- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:130 s.v. Vedic pitú- 'food, solid food).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Strand 2011a}.
Etymology uncertain ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:533-534, cf. {ref HED L}:111-114, 127-128).
Light verb constructions using parallel loans from Arabic as the semantic head, cf. Arabic milāḥa 'swimming, sailing', mallāḥ 'sailor' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:606-607).

Comment: loan, via Hindi farāḵẖ from Persian (Turner 1931: 401)

Justification: Onomatopoeic in origin, no further etymology outside of Slavic ({ref ESSJa} 8:135).
No certain etymology outside of Celtic (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:43-44, {ref Matasović 2009}:341).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10186
Turner 1931: 260

Justification: Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:410-411 for various proposals.
No clear etymology outside of Tocharian ({ref Adams 2013}:26-27).
Loanword from South or East Caucasian ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:376)
Of uncertain origin, perhaps an East Caucasian loanword? (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. {ref {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:383).
Loanword from Low German recht 'right' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:634-635).
Light verb construction with Marathi माहित / mahit 'know' as the semantic head.
Cf. Old Lithuanian tiẽsus 'straight, direct', without certain connections outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 1100-1102).

From MHG swanz, a backformation to MHG swanzen which is in turn in all likelihood an intensive formation to schwanken 'to waver, oscillate', in turn derived from the adjective schwank 'swaying' < Gmc. *swanka- (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:832, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:573).

Comment: fr. Ir. FIADH  'animal' (Buck 1949: 191)

Justification: Loans from Middle Low German (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:144).
Modern Indic lexemes as though from *choṭṭa- 'small', further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:279 no. 5071).
Greek and Celtic lexemes as nominal derivatives of PIE *h₁ers- 'rear' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:838, {ref Beekes 2010}:1127-1128, {ref Matasović 2009}:118).
Loan from Persian تخم / toxm 'seed'.
The Modern Goidelic forms in this class derive from the OId Irish compound do·srenga.
An old borrowing from Persian/Tajik xān(a)- 'house' ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:409).
Italic and Romance lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *u̯enH- 'to grow fond of' ({ref LIV²} 682-683, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:662, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:766 no. 9186).

Generally connected to words for male sexual organs in other IE languages, cf. Vedic pásas- 'penis', Gk. πέος 'penis', Lat. pēnis 'penis', OHG fasal 'seed, descendant' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:670, {ref HED PE, PI, PU}:37-45).
Without certain etymology (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:276-277).
Etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:583 for a critical discussion of previous proposals).

Comment: = NE EVEN

Justification: Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:278 for discussion of various proposals.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:571 for references to older (now uncertain) proposed etymologies, {ref Orel 2003}:395 for a proposed Albanian cognate and references to older literature. No lemma in {ref Kroonen 2013}.
Etymology outside of Anatolian uncertain ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:554).
No convincing etymology outside of Celtic. See {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:7-8, {ref Matasović 2009}:86-87 for various suggestions.
Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *walþu- 'field, uncultivated area, wood', further from a PIE derived stem *uólH-tu- ({ref Kluge 2011}:968, {ref Kroonen 2013}:571-572).
As though from *h₂er-u-ti- to PIE *h₂er- 'to fit (together), join' ({ref Melchert 1988}:224-225).
Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:319-320).
Loanword from Latin spīna 'thorn, spine; spine, backbone' ({ref Orel 1998}:430).
Etymology outside of Tocharian unclear ({ref Adams 2013}:611-612).

Generally considered a loanword from Latin ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:128) but occasionally disputed (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:587). On upholding the loanword hypothesis, cf. comments by Irslinger in this class.
Apparently a loanword from Old Norse hitta 'to hit upon, light upon, meet with' ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Welsh lexemes derived from PIE *terh₁- 'to rub, bore' ({ref Matasović 2009}:370-371, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, cf. {ref LIV²} 632-633).
Loanword from Modern High German leben 'to live' ({ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:796).

Comment: fr. Lat. SOLUM 'bottom, base, sole, ground'

Justification: Etymology uncertain; cf. {ref HED A+E/I}:178-182 and {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:212 for various proposals.
Anatolian lexemes generally compared with Proto-Germanic *dankwa- 'dark' derived to a PIE root *dʰengʷ- ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:829, cf. also {ref Heidermanns 1993}:146).
Old and Middle Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √ard- 'to scatter, spray'. Further connections unclear, cf. {ref EWAia} I:60 for various suggestions.

Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'to shear, scratch, cut off' ({ref EWAia} I:537, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:255 no. 4701, {ref Boryś 2005}:553, {ref Derksen 2008}:234, 452; cf. {ref LIV²} 556-557).
Loan from Low German, cf. Middle Low German sât 'seed' ({ref Polański & Sehnert 1967}:135).
Loanword from Slavic *kostъka ({ref Orel 1998}:187, {ref Holm 2011}:53-54).

Ossetic lexemes as though from Proto-Iranic *u̯i-tarta-, a verbal adjective to PIE *terh₂- 'to go through, cross over' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:344, {ref Cheung 2007}:382, cf. {ref EWAia} I:629-632, {ref LIV²} 633-634).
Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *rak(k)an- '(sleuth) dog'. No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:432, {ref Kroonen 2013}:404).

Comment: cf. *kauč- “to bend, draw into, contract”, which is possibly reflected in Abyānei köta/kuǰ- “to gnaw” (Cheung 2007: 249)

Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit accha- 'clear transparent'; further etymology uncertain, perhaps to Vedic acchāyá- 'shadowless' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:8 no. 142).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2538, Turner 1931: 565

Justification: Probably an from an IE s-stem *h₃er-es- 'high' to PIE *h₃er- 'rise' (cf. {ref LIV²} 299-300) that has been secondarily transferred into -r/n- inflection, which is morphologically productive in Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:314-315).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4153: presumably from a non-Indo-Aryan source

Justification: Root etymology in this class follows {ref LIV²} 402, {ref de Vaan 2008}:350-351 to PIE *lei̯d- 'set in motion'.

Comment: Morgenstierne considers the derivation of kˈāṇay < *karna-ka- possible and compares it with Lithuanian kálnas. This suggests an input form *klͅHn- or *kolHn-.

Justification: Denominal formation, but further details are disputed (cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:963-964, {ref Adams 2013}:787-788 for further discussion).
Parallel loans from Persian (زندگى (كردن  / zendegī (kardan) 'to live'.
Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}, no. 8397 s.v. *pōḍ- 'burn'. No further etymology.
Loanword from Iranic (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1936}:666).
Parallel loans from Persian گردن / gardan 'neck'.
According to {ref Strand 1998} to be connected with Vedic hári- 'golden, yellow' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:809 no. 13981). If so, further to PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green'.
Loan from Middle Persian.
Of uncertain etymology ({ref EWAia} I:487-488).
Etymology outside of Iranian uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:104-105).
Ultimately derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'make red' ({ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} III:207, cf. {ref LIV²} 508-509).
Loanword from Livonian nuja 'stick' ({ref Karulis 1992} I:631).

Comment: Perhaps with Slavic *mězga 'sap'?

Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hrugja- 'ridge; back'. Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:250, {ref Kluge 2011}:775 for further discussion.
Adjective derived from the common Iranic word for 'stone, rock'.
