Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing secondary derivatives of a Celtic verbal root *klek- (cf. Old Irish clich- '(s)he moves', nominal cluiche 'game, event, sport'), probably of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:127).
Romance lexemes apparently going back to a stem *pe/itt- 'small', probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:543 no. 6544a, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 8:342-347).
Parallel loans from Persian. The Pamir words (Wakhi, Sarikoli) are probably loaned from Tajik.
No clear etymology; often considered to be a non-Indo-European Wanderwort (cf. {ref Weeks 1985}:125, {ref HED A+E/I}:32-33 for further discussion).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:46-47, {ref Demiraj 1997}:113-114, {ref Orel 1998}:42-43, {ref Holm 2011}:70-71 for various suggestions and discussion.
Loan from Old Norse vængir ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Loan from Pāli sītala- 'cold', cf. Sinhalese hīl 'cold' as the inherited reflex from Sanskrit śītalá- 'cold' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:723 no. 12487).

Comment: Loan from Arabic qarīb

Justification: Unexpected vocalism points to parallel loans from Persian.
Parallel loans from Persian گوشت / gūšt 'meat'.
Parallel loans from Middle Low German swanz 'trailer; tail, penis' (cf. {ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok}).
Loan from Latin coccum '(berry which was used to produce scarlet dye)' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Falileyev 2000}:139).
According to {ref Orel 1998}:425, a loanword from Germanic *skurta- 'short'.
Parallel loans from Persian, cf. Middle Persian pwst / põst 'skin', Persian: Tehran پوست	 / pūst 'id.'.
Loanword from within Iranic, probably via Tajik or Persian.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 14018 s.v. *hallati intr. 'moves, shakes'
Justification: Modern Indic as though from Old Indic *hallati 'moves, shakes', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:810 no. 14018. Further etymology unclear.

Comment: via "swollen" > "thick", cf. Benzing (1983:256)
Ir. *duai > (WA)LWEDEL; root cautiously proposed by Cheung (2007: 81).
etym. dub. (Buck 1949: 1012)
Justification: The forms seem to point back to a root *blei̯d- / *blid- to which different stems were formed within Celtic; further connections outside of Celtic uncertain (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:59, {ref Matasović 2009}:69). See {ref de Bernardo Stempel 1999}:79 for a discussion of the stem formation.
Loanword from Russian год 'year' (cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965} I:127).
Loanword from Latin bestia ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:49).

Possibly to IE *drep- 'scratch, tear' according to {ref Adams 2013}:574, although note that the Anatolian evidence which he cites for a semantic parallel is not certainly from this root ({ref Malzahn 2010}:812-813, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:871).
Parallel loans from Persian, cf. Persian: Tehran تیز / tīz 'sharp'.
Anatolian lexemes from PIE *h₁erH- 'to wash', cf. TochA yär- 'to bathe' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:197-198, {ref LIV²} 239).
Possibly from PIE *mergʷ- if to be compared with Proto-Germanic *merkwa- 'dark' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:562-563, cf. also {ref Heidermanns 1993}:409-410, {ref Kroonen 2013}:366).
Slavic lexemes from PIE *(s)keu̯h₁- 'to perceive, see' ({ref LIV²} 561, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:91, {ref ESSJa} 4:136-138).

Etymology uncertain, possibly connected with Ancient Greek αἰονάω 'to moisten' (cf. {ref Melchert 1994}:102), but this proposal is not without some formal difficulties ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:340-341, cf. also {ref HED H}:301-304).
Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes reflecting an original athematic root-present to PIE *ses- 'to sleep' ({ref LIV²} 536-537, {ref EWAia} II:716-717, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:746-747).
From PIE *mneh₂- according to {ref Starke 1990}:147; tentatively accepted by {ref LIV²} 447.
Etymology uncertain, either an onomatopoeic formation or an East Caucasian loanword (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:620).

Comment: cf. Avestan frā̊nk-/ Instrumental sg. frača and Old Indic prā́ñc-
lit. 'un-swallow', Ir. SLUCIM 'swallow' (Buck)
etym. dub.?

Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin sentīre 'to sense, feel' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:645-646), further to PIE *sent- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:554, {ref LIV²} 533).
Well attested in Pamir languages, origin uncertain.
No certain etymology outside of Greek (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:762, {ref Beekes 2010}:1031).
Hellenic lexemes continuing PIE *poi̯H-u̯eh₂- 'grass, meadow', cf. Lithuanian píeva 'meadow' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:922, {ref Beekes 2010}:1214-1215, cf. {ref ALEW} 769).
Cf. 'shadow' in /cognate/8269/ for further discussion regarding the root ref. form.

It is often assumed that Proto-Slavic *bľĭvati is derived from *bʰleu̯H- and related to Latin fluō, fluere etc. ({ref LIV²} 90, {ref Derksen 2008}:46). This etymology is adopted here, however cf. {ref ESSJa} 2:140-141, {ref Rejzek 2001}:82, {ref Snoj 1997-2016} with skepticism.

The link to PIE *terkʷ- is formally and semantically attractive. An alternative etymology points to PIE *(s)ter- 'hard(en)', cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}, but it has formal and semantic issues, cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 4: 227.
The etymology of this word is obscure.
Loanword from Lahnda laṇdā 'crop-tailed' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:44, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:645 no.11081).
Parallel loans into Modern Indo-Iranic languages from Persian جگر / ǰigar 'liver'

Comment: Etymology disputed.
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Albanian, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:131-132, {ref Orel 1998}:513, {ref Holm 2011}:80 for various proposals and further discussion.
Derived from PIE *h₂edʰ⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'to press' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:334-335, {ref LIV²} 255).
Etymology unclear, perhaps further to PIE *pelh₁- 'to make swing' ({ref Derksen 2008}:410-411, cf. {ref LIV²} 469-470).

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *sal- 'salt' ({ref NIL 586-590, cf. {ref ALEW} 586-587, {ref Derksen 2015}:387-388, {ref Derksen 2008}:459. Cf. 'salt' in /cognate/283/ for further discussion of the root reconstruction.
Loanword from Scots, cf. Middle English flour, Old French flour ({ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:176).

Etymology uncertain, {ref Abaev 1959–1995}:18-19 suggests from Proto-Iranic *laštyaka- in comparison to Lithuanian lazdà 'stick' but without further parallels within Iranic; alternatively possibly an old loanword from Armenian lcʼakʼ 'lever' (Oleg Belyaev p.c.).
Since the source is as late as Middle Low German, then the Faroese and Danish lineages should be considered by then already divergent, and therefore this is a parallel loan.

Comment: Loan from Low German.
Justification: Loan from Low German mân 'moon' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:396).
Loan from Latin pōmum 'fruit tree; fruit' ({ref Meyer 1891}:326, {ref Orel 1998}:314, {ref Holm 2011}:85-86).
The Vedic root √cakṣ- is likely to have been an inner-Indo-Iranic reanalysis of an s-desiderative form of the root *kʷek̑- (cf. {ref EWAia} I:523, {ref LIV²} 383-385).

Comment: with prefix ham-

Justification: Cf. Vedic parṣá- 'sheaf, bundle', Young Avestan parša- ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:75), further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:101, cf. {ref KEWA} II:230 for various uncertain proposals).
Loanword from (Eastern) Middle High German stomm, cf. Middle High German stam ({ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1474).

Comment: < DRECK 'dirt'

Justification: Of obscure etymology; cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:66 for various unsatisfying proposals.
Etymology outside of Germanic unclear ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:404). Cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:386 for older proposals.
Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *tres- 'to tremble, be afraid' ({ref LIV²} 650-651, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:393-394, {ref EWAia} I:678-679).
Loanword from Old French flour, flur, flor ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Comment: etym. dub.
Justification: Denominal from Welsh gwth 'a push, shove, thrust', further root etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} for various suggestions.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Karulis 1992} II:188-189 for further discussion.

The Celtic forms in this class are often considered to be connected with Germanic in OHG eben, Goth. ibns, etc. (cf. {ref Pedersen 1909}:92), but there are many formal difficulties with this identification (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:222, {ref Matasović 2009}:113, {ref Lehmann 1986}:202)

Comment: Parallel loans from Persian (after p > f, but before ē > ī)

Justification: From Latin captīvus 'taken prisoner' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:157), derived from Latin capiō, -ere 'take', further to PIE *keh₂p- (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:89-90, {ref LIV²} 344-345).

Comment: cf. OCS loza 'vine'
LIV suggests *h₂u̯i̯edʰ-

Justification: Loanword from dialectal southern Italian ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:301-302).
Anatolian lexemes from PIE *neh₂- 'to become afraid' ({ref LIV²} 449, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:591-592).
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain ({ref Adams 2013}:628).

Comment: Parallel loans from Skt. yákr̥t /lexeme/22444/
Justification: Parallel loans into Modern Indic from Sanskrit yákr̥t 'liver'.
Parallel loans from Old Turkic arqa.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5574 ?

Justification: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:275, no. 5014; no further etymology.
No certain etymology, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:901-902 for a critical appraisal of previous proposals.
From Vedic śilā́- 'rock, stone' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:721-722, no. 12459), further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:640).
Balto-Slavic lexemes from PIE *(h₂)u̯elk- 'to drag, pull' ({ref Derksen 2008}:514, {ref Derksen 2015}:504, {ref ALEW} 1244-1245, {ref LIV²} 289-290).
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:667 and {ref Adams 2013}:333-334 for previous proposals.

Comment: < MHG BOZEN 'to strike' (Diez 1864: 86)

Justification: No clear Indo-European etymology ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:440), cf. {ref HED K} 66-72 for older unconvincing proposals.
Generally considered a loanword from Romance *pluverem < Latin *pulverem 'dust' ({ref Meyer 1891}:346, {ref Demiraj 1997}:323-324; but cf. {ref Orel 1998}:331-332, 335 for an alternative proposal.
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:158 for various proposals).
Loan from Latin pulsus 'a pushing, beating, striking' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:595-596)

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10781 s.v. rundra ʻrich inʼ (lex.)
Loan from Latin angustus 'narrow'.
Justification: Loanword from Latin angustus 'narrow' ({ref Meyer 1891}:307, {ref Huld 1984}:98, {ref Orel 1998}:298).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:349-352 for a critical survey of previous proposals.
No certain etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:218-219, {ref Beekes 2010}:269-270).
Armenian lexemes probably to be derived from PIE *sengʷ- 'to go under, sink' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:90-91, {ref LIV²} 531-532).

Comment: Loan from Latin
Justification: Borrowing from Late Latin *virdis (Lat. viridis), cf. {ref Falileyev 2000}:69, {ref Deshayes 2003}:305-306.
(Parallel?) Loan from Middle Low German.
Lexemes continuing Old Breton strit, a loanword from Latin strictus 'drawn together, close, strait, tight' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:699)
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ekʷ- 'to say' ({ref LIV²} 673-674, {ref EWAia} II:489-491, {ref Cheung 2007}:402-404).
Etymology outside of Celtic difficult to establish ({ref Matasović 2009}:239-240, cf. also {ref Deshayes 2003}:458).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *pei̯H- 'to swell up' ({ref EWAia} II:83-84, {ref LIV²} 464-465).

From Old Norse reikna, a loanword from Middle Low German rekenen ({ref de Vries 1977}:438).  Since this is already found in Old Norse, its presence in both Elfdalian and Swedish can be presumed to reflect a parallel shift to this meaning, not a parallel loan.

Tocharian, Albanian, and Balto-Slavic lexemes from PIE *g̑ombʰ-o- 'peg; tooth' ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:126-127, {ref Adams 2013}:208, {ref Demiraj 1997}:158, {ref Orel 1998}:82, {ref ALEW} 1289, {ref Derksen 2008}:549, {ref Derksen 2015}:512).
From Proto-Celtic *slattā; further connections outside of Celtic are difficult (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:127-128, {ref Matasović 2009}:345).

Generally connected since {ref Fraenkel 1932}:229-230 to Lithuanian ker̃gti 'tie, bind' ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:87-88, {ref Malzahn 2010}:573-574, {ref Adams 2013}:171-172) from a PIE root *kergʰ- or *kergʷʰ- (not in {ref LIV²}).
Etymology uncertain ({ref HAB} III:577). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *ord-].
Etymology outside Hellenic uncertain ({ref Chantraine {1968–1980}:1025-1026, {ref Beekes 2010}:1364).

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ({ref Kluge 2011}:142, {ref de Vries 1977}:70). Traditionally considered an extended from an extended form of a root *bʰer- 'to cut' according to {ref IEW} 166 (cf. {ref Orel 2003}:37). Cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:53 for a proposed comparison to Albanian barmë 'bast'.

Modern Greek φεγγάρι from Medieval Greek φεγγαρίον, a diminutive in -αριον, derived from Ancient Greek φέγγος 'light, splendour, lustre' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1528). Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1184-1185, {ref Beekes 2010}:1559-1560).
No known etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:519-520, {ref Beekes 2010}:679).
Root etymology outside of Slavic disputed: Either to PIE *g̑u̯elH- 'to burn, blaze' or to PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'green, yellow' (cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} II:103).

Modern Hellenic lexemes, ultimately from an Ancient Greek diminutive formation πέσκος 'skin, rind'. Further etymology uncertain cf. {ref Andriotis 1999}:1168, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:890, {ref Beekes 2010}:1180.

Comment: Non-Persian words with additional -xVnV might all be loans from early Persian rōdxāna (or a later form), although this can be proved only for Mazanderani.
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *sreu̯- 'to flow, stream' ({ref EWAia II:784-785, cf. {ref LIV²} 588).
Probably a loan from Tocharian B ({ref Adams 2013}:115, {ref Carling 2009}).

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek λαιμός 'throat, gullet' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:755). Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:613-614, {ref Beekes 2010}:824).

Modern Greek lexemes continuing a derived adjective to Ancient Greek κόκκος 'kernel' used in the production of red dye, further etymology unknown ({ref Andriotis 1999}:729, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:553, {ref Beekes 2010}:733}).
A formation probably of onomatopoeic origin, originally in the sense 'chat, prattle', later generalised as the generic verb 'to say' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:615-616, {ref Beekes 2010}:827-828).
Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *ned⁽ʰ⁾- 'to link, connect' ({ref Untermann 2000}:493-494, {ref Falileyev 2000}:119).
No convincing etymology outside of Greek (cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:522-523, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:892-893, {ref Beekes 2010}:1182).
Etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:6, {ref Beekes 2010}:7), cf. {ref Pinault 1979}, {ref Beekes 1996} for competing hypotheses.
Loan from Italian petto 'chest'.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:61-62 for various doubtful suggestions.
Etymology outside of Italic uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:289, {ref de Vaan 2008}:279).
Related to the common words for '(finger)nail' widely found elsewhere in Indo-European via a derived feminine stem *h₃nogʷʰ-eh₂ (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:354-355, {ref ESSJa} 25:161-164).

Etymology dubious. {ref Adams 2013}:517 connects to a putative PIE *mel- 'member' comparing Gk. μέλος 'member', Breton mell 'knuckle' < *melso-, Lith. mélmenys 'fat around the kidneys', Skt. márman- 'member, vulnerable part of the body', but the etymologies of these compared lexemes are all for the most part considered to be unknown or dubious (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:927-928, {ref EWAia} II:329, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:386).
Loan from Church Slavonic нєбо 'sky' ({ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:53).
Loanword from Iranic (cf. {ref Hübschmann 1897}:243, {ref Olsen 1999}:908). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯at-a-].
Parallel loans in Modern Greek dialects from Turkish toz 'dust'.

Indo-Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *reu̯dH- 'to howl, to weep' ({ref LIV²} 508, cf. {ref EWAia} II:465-466, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:627 no. 10840, {ref Cheung 2007}:194, {ref ALEW} 847-848, {ref Derksen 2015}:377).
Parallel loans from Persian گرد / gard 'dust'.
As though from Indic *phutta- 'insignificant', cf. Bashkarik phut 'fly' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:511 no. 9085). Further etymology uncertain.
Loanword from Italian frutto 'fruit' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1562).
Parallel loans from Church Slavonic ({ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:102, 105, {ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-} 2:174).
Loanword from Turkish, cf. Turkish avlamak 'to hunt' (cf. also {ref Dawkins 1916}:665).
Parallel loans from Middle Low German.
Loan from Turkish kanca 'hook' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 2:201).
No generally agreed etymology ({ref Frisk 1960-1972}:64-66, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:609-610, {ref Beekes 2010}:817-818. For a recent attempt, cf. {ref Nikolaev 2010}.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn (around)' ({ref Boryś 2005}:694-695, 710; cf. {ref LIV²} 691-692).
No satisfactory etymology outside of Greek; for some proposed inner-Greek connections cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:384-385, {ref Beekes 2010}:479.
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *vę̄zati 'tie', a derivative of PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ- 'make narrow' ({ref Derksen 2008}:521, {ref Boryś 2005}:688; cf. {ref LIV²} 264-265, {ref NIL} 301-303).

Romance lexemes from Latin iactāre 'to hurl' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:372), an intensive/iterative stem to Latin iaciō 'to throw' and further to PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'to throw' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:292-293, {ref LIV²} 225). The Italic derivatives from this root show an anomalous extension in *-k-.

No clear etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:34, {ref Beekes 2010}:38-39}). It is likely that Ancient Greek αἷμα was a lexical replacement for the inherited word for 'blood', ἔαρ < *h₁esh₂-r̥- (cf. /cognate/859/), which was only retained as a poetic word in the language of Homeric epic and other archaic poetry.
Generally derived from a PIE root *ser- 'to string together, connect' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:727, {ref LIV²} 534-535).
Indo-European root etymology uncertain (see note by Irslinger to this class); cf. {ref Untermann 2000}:442-443, {ref de Vaan 2008}:359, {ref NIL} 476n33 for competing proposals.

{ref EWAia} II:258-259 supposes two possible (homophonous) root etymologies either to *bʰes- 'to skew, to crunch' (cf. {ref LIV²} 82 s.v. ?*bʰes- '(zer)kauen') or *bʰes- 'to blow, to breathe', however {ref NIL} 34-36 considers these two postulated roots to be one and the same. For developments in Middle and Modern Indic, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:537, no. 9425.
Etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Frisk 1960-1972}: II:333, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:763-764, {ref Beekes 2010}:1033).
Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic dunóti 'distresses' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:366, no. 6410), further derived from PIE *deh₂u̯- 'to catch fire' ({ref EWAia} I:707-708, {ref LIV²} 104-105).

Romance lexemes from Latin tornāre 'to turn (in a lathe)' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 13/2:46-80, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:729-730). A denominal verb from Latin tornus 'turner's wheel, lathe', in turn an old loanword from Ancient Greek τόρνος 'turning lathe' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:695-696).

It is uncertain whether this lexeme is a loanword from Latin spīna (via Old Polish?) or a cognate of it (cf. {ref Vasmer 1953-1958} II:708, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} III:735). [Not in {ref Derksen 2008} and therefore implicitly not considered a part of the Slavic inherited lexicon in that work.]
Parallel loans from Low German brav, further borrowed from French brave, from Italian bravo (cf. {ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok}).
Parallel loans from Polish skóra 'skin' (cf. {ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-} 12:167, {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 6:432, 436

Originally referring to counting by making scores on a piece of wood with a knife. A description of this method of counting is attested in one of the oldest Slavic texts ("On the Letters" by Chernorizets Hrabar). The meaning 'cut' is attested in Old/Middle Polish. Cf. Proto-Slavic *briti 'to shave', ultimately derivatives to PIE *bʰrei̯H- 'to cut' ({ref Derksen 2008}:63, {ref ESSJa} III:31-32, {ref Boryś 2005}:40, {ref Skok 1971-1974} 1:209-210, cf. {ref LIV²} 92-93).

Comment: Reflexes of this root in Slavic have meanings 'hail', 'black, rain cloud', 'cloud', 'rainbow' etc.

Justification: Etymology outside Italic uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:148-149, {ref de Vaan 2008}:142 for various speculative proposals). {ref LIV²} mechanically reconstructs ?*⁽k̑⁾remH-, but without any certain cognates outside of Italic.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯h₁- (Cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:706-709, {ref Derksen 2008}:415, 524 {ref LIV²} 668-669).

Comment: Loan from Turkish
Justification: Loanword from Turkish deniz 'sea' ({ref Dawkins 1916}:674).
No certain etymology outside of Greek (cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:122, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:640, {ref Beekes 2010}:861).
Loan from Old Spanish chifle 'whistle; container made of horn'.
Etymology outside of Italic uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:441, {ref de Vaan 2008}:409).
Loan from Middle German rechen 'to count' (cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:507-508).

Hellenic, Armenian, and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂leh₁- 'to grind up' (cf. {ref LIV²} 277, {ref Beekes 2010}:65, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:26-27, {ref Cheung 2007}:166, {ref Bailey 1979}:22, {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:93).
Lexemes from PIE *stéh₃-mn, *sth₃-mén-s, cf. Gk. στόμα 'mouth', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:411-413).
No convincing etymology outside of Slavic (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:57-58, 10:124, {ref Derksen 2008}:203-204, and further discussion by Lechosław Jocz in the further citations to this class).

Modern Indic lexemes derived to Ved. √chad- 'to cover' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:275, nos. 5020-5021); further etymology uncertain, perhaps to PIE ?*(s)k̑ed- ({ref IEW} 919, {ref LIV²} 546) if connected with Old English hætera 'garments' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:554-555 for further discussion). The root reference form for this set tentatively follows this etymology.
Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Vedic daṇḍá- 'stick' No certain further etymology ({ref EWAia} I:692, {ref KEWA} II:11-12, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:350 no.6128).

Tocharian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE ?*pei̯H- 'to sing'. The cross-branch cognacy in this class tentatively follows {ref LIV²} 465, {ref Adams 1982}:133, {ref Adams 2013}:409-410, {ref Derksen 2008}:398, but cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:723-724 with some reservations over the proposed Tocharian-Slavic connection.
{ref Samadi 1986}:247 suggests *xšiwya-, {ref Cheung 2007}:452 connects with Avestan xšī- 'misery' and suggests a root *xšai-.

Comment: PS *ob-volk- with PS *volk < PS *velkti 'pull'. The etymological meaning of the compound is 'something that covers (the sky). The similarity to ?*u̯elg-/*u̯elk- is superficial.

Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *pei̯s- 'to pound, beat' ({ref EWAia} II:169, {ref LIV²} 466-467; cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:460 no. 8140, 465 no. 8221).

Modern Indo-Iranic lexemes based on Vedic pipīlá- 'ant', of unknown origin ({ref EWAia} II:132-133, {ref KEWA} II:284-285). The modern forms exhibit six main variants, for which cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:463, no. 8201.

Comment: The Etymological Dictionary of Belarusian claims that this lexeme is a derivative from Proto-Slavic *kyp- 'seethe' (Proto-Indo-European ku̯eh₁p-). However, it seems unconvincing.

Justification: Etymology outside of Italic uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:628, {ref Sihler 1995}:40, {ref de Vaan 2008}:566). For Romance lexemes, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:655 no. 7947.
Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit lakuṭa- (~ laguḍa-) 'club', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:629 no. 10875, {ref KEWA} III:84-85).

Comment: < *chaṭa- and variants, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 271f., no. 4966
Justification: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:272 no. 4966 s.v. *chaṭa- 'stick, cane'. Further etymology uncertain.
From PIE *séh₂u̯el-, sh₂(u)u̯en- (?), *sh₂un-, *sh₂ul- 'sun' ({ref NIL} 606-611; for the semantics cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:201-202, {ref Matasović 2009}:324).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:424 for various proposals. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *an(-)dzreu̯-o-/-a-].
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑u̯ei̯t- 'to shine brightly' ({ref ESSJa} 13:162-163, {ref Derksen 2008}:258-259, cf. {ref LIV²} 340).

Comment: possibly related to Vedic (RV, AV) pavástam n. 'covering' (cf. Old Persian pavastā- f. 'skin, parchment'), cf. entries *pōta-, *pōtta- and *pōttha- 'cloth' (with variants) in Turner 1962-66, p. 477f., no. 8400, 8414
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10299, s.v. mr̥ṣṭá-, either from marś- (< Hmelk̑-) or marj- (or blend), cf. LIV, p. 280f. with Anm. 1
Justification: IE root etymology uncertain: either to {ref LIV²} 226-227 *Hmelk̑- 'abstreifen, (ab)wischen' (> Ved. √marś- 'touch, stroke, handle') or {ref LIV²} 280-281 *h₂merg̑- (> Ved. √marj- 'wipe, rub, cleanse'). A blend might also be possible. (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:594-595 no. 10299, {ref EWAia} II:325-326, 331-332, 373.

Perhaps from IE *kai̯to- ({ref IEW} 521) if inherited and comparable to Germanic terms found in Goth. haiϸi 'field', Engl. heath, etc. These forms are, however, restricted to Celtic and Germanic and we may be dealing with borrowing or (independent) borrowings from a prehistoric NW European substratum language (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:198).
To be derived from PIE *bʰerH- 'to work with a sharp tool' ({ref Olsen 1999}:62, see which for a discussion of the possible stem formations in Armenian; cf. also {ref HAB} I:452, {ref LIV²} 80).

Modern Indic lexemes derived from Sanskrit rakṣā- f. 'preservation, care; guarding'; 2. 'ashes (used as a preservative)', further derived from Ved. √rakṣ- 'to protect' and derived from PIE *h₂leks- (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:611, no. 10551-10552; {ref EWAia} II:422, {ref LIV²} 258).
Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic kṣudrá- 'small, minute' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:193, no. 3712), further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾seu̯d- (cf. {ref EWAia} I:434, 439; {ref LIV²} 372).
From Ancient Greek σφάζω ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:493-494), further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1073, {ref Beekes 2010}:1426-1427).
From Hellenistic Greek κέλλα 'room, chamber', a loanword from Latin cella 'storeroom, chamber' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Comment: In Avestan, gaona- is also attested with the meaning "hair", probably "body hair" or "hairy meat" (probably animal meat with hair on it), cf. the Nerangistan 47.4/9 and the forms gaonauuaṇt- "hairy" and pouru.gaona- "having much hair".
Justification: Cf. Avestan gaona- 'hair' ({ref Benzing 1983}:299), further etymology uncertain.
Loanword from Pāli aggini- , gini- 'fire', replacing Old Sinhalese aga 'fire' < Ved. agní- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:3 no. 55).

Of unknown origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:943, cf. {ref HAB} II:468). Sometimes considered a loanword from Urartian ṣûə 'inland sea' ({ref Diakonoff 1985}:600), but the Urartian word could just as well be a loan from Armenian (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:140-141). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsou̯-u-].
Probably inherited from Indo-European in view of the morphology, but there are no known cognates outside of Hittite (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:987).

Etymology uncertain. Traditionally derived from *k̑l(e)i̯-tr- (cf. Gk. κλιτύς,  Lat. clīvus 'slope, rise; hill'; Goth. hleiþra 'booth, tent' (PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lean') (rejected by {ref HAB} II:270). Alternatively, from *lḗh₂-sr̥ ‎(cf. Alb. lerë '(heap of) stone(s)', Gk. λᾶας, OIr. líe 'stone' ({ref Hamp 1967}:16-17, accepted by {ref Olsen 1999}:122). Both etymologies rejected by {ref Martirosyan 2010}:306. [MM: Proto-Armenian *liar-in-].

From Ancient Greek κοβαλεύω 'to carry as a porter', a derived verb from the nominal κόβαλος ({ref Babinotis 2010}:717); further origins obscure (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:550, {ref Beekes 2010}:727-728}).
For root ref. form *leh₃u̯-, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} and {ref Melchert 2011}:127-132.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:81-82, {ref Demiraj 1997}:224, {ref Orel 1998}:193-194 for various proposals and further discussion.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10948 s.v. lábhate (~ rábhate), analogically influenced by MIA deti and neti 'takes', thus e instead of a
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes derived from Old Indic √labh- 'to grasp, seize', ultimately from PIE *lembʰ- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:635 no. 10948, {ref EWAia} II:434-435, {ref LIV²} 411-412).
No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:297-298, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:560, no. 9758).
Origin uncertain ({ref Olsen 1999}:944, cf. also {ref HAB} IIi:262, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:511). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *mar-].

This word is well attested in Iranian languages. Cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:267 on Khotanese bata- "small" deriving it from a root *vā "be deficient", cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:204 *h₁u̯eh₂- "to be empty, absent, lacking".
Armenian and Iranic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *h₁erkʷ- 'to shine, to sing' ({ref LIV²} 240-241, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:259, {ref EWAia} I:114-115, {ref Bailey 1979}:25).

The Celtic and Italic lexemes in this class are generally agreed to be cognate, although some aspects of the formal reconstruction of a common root are uncertain ({ref LIV²} 195, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:277-278, {ref Schumacher 2004}:318-324, {ref Matasović 2009}:148-149).

Comment: < Vedic vā́ra- ~ vā́la- m. 'tail hair', 'hair of animal, wool', cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 545, Turner 1962-66, no. 11549, 11572
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic vā́ra- (~ Sanskrit vā́la-) 'hair of tail, tail, hair' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:673-674 no. 11549). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref EWAia} II:545 for further discussion.

From Ancient Greek κρούω 'to strike, stamp, knock' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:337, {ref Babinotis 2010}:736), possibly further connected to TochAB kärn- if the lexemes in /cognate/2701/ reflect an unextended form of the same Indo-European root (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:785-786, {ref LIV²} 371).
There is no certain etymology ({ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:396). The relationship to Proto-Slavic *prǫtŭ and Russian prygat' is dubious.
Loan from Polish rachować 'to count', itself ultimately a borrowing from Middle German rechen 'to count' (cf. {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 5:33)

Comment: Uncertain origin. Formerly connected with Goth. dags 'day', Skt. dáhati 'burns', LIth. dagà 'heat of the Sun', etc; the latter, however, go back to PIE *dʰegʷʰ-, which is incompatible with the Armenian development.
Justification: Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian takʿ 'warm, hot'. Of uncertain origin (cf. {ref HAB} IV:391). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}, {ref Olsen 1999}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *takʰ-i-].
Originally a root-noun in the sense *'visible, outer form' > '(outer) body; skin' (cf. Hittite tu̯ekka- 'body, person') from PIE *tu̯ek- 'be visible' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:684, {ref LIV²} 654).

Romance lexemes from Latin metus 'fear, alarm' ({ref DCECH} IV:66-67), no further etymology outside of Italic (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:402, {ref de Vaan 2008}:378 for various uncertain proposals).
Loanword from French jambe 'leg' ({ref Varella 2006}:252).

Traditionally connected to PIE *(s)teu̯d- 'push' ({ref IEW} 1032-1034, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:564-565), but more recently {ref Kroonen 2013}:487 argues that the Germanic internal evidence cannot support this etymology.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref DCECH} VI:849-851 for various proposals.
Etymology outside of Anatolian uncertain, perhaps to the root *meh₁- 'to measure', but  ultimately unclear. Cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:571-572, {ref HED M} 116-119 for further discussion.
Loan from Low German grö̂ne 'green' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:187).
Based on a loanword from Italian largo. Greek: Italiot λάργκα treated as a separate loan event in in /cognate/5868/.

Cf. Vedic raśmi- 'rein, ray of light', Sinhalese rasmiya 'rays', rasnaya 'heat' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:616 no. 10648). The root of Vedic raśmi- is not attested verbally, but cognates in Iranic allow for the reconstruction of a basic root *rać-, probably 'to bind' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:440-441).

Comment: Connected with SMG δουλεύω 'I work' in the sense 'worked, finished' > 'smooth'??? (-MJCS)

Justification: Root etymology in this set follows {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:366-368, {ref Oettinger 1979}:480-481 to PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'to blow' ({ref LIV²} 287), however cf. {ref HED H} 423, {ref LIV²} 287-288 preferring to set up *h₂u̯ei̯- to a perfect stem ?*h₂e-h₂u̯ói-/u̯i- considering the semantics 'blow' > 'run' semantically problematic.

Of uncertain origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:941), perhaps a Semitic loanword according to {ref HAB} II:517-518 (cf. Akkadian kūšu 'skin', Arab. qašʿa 'dry skin' [< Sumerian kuš 'skin']). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kaʃ-ii̯a-].
Loanword from Italian anca 'hip'.

Cf. SMG άχαρος ᾽without grace, elegance, beauty' from Ancient Greek ἄχαρις, remodelled as an o-stem άχαρος ({ref Babinotis 2010}:246), further to PIE *g̑ʰer(H)- 'desire, enjoy' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1606-1607, {ref LIV²} 176-177).
Loanword from Low German runt 'round' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:655).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic ({ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:249-250, cf. also {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 4:123-124)

Greek: Pontic ροΐζω 'fall' from Ancient Greek ῥοΐζω 'to drench (of horses)', a derivative of PIE *sreu̯- 'to flow, stream' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:482, {ref Beekes 2010}:1281-1282, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:970-971, cf. {ref LIV²} 588).

Tsakonian σποΐα, π̔οΐα from Ancient Greek σποδία 'ash' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:507). Further etymology outside of Greek obscure ({ref Frisk 1960-1972}:771, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1040, {ref Beekes 2010}:1386).

Cf. SMG αδρός 'sizable, stout' from Ancient Greek ἀδρός 'thick, stout, bulky', further a derivative of PIE *seh₂- 'to satiate' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:69, {ref Beekes 2010}:22, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:20, 121-122).

Cf. Standard Modern Greek τρανός 'very big in power or importance', from Hellenistic Greek τρανός, morphologically remodelled from early Ancient Greek τρανής 'clear distinct' < PIE *tr̥h₂-n-, cf. PIE *terh₂- 'to pass through, cross' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1444, {ref Beekes 2010}:1498-1499, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1128).
Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *dʰer- 'to fix, make firm' ({ref LIV²} 145-146, {ref ALEW} 177-180, 193-194, {ref Derksen 2015}:116, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:93-94).
Parallel loans from Persian مکان 'place, location', ultimately from Arabic مکان 'id.'.

Cf. Lithuanian gul̃ti 'to lie down', which with the Latvian and Latgalian lexemes in this set may go back to an East Baltic root *gul-, but a further IE root etymology remains uncertain (cf. {ref ALEW} 377-379, {ref Derksen 2015}:193-194, 196).

Generally considered to be a (at least a semantic) loanword from Middle Low German ({ref de Vries 1977}:289; no North Germanic cognates connected by {ref Kroonen 2013}:271-272 s.v. Proto-Germanic *jakk/gōn-).
If this is only a semantic realignment by contact influence, then technically it is not to be considered a loanword in CoBL, but a semantic realignment of a still cognate word.  
But since this is analysed as a loanword from Middle Low German, by that period fragmentation of North Germanic varieties had already begun, so this is to be taken as a parallel loan.

Generally connected to Gk. κιχάνω < *gʰeh₁- ({ref LIV²} 196, {ref Kroonen 2013}174-175). Whether these forms are to be further connected on one hand to Arm. gam 'come' (so {ref LIV²}) or to Indo-Iranian lexemes (so {Kroonen 2013}) would decide whether to reconstruct initial *g̑ʰ or *gʰ.
From Ancient Greek ἐκκλύζω 'wash out, wash away' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:227), further to PIE *k̑leu̯H- 'purify' ({ref Beekes 2010}:718-719, {ref LIV²} 335).

Comment: not found in Cheung (2007)

Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek βέργα, a loan from Latin virga 'twig, bough, branch' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:263).

From Ancient Greek ῥύγχνος 'snout, beak' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:482). This is further connected to Armenian ṙngunkʻ 'nostrils, nose' by {ref Frisk 1960-1972} and {ref Beekes 2010}, but the lexeme may well also be expressive in origin (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:978-979).

No certain etymology outside of Slavic ({ref Derksen 2008}:390; cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:191-193, {ref Rejzek 2001}:441-443, {ref Boryś 2005}:408-409, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 3:5 for various proposals and further discussion).
Loanword from Tocharian B eprer ({ref Carling 2009}:74-75, {ref Adams 2013}:70).
For the etymology, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:545-546; for the root ref. form cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.
Indic lexemes from Vedic uṣṇá- 'hot', derived to Vedic √oṣ- 'to burn' and further connected with PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'id.' ({ref EWAia} I:281, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:112, no. 2389; {ref LIV²} 245).

Romance lexemes from Latin casa 'small house, hut, cabin' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:165-166). Further origins uncertain, possibly a loanword from one of the non-Indo-European languages of Ancient Italy ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:103, {ref de Vaan 2008}:96).

A verbal adjective derived from Hellenistic Greek βράζω 'boil, froth up' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:277). No further etymology, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:193, {ref Beekes 2010}:235-236 for various uncertain proposals.

According to {ref Cheung 2007}:32-33, from Proto-Iranic *čap- 'to seize, attach, stick, strike'. Further etymology uncertain, {ref Cheung 2007}:33 further speculates a possible connection to PIE *keh₂p- 'to seize, grasp' as semantically attractive; cf. also {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:306-307).
Loanword from Italian l'occhio 'the eye' with the Italian definite article analysed as part of the nominal stem.
Slavic lexemes generally considered to continue a derivative from a PIE root *gʷeh₁dʰ- 'disgusting, gross' ({ref Derksen 2008}:160-161, {ref ALEW} 303-304, cf. {ref ESSJa} 6:81-82).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 273, no. 4994 s.v. *chapp- ~ *chipp-; further etymology unclear
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from an Indic stem *chapp- ~ *chipp- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:273 no. 4994), further etymology obscure.
Loanword from Middle English battle, cf. Scottish Gaelic baideal 'battle, battlement' ({ref Broaderick 1984b}:37, {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:26).
Loanword from Venetian rozza 'stone' ({ref Varella 2006}:251).
Etymology outside of Iranic uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:304, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:467 for older hypotheses).
From Ancient Greek ῥεῦμα 'that which flows' ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:438, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1210), further to PIE *sreu̯- 'to flow' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1281-1282, {ref LIV²} 588).
Loan from Latin fortis 'strong' or Italian forte 'id.' (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:110, {ref Orel 1998}:101).
Loanword from Turkish kelle 'head' ({ref Varella 2006}:268).
From Ancient Greek κωφίας 'a kind of snake' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:344). No clear cognates outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:528, 607; {ref Beekes 2010}:816).
Loan from Latin coxa 'hip' ({ref Meyer 1891}:193, {ref Orel 1998}:188).

Baltic lexemes as though from PIE ?*seu̯k- ({ref LIV²} 540, {ref ALEW} 988-989), although there are no certain cognates outside of Balto-Slavic so an IE provenance is not assured. [Not in {ref Derksen 2015}].

Comment: cf. Vedic (Br) grathnā́ti, Sanskrit granthayati (MhB), grathati (Dhātup.), Pali gantheti; cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 233, no. 4353, Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 504f.

Justification: Albanian forms derived to an original loan from Latin līmāre 'to file, polish, finish' ({ref Orel 1998}:222).

No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic according to {ref ALEW} 1218-1219. {ref Derksen 2015}:497 connects the Balto-Slavic forms with Germanic *warha- following {ref Kroonen 2013}:574, but this proposal has not yet been widely accepted.
Etymology uncertain, perhaps with PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'throw' according to {ref LIV²} 225, but rejected by {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:381-382 on formal and semantic grounds.
No certain etymology, probably of expressive or imitative origin (cf. {ref DCECH} IV:498-502).
Borrowing from East Romance, cf. Romanian luptă 'fight' < Latin lucta 'wrestling' ({ref Orel 1998}:233)
Assumed to be Persian loans.

No clear etymology outside of Baltic. A connection with PIE *klep- '(secretly) steal', hide' is often considered, but is only possible if one considers a secondary s-mobile and if the initial cluster *skl- can be simplified to *sl- ({ref LIV²} 363-364, {ref ALEW} 940-941).
Loanword from Latin hospitium 'lodging, inn' (with metathesis of p and t in the borrowed form), cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:415-416, {ref Huld 1984}:115, {ref Orel 1998}:438.

Italiot Greek lexemes continuing a diminutive formation *σκουλλίον 'little neck' to Ancient Greek σκόλλυς 'fringe of hair' ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:466-467). Further etymology disputed (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1020-1021, {ref Beekes 2010}:1356).

Tsakonian νίου 'hear' from Ancient Greek νοέω 'perceive, observe, apprehend' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:395), which is turn a denominal verb from Ancient Greek νόος 'mind, sense, intellect'. Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:756-757, {ref Beekes 2010}:1023).
Derived from Ancient Greek ἁπαλύνω (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), further a denominal verb to Ancient Greek ἁπαλός 'tender, weak' of uncertain etymology ({ref Beekes 2010}:113).

Stem alternation between, e.g., nominative singular θρίξ, genitive singular τριχός due to Graßmann's Law point to a Proto-Greek stem *tʰrikʰ-, but further connections outside of Greek are unclear ({ref Frisk 1960-1972} I:684, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:441-442, {ref Beekes 2010}:556).

Identical to the general word for 'foot' and 'leg' in many other Slavic languages (cf. 'foot' in /cognate/1252/, 'leg' in /cognate/1231/), and ultimately derived to the same root as the widespread root *h₃negʷʰ- also found in '(finger)nail' and 'claw' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:354-355, {ref ESSJa} 25:161-164).
Generally derived from Proto-Celtic *tuk-slo- ({ref Deshayes 2003}:734, but cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:393-394 preferring *tullo-), ultimately derived from PIE *teu̯k- 'beat, hit' ({ref LIV²} 640).

Comment: Loan from English.
Justification: Loanword from English 'carry' (first attested 1500s) ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).

Comment: The Avestan verb vaxš- means "to sprinkle" (not found in Cheung 2007). MacKenzie (1970: 553) "The Khwarezmian Glossary I" (BSOAS 33): derives the noun from *waxšu-.

Justification: Etymology uncertain ({ref Matasović 2009}:363-364), for various proposals cf. {ref IEW} 1050, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:90).
Loan from North Italian
No certain etymology ({ref ALEW} 308).
Loanword from Middle Low German schrī(e)n.
No certain etymology ({ref Schrijver 1995}:223). {ref Deshayes 2003}:281 considers a loanword from English wail.

Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *3. men- 'to rise, stick up' ({ref EWAia} II:313, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:566 no. 9858, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:72, {ref Matasović 2009}:276, cf. {ref IEW} 726, 747-748, {ref LIV²} 437).
Loanword from Slavic *glъtъ 'sip, gulp' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
Loanword from North Italian

Comment: cf cognate/6399

Justification: A loanword from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian njušiti 'to smell' (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:311, {ref Orel 1998}:301-302).

Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:68-69, {ref IEW} 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ({ref Matasović 2009}:205, cf. {ref ALEW} 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, {ref EWAia} II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this set).
From Old English cest 'box, coffer', perhaps a loanword from Latin cista 'box, chest', but not fully clear (cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Comment: scrape off, cut off > reject, refuse > throw out > throw

Justification: The etymology is not entirely clear but the word is probably related to Proto-Slavic onomatopoeic *pukati 'bang, knock, beat' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:489-490).

From PIE *g̑erh₂- 'wear down, make old' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:271, {ref Kroonen 2013}:312; cf. {ref LIV²} 165-166); for the Romance lexemes in this class from Latin granum 'grain, seed', cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:327-328.
No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:95, {ref LIV²} 157-158, {ref Kroonen 2013}:102 for further discussion).
Loan from Slavic zapadati 'to fall' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).

Romance lexemes from Latin prehendere 'grasp, seize' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:558-559, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 9:339-354), further derived from PIE *gʰed- 'grasp' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:487, {ref LIV²} 194).
Continuing a derivative of PIE *kemb- 'small' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:439).
No convincing etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} I:39).
No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:564-565, {ref de Vries 1977}:684).
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:163-164, {ref Kroonen 2013}:75, 150 for proposed further connections.
Loanword from Italian or Latin combatt(u)ere 'to fight'.

Romance lexemes continuing Latin sapere 'to have a good taste, taste of' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:628 no. 7586, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 11:193-201, further to PIE *seh₁p- 'to perceive (by taste)' ({ref LIV²} 519, {ref de Vaan 2008}:538-539).
Etymology uncertain, an old proposal of {ref Thurneysen 1917}:312 connects with Old Irish fairsing 'broad, spacious'.
Parallel loans from Persian برگ / barg 'leaf'.
Romance nominal derivatives based on a loanword from Old High German grīfan 'to grasp, grab' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:330, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 16:73-80).

Lexemes continuing a derivative with PIE *-mo- to Proto-Germanic *malan- 'to grind', further from PIE *melh₂- 'to crush, grind' ({ref Lehmann 1986}:242-243, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:351, {ref LIV²} 432-433).
Continuing Old Irish úr 'soil, earth' ({ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:387), further etymology unknown (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} U:26 an evaluation of various uncertain proposals).
From Old English brid, further etymology unknown ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Loans from Low German (cf. {ref Den Danske Ordbog}).  Given that Danish is the main lexical source of Riksmal, and the latter derives from it within the last few centuries, the loan event here should arguably have been into Danish before the derivation of Riksmal, and therefore not 'parallel'.
Romanian lexemes from Lat. frondea ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:244 for further discussion).

Romanian pădure, as though from *padule(m) < Latin palūde(m) 'fen swamp' (nom.sg. palūs) with metathesis ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:507, {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further generally compared to Skt. palvala- 'pond, pool' and Lith. pélkė 'bog, marsh' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:442, cf. {ref EWAia} II:105, but {ref ALEW} 753 against the connection of the Baltic lexemes).
Loanword from Turkish sert 'hard, stiff', cf. SMG σέρτικος 'heavy, strong (of blends of tobacco and cigarettes)' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1260).

Romance lexemes from Latin fracidus 'very soft' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:297-298), a derivative of Latin fracēs 'grounds, dregs (from olive pressing)'. Further etymology obscure (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:251, {ref de Vaan 2008}:238 for various proposals).

Comment: Dhātup., cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3747

Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin uadere 'to advance, proceed' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:760), further to PIE *u̯eh₂dʰ- 'to stride' (cf. {ref LIV²} 664, {ref de Vaan 2008}:650).

Derived from a PIE base *k̑uH-, if to be connected with Skt. śū́la- 'spear' with the shortened vowel length in Celtic and Italic due to Dybo's Law (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:150, {ref Matasović 2009}:229).

Comment: via verbal meaning "to fit", however Bailey's link to the PIE root is not very convincing

Justification: Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin gelus, -ūs 'cold, frost, ice' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:317-318, {ref DCECH} III:353-354), further to PIE *⁽g̑⁾el- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:256).
Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *tekti, in turn derived from PIE *tekʷ- ({ref Derksen 2008}:489, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:159, cf. {ref LIV²} 620-621).

From Latin pavimentum 'pavement' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), derived from Latin paviō 'to thump, pound, strike' and further to PIE *pi̯eh₂- 'beat' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:451-452, cf. {ref LIV²} 481-482).
Generally assumed to be a loanword from Continental Celtic, cf. Gaulish *banno- 'horn'.
No certain etymology outside of East Baltic ({ref ALEW} 512-513, cf. also {ref Smoczyński 2007}:303-304).
Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *menH- 'to step, stamp on' ({ref Matasović 2009}:276, cf. {ref LIV²} 438).
Probably a loanword from Andalusian Arabic ġárfa 'handful' ({ref DCECH} III:102)
Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:178 no. 3441, to Vedic kr̥śá- 'lean, thin', further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾erk̑- 'to emaciate' ({ref EWAia} I:318-319, 395-396, cf. {ref LIV²} 355).
Loan from Bulgarian nasip 'bank, embankment' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).

Possibly to be connected with Greek κακός (cf. {ref Orel 1998}:175, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:239, {ref Beekes 2010}:619-620), but it is difficult to be fully certain of the etymology (cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:216-217); cf. discussion in /cognate/7332/.

The further IE cognacy and the PIE root are not entirely clear (cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 3:323, {ref Boryś 2005}:579, {ref Rejzek 2001}:604-605, {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1362-1363. The Kashubian and Sorbian phrases are calques of German 'Angst haben'.
Loan from Church Slavonic used in place of the inherited Russian lexeme солодкий ({ref Vasmer 1953-1958} II:657, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} III:666).
Loanword from German schwach 'weak' [Not in {ref Karulis 1992}].

From Ancient Greek τρανόω 'make clear, plain, distinct', a secondary verbal derivative via Ancient Greek τρανής 'clear, distinct', ultimately from PIE *terh₂- 'to pass, cross' ({ref Dawkins 1916}:652, {ref Beekes 2010}:1498-1499, cf. {ref LIV²} 633-634).
No satisfactory etymology. Some attempts have been made to relate to PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink', cf. {ref Smoczyński 2005}:267 for further discussion.
Goidelic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives of PIE *stei̯gʰ- 'to rise, to stride' ({ref LIV²} 593-594, cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:637-640, {ref Matasović 2009}:376).
Loan from Scots English debate (?), cf. {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:299, 354.

Comment: uncertain etymology

Justification: Loan from Arabic بحر / baḥr 'sea' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:110).
Loan from Persian ستاره / setāreh 'star'.

There is no certain etymology. The widespread hypothesis ({ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:46,  {ref Rejzek 2001}:629, {ref Boryś 2005}:602) assumes an irregular phonetic change, cf. also {ref LIV²} 546. [Not in {ref Derksen 2008}].

The cognacy of the Greek and Germanic forms is generally agreed, but the derivation of the forms from a common IE proto-form is disputed. An explanation from a compound stem *h₂k-h₂ou̯s-i̯e- 'is sharp-eared' is commonly considered (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:71), but this analysis remains uncertain (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:55). For references to older literature, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:50-51; {ref Lehmann 1986}:180-181.

Comment: cf. Vedic (ŚB) abhyàkta- 'anointed', nasalization due to blend with abhyaṅga- 'anointed' (Mn.) (both from √añj-), palatal due to *bhiyajyate 'is smeared, get wet'; cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 542; parallel derivations

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Lehmann 1986}:231, {ref Kroonen 2013}:339; cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:371-372 for discussion of variant forms within Germanic).

Often considered cognate with Lat. crūdus 'raw, bloody, rough' although aspects of the nominal stem formation remain unclear, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:250-251, {ref de Vaan 2008}:146; against a connection with Lat. crūdus, cf. {ref NIL} 448n30, with references.
Loanword from Greek φρίκη 'horror' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
Loanword from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian, Slovenian umoriti 'to murder, kill' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
From Ancient Greek ἰσχίον 'hip, hip-joint'. No further etymology (cf. {ref Andriotis 1974}:285, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:472, {ref Beekes 2010}:602-603).

Comment: with parallel sound substitutions: kʰ for x
Justification: Parallel loanwords from Persian خون / xūn 'blood'.
Loanword from Slavic prachŭ 'dust' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).

Comment: Loan from Latin
Justification: Loan from Latin galbinus 'greenish-yellow' ({ref Orel 1998}:131, {ref Holm 2011}:64, cf. 'yellow' in /cognate/1409/).
Derived from PIE *(s)teg- 'cover' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:39-40, {ref Matasović 2009}:376; cf. {ref LIV²} 589).
No certain etymology ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:76).
Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √dru- 'to run, hurry', ultimately to PIE *dreu̯- 'to run' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:378-379 no. 6624, 6634, {ref EWAia} I:755-756, {ref LIV²} 129).
A loan from South Slavic mirosati, cf. Serbo-Croatian mirisati 'to smell' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).

Comment: cf. Sanskrit nāśaka- (MBh) 'destroying, wasting'

Justification: Derived from Hungarian gând 'thinking, thoughts', a loanword from Hungarian gond ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 331, no. 5812 and p. 789, no. 13693; Sinhalese e in teta from temanavā < *temayati

Justification: From earlier Greek ῥαπίς, with contamination from Lat. ramus ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:435, {ref Andriotis 1974}:477). Further etymology within Greek uncertain ({ref Beekes 2010}:1275).

Comment: original meaning "to shine, to bloom"
Justification: Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *spaič- 'to shine; to bloom'; further etymology outside of Iranic uncertain (cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:437, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:350).
A loanword into Tsakonian from Medieval Greek (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).
From Ancient Greek τραύσανον 'firewood' (Hesych.) (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), further etymology disputed (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1129, {ref Beekes 2010}:1500).
Cf. Lithuanian žíedas 'blossom, flower'. No certain etymology outside of Baltic ({ref ALEW} 1304-1305).

Cf. Avestan gaēsa- 'hair'. According to {ref Bailey 1979}:84 the Avestan and Khotanese forms may be related via a more basic root *gai̯- to a group of Iranic words also found in Proto-Iranic *gaip/b- 'to spin (thread)', but the proposed derivational morphology in such a connection is entirely unclear (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:96-97).

Comment: cf. S, Cr. čȉt 'whole'
Justification: Extra-Baltic connections unclear. The traditional connection to the family of Serbo-Croat čȉt 'whole', etc. is improbable ({ref ALEW} 490, cf. also {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:252, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:285). [Not in {ref Derksen 2015}].
Loan from Latin baptisma.

A denominal adjective from Ancient Greek ῥόδος 'rose', in turn a loanword from the East, probably from Old Iranian *u̯r̥da- 'rose' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:976-977, {ref Beekes 2010}:1289-1290).

Comment: Proto-Indo-European *mo[u]-lo-
Verbal meaning in Avestan "to press together", PP ϑraxta-, this is taken by Benzing (1983: 100) as the input of Khwarazmian ˀšxt "near", which is formally possible.
perhaps from Vedic (ud- +) drāpáyati (ŚB), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 379, no. 6634

Justification: Root ref. form in this class follows {ref LIV²} 353-355, {ref Schumacher 2004}:401-403, but cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:72, {ref Matasović 2009}:202-203 for older proposals.

Hellenic lexemes from a PIE stem *gʰebʰh₂l-. A reconstruction with a laryngeal *-h₂- is required because of the connection with Tocharian AB śpāl 'head'; also connected with OHG gebal 'skull' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:522, {ref Beekes 2010}:682-683, {ref Adams 2013}:703).
Romance lexemes from Latin colubra 'snake' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:195), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:133-134, {ref de Vaan 2008}:126 for various proposals).
Of unknown origin (cf. {ref DCECH} I:227-229 for discussion of various hypotheses).
Loanword from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian loviti 'hunt', etc. ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, cf. 'hunt' in /cognate/1145/).
Etymology outside of Greek uncertain, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:601, {ref Beekes 2010}:805-806 for various proposals.
No certain etymology outside of Indic ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:729 no. 12579, {ref EWAia} II:652-653).
Loanword from Finnic (cf. {ref Karulis 1992}:561).
Ossetic lexemes, probably of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:336).
Loanword from Old French flour, flur, flor 'flower' (via Middle English flour, flur 'flower'?).

Derived from the verb γyr- 'to turn' and further to Proto-Iranic *gar- 'to turn, wind', without clear correspondences outside of Iranic ({ref Samadi 1986}:84, {ref Cheung 2007}:104). Probably further related to Proto-Iranic *gart- 'to turn' in /cognate/8398/.
Mycenaean pa-si (= Attic φησί), derived from PIE *bʰeh₂- 'to speak, say' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1566-1567, {ref LIV²} 69-70, cf. {ref Aura Jorro 1993}:88).
According to {ref Deshayes 2003}:97, a loanword from regional Latin *batto-, in turn borrowed from Gaulish batta (cf. Fr. batte).

Comment: pǝrǝtu- means "passage" in Avestan, etymology follows Humbach (CLI, 1989: 195), derived from the verbal root PIE *per- "to transfer, come, bring across" (Cheung 2007: 294)

Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit jválati 'burns brightly' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:292,  no. 5306). Indo-European root assignment in this class follows {ref LIV²} 170-171, but cf. the reservations of {ref EWAia} I:607.
Of uncertain origin, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:747 no. 8975, {ref DCECH} 5:539-543 for further discussion.
Identical with Albanian madh 'big' < PIE *meg̑- in /cognate/360/.

Romance lexemes derived from Latin fascis 'bundle of rods; (symbol of) power' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:279), further to be connected with Celtic lexemes, cf. Old Irish basc 'necklace', Welsh beich 'burden', Breton bec'h 'load' < PCl. *baskio-, as a unique Italo-Celtic isogloss from *bʰaski-, probably a non-Indo-European loanword in origin (cf. {ref Schrijver 1991}:102-103, {ref de Vaan 2008}:203).
Probably to a Romance root *bot- of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} I:420-423).
A probable nursery word, but cf. {ref Tischler 1991}:393-394 for various alternative proposals.
Etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:757-758).

Comment: Wider connections uncertain

Justification: Loanword from Arabic صاف / ṣāf
Connections outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, cf. {ref EWAia} II:336, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:76-77.
A loan from Germanic *handjan- (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 16:139).
According to {ref EWNl}, an early loanword from Latin plūma 'feather'.

Apparently continuing a verbal root √mac- attested in various meanings by Sanskrit lexicographical works which may have further IE connections but ultimately uncertain (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:555 no. 9710, {ref KEWA} II:548).
Probably a Caucasian loanword, although the exact source language is difficult to ascertain (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:320).

Comment: Suggested by Cheung (2007: 244) *ham-kr̩nta- "to twist, braid together". Samadi (1986: 128) suggested a "Gegenbildung" to *wi-kana- "to destroy" (i.e. *ham-kana- "to repaire" ?) of the root *kan- "to dig".

Justification: Borrowing from Old Low Franconian sûr 'sour' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 17:288-289, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:698).
Root etymology in this class follows {ref LIV²} 79-80, cf. also {ref Seebold 1970}:106-107, {ref Kroonen 2013}:60 for further discussion.

Romance lexemes from Latin recentāre 'refresh; wash with water; clean' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:589-590), a derivative of Latin recēns 'of recent origin, new, fresh', further to PIE *ken- 'fresh, recent' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:516, cf. {ref LIV²} 351).
No certain etymology ({ref ALEW} 242).

Denominal formation based on Classical Armenian apowr 'salvation, deliverance; life'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:70, cf. {ref HAB} I:239-240). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010} or {ref Olsen 1999}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *apur-].
Ossetic lexemes of disputed further etymology, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:552, {ref Cheung 2007}:158, {ref LIV²} 223 for proposals and further discussion.
Loanword from Germanic *sunni-, cf. Old French songne 'worry, concern' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 17:272-282, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:667 no. 8089a).
Etymology outside of Germanic difficult (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:135, {ref Lehmann 1986}:115).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *dʰā́rā- 'cutting edge' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:389 no. 6793, {ref Strand 1998}, {ref EWAia} I:789).

A Germanic-Celtic isogloss with further connections uncertain (cf. {ref IEW} 1057, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:76, {ref Matasović 2009}:377, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:617-618, {ref Kroonen 2013}:537).
Loanword from Germanic *harpa 'curved instrument' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:341, {ref DCECH} I:344-345 for further discussion).
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *čai̯H- 'to sew', without certain etymology outside of Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:29).
Etymology uncertain, perhaps from Iranic *āyavana-, cf. Avestan ayaona- 'dwelling' with the meaning 'shadow' arising via *'shelter' (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:87).

Comment: Loan from Russian
cf. Old Indic namrá- "untertan, ergeben, demütig, unterwürfig", lit. "biegsam". This cognate set may rather mean 'soft'.

Justification: It is unclear whether the *-s- reconstructed is part of the root or s-stem morphology that has been transferred into thematic classes. Cf. {ref EWA 3}:142-145, {ref Kroonen 2013}:134 for further discussion.

Comment: Parallel loans from Persian or Iranic
cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 476

Justification: Forms from Proto-Germanic *ūtian-, secondarily derived to Proto-Germanic *ūd- 'out' ({ref de Vries 1977}:680), further to PIE *úd- 'upwards, up; out' (cf. {ref LIPP 2} 824).
Continuing Indic *giḍḍ- 'to fall' with metathesis > *ḍigg- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:222 no. 4157). Further etymology uncertain.
Derived from Ossetic ad | adæ 'taste', possibly further to PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat' but this proposal is quite speculative (cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:28).
Lexemes continuing Old Norse springa from Proto-Germanic *spring/kan- 'to break out, leap', ultimately from PIE *(s)préngʰ-e- ({ref LIV²} 583, {ref Kroonen 2013}:470, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:457-458).
West Caucasian loanword, cf. Kabardian tẖapä, Adyghe tẖap 'leaf' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:351).
Parallel loans from Persian بلند / buland 'long'.
Etymology outside of Germanic disputed, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:104-105, {ref Kroonen 2013}:136 for various proposals.
Loan from English serpent 'snake, serpent'.
Lexemes as though from Indic *muṭṭa- 'defective' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:587 no.10187.1).
Loan from Middle English smọ̄th(e) 'smooth'.
Etymology uncertain. First connected by {ref Bailey 1979}:383 to Vedic aváni- 'stream', but this proposal has been judged to be unclear by {ref EWAia} I:131.
Denominal verbs from Latin sāpō 'soap' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:628). Further etymology uncertain, probably a loanword from either Celtic or Germanic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:596).
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:793, {ref Kroonen 2013}:443 for various proposals).
Loan from Latin lūdere 'to play' ({ref Meyer 1891}:242-243, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:231-232).
A loanword from Hurrian ({ref Starke 1990}:220, {ref Melchert 1993a}:285, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:936).

Comment: possibly base of *kʷels-, but not well attested outside Iranian

Justification: Of uncertain origin, possibly a Dravidian loanword? Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}161, no. 3153.

Perhaps an extension to an original onomatopoeic base *mu- and connected to the more widely attested PIE *mus- in /cognate/5031/, but this proposed connection remains speculative. Cf. {ref Orel 2003}:278, {ref Kluge 2011}:637, {ref Kroonen 2013}:379-380.
Lexemes based on an Iranic root čak- ({ref Abaev 1959–1995}:I:387-388, cf. {ref Benzing 1983}:213).
Tocharian lexemes generally derived from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'to chew' ({ref LIV²} 168, {ref Malzahn 2010}:922-924, {ref Adams 2013}:691-692).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:159-161 for various proposals.
Etymology uncertain (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.; cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:280 for an earlier, unconvincing proposal).
To be connected with Hittite Hitt. šani- 'the same, one and the same', but further etymology outside of Anatolian unclear (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:722-723).
According to {ref EWNl}, to be connected with PIE *(s)teup-/*(s)teub- 'to hit, beat' (cf. {ref LIV²} 602-603 s.v. *(s)teu̯p-, without Germanic lexical material listed).
No certain etymology outside of Anatolian.
Of uncertain origin (cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Origin uncertain, perhaps a loanword from South Caucasian (cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:631).
Loan from Arabic جلد 'leather, skin'
As though from Sanskrit *ghum(m)ati, further root etymology unclear (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:243 no. 4485).
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:662-664, {ref Adams 2013}:317 for various proposals.
Possibly to be derived from PIE *dens- 'to become informed; skilled' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:853-855, cf. {ref LIV²} 118-119).

Likely to be connected to Old Lithuanian žieždrà 'Sand', but there are difficulties in reconciling the forms to a single Proto-Baltic reconstruction; no certain connections outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 1307-1308 for further discussion).

Comment: Further etymology uncertain. It is probably an expressive variant of PS *svig- (cf. Polish śmigać and dialectal świgać) which can be linked to PIE *su̯ei̯- 'bend, spin, wave'.

Justification: Derived from PIE *h₁nek̑- 'take, obtain' ({ref LIV²} 250-251, {ref Malzahn 2010}:538-539, {ref Adams 2013}:81-82).
Generally considered a nursery word (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:614).
Probably a loan from Turkic qabar, qapar- 'bulging, swelling' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:278).
Loanword from East Caucasian (cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:408-409).
Cf. Lith. võras 'old', further etymology uncertain ({ref Smoczyński 2007}:767, cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:1274).

Iranian root *sau̯H- 'to rub, wear, whet', either a u-stem derivative of Proto-Iranian *saH- (from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)-, cf. {ref EWAia} II:627), or a contamination of two semantically similar roots *dauH- and *skauH- (so {ref Cheung 2007}:340-341); cf. also {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:278, {ref MacKenzie 1990}:120.
Generally assumed to be a nursery word (cf. {ref Tischler 1991}:345-346).

As though continuing ā-lagna- 'fastened to', a derivative of Proto-Indo-Iranic *√lag- 'to stick, attach', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:61 no. 1356.2, {ref Strand 1998}, {ref EWAia} II:473).
Connections outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:147-148, {ref Malzahn 2010}:619-620, {ref Adams 2013}:238-239 for various proposals.
Parallel loans from Persian.
Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *ten- 'to stretch, span' ({ref ALEW} 1111, {ref Derksen 2015}:467-468, cf. {ref LIV²} 626-627).
From Latin longa (G. Cadorini, p.c.); for further cognates and the etymology cf. 'long' in /cognate/257/.

Comment: Etymology uncertain, perhaps from PIE *k̑elH- 'cold'.
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Lithuanian (cf. {ref ALEW} 1022).
Generally assumed to be a loan from (early) Middle Iranian, cf. {ref Tremblay 2005}:426, {ref Adams 2013}:657-658 for recent discussions and references to further literature.

Comment: orig. 'right, true'
Justification: Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. {ref ALEW} 1106-1108, {ref Derksen 2015}:465 for further discussion and various proposals.
Etymology uncertain.
No known etymology ({ref Adams 2013}:675).
Loan from Russian лытка 'leg, calf, shin, thigh, heel'.

Originally a denominal verb to Ancient Greek κτύπος 'loud noise, crashing sound', probably of onomatopoeic or expressive origin ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:592-593, {ref Beekes 2010}:792, {ref Babinotis 2010}:740).
From Proto-Germanic *knūϸan- ~ *knuttan- 'knot' and probably continuing a derivation of PIE *g̑enu- 'knee, nodule' ({ref de Vries 1977}:322-323, {ref Kroonen 2013}:298-299; cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:508).

Comment: Cognate with /cognate/8503/???

Justification: Derived from PIE *u̯elh₂- 'hit, strike' ({ref Malzahn 2010}:872-873}, {ref Adams 2013}:639; for the root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).

Etymology unclear ({ref Adams 2013}:483-484); {ref Malzahn & Peters 2010} suggest a relationship with Greek μάχομαι 'fight' < *megʰh₂-, but the meanings are divergent and the etymology of μάχομαι remains disputed (cf. 'fight' /cognate/4897/).
Probably a loanword from South Caucasian (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.)
Semantic identification not entirely clear ({ref Melchert 1993a}:9), therefore etymology also uncertain.
No certain etymology ({ref ALEW} 1285).
According to {ref Strand 1998}, to be connected with Old Indic *ṭakk- (1) 'remain, stop' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:300 no. 5420).
Loanword from Arabic قلب / qalb 'heart'.
No known etymology ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
Parallel loans from Persian سينه sīneh 'chest'.
No known extra-Tocharian connections ({ref Adams 2013}:64).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Smoczyński 2005}:205, {ref ALEW} 368, 521-522 for further discussion.
Loanword from English '(to) hit' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).
North Germanic lexemes continuing Old Norse ský 'cloud', further connections unclear (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:508).
Root etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:892-893 for further discussion.
Pace {ref Orel 1998}:359, because of the onomatopoeic nature of the lexemes in this meaning it is difficult to establish an etymology outside of Albanian with certainty.
Probable loanword, either from Turkic or West Caucasian ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:404).
Lexemes as though from Sanskrit dhūli-, Indic *dhūḍi- 'dust, powder' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:391 no. 6835), further etymology uncertain ({ref KEWA} II:110).
A Brythonic word of uncertain origin ({ref Deshayes 2003}:99, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).
From PGmc. *uber- 'over' + *geban- 'to give'. For the problems of the IE root reconstruction, cf. 'give' in /cognate/228/.
Germanic forms as though from PIE *u̯olH-u-, a derivative of PIE 2. *u̯elH- 'to roll' (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:393, {ref Kroonen 2013}:572; for the root reconstruction cf. {ref LIV²} 677).
Cf. s.v. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:310 no. 5524 *ḍagga- (2) 'defective'.
A loanword from Syriac mezzē 'crines parvi' ({ref Olsen 1999}:932). [MM: Proto-Armenian *maz-o-].

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √krand- 'to neigh (of a horse), roar (of clouds, wind, water); cry piteously, lament, weep' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:185), further etymology outside of Indic uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:408-409).

Possibly to be connected with Proto-Albanian *kakii̯ā̆- (cf. {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:239), but it is difficult to be fully certain of the etymology (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:619-620. Cf. further in /cognate/6597/.

Hellenic and Indo-Iranic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *meh₁- 'to measure' ({ref LIV²} 424-425, cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:852-853, {ref Beekes 2010}:939-940, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:199-201, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:596 no. 10329, {ref EWAia} II:341-343).
A loan from Old French ({ref Deshayes 2003}:639).
No certain etymology, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:61-62 for a survey of various proposals.
Loanword from Old French flor 'flower; choice, elite' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:243).
loan from Arabic اخسأ
As though from *cīssa- 'sharp pain' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:263 no. 4847). No further etymology.
Possibly to be connected with Vedic kurkurá- 'dog'? Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:164, no.3219. Otherwise uncertain.
As though from Sanskrit *khasati ʻfalls, slips' ({ref Turner 1962–1966} no. 3856), further etymology uncertain.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar- 'to consume, eat', further connections uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:147-150, cf. {ref LIV²} 609).
As though from Sanskrit *girati ʻdrips, falls' ({ref Turner 1962–1966} no. 4159). Further etymology uncertain.
Generally connected to PIE *gei̯bʰ- 'bend' ({ref IEW} 354, cf. Lat. gibber 'humpbacked', Lith. geibùs 'frail') after {ref Starke 1990}:504-509; etymology followed by {ref Melchert 1994}:254.

Comment: From older Iranian *miθra-, name of the sun god
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *mitrá- 'contract; god of contract', further etymology disputed (cf. {ref EWAia} II:354-355, {ref Encyclopædia Iranica} s.v. Mithra).
Loanword from French cacher 'to hide'.
Parallel loans from Persian ناف / nāf 'navel'.
Borrowing from Old French estanc 'pond', itself ultimately from Latin stagnum 'body of standing water, pond, pool, fen, etc.' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:689).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *per- 'to beat' ({ref Derksen 2008}:427-428, {ref Boryś 2005}:478-479, cf. {ref LIV²} 473).
No certain etymology outside of Albanian, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:45, {ref Demiraj 1997}:103, {ref Orel 1998}:27, {ref Holm 2011}:83 for various proposals and further discussion.

From Classical Armenian ertʿa- 'go'. The etymology in this class follows {ref LIV²} 590-592, {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:96, 104 to *per-steh₂-, but cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:263 who instead prefers a denominal formation from ertʿ 'going, journey' as though from a nominal stem *h₁r-sk-ti-, and in which case could be root-cognate with Greek ἔρχομαι 'come, go' in /cognate/5151/.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 645, no. 11083: s.v. Vedic lúpyate 'is lost, is removed' (TS), apalupyate 'perishes' (AV) "replaced in MIA. by *lukka- in P[rakrit] lukkaï intr. 'hides'"
Lat. crocus (ultimately a LW from Gk. κρόκος).
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin crocum 'saffron flower' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:216), a loanword from Ancient Greek κρόκος 'saffron flower, Crocus sativus' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:152).
Loanword from Latin or Romance floc(cus) ({ref Orel 1998}:100, {ref Holm 2011}:65).
Etymology outside of Indic uncertain, possibly to Old Norse hrista 'shake' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:413).
As though from Sanskrit *jañjāla- 'worry, affairs' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:280, no. 5085).
Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:301 no. 5441 s.v. *ṭaḍḍha 'distant'; further etymology uncertain.
Continuing a derivative of Sanskrit √gharṣ- 'to rub', further connections remain unclear ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:240 no. 4450, {ref EWAia} I:513-514)
Parallel loans from Sanskrit hr̥dayam 'heart'.
Derived from PIE *bʰelH- 'to sound' ({ref ALEW} 113-115, {ref Derksen 2015}:90, cf. {ref Smoczyński 2005}:54ff. {ref LIV²} 74).
Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit pallava- 'sprout, shoot, twig', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:450, {ref KEWA} II:235-236).
Parallel loans from Persian ناخن / nāxun 'nail', in some cases with sound substitution kh for x; Sanskrit nakha- 'nail' also may have had influence.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13264 s.v. saru- 'fine' lex.
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit saru- 'fine', only attested in lexicographical works ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:766 no. 13264). Further etymology unclear ({ref KEWA} III:445).

As though from Latin iūstus 'lawful, just', a derived adjective from Latin iūs 'law'. Further etymology disputed (cf. {ref NIL} 283n17, {ref de Vaan 2008}:316-317 for various proposals and further discussion).
Parallel loans from Persian آسمان / āsmān or Tajik осмон / osmon 'sky'.
Etymology uncertain. Loan from Greek θυμός?, Bulgarian dymъ?, Turkish duman? (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:117, {ref Orel 1998}:470-471, {ref Holm 2011}:81 for various proposals and further discussion).
Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing a PIE root noun *h₂ep- 'water, river' ({ref NIL} 311-317, {ref EWAia} I:81-82, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:19 no.407).

Romance lexemes from Latin galbinus 'yellow' {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:312, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 4:24-27). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a Celtic loanword (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:266, 291, 297 for further discussion).
Root cognacy outside of Slavic uncertain ({ref Derksen 2008}:494, cf. {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 4:183, {ref Boryś 2005}:77, 84 for various proposals.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kep- 'to chop, hit' (cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:594, {ref LIV²} 555).

Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek ἀέρας, a new α-stem morphologically remodelled from Ancient Greek ἀήρ, ἀέρος 'mist, haze, clouds, atmosphere', and ultimately derived from PIE *h₂eu̯s-er- ({ref Babinotis 2010}:70, {ref Beekes 2010}:27).

Often connected to PIE 1. *sekʷ- 'follow' under the assumption of a semantic development 'follow with the eyes'; cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:431-432; {ref LIV²} 525-526; {ref Seebold 1970}:387-388. Probably to be connected with Hitt. šākuu̯a- 'eye' in /cognate/3305/.
From Ancient Greek κράζω 'to croak, cry' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), further probably of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:575-576, {ref Beekes 2010}:767-768).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 409, no. 7136 s.v. nikaṭam vel sim. adv. 'near' R.

Justification: Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry (through heat)' ({ref Malzahn 2010}:533-535, {ref Adams 2013}:63, cf. {ref LIV²} 257-258).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *ātr-, *ātar-, a derivative of PIE *h₂eh₁- 'to be hot' ({ref ESIJa} 1:318-324, cf. {ref LIV²} 257).

Etymology uncertain. No connection to Lithuanian lãbas, etc., as suggested by {ref Hübschmann 1897}:451 is accepted by {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965} or {ref ALEW} (cf. /cognate/678/). {ref Clackson 1994}:181-182 likewise finds Hübschmann's proposed connection to Gk. λωΐων doubtful. Arm. law seems to be etymologically isolated.

Comment: Parallel loans from Sanskrit
Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit puruṣa- 'man, person'.
Parallel loans from Sanskrit párvata- 'mountain'.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 459, no. 8141 s.v. *pāhāḍa- 'rock, hill' and no. 8140; compare RV gen. du. pāṣyóḥ 'stone, rock'
Justification: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:460 no. 8141 'rock, hill'.
Probably a loanword from French ciel 'sky'.

Comment: The loan note "hard to tell if from Persian āftāb" probably refers to Kashmiri alone.

Justification: Armenian forms reflect a derived i-stem *h₂reu̯-i-, and are directly cognate with Vedic ravi- 'sun, sun-god' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:135-138, cf. {ref EWAia} II:440). NB: Classical Armenian aregakn is a nominal compound of arew 'sun' with akn 'eye' (cf. /cognate/211/).
Modern Indic lexemes as though from Middle Indic *jhilla- 'swamp, lake', cf. Prakrit jhillaï 'bathes', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:297 no. 5392).
Cf. Lith. vė̃zdas 'stick'. No certain etymology ({ref ALEW} 1228-1229), perhaps a loanword from Belarusian vjaz 'elm' according to {ref Smoczyński 2007}:745.

Etymology uncertain. {ref Orel 1998}:100 connects to PIE *lek- (of uncertain reconstruction in {ref LIV²} 411 s.v. ?*lek- 'die Gliedmaßen bewegen'(?)). {ref Meyer 1891}:108 assumed a loan from Italian foglietta 'leaf'; cf. {ref Orel 1998}:100 for a summary of various other proposals.
