Cf. SMG χώνω, from Ancient Greek χώννυμι 'heap up, raise, fill with earth' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1619), further to PIE *g̑ʰeu̯- 'to pour' (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1654, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1281, cf. {ref LIV²} 179).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 1324, s.v. āruddha- 'blocked', ppp. of ā́ruṇaddhi RV, rudh- 'grow'
construction with t̪ʰɑːʋon < stāpháyati, cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13756, initial part presumably non-Aryan, cf. ibid. no. 4937f.?

cf. Sanskrit kṣvelati 'leaps, jumps, plays' and keli- f. 'play, sport, fun', -d- may stem from blend with Sanskrit krīḍa-, cf. Maryhofer EWAia I, p. 413, Turner 1962-66, no. 3918 s.v. *kheḍ- vel sim: "if krī́ḍati is IE., it has crossed with these"

Justification: Etymology outside of Indic uncertain. Perhaps associated Nūristāni forms (e.g. Kati parši 'mountain' might allow a preform *parṣ- which in turn could be connected to PIE *pel(e)s- in Gk. πέλλα· λίθος (Hesych.), OHG felis, NHG Fels, etc., but this remains uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:125-126; cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:459, no. 8138).

Cf. SMG χλιός 'warm', χλιαίνω 'to make warm' ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:569, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1601), probably further to an IE root *g̑ʰlei̯- 'gleaming, clear' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1637-1638), but cf. the reservations of {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1263 on the comparative semantics.
Etymology uncertain. Probable parallel loans from Dravidian (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:166 no. 3243, {ref KEWA} I:359, {ref Burrow 1948}:377).

As though continuing Sanskrit alupta- 'not cut off, undiminished' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:32 no. 719), derived from Vedic √lop- 'to break, damage, destroy' and further to PIE *reu̯p- 'to break, tear (apart)' ({ref EWAia} II:482, {ref LIV²} 510-511).

Comment: Parallel loans from Sanskrit
Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit nā́bhiḥ 'navel'.
Middle and Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *(ava-)kaḍḍh- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:133 no. 2660, 822 no. 14245), further etymology uncertain.

Comment: < Sanskrit lambate (MhB), Vedic rámbate, PIE *lemb(H)-, cf. LIV, p. 411
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √ramb- ~ √lamb- 'hang down, dangle', {ref Turner 1962–1966}:636 no. 10954), further to PIE *lembH- 'to hang slack' ({ref EWAia} II:436-437, {ref LIV²} 411).
Parallel loans from Persian بارش / bārish 'rain, precipitation'.

Comment: < 'fine, minute, thin, small' according to Turner 1962-66, no. 13548 s.v. *sūṅkṣa-
cogn. with 'suck' in /lexeme/25941/, ultimately related to 'eat' /lexeme/19955/ and probably 'breast' /lexeme/18670/

Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit kāleyaka- 'a particular part of the intestines; liver' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:158 no. 3103). Further etymology uncertain. [Not in {ref KEWA}, {ref EWAia}].
No convincing etymology outside of Greek ({ref Beekes 2010}:551), but {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:438, {ref Beekes 2010}:551 for older proposals to Germanic lexemes.
Further etymology outside of Balto-Slavic uncertain, cf. {ref ESSJa} 15:143-144, 147-148, {ref Derksen 2008}:279-280 for further discussion.
Without secure correspondences elsewhere in Celtic or other Indo-European languages; perhaps a non-Indo-European substratum borrowing ({ref Lucht 2007}:331-332).

Of uncertain origin, possibly an Iranian loanword ({ref Olsen 1999}:965, cf. {ref HAB} IV:82). {ref Martirosyan 2010}:552 considers the proposed etymology to PIE *bʰendʰ- 'to bind, fasten', but this requires the assumption of Grassmann's Law in Armenian, for which there are no other parallel examples.

Comment: Loan from Germanic.
Justification: Romance lexemes loaned into Late Latin from Germanic *blanka- 'colourless(?)' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 15/1:138-146, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:100; cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:67).

Comment: cf. ākhu-kirí- (MS), Turner 1962-66, no. 3175; thus < PIE *kerH- (3.) "austreuen, schütten" (LIV, p. 353)

Justification: Parallel loans from German (cf. {ref Polański 1962-1994} 243-244, {ref Rejzek 2001}:272).
Indic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁reh₁- 'be calm' ({ref EWAia} II:443-444, 447; cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:619, no. 10702).
Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Late Vedic lāṅgūla- 'tail' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:639 no. 11009), further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:477-478, {ref KEWA} III:98).

From Latin astrātum 'starred' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:59), a derivative of Latin aster 'star' < PIE *h₂ster- 'star', cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:585, {ref NIL} 348-354, and 'star' in /cognate/131/ for further etymological discussion.
Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯olk̑-o- ({ref Derksen 2008}:526-527, {ref EWAia} II:526-627; for Pashto cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:94).
Loan from Sanskrit vr̥ṣṭi-.
Loan from Persian رود / rūd 'river, stream, flood'.
Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of a stem *khaḍa- *'erect'(?), further etymology unclear ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:198 no. 3784, cf. {ref EWAia} I:443).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8588 s.v. prátirati and prátarati and no. 5821 tiráte, for Bengali cf. ibid. no. 12888 - different derivations
? cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4883

Justification: A denominal verb from Ancient Greek παῖς (gen. παιδός) 'child', cf. /cognate/1462/ for further discussion.
Probably to be derived from PIE *gʷʰen- 'beat' ({ref Starke 1990}:313-316, {ref Melchert 1993a}:269).

Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian počʿ 'tail'. Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref HAB} IV:98, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:641 for various proposals). [MM: Proto-Armenian *potʃʰ-o-]
Probably to be derived from Vedic √ray- 'flow' ({ref EWAia}:459); for the root reconstruction. cf. {ref LIV²} 305–306.
Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *ḍhākka- 'back, waist' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:316, no. 5582). No further etymology.
Baltic lexemes generally derived from PIE *u̯elg- 'to become damp' ({ref ALEW} 1178-1179, 1242-1243; {ref Derksen 2015}:486, cf. {ref LIV²} 676).
Loanword from Turkish çayır 'meadow, grass' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

An Indo-Iranic and Albanian lexical isogloss from PIE *dʰei̯H- 'to envisage, contemplate' ({ref LIV²} 141-142, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:969; cf. {ref EWAia} I:777-778 without discussion of proposed Albanian cognates).

Comment: PLEASE REVISE ENTRY! cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13253

Justification: From Ancient Greek ἐξευπορῶ 'to supply, deliver' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:246), further to PIE *perh₃- 'to provide, make available' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1222, {ref LIV²} 474-475).

No accepted etymology outside of Germanic; cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:292, for the suggestion that Proto-Germanic *saiwi- is a probable non-IE, pre-Gmc. loanword. {ref Kroonen 2013}:423, 435-436 accepts an etymology from IE *sei̯kʷ- without referring to other hypotheses.

Comment: ultimately *kʷetu̯or-, *kʷ(e)tu̯r̥-, *kʷ(e)tur-

Justification: Loan from French sucré 'sweet'.
As though continuing Indic *laṭṭa- 'hanging, tangled', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:633 no. 10918).

Comment: Not listed in Morgenstierne 2003.

Justification: Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Root etymology possibly to PIE *h₃ekʷ- as in Ancient Greek ὄσσε 'eyes' (dual), but the stem formation is very unclear ({ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:452-453, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:811-813}, {ref Beekes 2010}:1133-1134). Cf. note by Scarborough in cognate set citations for further justification and discussion.

{ref Adams 2013}:714 connects the root of the Tocharian forms to Proto-Germanic *swellan- 'swell' (cf. /cognate/315/), but this etymological connection remains uncertain (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:489-490, {ref Kroonen 2013}:499).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5545 and 11004

Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek ὀψάριον 'little side-dish', a diminutive formation to Ancient Greek ὄψον 'cooked or prepared food', but esp. at Athens 'fish' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1624), further from an o-grade derivative *h₁op-s to *h₁ep- 'on, upon' with the sense of being a supplementary dish eaten on top of grain or bread ({ref Beekes 2010}:1139-1140).

No certain etymology ({ref Olsen 1999}:940, cf. {ref HAB} I:77-78, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:5-7). Cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:6-7 for further discussion and a tentative proposal to PIE *p(e)h₂u̯- 'small'. [MM: Proto-Armenian *(h)ag-ii̯a-].

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 6419: "poss. all NIA. forms, and cert. those of Dard. with l-, are < Ir., Av. duma- [...]. But. besides Kal., some derivatives [...] suggest possibility of orig. IA. form" - Hindi and Urdu may have Persianized forms of an originally inherited form; not a simple loan event - for the sequence *Cumbʱa- compare Vedic kumbhá- m. 'pot' and Av. xumba-
presumably ideophonic nursery word
extracted from compounds in catur- via 'square', thus 'squared', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4534 and 4595ff.
tentative, cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8996
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9933

Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Old Indic *bura- 'defective' ({ref Turner 1962–1966} 526 no. 9289). No further etymology.

Compared by {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:183-184 to the root of Avestan saef- / sif- 'carry out a sliding, sweeping movement', no certain etymology outside of Iranic, sometimes compared to Vedic śíphā- (name of a river) but the connection remains uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:327-328, {ref EWAia} II:637).
Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit ṭaṅka- ~ ṭaṅga- 'leg', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:301 no. 5428, {ref KEWA} I:456).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8377; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

Justification: Generally considered to be cognate with the Balto-Slavic word for 'head' (cf. Lith. galvà, etc.). The Balto-Slavic lexemes can be transparently derived from a reconstructable PIE *golH-u̯eh₂-, but many details of the Armenian form remain unclear (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:43, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:220). Cf. further discussion regarding the Balto-Slavic lexemes in /cognate/1142/. Classes indexed at proposed-cognacy level 5/6: large majority view.
Root ref. form follows {ref LIV²} 386-388.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no 9962
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8393
MBh.,cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7788

Justification: Loan from Late Latin putris (putridus) 'rotten, putrid' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).
Of obscure etymology ({ref Olsen 1999}:168-169; cf. {ref HAB} II:445). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsan-u-(r)]
Loanword from Middle Low German slichts ({ref Karulis 1992} II:227).
No certain etymology outside of English ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Parallel loans from Persian میوه / mīwah 'fruit'.
From Latin costa 'rib, side' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:211, {ref DCECH} II:278-279), further etymology obscure (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:146, {ref de Vaan 2008}:140)
Modern Indic lexemes derived from Sanskrit √ḍhauk- 'approach, bring near'; of uncertain etymology, probably a loanword ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:318 no. 5610, {ref KEWA} I:465).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4782
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit cikkaṇa- 'smooth, slippery' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:259 no. 4782). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword from Dravidian (cf. {ref KEWA} I:385).
Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Cech. kog, Tush. kok, Ing. kog, etc. ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:619).
Loan from Latin frūctus 'fruit' ({ref Orel 1998}:103).
The Breton verb chasseal was productively formed within Breton to chass 'dogs', a loanword from Old French chace 'hunt' (n.) ({ref Deshayes 2003}:153).
Etymology uncertain; perhaps originally 'to carry on the back', cf. Skt. vr̥kká- 'kidney' ({ref Turner 1931}:460, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:527, no. 9311).
Hellenic lexemes as nominal derivatives PIE *dʰegʷʰ-r-h₂ from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1475-1476, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1112; cf. {ref LIV²} 133-134).

Comment: via 'strong' from 'overpower, have power over', cf. LIV, p. 515; Turner 1962-66, no. 13298ff.

Justification: Loan from Turkish bed, ultimately from Persian bad 'bad' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 1:39).
Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *gʰr̥dʰ-ó- ~ *gʰordʰ-ó- 'enclosure' ({ref EWAia} I:495, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:239, no. 4428; {ref Kroonen 2013}:169, cf. {ref LIV²} 197).

Derivatives of Ossetic myg | mugæ 'sperm', according to {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:137-138 to be further connected to Latin mūcus 'snot, mucus', Ancient Greek μύξα 'mucus, discharge from nose' to PIE *meu̯k- 'to untie, remove (smth.)' (cf. {ref LIV²} 443-444) as a Scythian-European isogloss.

Uncertain, perhaps to in some way to Sanskrit madhurá- 'sweet' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:562 no. 9793)? If so, then to be connected with PIE *médʰu- 'sweet drink, honey' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:302-303).

Indo-Iranic and Balto-Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *h₂seu̯s- 'to become dry' ({ref EWAia} II:648-649, 658, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:724, 727 no. 12548, 12508; {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:250-251, {ref ALEW} 892-893, {ref Derksen 2015}:390, {ref Derksen 2008}:473-474, cf. {ref LIV²} 285).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7955 s.v. Vedic pálāyate ʻfleesʼ (TS); cf. Vedic párā + i (áyate?), cf. Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 233

Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit piccha- 'tail-feather' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:460 no. 8151), further etymology unclear ({ref KEWA} II:270-271; cf. also 'tail' in /cognate/1260/ ???).

Comment: Common Brythonic loan from Latin fructus /cognate/227/
Justification: Borrowing into Brythonic from Latin frūctus ({ref Deshayes 2003}:258, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} s.v. ffrwyth).

Comment: سبز with sound substitution uj for z
Justification: Parallel loans from Persian سبز / sæbz.

Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian hast 'firm, steady, tough; thick, dense', generally connected with Germanic lexemes for 'hard, steady, strong, dense' (OIc. fastr, OHG festi, fasti) from PIE *past- ({ref Olsen 1999}:201, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}390-391, but preferring the hypothesis of an old European loanword in PIE on the basis of medial *-a-).

Comment: Vedic mr̥dú- 'soft' (VS), 'weak' (AV), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10292

perhaps comparable to Sanskrit lokottara- (loka- + uttara-) adj. 'surpassing the world, extraordinary', Pali lokuttara-; Prakrit loguttara-, later also 'uncommon', 'sublime', cf. Sinhalese lovuturu, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 648, no. 11126
< Skrt. ŚOCYATE 'is purified' (Turner 1931: 622), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12621; LIV, p. 331

Justification: There is no certain etymology outside of Slavic. All the existing hypotheses (linking it to PIE *kes-, PIE *i̯eh₃s- and PIE *h₂ek̑-, cf. {ref LIV²}: 261, 311, 357) are unconvincing formally and/or semantically (cf. {ref ESSJa} 32:9-10, {ref Rejzek 2001}:421-422, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:178).
Germanic forms identical to Old Latin tongēre 'to know' < *ton⁽g̑⁾-éi̯e- (cf. {ref LIV²} 629, {ref IEW} 1088, {ref Kroonen 2013}:533-534, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:353).

Root ref. form tentatively follows the reconstruction of {ref Adams 2013}:241 to a putative PIE *klemH- (not in {ref LIV²} or {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}), rejecting alternative proposals to PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lean' as formally improbable; cf. {ref Adams 2013} s.v. TochB klänts- and {ref Malzahn 2010}:624-625 for further discussion.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5979 s.v. toláyati ʻlifts, weights, considersʼ (MBh.), √tul-

Justification: Traditionally derived from PIE *pro-u̯o-, remodelled in PGmc. as *frau̯i̯a- 'the one in front, lord' (cf. {ref NIL} 645, {ref Kluge 2011}:314). Doubted by {ref Kroonen 2013}:153) on account of phonological difficulties.

Perhaps continuing an original causative formation *dou̯h₂-éi̯e- to PIE *deu̯h₂- 'to join, fit together' but the details remain unclear (cf. {ref LIV²} 123, {ref Lehmann 1986}:342, {ref Kroonen 2013}:511). Cf. also Runic (Gallehus Horn) 1.sg.pret. tawido 'I made'.

Comment: cf. lápati (AV) 'chatters, talks'; via 'whisper', 'talk secretly, make secrets'

Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes derived from Sanskrit √dar-¹ 'to tear, split' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966} 353-354, no. 6186, 6190), ultimately from PIE *der- 'tear (intr.), split' ({ref EWAia} I:701-703, {ref LIV²} 119-120).
Parallel loans into Modern Indic from Persian برف / barf 'snow' (cf. /cognate/126/).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *staba- 'staff; letter'. Further connections not fully uncertain, possibly with Lithuanian stãbas 'post', Old Irish sab 'shaft, pole' < *stabʰ-o- or *stobʰ-o-? (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:471, {ref ALEW} 967).
Indo-Iranic lexemes of onomatopoeic origin, imitative of suckling, cf. Skt. cuci- 'female breast' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:264, no. 4855; cf. {ref KEWA} I:394-395).
Anatolian and Indic lexemes from PIE *u̯eh₁-r-, *uh₁-r- 'water' ({ref NIL} 715-717, {ref EWAia} II:544-545).

Romance lexemes from Latin impingere 'to push, strike, drive at' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:358), further to PIE *pei̯g- 'to paint', probably a variant of the better attested root *pei̯k̑- 'carve out, cut out' ({ref LIV²} 464, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:465-466).

Etymology outside of Germanic unclear ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:517-518, {ref Kroonen 2013}:456}). A connection has been proposed with Lat. malus 'bad', OCS malъ 'small', and Gk. μῆλον 'small cattle, sheep, goat' since {ref Solmsen 1904}:17-18, but the semantics and morphological structure are unclear.

Comment: Loan from Old High German

Justification: Loanword from Turkish kuyruk 'tail' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-}:82).
No clear correspondences outside of Germanic, cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:517-518, {ref Kroonen 2013}:456.
No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. {ref ESSJa} 5:154-156, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 1:552, {ref Rejzek 2001}:149, {ref Boryś 2005}:132).
Loanword from Waigali yū̆z, yoz 'cold' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:601 no. 10396).
Loan from Arabic فاكهة / fākiha 'fruit' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:352).

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing a denominal formation from Ancient Greek σκότος 'darkness, dark' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1287). For further discussion and justification of the root ref. form, cf. 'shadow' in /cognate/8269/.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'to beat, strike, slay', possibly from a root ?*slak- 'to hit, beat' only otherwise attested Celtic, cf. Middle Irish slacc 'sword' ({ref Seebold 1970}:425-427, {ref Lehmann 1986}:314, {ref Kroonen 2013}:452, {ref LIV²} 564).

Comment: cf. Persian نزدیک næzdi:k - via Urdu? - outside Urdu with sound substitution j for zd

Justification: Goidelic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *rēdi- 'simple, easy', further derived from PIE *(H)rei̯dʰ- 'to shake, wobble' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:16-17, {ref Matasović 2009}:306-307, cf. {ref LIV²} 502).

Comment: parallel Persian loans, with sound substitutions j for z in Magahi, Marathi, Nepali

cf. Henning "Sogdica" (1940: 51): "Here, ʾʾywz is clearly "pond, fish-pond", or "lake" ("river", as the obvious etymology might suggest, is perhaps less likely)." Could this word be related to Sogdian ʾwzy "lake"? The Parthian reading may then be 'āywaz' or similar.

Justification: Cf. Standard German holen 'to fetch, get'. Etymology outside of Germanic unclear ({ref EWA 4}:774-777).
Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑u̯eh₁- 'to swell up' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:728 no. 12565, 12568, {ref EWAia} II:623-624, {ref Cheung 2007}:341, cf. {ref LIV²} 339-340).

Comment: cf. Vedic (ŚB) chardáyati 'vomits', etc.; root related to PIE *k̑er-H- 'to defecate'

Justification: Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:241-242, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:114 no. 2420); for Khotanese cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:492.
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:96 for various proposals.

Comment: Morgenstierne (1974: 72) only notes suγδ for Sarikoli, which could be a dialectal variant of sleʁ with metathesis and δ/l alternation.

Justification: The basis of this Ossetic lexeme may go back to a root *men- (cf. {ref IEW} 728-729) if {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:122 and {ref EWAia} III:386 are correct in connecting the lexeme to the basis of Sanskrit manāk 'a little, slightly, in a small degree', but there are many unclear details of this etymology.
Armenian and Nuristani lexemes derived from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'to sharpen' ({ref Olsen 1999}:55, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:720 no. 12438, {ref EWAia} II:627, cf. {ref LIV²} 319-320).

Of unknown origin. Traditionally connected with Germanic *buddǭ 'bud, seed-pod' but the comparison is uncertain (cf. {ref HAB} IV:112-113, {ref Olsen 1999}:937, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:552-556 for further discussion). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pi/utuł-o-].

Hellenic and Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑elh₃- 'green, yellow' ({ref Derksen 2008}:542, {ref Polański 1962-1994}:1067-1068, {ref ALEW} 1296, 1325-1327, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1263-1264, {ref Beekes 2010}:1638).
Parallel loans from Persian هموار / hamwār 'smooth, flat, level'

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ({ref NIL} 526-540), cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1227-1228, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:534-535, {ref EWAia} II:77-78, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:438 no. 7747, {ref Kroonen 2013}:152, {ref de Vaan 2008}:462, {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, {ref LIV²} 458).
Latin rotundus 'round' and its Romance continuants, derived from Latin rota 'wheel' and ultimately further to PIE *ret- 'run' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:611, {ref de Vaan 2008}:527, {ref NIL} 575-580).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hwassa- 'sharp', further connections outside of Germanic uncertain ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:315-316, {ref Kroonen 2013}:264, 266, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:284-285).

No generally accepted etymology (cf. {ref HAB} IV:385-386, {ref Olsen 1999}:442, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:724 for various proposals; not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tar-i̯a-].

Comment: nursery word for 'mother', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9198
variant of kūdak < *kau̯tá-?
blends of word of different origins, cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4111 s.v. *gāṭṭa- ʻneck, throatʼ and no. 4459 s.v. ghāṭā- f. ʻnape of neckʼ (Suśr.), no. 4124; cf. Vedic gā́tram

Justification: No certain etymology (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:418-419, {ref de Vaan 2008}:393 for further discussion, rejecting formerly proposed connections to Latin mollis 'soft'); for the Romance forms cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:472.
No etymology given in Morgenstierne (1974:48); onomatopoeic according to {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:227.
Slavic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰerH- 'to work with a sharp tool' ({ref LIV²} 80, cf. {ref ESSJa} 2:203-204, 2:213-214, {ref Derksen 2008}:57-58, {ref Kroonen 2013}:53).
Its Slavic and further IE cognacy is not entirely certain.
Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑enu- 'jaw' ({ref Lucht 2007}:280, {ref Matasović 2009}:158).

Comment: could this word be related to the verb var „zusammenhalten, einschließen, umhüllen, bedecken“? cf. EWAia II 512 , cf. Sanskrit vará- and derivations like varimán, várivas, all ≈ “Raum, Gebiet”

Justification: Continuing Latin vallis 'valley' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:762 no. 9134), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:712, {ref de Vaan 2008}:652).
Generally agreed to be derived from PIE *seu̯h₁-, but some debate remains over the precise details of the verbal stem formation (cf. {ref LIV²} 538-539, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:797-798).
Etymology disputed, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:226, 494, 511-512; {ref Holm 2011}:50-51 for further discussion.
Of imitative/onomatopoeic origin, cf. {ref HED H}:7-8, HW² Ḫ. Unlikely to be etymologically related to the comparanda given by {ref Weeks 1985}:223 for phonological reasons.
Armenian, Indic, Baltic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *sen- 'old' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:, {ref EWAia} II:695, {ref ALEW} 901-902, {ref Derksen 2015}:393, {ref Matasović 2009}:330).
No certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 512-513 for further discussion).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ({ref LIV²} 572-573, {ref EWAia} II:769-770, {ref Cheung 2007}:348-349). For Punjabi, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:796, no. 13791.
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *skel- 'bend, curve' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1013, {ref Beekes 2010}:1346).
Loan from Persian خوب / xūb 'good'.
From Latin cōlāre 'to percolate, sieve' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:193), a denominal verb to Latin cōlum 'sieve, wine filter', no further certain etymology ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:193).
Greek θηρεύω is a secondary formation to an old IE root noun *g̑ʰu̯eh₁r- 'wild animal' (> AGk. θήρ) ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:435-436, {ref Beekes 2010}:547).
Etymology unknown. Derivation from Lat. suburgere or superurgere? From a verb in some German language related to Old High German sweran? (G. Cadorini, p.c.)
Generally derived to IE *u̯er- 'observe, perceive' ({ref LIV²} 3. *u̯er-, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:886-888, {ref Adams 2013}:647-648).

Modern Greek lexemes directly continuing or continuing secondary derivatives of Ancient Greek χόρτος 'enclosure, court', from PIE *gʰor-to- 'fence, enclosure' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1606-1607, {ref Beekes 2010}:1644-1645).
Loan from Latin sonus 'a noise, sound' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:677).
Parallel loans from Persian.

Comment: The Lari form may contain an inchoative suffix. Not noted in Cheung (2007).

Justification: Loan from English 'fight'.
From Latin *plattare, a derivative of Latin plattus 'flat, level', in turn a loan from Greek πλατύς ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:547)
Derived from Sanskrit valāhaka- m. 'rain-cloud, thunder-cloud', further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:665, no. 11411, {ref KEWA} III:162-163).
Loanword from Arabic.
Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. {ref ALEW} 455-456, {ref Derksen 2015}:228, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:278.
Loanword from Arabic, cf. Standard Arabic  رقبة / raqaba 'neck'.

North Germanic lexemes continuing Old Norse slangi, a loan from Middle Low German slange 'snake' ({ref de Vries 1977}:513).  But if the source is as late as Middle Low German, then the Icelandic and Danish lineages should be considered by then already divergent, and therefore this is a parallel loan.
Armenian lexemes continuing PIE *h₂r-nu-, derived to PIE *h₂er- 'to take, acquire' ({ref LIV²} 270-271, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:112-113).

Friulian cjoli, from Latin tollere (G. Cadorini, p.c., cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:727), further a nasal-infix present stem formed to PIE *telh₂- 'raise up' in origin ({ref de Vaan 2008}:621-622, {ref LIV²} 622-623).

Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic /cognate/8267/, Baltic /cognate/8266/, Slavic /cognate/8265/, and Indic(-Nuristani) /cognate/7396/ have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.
From Latin boreās 'north wind; north' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:107), an old loanword from Greek βορέας 'north wind; north' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:73-74).
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} II:120-121).

Cappadocian ανανούμαι 'think' from Ancient Greek ἀνανοέω 'call to mind' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:101-102), which is turn a denominal verb from Ancient Greek νόος 'mind, sense, intellect'. Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:756-757, {ref Beekes 2010}:1023).

Comment: Probable loanword from local Arabic 'powder'.

Justification: No satisfactory etymology.

Comment: from Sanskrit raṭati 'howls, shouts', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 1301 s.v. āraṭa- n. ʻcrying outʼ (Pāṇ.), 2. āraṭi- f. ʻnoiseʼ (Kathās.), √raṭ-
Justification: From Sanskrit √raṭ- 'to howl, shout' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:59 no. 1301, 1302); no certain further etymology, probably onomatopoeic (cf. {ref KEWA} III:36).
As though from Proto-Slavic *životŭkŭ 'small stomach', the diminutive of *životŭ 'stomach' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:1054-1055), cf. 'belly' in /cognate/2238/ for further etymological discussion.

Armenian lexemes generally connected to the family of Greek θάλλω 'to bloom, flourish, grow' ({ref Clackson 1994}:118-120, {ref Olsen 1999}:51, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:231-232, 237-238). The PIE root reconstruction *dʰalh₁- for this class follows {ref LIV²} 132.
Unknown etymology ({ref Olsen 1999}:964, {ref HAB} III:142-143). [MM: Proto-Armenian *dzax-o-/-u-].
Loanword from Latin veterem 'old' (acc.sg.) ({ref Meyer 1891}:476, {ref Huld 1984}:131, {ref Orel 1998}:512).
Derived from the inherited word for 'nose'. For further etymological discussion, cf. /cognate/267/.

The root has an onomatopoeic origin and and its reflexes show various instances of an irregular phonological development. No certain further IE cognates (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:122-123, 129-135; {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 6:161, {ref Boryś 2005}:57).
A borrowing from English savour ({ref Broaderick 1984b}:422-423).
Loanword from Iranic (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:21-22, {ref Boryś 2005}:57).
Loanword from German, possibly via Polish ({ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 1: 317-318).

Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn around, roll' ({ref LIV²} 691-692, {ref EWAia} II:518-519, {ref ALEW} 1197-1198, {ref Derksen 2008}:529, 539, {ref Derksen 2015}:492, {ref de Vaan 2008}:666-667).
Baltic lexemes derived to PIE 2. *keh₂u̯- 'to beat, split' (cf. {ref ALEW} 470-471, 517; {ref Derksen 2015}:234, 254, {ref LIV²} 345-346).
Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯d- 'to let go, release' ({ref ALEW} 567, 577-578; {ref LIV²} 402-403).

Comment: Parallel loans from Persian

Justification: Loanword from Arabic قرن / qarn 'horn'.
Possibly an Arabic loanword.
Etymology uncertain, maybe a loan from local Arabic.

Pace {ref Katz 1998} who argues for a compound 'eel-snake' consisting of elements *illui̯- (cf. Proto-Germanic *ǣla- 'eel') and *anka- 'snake' (Latin anguis, Greek ὄφις), Hittite illui̯anka- is generally considered a Hattic loanword ({ref HED A+E/I}:358-359, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:384).
Loan from Slovenian modrak (G. Cadorini, p.c.)

Comment: Cheung (2007: 379) assumes prefix *abi-. Horn (1893: 1, 9) suggested a compound of āb + tāb with āb „Glanz“.

Justification: Loan from local Arabic, cf. Arabic wād 'dry riverbed'.
Loan from Kâta-vari: Ktivi gulʹava
Romance lexemes derived from Latin pēnsāre 'to weigh' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:526), further to be connected to PIE 2. *spend- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:457, cf. {ref LIV²} 578).

Comment: probably loans from New Persian (Tajik: garon)

Justification: Possibly a variant to the more widely attested root *terh₁- 'bore, rub' ({ref LIV²} 632), cf. {ref LIV²} 647 s.v. ?*treh₁-, {ref Kroonen 2013}:546, {ref Seebold 1970}:519.
Ossetic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *g̑ar- 'to sound, call' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:288-289, {ref LIV²} 161, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:470).

Cf. Sanskrit gāḍha- 'dived into; pressed together, thick, firm' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:220 no. 4118), derived from Vedic √gāh- 'to dive into, bathe in, plunge into; penetrate, enter deeply into' and ultimately to PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eg̑ʰ- 'to go into water, wade into' ({ref EWAia} I:486, {ref LIV²} 183).
Loan from English cloud.
Loan from Arabic ركبة / rakba 'knee'.

Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit bhagín- 'prosperous, happy' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:531, no. 9348), further derived from Vedic √bhag- 'to apportion' from PIE *bʰag- ({ref EWAia} II:239-240; cf. {ref LIV²} 65).

Comment: "From a pre-Indoeuropean root meaning "to cut", attested in Romanian and Bulgarian too." (–G. Cadorini)

Justification: Probably to be connected with lexemes for 'belly' in /cognate/854/ ({ref Adams 2013}:651).
No certain etymology outside of Tocharian. Cf. {ref Adams 2013}:778 for some proposed Balto-Slavic comparanda, but no etymology given by {ref Malzahn 2010}. Not in {ref LIV²}.

Comment: for Ossetic *frā-xai̯za-

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indic ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:132, no. 2641; {ref EWAia} I:290).

For the purposes of establishing a root-ref. form, we tentatively follow {ref Cheung 2007}:15-16 in distinguishing two separate Proto-Iranian roots, although the semantic shift *'to perceive, notice' > 'smell' is not entirely inconceivable and the lexemes could very well belong to PIE *bʰeu̯dʰ- ({ref LIV²} 83-84, {ref IEW} 150-2).
Classical Armenian am 'year' seems to continue an old deverbative stem *sem-(e)h₂- ({ref Olsen 1999}:60, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:45-46; cf. {ref EWAia} II:704).
Loanword from Middle High German bom, boum 'tree' ({ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:51
Etymology outside of Slavic uncertain, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:507-508 for further discussion.
According to {ref Adams 2013}:318 to be derived from PIE *dʰeu̯H- 'move quickly back and forth' via a semantic development 'make arise (a cloud of dust)' > 'covered in dust', 'yellow'.
Loan from Modern Greek κόκκαλο(ν) 'bone' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 2:530-532)
According to {ref Adams 2013}:617, probably to be connected with Ancient Greek ὀλίγος 'few, small', Albanian lig 'bad, evil; thin' etc. as a derivative from PIE *h₃lei̯g̑-.
Armenian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂er- 'to fix, fit together' ({ref LIV²} 269-270, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:112).
Presumably a loanword from Arabic.
Origin unknown (cf. {ref HAB} III:202). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010} or {OIsen 1999}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʃei̯r(-)ana-].
Etymology uncertain, possibly an Arabic loanword.
Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:592). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:470, {ref Beekes 2010}:600-601 for various proposals.
No certain etymology ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:147, {ref de Vaan 2008}:141).

Denominal to Classical Armenian vax 'fear, dread; steep place, precipice'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref HAB} IV:294-295; not in {ref Olsen 1999} or {ref Martirosyan 2010}). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯ax-].
Romance lexemes as though from Latin *tīrāre, of uncertain origin (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:725, {ref DCECH} V:505-508 for further discussion).

Negative compound as though from Sanskrit na- 'not' + rāma- 'good, pleasant', cf. RV su-rā́ma- ({ref Turner 1931}:536, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:615, no. 10636). Further to Skt. √ram- from PIE *h₁rem- 'become calm' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:435-436).
Possibly from an IE formation *h₁ēd-so- *'flesh (for eating' > 'skin' according to {ref Adams 2013}:549, but this proposal remains uncertain.
Loanword from Iranic ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:189-190, {ref HAB} 3:198). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʃerm(-)aka-].

Comment: 'stab'>'kill'.
Justification: Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *kelh₂- 'to hit, break', cf. OCS klati, 1.sg. koljǫ 'to stab' ({ref ESSJa} 10:154-156, {ref Derksen 2008}:230, {ref LIV²} 350).

Comment: presumably from 'to clump together', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4177, 4182, 4271

Justification: Continuing Proto-Iranic *čak/g 'to strike, hit', probably of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Cheung 2007}:31-32).
The root etymology in this cognate set follows {ref LIV²} 154 to PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'to haul, to pull', cf. also {ref Kroonen 2013}:99, {ref Lehmann 1986}:93-94, {ref Seebold 1970}:160-162.
No certain etymology (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:362-363, {ref HAB} II:587 for further discussion).
Of onomatopoeic origin ({ref ESSJa} 8:146-147).
Loanword from Arabic (dial.) salj (cf. Standard Arabic ثلج / thalj 'snow').
Loanword from Luvian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:980).
Loanword from Turkish göl 'lake' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} I:306).
Loan from Turkish çomak 'club'.
Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin aptāre ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:46, {ref DCECH} I:389-390), further to PIE *h₁ep- 'grasp, seize' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:47, {ref LIV²} 237-238).
Of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} I:357).

Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑u̯eit- 'to shine brightly' {ref EWAia} II:679-680, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:316-317, {ref Kroonen 2013}:267, cf. {ref LIV²} 340). The Germanic forms irregularly reflect final *-t-, but this is generally explained by a secondary gemination *-tn- > -tt- or secondary influence from Gmc. *swart- (< IE *su̯ord-o-, cf. /cognate/188/), cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:980.
Loanword from Middle Low German gel, gele 'yellow' ({ref Polański 1962-1994} II:149).
IE root etymology unclear, cf. {ref LIV²} 92-93, 219-220; {ref Kroonen 2013}:77-78; {ref Seebold 1970}:137-138, {ref EWA 2}:290-292, 342-345.
Loan from Middle Iranian, cf. Pahlavi spētak, Parthian spytk' ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:240, {ref HAB} IV:264-265, {ref Olsen 1999}:907). [MM: Proto-Armenian *spei̯t-aka-].
Loanword from Persian پست past 'low, inferior, small' (cf. {ref HAB} IV:77 {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:636).
Etymology outside of Italic uncertain, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:83-84, {ref de Vaan 2008}:80-81 for various hypotheses.
Usually explained as a blend of PIE *k̑erh₁- 'grow' with *sper- 'strew' (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:504, {ref Clackson 2017}:112).
Loan from Kâta-vari: Ktivi büm 'earth'.

Goidelic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach' ({ref LIV² 282-284, cf. {ref Pedersen 1913}:557, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:151, {ref Schumacher 2004}:200-204, {ref Matasović 2009}:36-37).
Loanword from Latin cantāre 'sing' ({ref Meyer 1891}:187, {ref Huld 1984}:80, {ref Orel 1998}:178)
Etymology uncertain but generally connected to PIE *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'to kindle' ({ref LIV²} 259) despite phonological difficulties, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:11; {ref Orel 2003}:7; {ref de Vries 1977}:99-100.
Generally considered to be of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-}:235-237).
From Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike, thresh' + preverb *pati-; further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:141-143).
Loan from Latin directum 'straight, not curved' ({ref Huld 1984}:55, {ref Orel 1998}:73).
Armenian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ({ref NIL} 706-715, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:205, {ref Derksen 2008}:523).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. OCS лѣвъ 'left', Macedonian лев 'id.', etc.
Latvian and Latgalian forms derived from Latvian siẽva 'wife' and further connected to PIE *k̑ei̯-u̯o- 'socially close' (cf. {ref ALEW} 1016-1017, {ref Villaneuva Svensson 2011}:32).
Generally connected with Lithuanian šùlas 'post, pole, stave' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:767, {ref Beekes 2010}:1037-1038; cf. {ref ALEW} 1053-1054) from PIE *ksúlo- 'block of wood'.
From Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:592). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:470, {ref Beekes 2010}:600-601 for various proposals.

Comment: Parallel loans from Old Indic

Justification: Root etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:407-408 for two possibilities to either *bʰleg- 'shine' or *bʰel- 'speak, yell; bark' of which {ref Malzahn 2010}:721 prefers the former etymology.

Comment: A general shape of the root as *(s)keu̯H- seems probable. Only Beekes assumes *(s)keHu-. However, alternative explanations of the Greek forms are presented by ALEW and EWA.The root might be identified with  *(s)keu̯h₂- 'stochern, ritzen' (LIV² p. 561) or for the time being accepted as *(s)keu̯H- 'to cover' without laryngeal identification (cf. IEW 951ff.).

Justification: Caucasian loanword, cf. e.g. Mingrelian č̣anǯi 'fly' ({ref HAB} III:184-185, cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:939). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʃantʃ-i-].
Armenian and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *med- 'to measure' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:470-471, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:48-49, cf. {ref LIV²} 423).
Loanword from Italian cantare ({ref Snoj 1997-2016}).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *hu̯anH- 'to call', further to PIE *su̯enh₂- 'to sound' ({ref Cheung 2007}:144-145, {ref LIV²} 611).
Loanword from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian лови, Serbo-Croatian loviti 'to hunt'.
Parallel loans from Sanskrit bī́ja- 'seed'.

From συκώτιον, the diminutive of Ancient Greek σῦκον. The meaning 'liver' was taken on as a transferred epithet from the phrase ἥπαρ συκωτόν 'liver (of an animal) fed on figs' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1354). Further etymology obscure, probably a prehistoric loanword ({ref Beekes 2010}:1421). For a parallel semantic development in Romance cf. /cognate/905/ from Lat. fīcus 'fig'.

Comment: sporadic Slavic ?*kob(-)ě/it-
Justification: Polish kobieta is a Polish-only innovation (originally the word was abusive). It has no certain etymology despite of many attempts to explain it ({ref Boryś 2005}:241). It is often linked to kobyla 'mare'. {ref ESSJa} links the lexeme to *kob- 'divination, fate', so the original meaning could be 'witch'. However, all etymologies are highly speculative.
Hellenic and Armenian lexemes generally derived from PIE *h₂enh₁- 'to breathe' ({ref NIL} 307-311, {ref Beekes 2010}:101-102, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:416, {ref Olsen 1999}:27, cf. {ref LIV²} 267-268).
Loanword from Middle High German spilen ({ref Snoj 1997-2016}).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic ({ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Rejzek 2001}:587, cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:696).

From Ancient Greek σύρω, remodelled as a -νω present in Modern Greek varieties ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1259); probably further derived from PIE *tu̯er- 'sweep' although the details of the stem formation remain debated (cf. {ref Vine 1999a}:570-571, {ref Beekes 2010}:1424-1425).

Romance lexemes from Latin rotella 'little wheel' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:610, {ref DCECH} V:85-86), a diminutive formation to Latin rota 'wheel' and further to PIE *ret- 'run' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:527, cf. {ref LIV²} 507).

Comment: Khwarazmian with prefix upa-
Loan from Iranian.
Justification: A loan from Iranic ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:99-100, {ref Olsen 1999}:864). [MM: Proto-Armenian *anoi̯ʃ-i-].
Loan from Turkish kötü 'bad'.
Loanword from French respirer ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived to a Proto-Balto-Slavic verbal root *renk- 'to gather'; no certain further etymology outside of Balto-Slavic ({ref Derksen 2008}:439-440, {ref Derksen 2015}:376, {ref ALEW} 842-843, 867-868, cf. {ref LIV²} 506). For proposed connections in the older literature, cf. {ref IEW} 1155.

Lithuanian júoktis 'to laugh' is derived from juõkas 'laugh, laughter'; probably a German loanword (cf. Prussian jōk 'joke') according to {ref Derksen 2015}:214; cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007} who considers there to be no good etymology.

Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit ākāśá- 'sky' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:45 no. 1008), to be further connected with Vedic √kāś- 'to be visible, appear' and further to PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of' ({ref EWAia} I:344-345, {ref LIV²} 383-385).
According to {ref Adams 2013}:548, to be derived from PIE 2.*u̯el- 'spin, roll' ({ref LIV²} 675).
No plausible etymology ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:101).
No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:500). For Modern Indic forms, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:657, no. 11258.

Comment: Loan from Sanskrit, cf. Vedic nā́raka-/nāraká-, Pali naraka-

Justification: A loan from Middle English batte, in turn borrowed from Old French batte ({ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:31)

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10187; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Goidelic ({ref Lucht 2007}:241).
No certain etymology outside of Goidelic ({ref Lucht 2007}:241).

Comment: original meaning "snake"

Justification: For the root ref. form, cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:578 assuming an unextended root form, probably to be connected with IE *(s)k̑ʰei̯d- ({ref LIV²} 547-548); cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:37-38, {ref Schumacher 2004}:578-579, {ref Matasović 2009}:343 for further discussion.
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic difficult, possibly further derived from PIE *pr̥-sth₂-o/i- ({ref Catt 2014}; cf. also {ref EWAia} II:100-101, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:474).
No generally accepted etymology (cf. {ref ALEW} 744-745).
First attested in Middle English, further origins obscure, cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)} for further discussion.
Loan from Kâta-vari
Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic múkha- 'mouth, face'. No secure etymology outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} II:360, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:585 no. 10158).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *Hi̯eu̯dʰ- 'to set in motion' ({ref EWAia} II:418-419, {ref Cheung 2007}:176-177, {ref LIV²} 225-226).

Comment: root cī- 'to attempt, fight', no further etymology

Justification: Lexemes continuing a derivative of Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'air', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Lehmann 1986}:237, {ref EWA 5}:1488-1491, {ref Kluge 2011}:586, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:328, 342).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bhan- 'to speak' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:534 no. 9383), further IE root etymology disputed, cf. {ref EWAia} II:244, {ref LIV²} 69-70 for further discussion.

In all likelihood an old loanword into Iberian Romance from the medieval forerunner of modern Basque eskerr, although it cannot be ruled out that the current Basque lexeme has not been influenced by the Romance forms (cf. {ref DCECH} III:469-472 for further discussion).
Of uncertain etymology, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:920-921 and {ref Adams 2013}:687-688 for discussion of various proposals.
No certain etymology, cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:471-472, {ref HAB} II:62-64, {ref Clackson 2017}:110 for further discussion. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *(e)rkin-i-].

Portuguese from Latin ad noctem 'at night' ({ref Williams 1962}:84-85, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:491), from PIE *nekʷt- 'night', a t-stem derivative to PIE *negʷ- 'become dark' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:416-417, {ref NIL} 504-513).

Comment: from Vedic varṣám n. 1. ʻrain ʼ (RV+), pl. ʻthe Rainsʼ (AV), 2. ʻyear' (ŚB) (root vr̥ṣ-), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 446, no. 1139: Pali vassa- m. n. ʻrainʼ, pl. ʻthe Rainsʼ, Prakrit vāsa- m. (or < vārṣa-), varisa- m. n. - NB. New Indo-Aryan forms are Sanskritisms - ultimately cognate with 'rain' in /cognate/1612/
loaned into Armenian as քարշ kʿarš, cf. /cognate/627/
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *kʷels- 'to draw a furrow' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:319-320, {ref LIV²} 388-389).
No known etymology outside of Celtic ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:32, {ref Matasović 2009}:309).
Loanword from Turkish but 'thigh, rump' (cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:899).
Loanword from Iranic, cf. Avestan pūiti- 'rottenness', Middle Persian pwtk' 'foul, rotten' ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:256, {ref Olsen 1999}:913). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰut-o-].

Hellenic lexemes to be derived from the same root as Ancient Greek φθείρω 'to ruin, destroy' < *dʰgʷʰer-i̯e/o- 'flow away, disappear' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1198, {ref Beekes 2010}:1569). The onset cluster ψ- found in some Modern Greek dialects has probably come about via contamination with Modern Greek ψύλλα 'flea' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1626).
Apparently a loan from Tungusic according to {ref HAB} II:437. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsa(-)tsuk-a-].

Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic ślakṣná- 'slippery, smooth, soft' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:738), further to PIE *slegh₂snó- ({ref EWAia} II:673), probably to be abstracted to a more basic root *(s)legh₂- (cf. Ancient Greek λαγαρός 'slack, loose').

Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'to limp' via a secondary nominalisation of Proto-Germanic *skanka- 'crooked' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:446, {ref Orel 2003}:334, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:485, {ref Kluge 2011}:800). For the root, cf. {ref LIV²} 555).
From PIE *seh₁dʰ-i̯o-, a derivative of PIE *seh₁dʰ- 'to reach the goal, be successful' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:99-100, {ref Olsen 1999}:186, cf. {ref EWAia} II:722-723, {ref LIV²} 517).
From Indic *ṭōkk- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:304, no. 5476. No further etymology.
Tocharian and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *deu̯k- 'to pull' ({ref LIV²} 124, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:982, {ref Seebold 1970}:503-505, {ref Lehmann 1986}:346, {ref Kroonen 2013}:515, 525).
From Vedic kapā́la- 'skull, cranium' ({ref Turner 1931}:79, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:137 no. 2744), further etymology disputed (cf. {ref EWAia} I:300).
Loan from Persian cf. /cognate/1831/

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Sanskrit phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:511 no. 9092-9093). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps originally a past passive participle *phal-na- to Sanskrit √phal- 'to burst, split' with an irregular labial vowel -u- (cf. {ref KEWA} II:398).

Often assumed to be a loanword from an unattested Lat. adj. excurtus (similarly cf. OHG kurz, kurt, etc. < non-prefixed Lat. curtus in /cognate/292/), alternatively inherited from Proto-Germanic *skurta- to Proto-Germanic *skertan- 'cut off' and perhaps further to be connected to PIE *skerd⁽ʰ⁾- and comparable to Lith. skérdėti, OIr. sceirtid (cf. {ref LIV²} 558 s.v. ?*skerdʰ- 'schneiden, stechen' (?), {ref Orel 2003}:346, {ref Kroonen 2013}:444.
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *orbiti 'do, work', a derivative of *orbъ 'servant, slave' and ultimately derived from PIE *h₃erbʰ- ({ref ESSJa} 32:116-118, {ref Derksen 2008}:373).

The Brythonic words in the meaning 'snow' in this set are sometimes compared to Old Irish arg 'drop' and connected to a root *sperg- or *spreg-, but this lexeme is only marginally attested. A better etymology for the Brythonic words would be a connection with the IE root *h₂erg̑̑- 'white, bright, shining' via Proto-Celtic *argi̯o- ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:88, {ref Matasović 2009}:41-42). Because of the uncertainties over the proposed Old Irish cognates, this latter etymology has been followed in this class, but note that it is not mentioned s.v. *h₂erg̑- in {ref NIL}.
Probably a loanword from Brythonic, cf. Welsh cwyn 'complaint' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:18-19), but cf. the discussion of {ref Le Mair 2011}:177.

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek σύρω, remodelled as a -νω present in Modern Greek varieties ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1259); probably further derived from PIE *tu̯er- 'sweep' although the details of the stem formation remain debated (cf. {ref Vine 1999a}:570-571, {ref Beekes 2010}:1424-1425).

Comment: cf. Middle Persian kamar "waist, belt, girdle"; Horn (1893:193) relates this word to Av. kamarā- "belt".

Justification: Loanword from Turkish göğüs 'chest'.
Anatolian lexemes from PIE *deh₃- 'to give' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:803-805, {ref LIV²} 105-106).
Lexemes from Proto-Tocharian *m⁽’⁾æy-, further IE root etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:777-778 for further discussion.

Hellenic lexemes, originally from a derived adjective in *-nā to Ancient Greek σέλας 'light, brightness', i.e. Proto-Greek *selásnā- (cf. Lesbian σέλαννα 'moon'). Further etymology obscure ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:955, {ref Beekes 2010}:1318-1319).
Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Chechen kujg 'hand' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:644).
Loanword into Middle English from Old French montaigne ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Etymology disputed: either to Ancient Greek. ῥίς 'nose' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:480, cf. /cognate/2356/) or Ancient Greek. θίς 'heap, dune' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).
Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *ter- 'to speak' ({ref ALEW} 1076-1078, {ref LIV²} 630-631

Eastern Romance lexemes from Latin *pullius 'young animal' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:565 no. 6826), further to PIE *putslo- ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:544, {ref de Vaan 2008}:502-505; cf. Ved. putrá- < *put-lo-).

Etymology for these lexemes follows that of {ref Weiss 1994}:143-145 and {ref de Vaan 2008}:639-640 to *u̯eh₁- over the older proposed etymology to *u̯egʷ- (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:745-746). Romanian ud 'wet' < Lat. ūdus may belong to this class but could also belong to PIE *u̯egʷ- in /cognate/5276/, cf. discussion in /cognate/8427/.
Romance lexemes from Latin inflāre 'blow into, inflate, swell' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:362), further to PIE *bʰleh₁- 'blow' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:226-227, {ref LIV²} 87).

Comment: Unknown etymology.
Justification: Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian krem 'to bear, to carry'. Further etymology uncertain. [MM: Proto-Armenian *ki/ur-].
From Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:284). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:470, {ref Beekes 2010}:600-601 for various proposals.
Derived from Latin complēre 'to fill, complete' (cf. {ref DCECH} II:290), further to PIE *pleh₁- 'be filled, become full' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:472-473, {ref LIV²} 482-483).
A loan from Old French jalne ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 4:26).

Comment: Loan from Latin
Justification: Loan from Latin caelum 'sky' ({ref Meyer 1891}:225-226, {ref Huld 1984}:107, {ref Orel 1998}:360).

Romance lexemes from Latin levāre 'to lift up, raise' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:405-406, cf. {ref DCECH} III:636-638), a derivative of Latin levis 'light in weight' and further to PIE *h₁legʰ-u- 'light (in weight)' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:336).

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes generally considered to be cognate, although the precise reconstruction debated; some taboo distortion is likely to have occurred in some branches ({ref Sihler 1995}:163, {ref Katz 1998}; cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1134-1135, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1535, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:153, {ref EWAia} I:157, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:44 no. 994, {ref ALEW} 40-41, {ref Derksen 2015}:55, {ref Derksen 2008}:388, {ref de Vaan 2008}:42).
More precise origins uncertain, but possibly a loanword from Greek (cf. {ref Orel 1998}:257 and discussion in /cognate/6209/).
Certain comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic are lacking ({ref ALEW} 933, cf. {ref LIV²} 562). Identical to 'fly_V' in /cognate/2273/.
Root reference form follows {ref LIV²} 386-388 to a causative-iterative stem *kʷolh₁-éi̯e- derived to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, to turn'.
Possibly derived from a putative PIE *stemH- 'to push', cf. {ref ALEW} 983-984, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:611 for further discussion.
Etymology outside of Celtic obscure, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:253, {ref Lucht 2007}:329-330, {ref Matasović 2009}:227-228 for further discussion.
A derivative of Tocharian tsäm- 'to grow', in turn derived from PIE *demh₂- 'to build' (cf. ref Adams 2013}:804, {ref Malzahn 2010}:984-987).
Root etymology uncertain, perhaps to Proto-Iranic *bauǰ- 'to release, free, open; save, deliver' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:18-19, {ref Samadi 1986}:43).
A secondary semantic development from Modern Greek νερό 'water'. For further etymological discussion, cf. 'water' in /cognate/1563/.
Goidelic lexemes continuing PIE *stei̯gʰ- 'to rise, stride' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:57-60, {ref Matasović 2009}:376, {ref LIV²} 593-594).
Cf. Skt. caṭaka- ~ *caṭikā- 'sparrow', Prakrit caḍaa ~ ciḍiga ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:248 no.4571. Of uncertain origin, possibly onomatopoeic ({ref KEWA} I:368).
Loanword from either Latin sphaera or Norman French spere ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:177)
Uncertain etymology (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). See further discussion below.
Of obscure origin, first attested in Middle English ME culle(n), kulle(n), kille(n), kylle, etc. ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Loanword from Turkish meyve 'fruit', in turn a loanword from Persian mive 'fruit' (cf. {ref Dawkins 1916}:623).

Armenian, Indo-Iranic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' ({ref LIV²} 334-335, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:313-315, {ref EWAia} II:666-667 {ref Turner 1962–1966}:730 no.12598, {ref Cheung 2007}:356-357, {ref Matasović 2009}:208). The parallel verbal root *k̑leu̯s- 'listen to' is a secondary verbal root abstracted from a desiderative formation from *k̑leu̯- 'hear' already in the protolanguage (cf. {ref LIV²} 336).

Comment: Preserved -d- in Modern Indic presupposes parallel loans from Sanskrit nadīḥ, cf. /cognate/808/.
Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit nadī- 'river'

Indic lexemes continuing Vedic ramyà- 'to be enjoyed, beautiful' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:616 no. 10636), further derived from PIE *h₁rem- 'to be calm' ({ref EWAia} II:435-436, cf. {ref LIV²} 252-253).

Romance lexemes from Latin levāre 'to lift up, raise' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:405-406), a derivative of Latin levis 'light in weight' and further to PIE *h₁legʰ-u- 'light (in weight)' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:336).
Loan from Low German (cf. {ref Karulis 1992} II:258).
Etymology unclear, cf. {ref Karulis 1992} I:266-268 for further discussion.

Romance lexemes from Latin portāre 'carry' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:554), further probably a denominal verb to Proto-Italic *porto/ā- 'a passage, crossing' and to PIE 1. *per- 'come through, cross' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:482-483, cf. {ref LIV²} 472-473).
Of uncertain origin (cf. {ref HAB} IV:546-547 for various proposals; not in {ref Martirosyan 2010} or {ref Olsen 1999}). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kʰam-ii̯o-].

Generally compared to Lat. torqueō from a causative-iterative stem *torkʷ-éi̯e/o- 'twist' ({ref Aura Jorro 1993}:366-367); whether this is to be identical with Ancient Greek τρέπω, τροπέω (cf. /cognate/5106/) is less certain (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1132-1133, {ref Beekes 2010}:1503-1504).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3245

Justification: Loan from Latin pallaca (Late Latin *placca) 'concubine; girl' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:582).

Derived from Old Breton mauu 'young man, servant' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:498), further connected to Old Irish mug 'boy, servant' and generally compared to lexemes from Proto-Germanic *magu- 'boy, relative' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:70-71, {ref Matasović 2009}:274). Further etymology uncertain; the lexemes may well have been substratum borrowings in the Western Indo-European languages (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:240, {ref Kroonen 2013}:347 for discussion of the Germanic comparanda).
Etymological connections outside of Germanic unclear (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:976, {ref Kroonen 2013}:584).
A derivative of PIE *klep- 'to (secretly) steal, hide' ({ref Smoczyński 2005}:33-34, cf. {ref ALEW} 940-941, {ref LIV²} 363-364).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic skandhá- 'shoulder, upper part of back', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:786 no. 13627, {ref EWAia} II:750).
Loanword from Turkish yuvarlak 'round'.

Cf. Old Lithuanian regė́ti 'to see', further etymology uncertain. {ref LIV²} 498 considers a possible derivation on the basis of an essive formation ?*r̥gʰ-h₁é-, but this is not fully certain (cf. {ref ALEW} 855-856 for further discussion).
No clear etymology outside of Balto-Slavic; probably further connected to Lithuanian píepala 'quail (coturnix coturnix)'. Cf. discussion in {ref ALEW} 766.

Comment: Loans in Kurdish would be old, viz. before *rd/rz > ł in Kurdish vs. l in Persian.

Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *gaHz- 'to run, start', probably further to PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eg̑ʰ- 'to enter (water), wade' ({ref Cheung 2007}:96, {ref LIV²} 183, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:111).

Comment: parallel Sanskritisms, cf. vicāra- m. 'pondering' (MBh.), Prakrit viāra- m. 'thought'

Justification: Loanword from Old Russian думать 'to think' ({ref Karulis 1992} I:223).

Denominal from Armenian xorh 'thought', probably an Iranian borrowing but there is no certain etymology (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:624, {ref HAB} II:409). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *xorh-].
As to the semantic development (relative) pronoun 'how, what kind' > 'strong, hard') cf. Latin 'qualitas' (cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} I:218).

Comment: jugded Sanskrit loan (NARI) by Turner (1931: 341), Buck gives "fem. der. fr. NAR- 'man'" (Buck 1949: 83)

Justification: Originally a root-noun in the sense *'visible, outer form' > '(outer) body; skin' (cf. Hittite tu̯ekka- 'body, person') from PIE *tu̯ek- 'be visible' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:684, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:346 no.6087, {ref LIV²} 654).

Baltic lexemes as through from PIE *greng̑ʰ- 'to turn' ({ref ALEW} 360-361, {ref LIV²} 191; cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:305-306). The reconstructed root is restricted in attestation to Germanic and Baltic.

Comment: loan from Persian, because old *t would appear as t.
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13358 s.v. Vedic sāráyati

Justification: Root assignment to PIE *kʷer- (cf. {ref LIV²} 391-392, {ref IEW} 641-2). Alternatively, the IIr. cognates assigned to this root might be with *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' (cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).
Loan from Turkish kanat 'wing'.

Comment: cf. Urdu /lexeme/26095/; bāl-forms via *barza-/bazra- ? Note the similarity of bāl-forms with the well-attested Hamito-Semitic *bal- root "wing, feather" (Orel/Stolbova 1995: 52) with a short vowel.

Justification: No known etymology outside of Goidelic ({ref Lucht 2007}:254).
Loan from Kâta-vati kk′ař.
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian дише, Bulgarian дишам 'breathe'.
Parallel loans from Persian ماهى / māhī 'fish'.

Comment: cf. Persian سفت seft
Justification: Parallel loans into Indic from Persian.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:450, {ref Kroonen 2013}:415 for various proposals.

Romance lexemes continuing Latin in-tendere 'to stretch out, stretch forth, extend' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:366 no. 4483, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 4:740-746). The IE root is either *ten- 'to stretch, extend' or *tend- 'to wear down', cf. {ref LIV²} 626-628, {ref de Vaan 2008}:612 for further discussion.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *mūlan- 'muzzle', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Kroonen 2013}:374, not in {ref Boutkan & Siebinga 2005}).
Loanword from early Scandinavian, cf. Old Icelandic rót 'root' ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:98 for various proposals.
Linked by Horn (1893: 160) to the Sanskrit verb śak- "to be able", cf. also śakti- "power" etc.

Generally further connected with Classical Armenian lerk 'hairless, bald' and sometimes compared with Old Irish lerg 'surface, level' (cf. {ref Pedersen 1909}:105), but this proposed etymology is quite uncertain ({ref Olsen 1999}:965, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:244). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}, cf. {ref HAB} III:555-556.

For the provisional root ref. form, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:114-115, but this IE root reconstruction is uncertain; it is possible that we are dealing with a contamination of two separate roots (cf. {ref LIV²} 199, 358-359 s.v. ?*gʷʰeu̯g̑ʰ- 'verbergen' and *keu̯dʰ- 'verbergen').

Etymology outside of Italic uncertain, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:380, {ref de Vaan 2008}:360 for a survey of proposed extra-Italic cognates. For the Romance lexemes cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:429.

Iberian Romance lexemes, probably to be derived from Latin rāpum 'turnip' ({ref DCECH} IV:744). Further etymology uncertain, possibly an early non-Indo-European loanword (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:514, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:564, {ref ALEW} 875 for further discussion).

Comment: Proto-Albanian loan (cf. Std. zgavër  'cavity, cave', also indicated by inflection) from Vulgar Latin *skavare (cf. Ital.scavare)

Justification: Loanword from Turkish göl 'lake'.
Indo-Iranic lexemes to be connected with the same root found in Vedic úru- 'wide' ({ref EWAia} I:226-227), cf. 'wide' in /cognate/3090/ regarding the root reconstruction *h₁u̯erH-.

Possibly cognate with Hittite peššii̯e/a- 'throw', but the connection is disputed; cf. /cognate/8675/ for further discussion and references. Otherwise only Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:144-145, {ref LIV²} 242-243).

Comment: could be derived from *fra-dmās- with fra- > ha-, assimilation fo dm > dn and subsequent loss of d

Justification: Loanword from Turkish puslu 'misty, hazy'.

Comment: Loan from Middle High German
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4344
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Sanskrit guḍa- (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:224 no. 4182, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:233 no. 4344). Further etymology uncertain, possibly an Austroasiatic loanword (cf. {ref KEWA} I:338).
Either a direct borrowing from Iranic or a secondary denominal verb from a borrowed substantive vaz 'leap, jump' (cf. {ref Hübschmann 1897}:242, {ref Olsen 1999}:908). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯az-].

Comment: Baltic goes back to *met-
Justification: IE root identification uncertain, cf. {ref ALEW} 641-643, {ref Derksen 2015}:307, 314 for further discussion.

The Classical Armenian present harkane- : aorist har(e)- go back to a suppletive pair in Proto-Armenian. The present stem may be derived from *h₃erg-, cf. Hitt. ḫark- 'perish', ḫarnik- 'destroy' ({ref LIV² 301, cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:215-216 for further discussion). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *kn̥-i̯o-, a derivative of PIE *ken- 'new, fresh' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:609, {ref Beekes 2010}:616). As a verbal root, cf. {ref LIV²} 351.

Comment: Gharib suggests *yaunikā- for Sogdian

Justification: Without clear correspondences outside of Greek ({ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:236-237, {ref Beekes 2010}:951-952).

Without clear etymology outside of Italic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:703). Cf. {ref Hill 2003}:128 for a recent attempt to connect with Germanic, but also the critical appraisal of {ref de Vaan 2008}:630).
Semantic identification not fully certain, therefore etymology also uncertain (cf. {ref Melchert 1993a}:173).
Parallel loans from Turkish toz 'dust'.

Comment: 'un-seasonable'Strand 1998; g < #VkV
Justification: Etymology uncertain, either an early loan from early Indic akāla- 'wrong time, unseasonable' or directly continuing Indic *ud-ghāra- 'pouring out' ({ref Strand 1998, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:1 no. 11, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:92 no.1977).
A loanword into Brythonic from Latin tostus 'grilled, burned', cf. Welsh tost 'severe, harsh, hard' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:732).
Loanword from Italian lago 'lake'.
According to {ref Adams 2013}:731-732 to be derived from PIE *smer-(u̯)o- 'fat, grease'.
Romance loanword, cf. Standard Italian coda 'queue, tail'.
Root reconstruction difficult. A contamination between two (possibly related) roots *teu̯h₂- and *teu̯k- is a possibility. Cf. 'fat' in /cognate/6104/ for further discussion.
Of unknown origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:944, cf. {ref HAB} IV:280). [MM: Proto-Armenian *stu(-)u̯er-a-].

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5607 s.v. *ḍhōṭṭa-

Justification: Rom. ud is from Lat. ūdus 'wet, moist' (cf. {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002} s.v. ud). The IE root etymology remains unclear. The traditional etymology of Lat. ūdus is to PIE *u̯egʷ- 'make damp (so {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:745-746, with references to earlier literature, tentatively also {ref de Vaan 2008}:648; cf. {ref LIV²} 662-663, {ref IEW} 1118), but {ref Weiss 1994}:141-143 makes a convincing case that a derivation to PIE *u̯eh₁- (cf. {ref NIL} 715-717 s.v. *u̯eh₁-r-. *uh₁-r- 'Wasser'; {ref IEW} 80f., {ref EIEC} 636) may also be a strong possibility. The prevailing majority opinion seems to judge the connection to *u̯egʷ- for Lat. ūdus to be more likely than *u̯eh₁- (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:639-640 s.v. ūmeō and notes to /cognate/1578/), albeit still uncertain.

Comment: Loan from early Scandinavian

Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'air', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Lehmann 1986}:237, {ref EWA 5}:1488-1491, {ref Kluge 2011}:586, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:328, 342).
Lexemes from Proto-Slavic *porxъ 'dust' and Proto-Slavic *pьrxъ 'dust' from PIE *pr̥s-o- (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:413, 428).

Etymology uncertain. Perhaps an expressive variant of Old Irish eitte 'feather', or a derivative of the verb cel- 'hide, cover' and subsequently contaminated with OIr. eitte ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:116).
Loanword from Kâta-vari.

Comment: Loanword from Sanskrit punḍra- via Kâta-vari.

Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √har- 'to carry, bring' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:808 no. 13980). No certain etymology outside of Indic ({ref EWAia} II:803-804), {ref LIV²} mechanically ?2.*g̑ʰer- 'to take, get'.
According to {ref Adams 2013}:706-707, a fossilised feminine accusative singular of the gerund śwālle ‘suitable for eating’ from śu- 'eat' from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H-eh₂-.
Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑rei̯H- 'to excel, be excellent' ({ref Bailey 1979}:400-401, {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:98, {ref EWAia} II:665-666, II:669-670, cf. {ref LIV²} 337).
Continuing Old English tacan, an early borrowing from Scandinavian, cf. Old Icelandic taka 'to grasp, seize', etc. ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Compared by {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:12 with Sanskrit ā-khid- 'seize', if so from Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰād- ~ *kʰid- which may formally reflect PIE ?*k⁽ʷ⁾eh₂d- 'to tear, squeeze', although further cognates outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain (cf. {ref LIV²} 344). [Not in {ref Cheung 2007}].
Root reconstruction follows {ref LIV²} 557-558, {ref Kroonen 2013}:440-441. Possibly an extended form of the root *(s)ker- 'to cut', cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:487.

North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse skógr; no certain etymology outside of Germanic. Traditionally derived from a root *(s)kek- / *skeg- 'springen; lebhafte Bewegung' ({ref IEW} 922-923, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:497). Not in {ref Orel 2003}, {ref Kroonen 2013}.

Comment: the Arabic noun is used as a verbal stem in some languages

Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit jāṅgala- 'jungle, wild forest'.
No certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 1328-1330, {ref Derksen 2015}:522).
Loan from Kâta-vari: Ktivi ḍag′ara.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13036 s.v. Sanskrit saṃsāra- m. 'undergoing transmigration', 'secular life, the world', from sar-

Justification: Nuristani lexemes for 'woman', continuing compounds containing the word for 'daughter' (cf. Kâmviri ǰʹü 'daughter'), continuing PIE *dʰugh₂ter- 'daughter' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:370 no. 6481, {ref EWAia} I:737-738).
Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Sanskrit kakkhaṭa- 'hard, solid' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:128, no. 2587). No further etymology.
This class encodes Proto-Indo-Iranic *kárna- 'ear'. The Khowar and Kalaṣa-alâ lexemes represent light verb constructions. Cf. 'ear' in /cognate/768/ for further etymological discussion/
Etymology unclear; {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:114 suggests some bird names, e.g. Persian šīšū, šīšak 'a kind of partridge' as potential cognates (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian корен 'root'.
Etymology difficult, {ref Meyer 1891}:153-154, {ref Orel 1998}:152, {ref Holm 2011}:73, {ref Hyllested 2012}:73-81 for various proposals and further discussion.
Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰeng̑ʰ- ({ref NIL} 13-15, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1159-1160, {ref EWAia} II:220-221, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:518, {ref ALEW} 115-116).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4411

Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'to beat' ({ref Derksen 2008}:41, {ref ESSJa} 2:99-100, {ref LIV²} 72).
To be derived from Vedic √kar- 'to make, do' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:147, no. 2900, {ref KEWA} I:176, {ref EWAia} I:307-309).
A verbal derivative of Ancient Greek φῦσα 'breath, bellows', further connections outside of Greek unclear (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1599-1600)

Comment: loan from Persian ران cf. /lexeme/47728/
Borrowing from Arabic?

Justification: Possibly of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:48).
Cf. OCS vrъzǫ 'tie' from PIE *u̯erg̑ʰ- (cf. {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 1:188-189, {ref LIV²} 688).

A derivative of Portuguese apertar 'tighten, press, clamp', from Latin appectorāre 'press on the chest' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:44), further derived from Latin pectus 'chest'. For connections elsewhere in Indo-European, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:491, {ref de Vaan 2008}:453, and further discussion in /cognate/4015/.

Romance lexemes from Latin domina 'mistress, lady', the feminine equivalent to Latin dominus 'master of a household' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:245-246), further derived from Latin domus 'house' < *dom-u-, cf. PIE *demh₂- 'build' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:177-179, cf. {ref LIV²} 114-116).

Etymology in this class follows {ref Hamp 1960}:276, {ref Demiraj 1997}:180-181, {ref Orel 1998}:125 to PIE *g̑erh₂- 'to become old'; but cf. also discussion of {ref Huld 1984}:66, {ref Holm 2011}:89-90.
Cf. Classical Armenian mēǰ- 'the middle; back' < PIE médʰ-i̯o- ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:466-467, {ref NIL} 465-466).

Derivatives from PIE 2. *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' ({ref Derksen 2008}:234, {ref ESSJa} 11:44-45, cf. {ref LIV²} 556-7), PIE *(s)kert- 'cut (to pieces)' ({cf. {ref LIV²} 559-560) is often considered to be a dental-enlarged form of this root.
Etymology outside of Indic uncertain ({ref KEWA} II:667, {ref EWAia} II:369). For Middle and Modern Indic forms cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:591, no. 10250.
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian песок 'sand'.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4272 s.v. 'foot, leg, knee'; cognate with /cognate/4586/; related to /cognate/7597/?
Justification: As though from Indic *goḍḍa- 'foot, leg, knee'; further connections unclear, perhaps related to *khuṭṭa- 'leg' in /cognate/9629/ ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:229 no. 4272).

To be derived from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'to hear, sound' ({ref LIV²} 187); possibly originally an IE light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- *dʰeh₁- 'to give tidings' ({ref ALEW} 331-332). Root reference form follows {ref LIV²} 210-211.
East Baltic lexemes, without certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 623-625, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:422-423 for further discussion).
Khwarazmian hwβ would appear to continue a present stem *hauba-, but there is no certain etymology (cf. {ref Samadi 1986}:92-93, {ref Cheung 2007}:299-301).
Old French fesse, from Latin fissus 'split' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 3:581-582), the past passive participle of Latin findere 'to split' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:221).

Comment: Unknown etymology. (e)i̯-n-
Justification: Of uncertain etymology.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *tu̯erH- 'to catch' ({ref Derksen 2008}:501, {ref ALEW} 1143, cf. {ref LIV²} 656).

Comment: cf. Young Avestan tiγra-, Old Persian tigra- 'sharp' < Proto-Indo-Iranian *tigrá-, compare Vedic tigmá-, cf. Maryhofer EWAia I, p. 668f.
re-sanskritized? not among Turner 1962-66, no. 9827f. mánuṣa- and manuṣyà-

Justification: Pāli pabbata 'mountain' from Vedic párvata- (adj.) 'stony', (n.) 'mountain, mountains, stone', as though from PIE *péru̯n̥to-, cf. Hitt. peru- 'stone' ({ref EWAia} II:99, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:668-669).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit pānīya- 'water' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:456 no. 8082), a derivative of Vedic √pā- 'to drink' and further to PIE *peh₃(i̯)- 'to drink' ({ref EWAia} II:113-114, {ref LIV²} 262).

Armenian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯g- 'to belch, vomit' ({ref Olsen 1999}:764, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:714-715, {ref Derksen 2008}:441-442, {ref Boryś 2005}:536, cf. {ref LIV²} 509).
Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit or Prakrit challī- 'bark' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:274, no. 5005). Of non-IE origin, possibly Dravidian or Munda (cf. {ref KEWA} I:405-406).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian мазен 'smooth'.

Slavic lexemes as though from PIE *lh₂eiuo- or *leh₂i-uo- 'left' ({ref ESSJa} 15:29-31, {ref Derksen 2008}:275), cf. Ancient Greek λαιός 'left', Latin laevus 'left' ({ref Beekes 2010}:824-825, {ref de Vaan 2008}:323).

Comment: cf. Bailey (1979: 420) who connects NP čap with Sogdian sʾpt deriving both from *k̑am- "to bend over" (cf. *kamp- in LIV 342). However, while Sogdian requires the input *k̑e, NP requires *ke.

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Ossetic ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:507).

Root_Gloss: 'to hit, to meet with, to come together'

Justification: Romance lexemes from or derived from Latin mollis 'soft' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:463); the Iberian Romance lexemes are secondarily derived to a de-adjectival verb *molliāre 'make soft' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:463, {ref DCECH} IV:181-182). Further to PIE *meld- 'be/make soft' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:386, cf. {ref LIV²} 431).

As though from a Sanskrit compound *kṣāradhānikā 'receptacle for ashes' (kṣārá- 'caustic substance', dhā́na- 'container'; cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:191, no. 3677). Further connections outside of Indo-Iranic are uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} I:430, {ref KEWA} I:288).

Comment: egg (of hen) < "round"
Buck 1949:226 from IE *skeu/*keu 'perceive, hear'

Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √yā- 'to go, advance, set out, travel', further to PIE *(H)i̯eh₂- ({ref EWAia} II:407-408, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:604, no. 10452, cf. {ref LIV²} 309-310.

Comment: Not related to bāzu-forms, because *b would appear as β. Cheung (2007: 430) puts the Sogdian word to the verbal root *waz- "to carry, drive".

Justification: Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from a PIE root *men- ({ref KEWA} II:575-576, {ref ESSJa} 20:158-161, {ref Derksen 2008}:330). Quite possibly (but not certainly) also cognate with Proto-Germanic *mannan- in /cognate/8248/, cf. further discussion in that cognate set.
Parallel loans from Persian نمک / namak 'salt'.
Loanword from Kâta-vati.

Lexemes from Proto-Iranic *či̯au̯- 'to move, go', and ultimately from PIE *kʷi̯eu̯- 'to set oneself in motion' cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:307-308, {ref Cheung 2007}:40-42, {ref EWAia} I:552-553, {ref LIV²} 394-395).
Lexemes continuing an Iranic root *Hrab/f-, further connections outside of Iranic uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:184-185).
Romance lexemes continuing Latin pilus 'hair' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:538 no. 6508), further etymological connections uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:507, {ref de Vaan 2008}:465).
Parallel loans from Persian مرد / mard 'man, person'.
Baltic lexemes, to judge from cognates such as Ved. śā́kha- 'branch', probably continuing an ablauting h₂-stem, like PIE *k̑ók-eh₂- ~ *k̑ek-h₂- (cf. {ref ALEW} 1003-1005, {ref Derksen 2015}:439).

Comment: see 3414 for the discussion of etymology

Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *swimman- 'to swim, float', further etymology uncertain ({ref Seebold 1970}:491-492, {ref Kroonen 2013}:501).
Loan from English river
No secure etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} I:314-315). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:143-144, no. 2830.

Albanian forms since {ref Meyer 1891}:23-24 compared with Greek φαίνω 'appear', a remodelled nasal-present stem *bʰ-né/n-h₂- to PIE 1. *bʰeh₂- 'shine' ({ref LIV²} 68-69, {ref Huld 1984}:43, {ref Demiraj 1997}:97-98, {ref Orel 1998}:22).

Comment: cognate with OHG dorn 'thorn', etc., cf. IEW 1031; cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 664
Justification: Indic lexemes generally considered cognate to OHG dorn 'thorn', etc. < *tr̥-no-; perhaps further derived from PIE *(s)ter- 'be rigid', cf. Gk. στερεός 'stiff, hard' but this is less certain ({ref {EWAia} I:664, cf. {ref IEW} 1031),
Etymology uncertain. Considered a loanword from Slavic according to {ref Meyer 1891}:206 and others, alternatively an inherited lexeme (cf. {ref Huld 1984}82-83}, {ref Orel 1998}:197).

Romance lexemes from Latin infūsum (Giovanni Abete, p.c.), the past passive participle of Latin infundere 'pour in' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:363). Further to PIE *g̑ʰeu̯d- 'pour', possibly a post-PIE enlargement of *g̑ʰeu̯- 'pour' for phonotactic reasons ({ref LIV²} 179-180n1, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:249-250). Root assignment in this class follows {ref LIV²} in reconstructing a separate root *g̑ʰeu̯d-.
