Etymology uncertain. Possibly a blend of PIE *spek̑- & *derk̑- (cf. {ref Meillet 1936}:135, {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:228, {ref Clackson 2017}:105-106); alternatively backformed to a root aorist etes < *dek̑-/dk̑- (cf. {ref Schmitt 1981}:146, {ref LIV²} 109-112).
Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:787-789, {ref Adams 2013}:529-531 for further discussion.

Comment: Loan from East Caucasian
Justification: No clear connection to the inherited Iranic or Indo-European words for salt, probably a loan from East Caucasian (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:310-311).

Indic and Balto-Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *bʰei̯h₂- to get scared' ({ref LIV²} 72-73, cf. {ref EWAia} II:245-246, {ref ALEW} 112-113, {ref Derksen 2015}:89, {ref ESSJa} 2:163-164, {ref Derksen 2008}:50).

Romance lexemes from Latin lūridus 'pale yellow, lurid' (({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 5:465-470, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:420), further etymology uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:371, {ref de Vaan 2008}:354).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯āstra- 'pasture, grass' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:93 {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:403, cf. {ref Bartholomae 1904}:1414, 1416).
No certain etymology (cf. {ref ALEW} 990-991).
Loan from English round.
Root etymology uncertain; probably either PIE *leg̑- 'gather' or PIE *leu̯k- 'shine' (cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:836-839, {ref Adams 2013}:596-597).
Parallel loans from Arabic حلو / ḥulw 'sweet, nice' (cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:461).
Loan from Standard Italian fumata 'smoking, a smoke'.

IE root etymology disputed. The Italic and Romance lexemes in this class might be connected with the lexemes from Proto-Germanic *dragan- in /cognate/2839/ via PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- but this would require the assumption of an irregular dissimilation of aspirates and devoicing in initial position. Alternatively some Celtic cognates are formally possible (cf. Old Irish tethraig* 'ran away, receded'), but note that the required reconstruction *tre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- violates Indo-European root structure constraints. Cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:626-627 and {ref LIV²} 154 for further discussion.

Comment: No certain further etymology no matter numerous proposals (cf. ESSJa).

Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic disputed; cf. {ref Falileyev 2000}:66, {ref Matasović 2009}:144-145 for various proposals. Root ref. form follows {ref Matasović 2009}.
Romance lexemes from Latin battuere 'hit, beat' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:85), of obscure origin ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:68).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9742; further etymology unclear, cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 294

Justification: Connections outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:153-155 for various proposals.
Loan from Romanian.
Generally considered a loan from Latin penna 'feather, wing, pinion' ({ref Orel 1998}:315, {ref Holm 2011}:62), but cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:62 who attempts alternative etymologies.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11004 and s.v. lag-
Justification: As though from Sanskrit lāgayati 'lays on', the causative stem to √lag- 'to stick, attach'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:638 no. 11004, {ref EWAia} II:473)
Loan from Germanic.
Perhaps from PIE *u̯élk̑-u-, if cognate with Skt. valśa- ‘sprout’, OCS vlasъ ‘hair’, Russ. vólos ‘hair’ ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:997).
For the root etymology, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:909-910, with references to further literature; cf. also discussion by {ref Adams 2013}:658-660.
Loanword from South Slavic, cf. /cognate/1171/.

Derivatives from Proto-Indo-Iranic *bʰau̯H- 'be, exist' < PIE *bʰeu̯h₂-/*bʰu̯eh₂- ({ref EWAia} II:255-257, 268, {ref LIV²} 98-101, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:545 no. 9556-9557, {ref Henning 1971}:34).

Comment: Past. Part. used as adjective 'good'

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:417, {ref Derksen 2015}:343-344, {ref Boryś 2005}:424, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:435-436). The verbal root is preserved in Baltic (cf. Lith. pam̃pti 'swell').
Etymology in this class follows {ref NIL} 122-124; cf. also the discussion of {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:123, {ref Matasović 2009}:107.

Comment: blend of *gadda- 'sediment, mud, dirt' with gandhá- 'smell' or Middle Persian and Persian gand 'bad smell' (?); cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4011 and 4014
Cognate with 'blow' /lexeme/31051/

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:271, {ref EWA 5}:195-199 for further discussion).
Of onomatopeic origin, first attested as Middle High German snūfen, cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:819 s.v. New High German schnauben 'to sniff, snort' for further discussion.

Comment: strangely enough similar to /cognate/2839/

Justification: Lexemes based on loans from Latin numerus 'number', cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:538).

Continuing Medieval Greek σκιάζομαι 'to be frightened' ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:462, cf. {ref Andriotis 1974}:498), denominal to Ancient Greek σκία 'shadow'. For further discussion of the etymology of this root, cf. 'shadow' in /cognate/5058/.
Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:308 no. 5512 *ṭhēḍḍ- 'push' with variants 2. *ṭhēll- . 3. *ṭēll-. Further etymology unclear.
Cf. Vedic dvā́ra- 'door' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:381 no. 6663), further from PIE *dʰu̯er- with an irregular dissimilation of the initial aspirate (cf. {ref EWAia} I:764-765).
Romance lexemes from Latin lārgus 'generous, bountiful' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:399), further etymology uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:342, {ref de Vaan 2008}:327).

Iberian Romance lexemes as though from Latin *sucīdus 'dirty', cf. Latin suc(c)īdia 'side of pork' derived from Latin sūs 'wild boar; pig' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:694, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:670, {ref de Vaan 2008}:603). For the reconstruction of the Indo-European word for 'wild boar; pig', cf. the discussion of {ref EIEC} 425.
Loan from Old French roont ({ref Deshayes 2003}:632).
Hellenic and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯k̑-/*u̯oi̯k̑- 'house' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1055-1056, {ref EWAia} II:584-585, cf. {ref LIV²} 669-670).

Comment: < *śāṭa- ~ *śāda- 'falling, rotting', different blends of Vedic -śada- 'falling' with Sanskrit śāta- m. 'fallout' (śātana- n. 'the cutting off') and MIA -saṭá- (Pali); cf. Vedic (AV) parṇa-śadá- m. 'falling of leaves' ~ Pali paṇṇa-saṭá- 'heap of fallen leaves'; Turner 1962-66, no. 12267, 12381, 12386, Mayrhofer KEWA III, p. 323; ultimately from PIE *k̑ad- 'fall', cf. ²LIV, p. 318 (IEW 516) - ATTENTION: Maithili साराब is VERB

Justification: Possibly cognate with Anatolian lexemes for 'bad' in /cognate/3299/ (so {ref Adams 2013:555-556}; tentatively mentioned but not explicitly rejected by {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:420-422). Alternatively a loan from Old Turkish ({ref Peyrot 2016}:327-335).

Comment: Gharib (1995: 454, #11143) derives the Sogdian word from *δrām.

Justification: IE root etymology unclear. {ref LIV²} s.v. ?*dʰreb-, considers the forms to be possibly connected with OCS drobiti 'to splinter, pulverise' but regards this connection as uncertain. {ref Seebold 1970} and {ref Kluge 2011} see no clear comparisons outside of Germanic. {ref Kroonen 2013} derives from via a backformation to iterative *drupp/bōn- 'to drip' and accepts a root etymology with OCS drobiti, but reconstructs from *dʰrebʰ- to avoid reconstructing PIE *b.
Probably a loanword from Turkic, but not fully certain (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:259-260).
Light verb constructions 'to become ice' with loanwords from Persian برف / barf 'snow' as the semantic-bearing head, cf. 'ice' in /cognate/7952/.

Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾sep- ({ref HED A+E/I}:431-435, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:404, {ref {EWAia} I:424, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:230-231, {ref Sims-Williams 2007}:276).
Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ({ref LIV²} 458, {ref EWAia} II:76-77, {ref Derksen 2008}:392, cf. {ref Rix 1976}:278-279).
Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *věděti 'know', a derivative of PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to see, catch sight of' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:518, {ref LIV²} 665-667).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:23 for a conjectural loanword hypothesis from Persian.

Comment: uncertain.
Justification: Of uncertain origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:941), {ref HAB} II:666-667). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kurts-i-].

Etymology uncertain. Attempts to relate to PIE *h₂ek̑-mōn in /cognate/7058/ are made with great difficulty (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:183-184, {ref Boutkan 1998}:113-115, {ref NIL} s.v. *h₂ek̑-), although this connection is still frequently assumed in secondary literature (cf. {ref Orel 2003}, {ref Kroonen 2013}).

Comment: Controversial, explained either as loanwords from Latin tendere or as inherited verbs, based on PIE *ten- 'to span, to stretch' (LIV 626). Perhaps related to /cognate/2837/, see citations in class for further references.

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:252, {ref Lehmann 1986}:192-193.
Romance forms based on Latin flō, flāre 'to blow', ultimately derived from PIE *bʰleh₁- 'blow' (cf. {ref {de Vaan 2008}:226-227, {ref LIV²} 87).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3624; Pali kiliṭṭha- 'soiled, morally impure'; LIV, p. 363 (IEW 602)

Justification: Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *séh₂u̯el-, sh₂(u)u̯en- (?), *sh₂un-, *sh₂ul- 'sun' ({ref NIL} 606-611, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:516, {ref EWAia} II:742, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:782 no. 13574, {ref  Abaev 1959–1995} IV:246-248, {ref ALEW} 892, {ref Derksen 2015}:390, {ref Derksen 2008}:479-480, {ref Kroonen 2013}:463-464, {ref de Vaan 2008}:570, {ref Matasović 2009}:324). For an influential analysis of the nominal formation cf. {ref Beekes 1984}.

Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √kart- 'to cut (off), split, break', ultimately from PIE *(s)kert- 'cut up' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:145 no. 2854, {ref EWAia} I:315-326, cf. {ref LIV²} 559-560).
Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish druimm 'back'. Further etymology unclear, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:203-204 for various suggestions.

Sometimes considered with cognate with PIE *h₂ost- in /cognate/519/ but the details  remain unclear (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:239, {ref ESSJa} 11:167-173 for further discussion). This cognate set is otherwise restricted to Slavic.
Etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword or of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:337, 329-330).
Parallel loans from Persian گرم  / garm 'hot'.
Uncertain, loan from Iranic (cf. /cognate/68/)?

Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear; to die' ({ref LIV²} 439, cf. {ref EWAia} II:318-319, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:578-579 no. 10066, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:19, {ref Matasović 2009}:259). For Germanic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this class, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:378-379.
Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:594 no. 10286, further to PIE *meld- 'to become soft' ({ref KEWA} II:675-677, {ref EWAia} II:386-387, cf. {ref LIV²} 431).
Loanword from Sanskrit tvác- 'skin, bark'.

Comment: re-sanskritized forms of the respective inherited forms, cf. /cognate/6949/ - note that this phenomenon is different from a simple loan event

Justification: If a derivative from Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar- 'consume' (cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:504) then perhaps to be linked with 'eat' in /cognate/27/, 'drink' in /cognate/3691/.
Loan from Turkish murdar 'unclean' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).

Uncertain origin. Suggested to be a blend of the roots found in Greek σφάζω 'kill' and κτείνω 'kill' {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:227, or the root of Greek σφάζω 'kill' and the PIE root *gʷʰen- {ref Watkins 1995}:521 (cf. {ref Clackson 2017}:104-105, 112-113). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *span-].

Derived from Indic *kaṇṭa- (3) 'backbone, podex, penis' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:131-132, no. 2670). Perhaps identical with Skt. kaṇṭa- 'thorn' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:131, no. 2668), of uncertain further etymology (cf. {ref KEWA} I:146).
Lexemes from Proto-Germanic *bītan- 'to bite, be sharp', further derived from PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split, cleave' ({ref LIV²} 70-71, {ref Kroonen 2013}:65, {ref Lehmann 1986}:68).

Comment: Listed by Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru to be a Latin loan in Welsh so ultimately deriving from /cognate/867/. Alternative forms with initial h- are likely to be inherited, whereas these ones, with initial s- are borrowings.
Justification: Brythonic lexemes derived from a loan event from Latin siccus 'dry' (cf. Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:60, {ref Falileyev 2000}:142-143)
Apparently a derivative of Latin cuppa 'cup, bowl' according to {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:223. Further etymology obscure (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:158-159, {ref de Vaan 2008}:155).
From Latin ambulāre ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:33 no. 412), further to PIE *h₂elh₂- 'go aimlessly, randomly' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:38, {ref LIV²} 264).
Gk. κοντός 'short' appears to derive from the same root as Ancient Greek κεντέω 'to sting, goad', for further discussion cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:563, {ref Beekes 2010}:672-673.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref MacKenzie 1990}:108 for suggestions and references to further literature.
Romance lexemes from Latin vīcīnus 'neighbour' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:777), further to Latin vīcus 'village, block of houses' and PIE *u̯ei̯k̑- 'settlement' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:675).
Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit taḍāga- 'pond, tank, (artificial) lake', further etymology obscure ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:320 no. 5635, {ref KEWA} I:470).
Parallel Sanskritisms, cf. /cognate/754/.
Lexemes in this set coded for Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ 'black' < PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾r̥s-nó- (cf. {ref ESSJa} 4:155-157, {ref Derksen 2008}:92). For further etymological discussion, cf. /cognate/1111/ 'black'.
From Ancient Greek τρέχω 'run' ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:510). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'run' in /cognate/5027/.

Greek and Armenian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ei̯d- 'to swell' ({ref LIV²} 258-259, {ref Beekes 2010}:1053-1054, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:61). Albanian forms in /cognate/8292/ might be cognate to this set but ultimately uncertain, cf. discussion in that cognate class.

Very similar in form and meaning to Ancient Greek γλυκύς 'sweet', but a common proto-form cannot be reconstructed. Perhaps the Italic and Greek lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:186-187, {ref de Vaan 2008}:182). Cf. further discussion in /cognate/5055/.
Etymology outside of Tocharian unclear, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:176 for a survey of various proposals.

Possibly related to Germanic /cognate/647/ and Armenian /cognate/8305/ lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible. For further discussion, cf. {ref ALEW} 947 (Baltic material), {ref Beekes 2010}:1371 (Greek material), {ref Seebold 1970}:440-441, {ref Kroonen 2013}:458-459 (Germanic material), {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:69-70, {ref Matasović 2009}:281 (Celtic material), {ref Martirosyan 2010}:484 (Armenian material).
Shortened from 'white head', cf. older Polish białogłowa 'women'. Cf. 'white' in /cognate/1190/ for further etymological discussion.

Romance lexemes from Latin āēr 'air' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:18), an early loanword in Latin (already attested by Ennius, late 3rd - early 2nd c. BCE) from Ancient Greek ἄηρ ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:11).

Reflecting Proto-Celtic *bal-ni- 'to throw away, die', further derived from PIE *gʷelh₁- 'to throw' ({ref LIV²} 208, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:98, {ref Schumacher 2004}:211-212, {ref Matasović 2009}:53).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar- 'to consume, eat', further connections uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:147-150, cf. {ref LIV²} 609).
No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:500). For Modern Indic forms, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:657, no. 11258.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10063 s.v. māra- m. ʻdeathʼ (VarBr̥S.), ʻkillingʼ (Rājat.); New Indo-Aryan words meaning ʻstriking, blowʼ from mārayati which continues the polysemy of Vedic hánti (han-) 'beat, slay, kill'; cognate with /cognate/712/

Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *médʰ-i̯o- 'middle, located in the middle' ({ref ALEW} 625-627, {ref Derksen 2015}:309).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Karulis 1992} II:188-189 s.v. Latvian sit 'to hit' for further discussion.
Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:418, {ref LIPP 2}:639).
The root etymology in this cognate set follows {ref LIV²} 154 to PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'to haul, to pull', cf. also {ref Kroonen 2013}:99, {ref Lehmann 1986}:93-94, {ref Seebold 1970}:160-162.
Loan from Turkish yeşil 'green' ({ref Holm 2011}:64).

Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rái̯as-, an s-stem noun formed to Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rai̯-'to stretch, extend', cf. Vedic √jray- 'id.', further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:606-607, cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:449).
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain; perhaps to Lat. grossus 'fat' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:79, {ref Matasović 2009}:74, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:273).
Probably a loanword from Middle Iranian ({ref Adams 2013}:48).
Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁- 'to be hot' ({ref Untermann 2000}:54-55, {ref de Vaan 2008}:60, cf. {ref LIV²} 257).

Indo-Iranic lexemes from Sanskrit lóhita- 'red' (Ved. róhita- 'red') with semantics generalised from 'red' > 'any red substance' > 'blood' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:650, no. 11165), further derived to PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'red' ({ref EWAia} II:471).

Cf. Old Lithuanian paũta 'egg, testicle', considered a vr̥ddhi-derivative to the Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'bird' *put- (cf. 'bird' in /cognate/1109), but further etymology uncertain ({ref ALEW} 745-746).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *rekti 'to speak, say', further derived from PIE *rek- ({ref Derksen 2008}:433, {ref LIV²} 506).

Italic lexemes, generally considered derivatives from PIE *pleu̯-mo-, a derivative of PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float'. An alternative possible reconstruction is *pleu̯k-smo- and connected with the extended variant *pleu̯k- which is only otherwise attested in Germanic and Baltic, cf. /cognate/2263/ ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:516, {ref de Vaan 2008}:474, cf. {ref LIV²} 487-488).
Originally 'mountain' ({ref ESSJa} 7:29-31, {ref Derksen 2008}:177-178; cf. /cognate/80/ for further etymological details).
Cf. Sanskrit kaṭhiná- 'hard, firm', probably a loanword from Dravidian (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:132 no .2650, {ref KEWA} I:144).

Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:578-579 no. 10066 Vedic māráyati (1) 'kills', the causative stem formation to Vedic √mar- 'to die', further to PIE *mer- 'to disappear, to die' ({ref EWAia} II:318-319, {ref LIV²} 439-440).
Indo-Iranic lexemes reflecting an original u-stem *di̯éu̯- ~ *diu̯- 'sky, day' to PIE *dei̯- 'be bright, shine' ({ref NIL} 69-81, {ref EWAia} I:750-752).

Iranic, Baltic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯et- 'year'. For the connection of Iranic lexemes, cf. {ref Szemerényi 1951} and further {ref EWAia} II:495. For Baltic, cf. {ref ALEW} 1228, {ref Karulis 1992} II:497-498. For Italic, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:672-673, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:775 no. 9291 & 9292.

Originally a possessive adjective formation to Vedic pakṣá- 'wing' > pakṣín- 'winged'; no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:62). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:430, no. 7636.
Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *melh₂- 'to grind, crush' ({ref de Vries 1977}:392, {ref Lehmann 1986}:260, cf. {ref LIV²} 432-433).

Connections outside of Armenian unclear; occasionally proposed to Gk. ξηρός 'dry' (cf. /cognate/1471/), but this requires postulating a sound law in Armenian for which this is the only example (cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:182, {ref Olsen 1999}:965 {ref Beekes 2010}:1035-1036, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:546).

From PIE *rei̯⁽g̑⁾- 'bind' via Proto-Celtic *rig-e/o- ({ref Schumacher 2004}:546-548, {ref Matasović 2009}:311-312, {ref Schumacher 2004}:546-548, cf. {ref LIV²} 503), but cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:161, {ref Falileyev 2000}:64.

Precise connections outside of Germanic are disputed. For the purposes of cognacy, this class follows the reconstruction of {ref LIV²} with possible but uncertain connections to ?*g̑ʰeHb- (cf. OIr. gaibid), but cf. the hypothesis of {ref Kortlandt 1992}:104-5, followed by {ref Kroonen 2013}:172-173, who suggests a remodelling of earlier *ga-ef- from *k̑o(m)-h₂ep-.
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ({ref Falileyev 2000}:76); root ref. form follows {ref Deshayes 2003}:316.

Comment: The alleged similarity with cognate 503 is probably accidental. Korn (2005: 189) seems to follow Horn (1893: 121) who derives these words from the PP of the Old Iranic verb *drang- "make strong/firm". Cf. Cheung (2007: 76) *dregʰ-.

Justification: Quite likely (but not certainly) cognate with Proto-Germanic *grasa- 'grass' in /cognate/230/; cf. note by Scarborough in citations for further discussion.
No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:207, {ref Lehmann 1986}:123, {ref Kroonen 2013}:152).

No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic; proposed etymologies outside of Indo-Iranic rely on comparisons with hydronyms which are not wholly reliable comparanda (cf. {ref EWAia} II:8-9, {ref LIV²} 448). For Middle and Modern Indic forms, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:399, no. 6943.
Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯r̥mi- 'worm' ({ref Lehmann 1986}:397, {ref Kroonen 2013}:600). Perhaps further connected to PIE *kʷr̥mi- 'worm' (cf. /cognate/348/ for further discussion).

Comment: Pashto would simplify /xt/ > /t/. Kurdish: Vxt > v̄t.

Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *kyjь 'stick, club', a jo-derivative to *ky- < PIE *kuh₂- with regular laryngeal metathesis from zero-grade *kh₂u̯- (full-grade PIE *keh₂u̯- 'hit, split', cf. {ref ESSJa} 13:257-258, 12:10-11; {ref Derksen 2008}:265, {ref LIV²} 345-346).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5424, presumably of non-Aryan origin.
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of a stem *ṭakk- 'cut, break', cf. Sanskrit ṭakkarā 'a blow on the head' first attested in Rājataraṃgiṇī (12th c. AD). Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:300 no. 5421, 5424; {ref KEWA} I:455).
Etymology outside of Greek unclear, possibly a prehistoric loanword (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:90-91, {ref Beekes 2010}:106).
Parallel loans from Persian daryāb; cf. 'lake' in /cognate/2771/ and 'sea' in /cognate/2011/.

Indo-European root etymology disputed. Either to *deh₂u̯- in /cognate/8388/ (so {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:8-9, {ref Schrijver 1995}:316), or *dʰegʷʰ- in /cognate/368/ (tentatively {ref LIV²} 133-134). {ref Matasović 2009}:92-93 gives both etymologies under different lemmata. Cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:180.

Comment: cf. Turner 1931: 534, 1962-66, no. 10539 s.v. rakta- ʻcoloured, dyedʼ (ŚB), ʻredʼ (ŚāṅkhGr̥.), n. ʻbloodʼ (Mn.), °aka- ʻredʼ (VarBr̥S) (√rañj-), Pali Prakrit ratta-, Rom. rat m.; cf. /cognate/1814/; LIV, p. 587
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit rakta- 'coloured, dyed', the past passive participle to Ved. √raj-¹, ultimately from PIE *(s)re⁽g̑⁾- 'to colour (smth.)' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:610, no. 10539; {ref EWAia} II:424-425, {ref LIV²} 587).
From Latin grossus 'fat, thick' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:330-331), further etymology unclear (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:273), formerly connected by {ref IEW} 485 with Celtic *brasso- in /cognate/4355/.
Germanic lexemes from PIE *dʰu̯n̥s-tó-, derived from PIE *dʰu̯ens- 'to scatter, to crumble' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:109, {ref LIV²} 159).

Possibly an unextended form of the root *u̯eh₂dʰ- found in Latin vādo, -ere 'to go, walk, rush' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:196; cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:86). The alternative proposed etymology to *⁽g̑⁾ʰeh₁- 'to come, arrive' depends on whether the Indo-Iranic lexemes (Av. za-zā-mi 'to leave' Skt. já-hā-ti 'to leave, abandon') are to be connected with the Germanic and Armenian ones (cf. {ref EWAia} II:813-814, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:196 for further discussion). The root etymology here follows {ref Martirosyan 2010}, but cf. {ref LIV²} 196 s.v. *gʰeh₁- and 644 s.v. *u̯eh₂dʰ- 'durchschreiten'.

Generally agreed that the Baltic and Slavic forms are cognate, but there is debate as to how the Proto-Balto-Slavic word is to be reconstructed. Cf. discussion in {ref Derksen 2008}:523, {ref ESSJa} 7:181-189, {ref Derksen 2015}:195-196, {ref ALEW} 1332-1333.

Romance forms based on the past passive participle of Latin balneāre 'to bathe' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:74-75), a nominal verb from Latin balneum 'bath, place for bathing', an old loanword from Ancient Greek βαλανεῖον 'id.' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:65, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:195).

Comment: The Tocharian words derive either from ie. *dʰeu̯H- or *dʰu̯eh₂-, cf. /cognate/2463/. On of these roots might in fact be the basis for ie. *dʰu̯ens- from which the Germanic 'dust'-words are derived (cf. /cognate/2464/), but they cannot be assigned the same cognate class on this level of analysis and regarding the state of the art concerning root extensions. -  Also cf. 'ashes' /cognate/2463/ and 'smoke' in /cognate/123/.
negation of baš "good", which Cabolov (2001: 155) explains as a Turkish loanword: baš 'head' > 'main' > 'good' (cf. German 'Kopf/Haupt' > 'haupt-' as with 'Hauptsache').

Justification: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:594 no. 10286, 10287, further to PIE *meld- 'to become soft' ({ref KEWA} II:675-677, {ref EWAia} II:386-387, cf. {ref LIV²} 431).

Comment: cf. Sanskrit (Dhātup.) kaḍḍati, Turner 1962-66, p. 133, no. 2657; loan from a substrate (Munda or Dravidian), cf. Mayrhofer KEWA I, p 144; perhaps related to /cognate/6387/
Justification: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:133 no. 2657. Sanskrit (Dhātup.) kaḍḍati 'is hard'. {ref KEWA} I:144 groups with kaṭhiná- 'hard, firm' as part of a group of probable loans from Dravidian (cf. Tamil kaṭṭu 'hardness').

{ref Rohlfs 1964}:288 considers the Italiot Greek words to be borrowings from Romance. Note, however, that AGk. λάκκος does exist, and might possibly be derived from *l̥ku̯o- (PIE *laku- or *loku-, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:827 s.v. λάκκος and further discussion in /cognate/8246/). It is difficult to exclude in principle the possibility of contamination or blending of inherited material with that of local Romance varieties. Similarly cf. Engl. lake in /cognate/5612/ which may well be a semantic calque from Romance.
Parallel loans from Sanskrit samudrá- 'gathering of the waters, sea, ocean', cf. /cognate/730/

Comment: Sardinian forms formerly with Balto-Slavic lexemes in /cognate/1109/. ALEW doubts cognacy outside of Balto-Slavic. This needs to be double-checked. (-MJCS 19.10.2017).
Origin unclear.
Justification: Commonly assumed to be a borrowing from Latin locusta 'grasshopper', but this is semantically unconvincing; rather, of uncertain origin ({ref Deshayes 2003}:445).

Root etymology disputed. Traditionally to IE *h₂ek̑- 'sharp' (cf. {ref IEW} 21-22, {ref Buck 1949}:1069, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:806-807), but this is difficult from a morphological point of view. Alternatively {ref Narten 1986}:204-214 has proposed a comparison with Ved. √akṣ- which could allow a Greek zero-grade formation *h₃k̑s- > ὀξ-, but this proposal has not been met with widespread acceptance (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1089).
Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:418, {ref LIPP 2}:639).

Comment: Considering the Parthian form gwyʾw and the ZMP form gwbyʾ, one may reconstruct a bilabial glide. There is a possibility that this word is a compound of gauu- "cow" and a second element, cf. Old Ind. *Hyavas- "pasture" or  yáva- "wheat".

Justification: From Ancient Greek τύπτω 'to hit, beat' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:563). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'hit' in /cognate/7794/.

Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic /cognate/8267/, Baltic /cognate/8266/, Slavic /cognate/8265/, and Indic(-Nuristani) /cognate/7396/ have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.

Possibly from a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic. Lat. plūma might be based on the *pleu̯k- root, but alternative derivations from unextended *pleu̯- are also possible, cf. /cognate/999/.
Possibly from PIE *bʰleu̯dh₂- if the comparison with Ancient Greek φλυδάω 'to be soft, weak' is correct (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:67, {ref Beekes 2010}:1579-1581 s.v. φλυδάω and φλιδάω).

Root etymology uncertain, probably connected in some way with Armenian gam 'to come' from PIE *gʰeh₁- according to {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:95-96 (cf. /cognate/580/); {ref LIV²} 668-669 suggests deriving from a nasal present stem *u̯i-n(e)-h₁- to *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach'. See {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:95-96 for further discussion. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}, cf. {ref HAB} I:567-568.
Denominal verb derived from Kashubian jachta 'hunt' (n.), a loanword from German Jagd ({ref Boryś & Popowska-Taborska 1994-2010} 2:327-328).

{ref Kloekhorst 2008}:393-394 considers the root to be an m-extended form of *seh₂- 'bind', but even if so Skt. sā́man- 'song, hymn' < *sh₂óm-en- demonstrates that such a formation must have already been of PIE date. The root ref. form for this class has therefore been given as *sh₂em- [Not in {ref LIV²}.]

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 180, no. 3471; cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 401: "schwerlich zu trennen von jav. (°)gaēsa-", perhaps a blend with *káisra- > Vedic (YV+) késara- n., but phonologically unclear; Indic forms constitue a cognacy subclass *gáića- (*káisra-?)
Justification: Indic lexemes from Vedic kéśa- 'hair of the head', difficult to separate from Young Avestan gaēsa- although there is disagreement over the voicing of the initial velar; {ref EWAia} I:401 suggests a contamination of an original *géśa- the Indic lexemes with Vedic késara- 'hair, mane'. For Middle and Modern Indic, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:180 no. 3471.
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *pakšá- 'wing, pinion', further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain unclear ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:429-430 no. 7627, {ref EWAia} II:62).
Lit. 'not-good', cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:106, cf. 'good' in /cognate/9287/ for further etymological discussion.
Slavic lexemes derived from the zero-grade stem of PIE 'earth' *dʰg̑ʰ-m- (cf. {ref NIL} 86-99, {ref Derksen 2008}:545, {ref Boryś 2005}:755).

An intensive formation to Proto-Germanic *ϸrug-. The root occasionally compared to Lith. trū́kti 'break, tear in two' (cf. {ref EWA 2} 813-815, but this connection is not fully certain (cf. {ref ALEW} 1118-1119).

Comment: cf. Geiger, W. (1941): An Etymological Glossary of the Sinhalese Language. Colombo, p. 47, no.687: "The initial k for g shows Tamil influence."

Justification: This set is coded for PIE *bʰelg̑ʰ- 'swell', whence Proto-Germanic *balgi- 'skin bag' > 'belly, stomach' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:49), Proto-Celtic *bolgo- 'sack, bag, stomach' ({ref Matasović 2009}:70, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}. NB: Welsh: North botwm bol 'button-belly' is a calque from English belly-button.

In all likelihood the lexemes can be accounted for via PIE *h₂elbʰ-o- 'white', however the reflexes of this form are restricted to Italic, Greek, and potentially also Albanian (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:20, {ref de Vaan 2008}:32). For the Romance lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:26.

Traditionally derived to PIE *mag̑- 'to spread, smear' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 3:613, {ref ESSJa} 18:23-25, {ref LIV²} 421). Cf., however, {ref Derksen 2008}:304 s.v. Proto-Slavic mazati 'smear, anoint' with an alternative proposed etymology to Lithuanian mė́žti 'manure, muck out', etc.

Origin uncertain. Since {ref Pedersen 1906}:379 connected with Greek γοργός 'grim, fierce, terrible', Old Irish garg(g) 'raw, wild' (cf. {ref HAB} II:552, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:392), but this proposed etymology is rejected by {ref Beekes 2010}:283, {ref Matasović 2009}:151. Not in {ref Olsen 1999} or {ref Martirosyan 2010}.

Comment: Pashto zanāna, must be a loan if from *gʷen-, because *ǰ > ž

perhaps PIE *li̯ú-, if *li̯ > Vedic y but Germanic l-, cf. 'liver' (if from *li̯ekʷ- ~ *li̯ep- but not *Hi̯ekʷ-); Proto-Germanic *lūs < *li̯ú-s etc. with reanalysis of the ending -s (?) (R.P.); not fully clear.
Justification: Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic /cognate/8267/, Baltic /cognate/8266/, Slavic /cognate/8265/, and Indic(-Nuristani) /cognate/7396/ have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.

The cognacy in this class follows {ref LIV²} to PIE *(s)teup- after {ref Oettinger 1979}:417, 535, {ref Hajnal 1995}:127. Note however disagreement of {ref Melchert 1994}:242, {ref Neumann 2007}:384-385, comparing Gk. στυφελίζω suggesting a root-variant *(s)teubʰ- (after {ref IEW} 1034; not in {ref LIV²}). According to {ref Beekes 2010}:1418-1419, however, Gk. στυφελίζω has no secure connections outside of Greek.
Indo-Iranic lexemes probably continuing PIE ?*pē(n)s- ({ref EIEC} 499, but cf. {ref EWAia} II:114-115).
Slavic lexemes as though from PIE *pē(n)s-u-ko-, for further discussion cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:398, {ref EIEC} 499.

Comment: (< Lat. dūcere 'to lead'?)

Justification: There are two widespread hypotheses as to the etymology of this root. It has been assumed that it is a loan from Germanic *óƀāt-. However, it seems that the exact source of this (Proto-Slavic) loanword has not been identified. There are also phonetic issues (*-o-, -ť-) which should be explained if the loanword hypothesis is accepted. Another possibility is to assume a derivation from PIE root *h₂u̯eg- 'grow, rise, become large' > PS *(o-)voktĭ > *(o-)voť-. Then the word would be related to German wachsen 'grow' etc., cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}: 566.
{ref Kroonen 2013}:234 reconstructs Proto-Germanic *hnefan- as though from *knep-on-, but does not provide any cognates justifying an extra-Germanic etymology.

Perhaps cognate with Proto-Germanic *hnekkan- 'neck', although there remains some uncertainty over formal aspects of the etymology ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:162-163, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:234-235), {ref van Windekens 1976}:225-226).

From Proto-Germanic *lūka- (with secondary lengthened grade), beside OHG liochan from Proto-Germanic *leu̯ke/a- based on PIE *leu̯g- 'lösen, brechen' (cf. {ref EWA 5} 1345-1347, {ref LIV²} 415-416. See {ref Seebold 1970}:337 for references to older literature.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯ab/f- 'to call, utter (sing, speak, etc.)', without clear etymology outside of Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:401, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:94).
Learned re-introduction (or adaptation) of Ancient Greek ὑγρός 'wet', lacking the characteristic loss of initial unstressed vowels found elsewhere in Modern Greek (cf. {ref Andriotis 1999}).

Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic /cognate/8267/, Baltic /cognate/8266/, Slavic /cognate/8265/, and Indic(-Nuristani) /cognate/7396/ have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.

Comment: Mayrhofer (EWAia I 240) assume a relation with OInd. ū́dhan- "coldness".
Justification: A connection with Vedic ū́dhan- 'coldness' is assumed by {ref EWAia} I:240, but further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain unclear.

The IE root etymology of Proto-Germanic *daujan- given here follows {ref LIV²} to *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen'. For an alternative etymology attempting to connect the Germanic words to Hitt. tuḫḫuš- 'to end', cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:90-91 (but cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:893-894, who does not give an IE etymology for Hitt. tuḫḫuš-). For older etymologies attempting to connect the words to PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'rauch machen' (cf. {ref LIV²} 158) and hypothesised variants, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:147-149 (followed in Seebold's revised version of {ref Kluge 2011}:919 s.v. Tod).
Loanword from Calabrian mbuttare 'throw, push, introduce'

Comment: denominal word, cf. poh "aware, intelligent"
Justification: Denominal verb based on Pashto poh 'aware, intelligent', a loanword from Lahnda *poh- which in turn continues Old Indic prabodha- 'awakening, knowledge' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:491, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:491 no. 8699).

Generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic.
Loanword from Italian manco 'useless' (cf. also Albanian: Arbëresh manka 'left' in /cognate/8517/). [Not in {ref Rohlfs 1964}]

Earlier literature (cf. {ref Buck 1949}:22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- /cognate/284/, Greek ἄμμος /cognate/8262/, and Lat. sabulum /cognate/8263/ together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in {ref EIEC} objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in /cognate/8261/ are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. There are some proposed possible cognates in Baltic, but these comparisons depend on the internal semantic reconstruction of Proto-Germanic *narwa-, cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:421, {ref Kroonen 2013}:383. The proposed cognacy to the Baltic lexemes is rejected by {ref ALEW} s.v. OLith. *nérti (II). In the Iranic literature, the Germanic forms are sometimes connected to Indo-Iranian *nāraka- < PIE *ner- following {ref IEW} 976, however this view is not followed in the most recent etymological dictionaries (cf. {ref EWAia} II:37 s.v. nāraka- 'Hölle, Unterwelt'); cf. further discussion in /cognate/3247/.

Root etymology and connections outside of Italic disputed, cf. {ref Meiser 2002}:112, {ref de Vaan 2008}:329-330 for further discussion. For the Romance lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:401.

Generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic.
Possibly (but not certainly) cognate with Latin grāmen 'grass' in /cognate/8369/. Cf. discussion in citations below.

Germanic and Celtic lexemes reflecting a u-stem noun *u̯idʰ-ú- with the zero-grade of the root. For the reconstruction given, see {ref ALEW} s.v. Lith. vidùs, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:585, {ref Matasović 2009}:420.

Possibly cognate with 'bite' in /cognate/4968/ if IE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth' is ultimately derived from *h₁ed- *'bite' → 'eat', cf. notes to 'tooth' in /cognate/328/ for further discussion. In any case the denominal verbs in /cognate/4968/ are a secondary replacement from the inherited primary verbal stem derived from *h₁ed-.
Loan from Albanian shkrumb 'black ashes, anything burned to ashes' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:423-424).
Loanword from West Germanic ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:624, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 17:12-15).

Comment: Cf. eDIL s.v. as-beir (www.dil.ie/4383)
Justification: A compound of Old Irish -beir 'bear, carry' (< PIE *bʰer- 'carry', cf. {ref LIV²} 76-77) with the preverb ess-, es-, e-, as- 'out of' (< PIE *(h₁}eg̑ʰ-s 'out of' adv., cf. {ref LIPP 2} 205).

Often considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 488), however the *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 789-790, {ref Derksen 2015}:363, {ref EWA 3}:385-388).

Perhaps a primary verbal adjective in *-to- to the IE root *(s)leup- 'schlaff herabhängen' (IEW 964f.) only otherwise attested in Germanic and Baltic, cf. {ref Faltings 2010}:372-374. Etymology otherwise obscure.

Romance lexemes in light verb constructions using on Latin pavor 'fear' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:520, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 8:86), further probably to a root *peu̯- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:451, cf. {ref IEW} 827, not in {ref LIV²}).

Comment: Unknown etymology.
Justification: No known etymology ({ref Olsen 1999}:962, cf. {ref HAB} I:624-625). [MM: Proto-Armenian *daṙ-in-].

Originally denominal to Classical Armenian xowpʿ-n 'cover', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref HAB} II:423, {ref Olsen 1999}:211, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:350 for various proposals). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *xupʰ-].

Tocharian, Hellenic, and Albanian lexemes from PIE *sh₂eu̯- 'to rain' ({ref LIV²} 545, {ref Adams 2013}:796, {ref Beekes 2010}:1541, {ref Demiraj 1997}:380-381, {ref Orel 1998}:413-414); note the zero-grade of the root was *suh₂- by laryngeal metathesis ({ref Jasanoff 1978a}:89n7, 90n11).

Etymology uncertain ({ref Olsen 1999}:941, cf. {ref HAB} IV:56-57). Perhaps a blend of an Iranic loanword and an element connected to the Germanic 'neck' words according to {ref Pisani 1934}:55, cf. {ref Clackson 2017}:112. For further discussion cf. {ref HAB} and note by Macak to this class. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *par-].

Etymology outside of Italic disputed; most recently {ref de Vaan 2008}:687-688 favours a return to an etymology to PIE *gʷelh₁- 'hit, throw' (cf. {ref LIV²} 208, without Italic lexemes connected) as proposed by {ref Müller 1926}:213, but rejected by {ref Walde & Hofmann 1938–1954} II:828. Cf. also {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:570-571. For the Romance lexemes, see {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:788.

Armenian lexemes generally connected to Germanic and Balto-Slavic lexemes for 'frozen snow' or 'hoarfrost', although the precise nominal stem formation in Armenian is not fully understood ({ref Olsen 1999}:137, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:567-568; cf. {ref HAB} IV:176-177 for older proposals). Note, however, {ref ALEW} 1019, {ref Kroonen 2013}:223 not do not explicitly connect the Armenian lexemes.

Possibly otherwise to be reconstructed as an s-stem neuter *kīkos-; further etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:95-96). {ref Matasović 2009}:204 considers the words of expressive origin with an original semantic development from '(female) breast' > 'meat', although {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} considers the semantics to have developed in the opposite direction on the basis of compounds in Middle Irish.

Etymology uncertain. The etymology given by {ref de Vries 1977} relies on the outdated theory of root-extensions as in {ref IEW}. Additionally, the etymological connection of the comparanda given by {ref de Vries 1977} are questionable (cf. s.v. Gk. ἀλθαίνω in {ref Beekes 2010}, s.v. Ved. √ardh- in {ref EWAia}). Consequently, the basis upon which the traditional proposed etymology of Old Norse aldin rests, remains uncertain. Not in {ref Orel 2003} or {ref Kroonen 2013}.
Continuing a derivative of Vedic daṇḍá- 'stick, club' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:350 no 6128). No certain further etymology ({ref EWAia} I:692, {ref KEWA} II:11-12).

Hellenic lexemes from the collocation σταχτή (κονία) 'distilled (ashes)', from the process of distilling ashes to produce lye (cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:1324), further to Ancient Greek στάζω 'drop, let fall' from PIE ?*steh₂⁽g̑⁾- (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1388, {ref LIV²} 592.

Comment: The Avestan context is about firewood "which is called nǝmaδka". Bartholomae (1904: 1068) connects this word to nǝmata- in comparison to Old Indic avatká- of avatá-. nǝmata- is interpreted as brushwood ('Reisig') and derived from the verbal root "nam" i.e. 'to bow'. If this is correct, the PIE origin would be the verbal root "nem".
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *namadkā-.

Romance lexemes derived from Latin coactāre 'press together' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:188-189, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 2:809), a derivative of Latin agere 'to drive' from PIE *h₂eg̑- (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:30-31).

From Classical Armenian lełi 'gall', generally considered of uncertain etymology (cf. {ref HAB II:275), but cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:440 who suggests a reconstruction *g̑ʰelh₃iom 'yellow (substance)' > †jełi which could have been subject to a tabooistic deformation or influenced by semantically related leard 'liver'. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *leł-io-].

Traditionally derived from PIE *mud-so- ({ref Matasović 2009}:281, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:65, {ref IEW} 742) in comparison to Greek μύσος 'filth', however the etymology of the Greek form is unclear (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:985).

No clear etymology outside of Celtic ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:42, {ref Matasović 2009}:66; cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:103-104). For various suggestions, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:42. Root ref. form for this class follows {ref Matasović 2009}:66.

Hellenic lexemes in the meaning 'round' as a derived relational adjective from Ancient Greek κύκλος 'circle, ring, wheel' < PIE *kʷe-kʷl-o- 'circle; wheel', a derivative to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to turn' ({ref Beekes 2010}:798-799, cf. {ref LIV²} 386-388).

Two variants within Celtic: W croen points to Proto-Celtic *krokno-, while the Goidelic and Breton forms point to a variant *krokkeno- ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:243-244; {ref Matasović 2009}:226). Further etymology less certain; traditionally from an extended variant of *(s)ker- 'cut' (cf. {ref IEW 938-940), but the derivation is formally difficult (cf. the entries in Vendryes et al. and Matasović).

Comment: Iranian loanword.
Justification: Loanword from Iranic (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:906, cf. {ref HAB} IV:195-196). [MM: Proto-Armenian *seu̯-o-/-i-].

Etymology disputed. Traditionally derived to PIE *u̯reh₁g̑- 'break, tear' ({ref Orel 1998}:377, {ref LIV²} 698), but {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:994 consider this unconvincing semantically and suggest alternatively a possible connection to rā-, the suppletive aorist to Albanian bie 'hit; fall'. In either case the verb must be a *-sk̑e/o- derived present stem.

Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian xmem 'to drink, to imbibe'. Further origins uncertain, probably a more recent loanword on the basis of dialectal variation but the exact source is difficult to establish ({ref HAB} III:122-123, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:467) Not in {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}, {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *xi/um-].

From Old Irish gelach 'moon', derived to the Old Irish adj. gel 'fair, white, bright, shining' ({ref Lucht 2007}:259-260), further to PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green' ({ref Matasović 2009}:156, {ref EIEC} 654).

While the cognacy between Lat. vesper, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ, etc. is generally agreed, a morphological analysis of the proto-form from which these lexemes arose is not generally agreed upon. For the purposes of providing a root reference form for this cognate set, we have followed the analysis of {ref Beekes 2004}, cf. also {ref Beekes 2010}:470-471) s.v. Ancient Greek ἕσπερος. Exceptionally against the these lexemes forming a class, cf. {ref LIPP 2} s.v. †*u̯é-kʷsp-ero-. For the lexemes in this class cf. {ref Andriotis 1974}:259, {ref Beekes 2010}:470-471, {ref ALEW} 1174-1175, {ref Derksen 2015}:485, {ref Derksen 2008}:513, 536. (–MJCS). The first vowel is irregularly reduced in Slavic, cf. Slavic večer- 'evening' with a regular reflex. (–LJ).

Germanic lexemes generally connected to a marginally attested strong verb *hwelban- ~ *hwelfan- ({ref Seebold 1970}:281, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:318, {ref Kroonen 2013}:265). The cognates within Germanic are generally connected to Gk. κόλπος 'bosom; womb; hollow space, pocket' to a reconstructable root *kʷelp- ({ref Kroonen 2013}:262; cf. also {ref Frisk 1960-1972}, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}, {ref Beekes 2010} s.v. Gk. κόλπος), although not acknowledged by {ref Seebold 1970}. Root not in {ref LIV²}, probably due to its marginal attestation as a strong verb in Germanic.

Originally a participle to the weak verb 'to stretch' (OE streccan), possibly to be further derived from *strak(k)a- 'tight, taut' ({ref Orel 2003}:380), but cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:559-560, who considers that the adjective may have been back-formed from the verb. Further etymology uncertain.
Loanword from English 'to cuff', i.e. 'to strike, buffet' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).

Comment: Adams (1985, Die Sprache 31, p.12) “In pąsta- we have an exocentric derivative in *-to-, meaning ‘characterized by [base noun]’, regularly built on the oblique stem. For both the semantics and the morphology we might compare Latin arbor ‘tree’ and arbustum ‘vineyard planted with trees’.” He assumes a development of *poums → *pōms → *pōs, cf. EWAia II p.144 assuming a PIE *péu̯mōs.

Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic disputed; cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:336 s.v. Goth. *swinϸs. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:577-578 s.v. PGmc. *swenϸa- favours a comparison with IE *seg̑ʰ- 'overpower, seize' (LIV² 515-516), cf. ad loc. for references to further literature. For older comparisons to Lith. siunčiu 'send', cf. {ref IEW} 1048, reconstructing *su̯ento-, *sunto- (but qualifying the entry "nur Germ.?").
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:109 for a summary of older attempts at an etymology in {ref IEW}.

IE root etymology unclear. {ref LIV²} s.v. ?*dʰreb-, considers the forms to be possibly connected with OCS drobiti 'to splinter, pulverise' but regards this connection as uncertain. {ref Seebold 1970} and {ref Kluge 2011} see no clear comparisons outside of Germanic. {ref Kroonen 2013} derives from via a backformation to iterative *drupp/bōn- 'to drip' and accepts a root etymology with OCS drobiti, but reconstructs from *dʰrebʰ- to avoid reconstructing PIE *b.

From Proto-Indic *vedhati 'pierces' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:701, {ref Strand 1998}), further to Indo-European *u̯edʰ(h₁)- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:496-497, {ref LIV²} 660). Reconstruction of the final laryngeal is not secure (cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).

Earlier literature (cf. {ref Buck 1949}:22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- /cognate/284/, Greek ἄμμος /cognate/8262/, and Lat. sabulum /cognate/8263/ together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in {ref EIEC} objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in /cognate/8261/ are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Comment: Origin uncertain.
Justification: From Classical Armenian kṙowim 'to fight', denominative to kṙiw 'fight'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref Olsen 1999}:16, cf. {ref HAB} II:670-671, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:431 for various proposals). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010} [MM: Proto-Armenian *kiṙiu̯-].

Originally a derived adjective from Latin uireō 'to be green', no further etymology ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:739, {ref de Vaan 2008}:681-682). For the Romance lexemes, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:782.
{ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} suggests a possible loanword from Old English céce 'fauces, mouth, cheek' (> Engl. cheek).

Etymology uncertain. Traditionally connected since {ref Meillet 1936}:36 to Greek χαλάω 'to slacken', but this etymology requires postulating an initial voiceless aspirate *kʰ-, and given that voiceless aspirates are no longer reconstructed for PIE this etymology should be abandoned ({ref Clackson 1994}:144-145, {ref Beekes 2010}:1608-1609). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *xał-].
From Proto-Brythonic *oepr ({ref Deshayes 2003}:543) or *ẹ̄pl-V- or *ẹ̄pr-V- ({ref Schrijver 1995}:221) (the latter is preferable, BI).

Tsakonian lexemes based on a new present stem backformed from the Ancient Greek suppletive aorist stem ἔδραμον to the old present stem τρέχω ({ref Andriotis 1974}:215-216), further to PIE *drem- 'to run' ({ref Beekes 2010}:351, {ref LIV²} 128).

Armenian lexemes reflecting a root *derg̑ʰ- 'turn (oneself)' together with Albanian dreth ({ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:110-111, {ref LIV²} 146, cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:193, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:234). Possibly a Schwebeablaut variant of *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'pull, drag' in which case to be further connected with 'walk' in /cognate/5824/, 'run' in /cognate/5027/ 'pull' in /cognate/2839/, 'carry' in /cognate/5330/.

Comment: This could be the name of a specific snake. If derived from garz- 'to lament', it might a kind of viper (similar to the puff adder, e.g. the Persian False Horned Viper).

Justification: This set is coded for the Welsh botwm 'button' a loan from Middle English botoun 'button' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}). NB: Welsh: North botwm bol 'button-belly' is a calque from English belly-button.

Romance lexemes from Latin machināre ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:423), a denominal verb to Latin machina 'machine, mechanical device', in turn an early loanword from (West) Greek μᾱχανᾱ́ 'id.' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:376).

Comment: The root means "to laugh". The semantic connotation to "prostitute" goes via "to flirt", i.e. "to smile at" someone.

Justification: Loan from Iranic, cf. Av. karš- 'drag, plough' ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:257, {ref HAB} IV:562-563). [MM: Proto-Armenian *karʃ-].
Root reconstruction follows {ref LIV²} 557-558, {ref Kroonen 2013}:440-441. Possibly an extended form of the root *(s)ker- 'to cut', cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:487.

Loanword from Lat. asper 'rough' as a transferred adjective in the phrase nummi aspri 'rough coins', the original semantic development to 'white' appears to have been '(rough) silver' → 'silver-white' → 'white' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:223-224, {ref Beekes 2010}:154, cf. /cognate/1565). In Italiot Greek the semantics further developed 'white' → 'white ash' → 'ash'.
From Classical Armenian kayṙi, of uncertain origin ({ref HAB} II:507-509, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:380). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.

The Goidelic forms in this class from Old Irish bél 'lip; (pl.) mouth' are doubtlessly connected to Middle Welsh gwefl 'lip', but the reconstruction of a Proto-Celtic preform is difficult ({ref Matasović 2009}:419), cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:29 for a survey of older, unconvincing suggestions.

Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *xand- 'to laugh' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:442-443). In view of the Nuristani cognates to this root (cf. 'laugh' in /cognate/68/) we reconstruct Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰand-.
A secondary formation to Welsh synnwyr 'sense, wisdom, sensibleness', borrowed from Latin sentīre 'to perceive' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}.

From Proto-Celtic *kʷrīyet- 'clay, earth, mud'; perhaps be further connected to Lat. crēta 'chalk' but further connections obscure ({ref Matasović 2009}:182-183, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:224).

Possibly related Germanic /cognate/647/ and Celtic /cognate/8304/ lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible. For further discussion, cf. {ref ALEW} 947 (Baltic material), {ref Beekes 2010}:1371 (Greek material), {ref Seebold 1970}:440-441, {ref Kroonen 2013}:458-459 (Germanic material), {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:69-70, {ref Matasović 2009}:281 (Celtic material), {ref Martirosyan 2010}:484 (Armenian material).

Romance lexemes from Latin portāre 'carry' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:554), further probably a denominal verb to Proto-Italic *porto/ā- 'a passage, crossing' and to PIE 1. *per- 'come through, cross' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:482-483, cf. {ref LIV²} 472-473).
Probably an onomatopoeic formation, but cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:522 for some proposed cognates outside of Armenian.
Denominal to Classical Armenian pʿor 'hole, cavity; belly'. Further origin unknown ({ref Olsen 1999}:942, cf. {ref HAB} IV:519). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰor-].
Loanword from Iranic, cf. Sogdian krm’yr 'red' ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:167, {ref HAB} II:558-559, {ref Olsen 1999}:887). [MM: Proto-Armenian *karmir-a-].

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek τραγῳδέω 'to take part in a tragic drama; speak in tragic style, declaim' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1442), a denominal verb to Ancient Greek τραγῳδός 'singer and dancer in the tragic choir, tragic actor'. Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1498 for various suggestions.

Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ῥάχις 'spine, back' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1207). Further etymology outside of Greek disputed; older literature compares to Lith. ražis 'stubble', from a preform *urág̑ʰ-i-, although the supposition of such a form would require postulating *a ~ *ā ablaut (with a full or lengthened grade in ῥᾱχός or ῥηχός) (cf. {ref IEW} 1180, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:968-969, {ref Beekes 2010}:1277-1278).

Comment: < Vedic úpaviśati 'approaches' (RV), 'sits down' (ŚB), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 105, no. 2245: "Contamination with vásati"; for Maithili cf. no. 2249
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic úpaviśati 'approaches' (RV), 'sits down' (ŚBr.), a derivative of Vedic √veś- 'to enter, enter in or settle down on, go into' and further to PIE *u̯ei̯k̑- 'to enter, step in' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:105 no. 2245, {ref EWAia} II:584, {ref LIV²} 669-670).
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *dér-mn̥ '(flayed) skin, leather' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:265-266, {ref Beekes 2010}:318; a derivative of PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split' cf. {ref LIV²} 119-121).

Comment: Extended root *h₁ei̯- (of the "facere" type), attested in Albanian only.

Justification: Possibly related to Celtic /cognate/8304/ and Armenian /cognate/8305/ lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible. Possibly related Germanic /cognate/647/ and Celtic /cognate/8304/ lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible. For further discussion, cf. {ref ALEW} 947 (Baltic material), {ref Beekes 2010}:1371 (Greek material), {ref Seebold 1970}:440-441, {ref Kroonen 2013}:458-459 (Germanic material), {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:69-70, {ref Matasović 2009}:281 (Celtic material), {ref Martirosyan 2010}:484 (Armenian material).

From Proto-Germanic *slihta-, an adjective derived to the strong verb *sleikan- 'to creep, sneak' ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:512-513, {ref Seebold 1970}:428-429), traditionally considered to be an extended form of the root *(s)lei̯- ({ref IEW} 663-664; cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:428-429, {ref Lehmann 1986}:314), cf. {ref LIV²} 566-567 for the revised reconstruction of a separate root *(s)lei̯g̑- 'smear, make smooth'.
Derived from Classical Armenian kełt 'filth'. Further etymology obscure ({ref Olsen 1999}:963, cf. {ref HAB} II:570-571). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kełt-].

Uncertain etymology. Typically explained as a blend of *su̯eh₂du- 'tasty' and *dluku- 'sweet', *su̯eh₂du- 'tasty' or *saldu- 'salty' ({ref Clackson 2017}:113, cf. {ref HAB} IV:546). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kʰałtsʰ-u-(r)].

Ultimately from a diminutive formation from Ancient Greek πέσκος 'skin, rind', no clear etymology outside of Greek, cf. {ref Andriotis 1999}:1168, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:890, {ref Beekes 2010}:1180.

From Latin tālem 'of such kind' acc.sg., ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:705 s.v. talis), further from PIE *teh₂li- 'such', either an adjective derived to the pronominal stem *teh₂- (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:605) or a univerbation of a decollective adverb *téh₂-h₁ with a deictic particle *li (so {ref LIPP 2} 490).

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed. Cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:1001 s.v. Zahl; {ref Kroonen 2013} postulates *dolH- following {ref Kloekhorst 2008} who compares the Germanic forms via ON telja, OE taljan 'to tell' with Hitt. tallii̯e/azi 'to pray, evoke (a deity)'. The connection between the Germanic words and the Hittite verb as well as Greek δόλος 'bait, trick' is accepted by {ref Kroonen 2013}. However, the situation may be more complex with several similar roots side by side, cf. the new entry of *del(H)- ‘ziehen, anziehen’ in {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} where it supposes the Hittite and Greek forms to belong together but not the other words mentioned here.
Connected to Proto-Iranic *kart- 'to cut' by some scholars, however this is difficult to justify semantically (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:243-244 for discussion and references to further literature).

Connection to a common root *gʷʰreh₁- follows {ref LIV²} 221 and {ref Beekes 2010}:1121, but cf. the reservations of {ref EWAia} I:520. For Modern Indic lexemes attached to this set, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:244, no. 4520, p.245 no. 4531; {ref KEWA} I:362. For this Hellenic lexemes in this cognate set, this class encodes the compound element -φραίνομαι.

Many sources link the Slavic lexeme to PIE *kʷer- 'cut, (do/make)' {ref LIV²}. The meaning 'to heat' in Lithuanian kùrti is assumed to arise through an ellipisis of the objects in phrases like 'make a fire'. The Slavic lexeme and the Germanic ones are, however, not listed in LIV {ref LIV²}.
Nor the Slavic lexeme, neither the possible Germanic cognates show any traces of the 'make/do' meaning. Moreover, PS *kuriti has a specified meaning and refers clearly to burning with smoke (pleas note that the Gemanic meaning referring to the 'coal' fits here semantically very well). The Baltic etymology seems to have some formal issues. It seems reasonable to join the view of {ref Derksen 2008} and {Kroonen 2013} and assume a root distinct from *kʷer- 'cut, (do/make)', *kerH- or *kerh₃-.

Connections outside of Germanic uncertain. Generally compared with Baltic material via Lith. klaũpti 'kneel down', etc. (cf. {ref LIV²} 364, {ref Kroonen 2013}:229, 232), but the connection is uncertain on semantic grounds (cf. {ref ALEW} 502-503}).  For older hypotheses, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:259-260, {ref Lehmann 1986}:382-383.
Welsh lexemes continuing PIE *kʷr̥mi- 'worm' ({ref Matasović 2009}:181-182, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'worm' in /cognate/172/.
From Latin grossus 'fat, thick' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:330-331), further etymology unclear (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:273), formerly connected by {ref IEW} 485 with Celtic *brasso- in /cognate/4355/.

Romance lexemes from Latin testa '(pot)sherd, shell' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:719-720, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 13/1:272-283). For the semantic development, cf. similarly within Germanic: NHG Kopf 'head' < MHG kopf 'drinking vessel; skull' in /cognate/3857/. Latin testa 'earthenware vessel, potsherd' is may very well be a prehistoric loanword as suggested by {ref de Vaan 2008}:617, but this hypothesis remains conjectural as there is no known candidate for a source lexeme.

Generally assumed to be a compound based on Old Irish rét 'thing' ({ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:290, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:22-23). Old Irish rét is occasionally compared to Sanskrit rátna- 'possession', but this etymology remains doubtful ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:22-23, {ref Matasović 2009}:309-310, cf. {ref EWAia} II:428-429 s.v. rátna-).
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:13, {ref Matasović 2009}:185); cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} for a survey of older proposals.

To be connected to the same root as Classical Armenian hogi 'spirit, soul', hewam 'I pant, puff; am breathless', probably from a formation *p⁽ʰ⁾eu̯H-io- ({ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:466, {ref HAB} III:115-116, {ref Olsen 1999}:441). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.
Etymology uncertain (cf. {ref HAB} IV:516-517, for further discussion cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:442-443). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰoʃ-i-/-o-].

Hellenic, Armenian, Baltic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃ed- 'to catch scent of (intr.), begin to smell' ({ref LIV²} 296, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1121, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:420, {ref ALEW} 1154, {ref Derksen 2015}:482, {ref de Vaan 2008}:425-426.  For this Hellenic lexemes in this cognate set, this class encodes the compound element *ὀσ-.

Perhaps from IE *kai̯to- ({ref IEW} 521) if inherited and comparable to Germanic terms found in Goth. haiϸi 'field', Engl. heath, etc. These forms are, however, restricted to Celtic and Germanic and we may be dealing with borrowing or (independent) borrowings from a prehistoric NW European substratum language (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:198).

Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian krak 'fire, flames', further origin uncertain, perhaps an Iranian loan ({ref HAB} II:678-679, {ref Olsen 1999}:943), cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:378; cf. s.v. for less likely proposed Indo-European etymologies). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kur-aka-].
As though from Proto-Iranic *kāra- 'people, army' via an intermediary sense 'social group, family' > 'house', cf. Old Persian kāra- 'people, army' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:39).

Comment: The semantic development in Slavic is 'something that waves, nods' > 'plant, flower' (> 'bouquet (Czech)', 'ponytail (Polish)' etc).
Justification: The etymology suggested by {ref ESSJa} points to PIE *keh₂u̯- but is less convincing semantically.
No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. {ref ESSJa} 4: 9-10; 9: 110-111, {ref Derksen 2008}:218-219 for further discussion).
Without clear etymology outside of Germanic; proposed Baltic cognates could well be loans from Germanic ({ref Kroonen 2013}:410; {ref ALEW} 878-879; cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:379-380).
No clear etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Kroonen 2013}:20). For older proposals to Lat. albus 'white' in /cognate/955/, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:100.

Arguably from the original aorist stem to the Classical Armenian suppletive present : aorist pair harkane- : har(e)-. The aorist stem may be derived from 3. *per-, cf. Lithuanian per̃ti 'hit with a bath brush', Latv. pḕrt 'hit', OCS pьrati 'hit; wash' ({ref LIV² 473, cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:215-216 for further discussion). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.
Romance lexemes derived from Latin pēnsāre 'to weigh' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:526, {ref DCECH} IV:503-504), further to be connected to PIE 2. *spend- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:457, cf. {ref LIV²} 578).

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek κοιμάομαι 'go to bed' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:690-691), a secondary denominal verbal formation from an unattested noun *κοιμή or *κοιμός to the same root as the Ancient Greek primary verbal derivative κείμαι 'to lie' from PIE *k̑ei̯- 'to lie' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:509-510, {ref Beekes 2010}:633-634, cf. {ref LIV²} 320).

Comment: TJ: probably identical to set K "*men", cf. Wakhi "mak"
Justification: Etymology uncertain, perhaps related to Avestan maγa- 'cavity' + -k? (cf. {MacKenzie 1990}:115).
As though from Latin *mūkyāre, a denominal verb from a stem *mūc- (cf. Old Irish múchaim 'I hide'), cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002}:6/3:197, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:471).

Root only found in Balto-Slavic ({ref Derksen 2008}:381-382, {ref LIV²} 316-317, cf. also discussion in {ref ALEW} 409-410). For the Slavic forms in this class the initial consonant is a part of a prefix (*ot-), which was subsequently was morphologically re-interpreted in the history of Slavic (*ot-jut- > *o-tjut- > *o-ťut-).

From the original aorist stem to the Classical Armenian suppletive present : aorist pair harkane- : har(e)- (cf. {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:471). The aorist stem may be derived from 3. *per-, cf. Lithuanian per̃ti 'hit with a bath brush', Latv. pḕrt 'hit', OCS pьrati 'hit; wash' ({ref LIV² 473, cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:215-216 for further discussion). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.

Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek ἀέρας, a new α-stem morphologically remodelled from Ancient Greek ἀήρ, ἀέρος 'mist, haze, clouds, atmosphere', and ultimately derived from PIE *h₂eu̯s-er- ({ref Babinotis 2010}:70, {ref Beekes 2010}:27).

Formerly connected to Gk. ἔρχομαι 'go' via *r̥gʰ- (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:15-16, {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:285), now a separate root *h₁erg̑ʰ- (cf. {ref LIV²} 238-239, {ref Schumacher 2004}:548-550).
Etymology unlikely to be with Iranic *nā̆xa- as Persian nāxun ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:56).

Extra-Germanic connections uncertain. Often compared to Lith. mìlšti(s) and other Balto-Slavic forms with various degrees of confidence of the etymology (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:255, {ref Kroonen 2013}:403). {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:453 suggests possibly related ('eventuell'). No lemma for Lith. mìlšti(s) in {ref ALEW} or {ref Derksen 2015}.
Light verb construction, literally 'to make wind' with semantic head bād 'wind' a loanword from from Persian (cf. /cognate/3436/).

Romance lexemes from Latin spissus 'laborious, slow, dense' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:674). Further etymology uncertain; generally compared to the family of lexemes around Greek σπίδιος 'extensive, wide' and Lithuanian 'swarm (of bees)' (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:643, {ref de Vaan 2008}:581). The proposed Baltic connections should be rejected because the root requires an unvoiced dental and is semantically remote (cf. {ref ALEW} 959). The proposed Greek connections might still be possible, but the original semantics of the forms are uncertain (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1382).

Comment: not found in Morgenstierne (1974), cf. Kâta-vari: Eastern: kâk′ok puṇuk [?] which is however sorted under puṇuk < *puṇra-.

Justification: Denominal verbs to Albanian mend 'mind', a borrowing from Latin mentem 'mind' (acc.sg.) ({ref Meyer 1891}:274, {ref Huld 1984}:91, {ref Orel 1998}:256).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *legʰ- 'to lie (oneself) down' via Slavic *ob-log- 'wrap, belay' (cf. {ref Rejzek 2001}:419, {ref ESSJa} 28:17-18, {ref LIV²} 398-399).

Comment: probably related with Parthian wiδān "tent"

Justification: Traditionally considered a derivative of a putative PIE *(s)plei̯g̑ʰ- 'spread the legs' according to {ref IEW} 1000, but the proposed cognates justifying this root reconstruction are very uncertain (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:131-132, {ref KEWA} II:387, {ref Beekes 2010}:1211).
From PIE *treu̯d- 'to strike' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:630, {ref LIV²} 651-652; cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:704).
Probably to be derived to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to turn' (cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:626-628, {ref Adams 2013}:626-628, with references to further literature), but not fully certain (Ron Kim, p.c.).

Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Sanskrit śuṇḍā- 'elephant's trunk' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:725, no. 12516). Further etymology uncertain; probably a loanword from a non-Indo-European source (cf. {ref KEWA} III:354 for discussion of various proposals).
Etymology unlikely to be with Iranic *nā̆xa- as Persian nāxun ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:56).
No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:58); {ref LIV²} 456 mechanically reconstructs PIE ?2. *neu̯d- 'stoßen' (cf. {ref IEW} 767).

Albanian and Italic derivatives from PIE *lei̯g̑- 'to bind'. In this set only Albanian lidh may be a primary verbal derivative, while the Italic and Romance forms probably denominal in origin ({ref LIV²} 403, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:86-87, {ref Demiraj 1997}:242-243, {ref Orel 1998}:226-227, {ref de Vaan 2008}:341, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:407-408).

Comment: Cf. Lith. pur̃vas 'dirt', Latv. pùrvs 'swamp'
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 404, 829).

From Old Irish olc and generally further connected with PIE *u̯ĺ̥kʷo- 'wolf' (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:400, {ref McCone 1985}:173–175; cf. also {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} O:20 for references to older literature).
Loanword from Italian foglietto 'slip, small piece of paper'.

Lexemes derived from the Proto-Germanic. strong verb *reukan- ~ *rūkan- 'to smoke' ({ref Seebold 1970}379-380, {ref Kluge 2011}:748, {ref Kroonen 2013}:406, 410). No further accepted etymology outside of Germanic, cf. further discussion in /cognate/299/.

The origin is obscure. It could be derived from an onomatopoeic interjection. An areal spreading is also not to be excluded. It can not be even assumed that the lexeme or the interjection it is hypothetically derived from had been present already in Proto-Slavic. Cf. {ref ESSJa} 13:81, 139, {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 3:160, 167-170, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 2:433-434 for further discussion. [Cf. also Indic *kutta- in /cognate/1599/, Iranic *kuti- in /cognate/3186/].
Loanword from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian плива 'to swim'.

Hellenic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes traditionally reconciled to a basic root *lei̯- 'smooth', although the Celtic forms here may also require s-mobile (cf. ({ref IEW} 662-664, {ref Falileyev 2000}:103, {ref Matasović 2009}:346, {ref Beekes 2010}:844, {ref de Vaan 2008}:336-337). The Germanic forms derived from PIE *slei̯g̑- 'smear, make smooth' in /cognate/8680/ might be an extended form of this root. See further discussion in that cognate class.

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek ὀμαλός 'equal, level, smooth' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:973), further to be considered a derivative of PIE *sem-, cf. Ancient Greek ὀμός 'common, one and the same, equal, similar, level' < *som-o- ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:799-800, {ref Beekes 2010}:1074-1075).

Comment: For the discussion on the further etymology of PS *koza and its relationship to PIE *ag̑- (cf. Old Indic ajā́) see {ref ESSJa}: 12: 19-21 and 1: 103-104.
Justification: Lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *koza 'goat', and originally in the sense 'goat leather'; further etymology uncertain but probably a Turkic loanword ({ref Derksen 2008}:242, {ref ESSJa} 12:35-36).

From Latin mūsculus 'muscle' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:476), a derivative of Latin mūs 'mouse', from PIE *mūs, (gen. mūsós) (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:424, {ref de Vaan 2008}:396-397). Precise stem analysis difficult; the attested languages consistently show a non-ablauting nom.sg. *mūs, but it is unclear whether this is inherited as such from PIE, or the result of secondary compensatory lengthening from laryngeal loss (e.g., {ref de Vaan 2008}:396-397 assuming a stem *muH-, cf. also {ref EIEC} 387 assuming *mūs < *mus-s).

Russian glaz 'eye' has without any doubt a PS origin (*glazŭ '(small, round,) smooth stone' with a semantic development that has parallels in Slavic, cf. Russian expressive šary 'eyes' < 'ball(s)' or Polish expressive gały 'eyes' < 'ball(s)'). However, the further etymology is uncertain.

Etymology in this class follows {ref NIL} 122-124; traditionally (but dubiously) connected to Greek τυφλός 'blind' ({ref IEW} 264, followed by {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:210-211, {ref Matasović 2009}:107-108, against which cf. {ref NIL} 123n4).
Etymologically obscure (cf. {ref Henning 1971}:29).
Probably a loan from Persian xandīdan 'laugh' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:95).

Comment: The Persian develoment would have been *siš < *ϑiš < *k̑u̯is or *ϑiš < *siš < *k̑u̯is, cf. Klingenschmitt (2000: 202).
Horn (1893: 85) suggests a relation to Avestan tauruna- "young", Old Indic táruṇa- "jung, zart" (probably via "fresh"). Kurdish and Kumzari suggest a simplification of *rn > r.

Justification: Albanian lexemes generally connected with PIE *bʰerh₁g̑- 'shine, gleam' ({ref LIV²} 92), but the precise stem derivation is uncertain (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:27, {ref Huld 1984}:40, {ref Demiraj 1997}:90-91, {ref Orel 1998}:17, {ref Holm 2011}:88-89).
No certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Seebold 1970}:162).
May go back to a root etymon *lei̯g- if connected with Baltic words connected with Lith. lýgus 'even, flat, similar' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:336-337, {ref ALEW} 584-586).
Generally derived from PIE *dʰei̯H- 'to envisage, consider' ({ref LIV²} 141-142, {ref Demiraj 1997}:132-133, {ref Orel 1998}:64-65, {ref Holm 2011}:68-69, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:969).
Loanword from Calabrian Italian manca 'left-hand' (cf. also Greek: Italiot μανκούσο 'left' in /cognate/6082/).

From Old Irish caithid 'use, spend; hurl, throw'; the diverse semantics of the verb make the etymology difficult to explain. Probably further connected to Gaulish cateia, glossed in Servius's commentary to the Aeneid (7.741) as a 'tela gallica' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:24; cf. {ref Delamarre 2003}:110).
