Romance lexemes from Latin mansio 'a staying, a remaining; lodging' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:433, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 6/1:234). Further to PIE 2. *men- 'stay, wait' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:362, cf. {ref LIV²} 437).
Loan from Romance *era < Latin āēr ({ref Meyer 1891}:96, {ref Huld 1984}:62, {ref Orel 1998}:89).

A European isogloss with proposed cognates also in Italic and Slavic; cf. {ref Schrijver 1991}:212-213 for further discussion. The Germanic forms in this class may go back to Proto-Germanic *salwo- as though from PIE *solH-u̯o- (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:466-467, {ref Kroonen 2013}:425), while the Celtic forms require a Proto-Celtic derived stem *salāko- (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:15-16, {ref Matasović 2009}:319).
Loan from Middle Low German scharp, scherp 'sharp' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:806).
Etymology outside of Goidelic uncertain. {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:104 proposed an etymology to a root *krei̯- 'split', but this was rejected by {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:222.

Comment: Wakhi šiš might belong here as well. The assimilation of siš > šiš is frequently attested (for Balochi examples cf. Korn 2005: 180).

Justification: Indic lexemes from Vedic jáṅghā- 'leg', further derived from PIE *g̑ʰengʰ- 'to stride' ({ref EWAia} I:564, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:280 no. 5082, cf. {ref LIV²} 175–176).
No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic, cf. {ref ALEW} 522-523, {ref Derksen 2015}:219, 256-257 for further discussion.

Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic takrá- 'buttermilk with a third part of water' (n.), *'bitter' (adj.) with further semantic developments 'sour' > 'rotten' > 'old' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:319, no. 5617), further to Vedic √tañc- 'to coagulate' from PIE *tenk- ({ref EWAia} I:611-612, 614-165).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ({ref LIV²} 572-573; cf. {ref Adams 2013}:354-355, {ref Beekes 2010}:1012-1013, {ref EWAia} II:769-770, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:39, {ref Cheung 2007}:348-349, {ref de Vaan 2008}:411, {ref Matasović 2009}:348).
Loan from Latin *camba ~ gamba 'leg' ({ref Huld 1984}:80, {ref Orel 1998}:177, {ref Holm 2011}:63).
Loanword from Romance *manctus ({ref Orel 1998}:242). On the semantic development within Romance from Latin mancus 'maimed, crippled' > 'left', cf. discussion in /cognate/2071/.
Possibly to be connected with PIE *s⁽k̑⁾eH- in /cognate/7189/, but the stem-formation in Celtic is difficult to reconcile (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:342-343, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).
Sabellic lexemes continuing a comparative formation derived to PIE *(h₁)ner- ({ref Untermann 2000}:492-493, Scarborough, p.c.).

Romance lexemes as though from Latin *captiāre ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:157), a secondary derivative from Latin capiō 'to take', ultimately from PIE *keh₂p- 'grasp, snatch' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:89-90, cf. {ref LIV²} 344-345).

Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain; possibly further to IE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom, blossom' (so {ref IEW} 122, {ref Matasović 2009}:61; cf. 'leaf' in /cognate/252/, but rejected by {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:50-51, {ref Delamarre 2003}:75). The proposed connection with Latin folium 'leaf' is uncertain (cf. 'leaf' in /cognate/8247/).

PS *rępŭ does not have any certain further IE etymology and cognates. In any case, I do not see any serious reason to treat PS the lexemes with the meaning 'tail' and lexemes referring to various creaky or crackling sounds as two separate etymona. Note that reflexes of *rępiti refer often to playing string instruments (and especially bowed string instruments) and there are also some attestations referring to whiping. That makes, in my opinion, a very good link to 'tail'. We have doubltess an ideophonic root here.

Comment: original meaning "to sting, stab"; Cheung (2007: 362) translates with "game; entertainment; joke" (probably: stab > kill while hunting > game > play) and considers the possibility of a loanword.

Justification: IE root etymology disputed. Two main possibilities: Either to (1) PIE *h₂enh₁- ({ref LIV²} 297-298, so {ref Huld 1984}:63, {ref Orel 1998}:91, and others), or (2) to PIE *h₂ei̯d- ({ref LIV²} 258-259, cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:256-257, {ref Demiraj 1997}:171-172).
Etymology uncertain (for various proposals cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:442-443, {ref DCECH} III:878-881).

Origin uncertain. Of unknown origin according to {ref Olsen 1999}:936. Some Caucasian parallels exist (Archi гьоти 'grass', Udi xod 'tree') although {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:342-343 rather consider it more likely that these are loans from Armenian. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *xot-o-].

Comment: cf. MP kumīg "stomach"
Derivation within (and therefore further connections outside of) Germanic uncertain.
Justification: Connections outside of Germanic uncertain. Frequently considered a derivative of the strong verb *hinϸan- 'grasp, seize' with the original sense of the word being *'grabber', but there are no clear morphological parallels for the stem formation, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:255-256, {ref Lehmann 1986}:176-177, {ref Kluge 2011}, {ref Kroonen 2013}:207-208, 227 for further discussion.
Loan from Turkish keskin 'sharp' (cf. {ref Dawkins 1916}:684).

Comment: cf. Proto-Indo-Iranian *dʱā́rā- f. 'blade, cutting edge' > Vedic dhā́rā- f. 'id.'; cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 789; parallel Indic noun to adjective derivations
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic dhā́ra- 'blade (of a sword, knife)' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:389 no. 6793), further to Proto-Indo-Iranic *dʰā́rā- 'id.', but without certain comparisons outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:789).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic síndhu- 'river; the Indus', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:774 no. 13415, {ref EWAia} II:729-730).

Continuing Proto-Germanic *flaka- 'flat'. Traditionally considered to be a *-g- extended form of the root *pelh₂- (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:199), alternatively {ref Kroonen 2013}:143-144 proposes cognacy to Greek πλάξ, -ακός 'plane, plain; flat stone, board table' < *pl̥k-; Lithuanian plãkanas, Latvian plakans 'flat' < *plokono- (cf. also {ref ALEW} 785-786, reconstructing *pleh₂k- 'mit flacher Hand schlagen, klatschen').

Uncertain origin. Possibly an Iranian loanword (perhaps) via (inner-Armenian) *ba(δ)r-ii̯o/a- (cf. Skt. bhadrá- 'blessed, fortunate; happy; Av. hu-baδra- 'extremely happy'); cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:436. Cf. {ref HAB} I:422-424. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *bar-i̯o-].

Comment: Bailey (1979: 19b)  connects this word to Saka ā̮ye 'ground, sole of foot' from āy- with Av. āi. He mentions a reconstruction by Morgenstierne (1942) proposed for NP xāk from *āhaka- 'ashes', which is followed by Klingenschmitt (2000: 213, fn.77).

Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *√tej- 'to sharpen' from PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'prick, be sharp' ({ref EWAia} I: 645, 668-669, cf. {ref LIV²} 592-593). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes attached to this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:332-333, no. 5839.

The sources are, in general, consistent as to further IE cognates of PS *gniti 'rot'. A minor formal issue is, however, the reconstruction of the underlying PIE root. In {ref Derksen 2008} a form with initial *g̑ʰ- is given, the other sources give a form with *gʰ-, e.g. {ref ESSJa}: 177, {ref Rejzek 2001}: 205, {ref Boryś 2005}: 168, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 1: 153, cf. also {ref Kroonen 2013}: 183. A question is, if PS *znojĭ 'heat, sweat' is related. If so, a variation *g̑ʰ- / *gʰ- should be assumed, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}: 546, {ref Rejzek 2001}: 740, {ref Boryś 2005}: 744.

Previously considered without a clear etymology by {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:164-165), see now {ref LIV²} 538-539, {ref Schumacher 2004}:605-607, {ref Matasović 2009}:360 to PIE *seu̯h₁- 'incite, set in motion'.

From PIE *meu̯h₂ or *meu̯h₃- according to {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:587-588 (cf. Gk. μῡ́ω 'to close the eyes'; {ref Oettinger 1979}:161ff.); the proposed Greek comparandum is listed under ?*meu̯s- in {ref LIV²} (only Greek), and may formally reflect either *meu̯H- or *meu̯s- (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:988).

Comment: not found in Korn 2005, onset speaks in favour of a loanword

Justification: From PIE *(s)lei̯-, perhaps via an extended variant *(s)lei̯b- (cf. {ref LIV²} 566 s.v. ?*(s)lei̯b- 'scheifen, gleiten', only Germanic), cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:134, {ref Deshayes 2003}:458, {ref Matasović 2009}:239, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}.
A loanword from Dardic languages ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:47, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:637, no. 10991 *laṣṭi- 'stick').
As though from Latin *trīnicāre 'divide into three' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 13/2:277-285). Further to PIE *trei̯- 'three' (cf. /cognate/146/).

Indic lexemes, probably originally *lavaná- 'cutting' derived to Vedic √lav- 'cut' < PIE *leu̯H- 'cut off, release' ({ref EWAia} II:475-476, cf. {ref LIV²} 417). For the Middle and Modern Indic forms attached to this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:637, no. 10978.

From Proto-Iranic *tanč- 'to twist (together), become narrow, dense, constrict', further to PIE *temk- 'to become firm, coagulate' ({ref Cheung 2007}:377-378, {ref LIV²} 625, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:82).
Loan from Italian liscio 'smooth'.

NB: The Hittite lexeme is somewhat dubious in this meaning (cf. {ref CHD P}, s.v.); Etymology unclear: According to {ref HED PA}, from the same stem as Hitt. partāu̯ar 'wing' from PIE *(s)per- in /cognate/5101/, cf. also cautiously Tischler, Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar, Vol. 2, p.506; however unconnected by {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:646-647.
To be connected with Old Irish uis 'sweet, suitable, appropriate', but further etymology obscure ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} U:21-22).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic nāḍī́- 'tubular stalk of any plant' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:404-405, no. 7047). Further etymology difficult, cf. {ref KEWA} II:127-129 for various possibilities.

The original meaning was 'a part of the body an animal can chase away (literally 'sweep away') insects with', cf. direct attestations of this motivation in {ref ESSJa} 28:141-142. There is no commonly accepted etymology outside of Slavic; all further proposals have formal issues ({ref Derksen 2008}:389, {ref Rejzek 2001}:440, cf. also {ref Boryś 2005}:406-407, {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 4:897-898, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}).

Derived from Old Irish cas 'curly, woven, twisted'; formerly proposed to PIE *kes- 'to comb' (so {ref IEW} 585, but the -a- vocalism is difficult to account for ({ref Matasović 2009}:194; cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:44-45 for a survey of earlier hypotheses.

Traditionally to PIE *sem- 'one, a unity' (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:715, with references to earlier literature), but alternatively to PIE *(s)k̑ens- (cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:925-926, {ref EWAia} II:836). The traditional etymology is not impossible, although the initial ṣ- is unexpected, and does not account for the root final *-s- (Ron Kim, p.c.), therefore the latter etymology is more preferable.

Armenian denominal verbs from Classical Armenian ors 'hunt, catch; hunted animal, game'. Further etymology uncertain. Traditionally compared with Greek πόρκος 'a kind of fish trap' (cf. {HAB} III:588, {ref Olsen 1999}:13), but disputed by others (cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:164 and {ref Martirosyan 2010}:544 for further discussion and alternative propsals). [MM: Proto-Armenian *ors-].

Romance lexemes from Latin occīdere 'strike down, knock down' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:495), possibly further to PIE *kh₂ei̯d- 'hit, beat' (cf. {ref LIV²} 360, {ref de Vaan 2008}:79-80) for further discussion).
Connections outside of Albanian uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:120, {ref Orel 1998}:481, {ref Holm 2011}:55-56 for various attempts at an IE root etymology and further discussion.

Comment: complex verb, no etymological information on Sarikoli 'kat' in Morgenstierne (1974) and Cheung (2007); maybe metathesis < *tak ?

Justification: Probably a loanword from Dravidian, cf. Tamil kaluḻ- 'become turbid', Kannada kaluhe 'dirt' ({ref KEWA} I:182).

The history of the Slavic lexeme(s) for 'shadow' is complicated. It can not be excluded that we deal here with one single etymon. However, we had to assume irregular phonetic changes, contaminations and taboo-deformation in this case. It is also possible that we deal here with two or three independent etyma even from the most deep etymology perspective. Only PS *sěnĭ has a convincing further IE etymology and cognates that are relatively unproblematic from the phonetic point of view. PS *těnĭ and *stěnĭ can be derivatives of / results of a contamination with PIE *temH- 'dark' {ref LIV²}: 624 or PIE *stei̯h₂- 'stiffen' < probably PIE *steh₂- 'stand' {ref Kroonen 2013}: 472.

Celtic and Indic lexemes from a root *g̑ʰers-/*g̑ʰres- ({ref EWAia} II:823), traditionally considered to be derived from an s-extended form of the root *g̑ʰer- 'short, small, slight' (cf. {ref IEW} 443, {ref de Bernardo Stempel 1999}:68n57; not in {ref Matasović 2009}).

Comment: no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974), surely identical with Wakhi bayd; cf. Arabic beyt "verse (consisting of two half verses)"

Justification: Attestation restricted to West Germanic, without clear comparisons outside of Germanic (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:406, {ref Kluge 2011}:794).
Loanword from Latin sella 'seat, saddle' ({ref Orel 1998}:407).
For the root ref. form as *(s)k̑eNs- with s-mobile, cf. discussion in /cognate/5451/.

Comment: Bailey (1979: 19b)  connects this word to Saka ā̮ye 'ground, sole of foot' from āy- with Av. āi. He mentions a reconstruction by Morgenstierne (1942) proposed for NP xāk from *āhaka- 'ashes', which is followed by Klingenschmitt (2000: 213, fn.77).
Justification: Identical to a word for 'ashes' with special development of the semantics
Etymology unknown. {ref Melchert 1994}:132 compares Lat. surcus 'twig, sprout', but {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:792-793 argues that the Latin comparandum is a ghost word.

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek χονδρός 'granular, coarse' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1604-1605). Further etymology unexplained, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1268-1269, {ref Beekes 2010}:1643 for various hypotheses.

Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed {ref LIV²}. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated {ref Smoczyński 2007} and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek {ref Beekes 2010}. I assume the root *peu̯H-, cf. PG *fūla- 'filthy, foul' {ref Kroonen 2013}. The meaning 'dust' could develop from 'rotten wood'. Cf. {ref Rejzek 2001}.
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *deh₁- 'to bind' ({ref Beekes 2010}:321-322, {ref LIV²} 102, cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:338).

Of uncertain origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:942), traditionally connected with Proto-Slavic *bedro- (cf. {ref IEW} 96, {ref HAB} IV:101, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:642). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *port-o-].
From Ancient Greek ἀ-κάθαρτος 'un-cleansed' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:604); no further etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:478-479; {ref Beekes 2010}:614-615)

Italiot τσ̌υλι(μ)μένο (< *κυλι(σ)μένος), the passive participle of τσ̌υλίω /τσ̌υλλίτζω ‘to roll (on a dirty surface), to make dirty’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c., cf. {ref Rohlfs 1964}:282-283). Further etymology disputed: possibly to IE *kʷel(h₁)- ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:598, cf. {ref LIV²} 386-388), but cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:800, who sees the word based on a substratum borrowing.
Internal reconstruction points to a root *tu̯eh₂p-, *ti̯eh₂p- or *⁽k̑⁾i̯eh₂p- ({ref LIV²} 361 reconstructs *Ki̯eh₂p-), but no cognates are known outside of Greek ({ref Beekes 2010}:1324).

The IE root etymology for this class is disputed. It seems equally plausible that the Italic forms from Lat. folium can go with either the Germanic and Greek words for 'leaf' from *bʰleh₃- in /cognate/252/, or with the Celtic words for 'leaf' from *dʰal(h₁)- in /cognate/1025/; cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:244; {ref de Vaan 2008}:230. For the Romance lexemes in this class cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:293-294.
Loanword from Modern Persian γaš(š) 'stupor, deceiving'(?) ({ref Morgenstierne 1974}:37).
Loanword from Latin sella 'seat, saddle' ({ref Orel 1998}:407).
Parallel loans from Arabic خراب / kharāb 'destruction, ruin' (via Persian?).
Loanword from Persian rušt 'brightly coloured' ({ref Morgenstierne 1974}:69).

The Hittite stem is paradigmatically suppletive; this cognate set is coded for 3.sg.pres.act. tēzzi < *dʰeh₁-ti ≠ ter-/tar- (< PIE *ter- 'to speak'), cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:857–858, 870–871; {ref LIV²} 136-138.
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *seh₁dʰ- 'to reach the goal, be successful' ({ref EWAia} II:722-723, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:773 no. 13401, cf. {ref LIV²} 517).

Etymology outside of Anatolian disputed. In spite of phonological and morphological difficulties, generally connected to Tocharian lexemes in /cognate/7599/ ({ref LIV²} 229, {ref Adams 2013}:107, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:542-543). The reconstruction *h₁ai̯-, however, is unusual from the reconstructed *-a- in the root. *h₂ei̯- would work for the Tocharian lexemes, but initial or medial *h₂ should have been preserved as -ḫḫ- in Hittite, and therefore this reconstruction is unsatisfactory. {ref Adams 2013}:107 reconstructs a root *h₄ei̯-, but the reconstruction of a phoneme *h₄ (an a-colouring laryngeal which left no traces in Hittite) is not commonly accepted. In view of the phonological difficulties in connecting of the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:614-616 prefers to split the Anatolian cognates as a derivative of Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'seize' with an ablauting suffix *-ói̯-/-i-´ (i.e. 3.sg. h₁p-ói̯-ei, 3.pl. *h₁p-i-énti). While the semantic connection between the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes for a root 'give' is tempting, the difficulties of reconciling the root etymology from a phonological and morphological point of view, it is methodologically more preferable to split the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes into separate cognate sets. Proposed cognacy between the two classes has been set at 4/6 – small majority view.

From Classical Armenian šowkʿ 'shadow', further etymology uncertain ({ref HAB} III:541, cf. {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:595 for a more recent proposal). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}, no etymology given in {ref Olsen 1999}:17. [MM: Proto-Armenian *ʃukʰ-o-].

Etymology uncertain. {ref HED A+E/I}:260-261 suggests to *ei̯-gʰ- ({ref IEW} 296) : Lith. eigà 'a going', Gk. οἴχομαι 'go off, be gone', ἴχνος 'footstep, track', TochB yku 'gone', thus egdu < *ei̯gʰ-tu- 'a going' > 'leg' by metonymy, but this is speculative. No lemma in {ref Kloekhorst 2008}.

Generally considered a loanword from South Slavic, possibly via the Ikavian dialect of Serbo-Croatian ({ref Jokl 1923}:177, 187-188, {ref Orel 1998}:229, cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:247), but cf. {ref Huld 1984}:87 who proposes an IE etymology. (Not in {ref Demiraj 1997}).

Etymology disputed. In spite of phonological and morphological difficulties, generally connected to Tocharian lexemes in /cognate/7599/ ({ref LIV²} 229, {ref Adams 2013}:107, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:542-543). The reconstruction *h₁ai̯-, however, is unusual from the reconstructed *-a- in the root. *h₂ei̯- would work for the Tocharian lexemes, but initial or medial *h₂ should have been preserved as -ḫḫ- in Hittite, and therefore this reconstruction is unsatisfactory. {ref Adams 2013}:107 reconstructs a root *h₄ei̯-, but the reconstruction of a phoneme *h₄ (an a-colouring laryngeal which left no traces in Hittite) is not commonly accepted. In view of the phonological difficulties in connecting of the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:614-616 prefers to split the Anatolian cognates as a derivative of Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'seize' with an ablauting suffix *-ói̯-/-i-´ (i.e. 3.sg. h₁p-ói̯-ei, 3.pl. *h₁p-i-énti). While the semantic connection between the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes for a root 'give' is tempting, the difficulties of reconciling the root etymology from a phonological and morphological point of view, it is methodologically more preferable to split the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes into separate cognate sets. Proposed cognacy between the two classes has been set at 4/6 – small majority view.

Latin cōgitō 'to think, consider', a derived frequentative/intensive form of Latin agō 'to drive' < PIE *h₂eg̑- ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:15-18, {ref de Vaan 2008}:30-31). For the Romance forms in this class cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 2:838-842, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:192.

Comment: From Lat. narrāre.
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin narrāre 'to relate, tell' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:481), further to PIE *g̑neh₃- 'know' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:267, {ref LIV²} 168-170).
Parallel loans from Turkish pis 'filthy, dirty'.
Loanword from Tajik vayron 'destroyed, devestated', cf. Middle Persian awērān "devastated".

Comment: Sanskritisms, cf. Old Bengali chāa ~ chāva 'shade', Hindi chāī̃, see Turner 1962-66, p. 257f., no. 5027
Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit chāyā- 'shadow'.

Romance lexemes from Latin mancus 'maimed, crippled' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:431), perhaps further derived from Latin manus 'hand' in /cognate/888/ (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:382, {ref de Vaan 2008}:361 for further discussion).
Probably based on a loanword from Latin crucem 'crosswise, askew' ({ref Orel 1998}:183); earlier {ref Meyer 1891}:188 supposed a loan from Latin cortīna 'round vessel, cauldron'.

The history of the Slavic lexeme(s) for 'shadow' is complicated. It can not be excluded that we deal here with one single etymon. However, we had to assume irregular phonetic changes, contaminations and taboo-deformation in this case. It is also possible that we deal here with two or three independent etyma even from the most deep etymology perspective. Only PS *sěnĭ has a convincing further IE etymology and cognates that are relatively unproblematic from the phonetic point of view. PS *těnĭ and *stěnĭ can be derivatives of / results of a contamination with PIE *temH- 'dark' {ref LIV²}: 624 or PIE *stei̯h₂- 'stiffen' < probably PIE *steh₂- 'stand' {ref Kroonen 2013}: 472.
Loanword from Latin saburra 'sand; ship's ballast' ({ref Meyer 1891}:420, {ref Orel 1998}:527).
Modern Greek and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *kʷei̯- 'to gather, pile' (cf. {ref LIV²} 378-379, {ref Andriotis 1974}:458, {ref Beekes 2010}:1216, {ref Derksen 2008}:89, {ref ESSJa} 4:112-115).

Slavic innovation (maybe taboo-motivated) without certain etymology. There are two most popular hypotheses on its etymology: 1) *demh₂- 'build' > 'wood used/good for building' > 'oak'; 2) *dʰu̯eh₂- 'smoke' > 'dark' > 'tree with dark wood'. {ref ESSJa} links it to *dʰeu̯b- 'deep' > 'lowland tree'. None of the versions seems to be really convincing.

Comment: Loan from Turkish
Justification: Loanword from Turkish kafa 'back of the head' ({ref Huld 1984}:106, {ref Orel 1998}:353, {ref Holm 2011}:72-73).

Of uncertain etymology ({ref Olsen 1999}:963, cf. {ref HAB} II:556-557), but cf. {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010} considering a possible Iranian loanword, following the suggestion of {ref Bailey 1979}:65. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.

Romance lexemes from Latin iocāri 'to joke, jest' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:374, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 5:36-41), a denominal verb to Latin iocus 'joke, jest' and further to PIE *i̯ek- 'speak' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:308, cf. {ref LIV²} 311).

Comment: lex., cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3228; Prakrit kuḍa- m. 'tree'

Justification: Lexemes derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear; to die' ({ref LIV²} 439-440). Note that the semantic extension 'to disappear' as a euphemism 'to die' appears to be a post-Anatolian innovation, where the Hittite cognate mer-/mar- retains the original meaning 'to disappear' (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:8).

Comment: not found in Morgenstierne (1974)
Justification: Etymology uncertain. [Not in {ref Morgenstierne 1974}].
Loanword (source?), well attested among Pamir languages; cf. Nuristani Vâsi-vari: Paṣki "li-" /cognate/7909/. Cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:42.
Possibly a loan from Indic? (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:62).
Loanword from Persian سایه / sāyeh 'shadow'.

Always written using the Sumerograms LÚ.ŠU.GI, but probably to be related to Hitt. mēḫur 'time, period', from which a stem *meḫuu̯ant- can be reconstructed on the basis of derived vocabulary ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:568-569, cf. derived factitive verb meḫuu̯andaḫḫ- 'to make old; to age', etc.). Further root etymology disputed. According to {ref Eichner 1973}:53-107, ultimately to PIE *meh₂- 'to be at the right time'; {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:567-568 to *mei̯h₂- 'disappear' (= {ref LIV²} 1. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, verschwinden sein'), or to *meh₁- 'measure' (semantically better, but formally more difficult). {ref Yakubovich 2011}:277-279 argues to *meh₁-, with the presence of Hitt. -ḫ- explained by secondary epenthesis.

Lit. 'to throw, cast out'. Cognacy is coded for the verbal head cuir 'throw' from Old Irish -cuirethar (cf. eDIL); synchronically suppletive to fo·ceird 'throw' within Irish but from the same Indo-European root ({ref LIV²} 353-355, cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:401-403), for older hypotheses cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:276-277.

Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated {ref Smoczyński 2007} and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek {ref Beekes 2010}.

Comment: Schmitt (2014: 278): "Offenbar handelt es sich um eine jüngere Ersatzbildung für ein Erbwort und am wahrscheinlichsten um eine -ka-Ableitung von heteroklitischem *vaz-r̥/*vaz-n- „Kraft, Größe“; es gehört dann letztlich zu der Wurzel idg. *u̯eǵ „kräftig sein/werden“." Schmitt emphasises that connections to vazra- "weapon" are to be discarded.

Justification: Perhaps PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the BSl. acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾- ({ref Derksen 2008}:243, {ref Derksen 2015}:231-232), but connections outside of Balto-Slavic ultimately uncertain; perhaps PIE *kʷend- according to {ref ALEW}, but likewise extra-Balto-Slavic connections uncertain. Cf. also {ref ESSJa} 12:65-66.

Origin uncertain, traditionally connected with PIE *peh₂u̯- 'few; little', but the connection is phonetically difficult to justify (cf. discussion in {ref Olsen 1999}:165). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰokʰ-u-(r)].
Romance lexemes from Latin eruncāre ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:258), further to PIE *h₃reu̯k- 'to dig, pluck (out)' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:530, {ref LIV²} 307).

Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed  {ref LIV²}. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated {ref Smoczyński 2007} and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek {ref Beekes 2010}.

Romance lexemes from Latin pulsāre 'to strike, beat' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:566-567), secondary from Latin pellere 'beat against, push, strike', further to PIE *pelh₂- 'to approach' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:455-456, {ref LIV²} 470-471).

Root etymology disputed. Either to *h₁es- 'throw' ({ref LIV²} 2. *h₁es-; cf. {ref Kimball 1987}; {ref Kimball 1999}:215, 391; {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:670-671 with references to earlier literature), alternatively others (cf. {ref Melchert 1994}:133) see a connection with the Hittite verb šii̯e/a- 'to shoot' and šai- 'to press' (cf. {ref LIV²} 1. *seh₁(i̯)-). Cf. also {ref HED PE, PI, PU} 27-37, Tischler, Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar, Vol. 2, pp.581-584.
Loanword from Italian mangiare 'to eat'.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, to chop' ({ref LIV²} 555, {ref Derksen 2008}:233, {ref ESSJa} 11:18-20).
Etymology uncertain, doubtful suggestion as though from Proto-Iranic ?*xā(ha)xa- by {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:79.
Parallel loans from Persian صاف / sāf 'smooth', ultimately from Arabic.
Loanword from Calabrian Italian uχχare 'to blow up, swell'.

A derivative from Latin marcere 'be withered' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:436), perhaps further to PIE *merk- if related to Vedic √marc- 'damage, hurt' and Hittite markii̯e/a- 'to disapprove of, refuse' (so {ref de Vaan 2008}:364-365), but cf. {ref EWAia} II:323-324, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:559).

Latin and Romance lexemes derived from PIE *peh₂u̯- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:448, 450-451, although note that Catalan poc directly continues Latin paucus 'few, small in number', not Latin paruus 'small' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:519).

Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed  {ref LIV²}. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated {ref Smoczyński 2007} and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek {ref Beekes 2010}.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *reu̯H- 'to tear (up)' ({ref LIV²} 510, {ref Derksen 2008}:442).

Romance lexemes from Latin lanceāre ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:396), a denominal verb to Latin lancea 'lance'. Further etymology uncertain, possibly a Celtic loanword ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:339-340).
No clear etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Lehmann 1986}:389, {ref Kroonen 2013}:555. For older proposed connections to Baltic material, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:525.

Comment: cf. Khowar tseq and Khotanese d͜ze̤i̯ṇa; maybe same stem but different suffix? Some West Iranic languages have diminutive suffixes with -l-. (Wakhi ʒ seems to stand for d͜z)
no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974)

Justification: Loan from Venetian.
Loan from Kâta-vari: Ktivi čʹum 'skin, hide'.

A denominal formation originating in Middle English. There are some possible correspondences, cf. {ref Orel 2003}:57 for some proposals and references to older literature, but ultimately no clear etymology outside of Germanic. {ref Kroonen 2013}:74-75 does not provide comparanda to support a root reconstruction *bʰreh₁- (not in {ref LIV²}).
Loanword from either Italian or Venetian mosca 'fly'.

Romance lexemes from Latin sabulum 'sand' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:619). Earlier literature (cf. {ref Buck 1949}:22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- /cognate/284/, Greek ἄμμος /cognate/8262/, and Lat. sabulum /cognate/8263/ together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in {ref EIEC} objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in /cognate/8261/ are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Generally derived from PIE *h₁ep- 'grasp, seize' ({ref Demiraj 1997}:79, {ref Orel 1998}:157, {ref Holm 2011}:64, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:978, {ref LIV²} 237); perhaps further connected to Anatolian lexemes in /cognate/7598/ if the etymology of {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:614-616 is correct, but this remains disputed (cf. notes in that class).

Root reconstruction follows {ref LIV²} 676, {ref ALEW} 1242-1243; cf. {ref ALEW} 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and {ref Matasović 2009}:427 s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic.

IE root etymology uncertain. According to {ref Orel 1998}:145) to PIE *selk- (tentatively cf. {ref LIV²} 530-531); according to {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:974-976) a straightforward derivation from PIE *selk- is impossible and may represent a contamination of *selk- (cf. /cognate/451/) and *h₂u̯elk- (cf. /cognate/5274/); alternatively Schumacher & Matzinger suggest possibly *sk̑ek- with contamination of -l- in the Old Tosk form of the root (see now {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).

Some aspects of the root reconstruction are disagreed upon (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:383 s.v. Lat. mītis), but generally the cognacy of the Celtic and Italic lexemes are agreed. {ref Matasović 2009}:278-279 suggests an alternative etymology s.v. Proto-Celtic *moyni- 'treasure, precious object' for potentially connected lexemes (W mwyn 'mild, tender, gentle', MoBret. moan 'tender, thin', OCo. muin 'thin' < *mēnV- < *meyHnV-), but is cryptic as to whether OIr. mín also should belong to this alternative etymology (not mentioned under the lemma for *moyni-).

The Goidelic forms in this class are from a compound imm·beir < Proto-Celtic *ambi- (preverb) 'around' (< PIE *h₂(e)mbʰi- or ámbʰi) + *ber- 'carry' (< PIE *bʰer-), cf. {Schumacher 2004}:218-233, {ref Matasović 2009}:62, {ref LIV²} 76-77, {ref LIPP 2} 36.
Denominal verbs from a Germanic loanword *stakka 'stake, vine stake' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:678, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 17:195-206).
Loanword from Venetian casar 'to hunt'.
Loanword from Venetian rosso.
Loan from Venetian.
Loanword from Venetian.

Comment: check for an PIE etymology

Justification: Origin uncertain according to {ref Olsen 1999}:942, a loanword from Caucasian according to {ref HAB} II:470-471. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsux-o-].
Loan from Italian serpente 'snake'.
Loanword from Venetian dolze 'sweet'.
Loanword from Italian nuotare 'to swim'.

Possibly to IE *kʷu̯ap- (or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-) if to be compared with Lat. vapor 'steam, exhalation', Gk. καπνός 'smoke' ({ref ALEW} 545-546, {ref Derksen 2015}:268), but these connections are not fully certain due to several irregular sound-changes needed to justify the comparison.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10187 s.v. 11./12. *moṭṭ(h)a- 'big, fat'; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
Some sources (cf. Derksen) suggest that the Polish word is an East Slavic (Ukrainian) loanword. The attestation is relatively late and there are some not fully certain phonetic clues.

Justification: Romanian neted is from Latin nitidus 'bright, shining' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), but further connections outside of Italic are obscure ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:442, {ref de Vaan 2008}:410).

Indo-Iranic lexemes generally connected to Latin orbus 'deprived of, childless, orphaned', Greek ὀρφανός 'orphaned' ({ref EWAia} I:119-120, {ref KEWA} I:52, cf. also {ref Weiss 2006}:256n30, {ref de Vaan 2008}:433, {ref Beekes 2010}:1113-1114).

Romance lexemes as though from Latin *nōdicāre 'to knot' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 7:169, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:489), a verbal derivative from Latin nōdus 'knot'. Further root etymology uncertain, possibly to Germanic lexemes meaning 'net', cf. Gothic nati, Old Icelandic nót 'net' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:412, {ref Kroonen 2013}:384, {ref Lehmann 1986}:263-264 for further discussion).
A formation probably of onomatopoeic origin, originally in the sense 'chat, prattle', later generalised as the generic verb 'to say' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:615-616, {ref Beekes 2010}:827-828).
Parallel loans from Arabic ﺣﺴﺐ / ḥasiba 'to reckon, count'.
Loan from Italian penna 'pen, feather, quill, plume'.
Loanword from Venetian.

Etymology uncertain; {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:101 suggests *fšatā- 'combed' (?); if so cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:92 for a further root etymology to Proto-Iranic *fšan- 'to drag, tear, split'? Further etymological connections uncertain.

A probable Mediterranean substratum word ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:42-43, cf. also {ref Falileyev 2000}:22, {ref Deshayes 2003}:373). Perhaps cognate with Armenian kʻar in /cognate/651/, but ultimately uncertain. Cf. notes in that class for further discussion. If this is the same substratum word as in Armenian, it is difficult to determine whether this was a single loan event or parallel loan events.
Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vaṇṭa- 'tailless' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:655, no. 11236), further etymology obscure (cf. {ref KEWA} III:131, {ref EWAia} II:206).

Comment: cf. Marathi ṭaṇaka (7579); Morgenstierne (1974: 82) quotes H. W. Bellew: Vocabulary of Sarigh Culi, etc., in Forsyth, Report on a mission to Yarkund 1873, Calcutta 1876 with "teyáng".
*b would > Sarikoli v; Sarikoli b < *p/V_V; cf. Persian bū < Middle Persian bōy

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic, although a connection with Germanic words for 'fox' (cf. OHG fuhs) remains worth considering ({ref EWAia} II:140, {ref KEWA} II:298; cf. also discussion in {ref Kroonen 2013}:157-158). For Middle and Modern Indic cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:467, no. 8249.

Romance lexemes are based on a denominal verb derived from Latin *colpus 'strike, blow' (Classical Latin colaphus) ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:193), further a loanword from Ancient Greek κόλαφος 'slap, buffet' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:131).

Origin uncertain. Since {ref Pedersen 1905}:220 connected with OIr. carrac 'rock', further compared to Classical Sanskrit karkara- 'hard, firm', Greek κάρκαρος 'prison' by {ref HAB} IV:558-560, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:778. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:685-686 considers a substratum loanword which is also shared with Germanic via pre-Proto-Germanic *karko/u- *'stony rise (where cultic rites were practiced)" (> OE hearg, OHG harug, OIc. harg), comparable to Armenian Kʻarkʻē the name of a mountain of religious importance. Cf. also {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:42-43 who rather assumes a Western Mediterranean substratum origin for the proposed Celtic cognates. If this is the same substratum word as in Celtic and/or Germanic, it is difficult to determine whether this was a single loan event or parallel loan events.

Comment: related to xvaēδa- swet? < PIE *su̯ei̯d ? EWAia 799 (Vol. II)

Justification: From Ancient Greek ὀξεῖα, the feminine stem of Ancient Greek ὀξύς (adj.) 'sharp' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:411). Root etymology disputed. Traditionally to IE *h₂ek̑- 'sharp' (cf. {ref IEW} 21-22, {ref Buck 1949}:1069, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:806-807), but this is difficult from a morphological point of view. Alternatively {ref Narten 1986}:204-214 has proposed a comparison with Ved. √akṣ- which could allow a Greek zero-grade formation *h₃k̑s- > ὀξ-, but this proposal has not been met with widespread acceptance (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1089).
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *mē(m)s- 'meat' ({ref NIL} 486-488, {ref Beekes 2010}:947).

Armenian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *leh₂- 'to bark'. The assignment of Armenian forms to this class follows {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:104-105, {ref LIV²} 400-401 (not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}); for Iranic cf. {ref EWAia} II:443, {ref Cheung 2007}:306.
Loanword from Venetian caldo 'hot'.
Loanword from Arabic رمل / raml 'sand' (cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:190).

No certain etymology. All existing hypotheses need special assumptions that are not impossible but hard to prove (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:80, 83, {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 6:203, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 4:267).

As though from Latin *plantāre, a verbal derivative from Latin planta 'sole of the foot' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:546), further to PIE *pleh₂- 'be flat, even' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:470, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:512, {ref NIL} 562-564).
Etymology uncertain. For various proposals and further discussion, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:86, {ref Demiraj 1997}:240-241, {ref Orel 1998}:211-212, 222, {ref Holm 2011}:79).
No clear etymology. Perhaps from PIE *h₃st-dʰ- (cf. Gk. ὀσφύς 'loins') an extension of PIE *h₃ost- 'bone' but this remains an uncertain conjecture ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:10, {ref Olsen 1999}:149).
An isolated archaic r/n-stem, probably connected with Vedic dhánuṣ- 'bow' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:210, {ref EWAia} I:773-774).
Balkan loanword from Albanian or Thraco-Dacian (cf. {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, {ref Schulte 2009}:252).
Probably a borrowing from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian vrtjeti 'spin', Bulgarian въртя 'turn' + prefix în- (cf. {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
Loan from Middle German komen 'to come' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:271-273).
Indic lexemes derived from PIE *Herd- (cf. {ref LIV²} 223-224, {ref EWAia} I:117-118). For Modern Indic lexemes connected to this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:60, no. 1340.

Within Albanian borë 'snow' is generally linked to bie 'fall' following {ref Jokl 1916}:93, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:45-46, {ref Demiraj 1997}:106-107, {ref Orel 1998}:32. For etymology of Alb. bie < PIE *bʰerH-, cf. {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:966 and further references in /cognate/388/.

Romance lexemes are based on a denominal verb derived from Latin *colpus 'strike, blow' (Classical Latin colaphus) ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:193), further a loanword from Ancient Greek κόλαφος 'slap, buffet' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:131).

Slavic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *pleh₂g- 'to beat'. There is anomalous devoicing of the velar in Slavic, but the two variants *pleh₂g- and ?*pleh₂g- are accepted to be the same root by {ref LIV²} 484-485). Cf. also {ref Derksen 2008}:402, {ref Boryś 2005}:443, {ref de Vaan 2008}:469-471.
Loanword from Old French crier ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

The IE etymology for the lexemes in this class follows {ref Schrijver 1995}:170-171, also followed by {ref Matasović 2009}:73, and {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, occasionally connected by others to Lat. marcēre, cf. {ref Schrijver 1995}:170 for further discussion.

Khowar gaan 'wind' from Old Indic gandhá- 'smell, scent' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:221, no. 4131). To be separated from comparable lexemes in Iranic (cf. Av. gaiṇti- 'bad smell', Parthian gndʾg 'stinking' etc.), but no secure connections outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:461-462).

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek ἐξερέω 'I speak out, utter' with semantic shift to 'spew out, vomit' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:948), further to PIE *h₁reh₁- ({ref LIV²} 251, but cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:391-392).

Comment: *(h₃)lig-o-
Justification: Connected since {ref Meyer 1891}:245 to Greek ὀλίγος 'few, little', Lith. ligà 'illness', cf. {ref Huld 1984}:87, {ref Demiraj 1997}:243, {ref Orel 1998}:227.

Origin uncertain (cf. {ref HAB} III:341). Perhaps related to Classical Armenian mowx 'smoke' of uncertain etymology (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:33 and further discussion in /cognate/8305/). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *moxir-o-].
Derived within English, with metathesis, from Middle English drit + -y suffix, probably originally a loan from Old Norse drit 'excrement' ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Romance lexemes from Latin curtus 'short' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:225, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 2:1585-1588); further root etymology uncertain, either to 2. *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' ({ref LIV²} 556-557, {ref IEW} 938-940) or to *kʷer- 'cut (off), incise' ({ref LIV² 391-392, {ref IEW} 641-642). The former etymology is preferred by {ref de Vaan 2008}:158, whereas the latter by {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:160-161).

A probable loanword from Syriac qəlāfāʼ 'folium libri', qəlāfəθā 'cortex, squama, putamen mali granata' ({ref Olsen 1999}:932), but cf. {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:398 who less plausibly argue for an Indo-European origin. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kełeu̯-o-].

Comment: In Avestan attested by darz- "to attach, fasten".

Justification: Although there are some possible formal issues, I find the comparison to PS *smykati, *smukati, derived from PIE *(s)meu̯k- 'glide, slide', very attractive.

Comment: a PIE variant is cognate/2394/
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Albanian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ód-r̥-, *u̯ed-en- 'water', a heteroclite r/n-stem derived to PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ({ref NIL} 706-715, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:987-988, {ref Adams 2013}:627-628, {ref Beekes 2010}:5126-1527, {ref Demiraj 1997}:401-402, {ref Orel 1998}:482-483, {ref EWAia} I:215-216, {ref ALEW} 1185-1186, {ref Derksen 2015}:488, {ref Derksen 2008}:523, {ref Kroonen 2013}:575-576, {ref Untermann 2000}:815-816, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} U:21, {ref Matasović 2009}:394).
No certain etymology outside of Albanian, cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:69, {ref Huld 1984}:50-51, {ref Demiraj 1997}:82, {ref Orel 1998}:65, {ref Holm 2011}:82 for various proposals and further discussion.
the Sogdian form is a compound "bird-born", since Mazanderani has been put here as well, the "bird"-component will be given as root reference form
Loan from German Krampel, Krämpel 'claw' ({ref Snoj 1997-2016}).

Light verb construction with French debout as the semantic-bearing morpheme, from Old French de + bot, the latter derived from an Old Low Franconian loanword *bōtan 'strike, hit' (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 15/1:219, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:109).

Cf. discussion s.v. Old Lithuanian stãbas 'graven image, idol' < ?*stobʰ-ó-  in {ref ALEW} 967. The status of this IE reconstruction remains uncertain, cf. Proto-Germanic *staba- 'stick' in /cognate/2980/ and {ref Kroonen 2013}:471.

Comment: Mayrhofer (EWAia II 658) suggests a PIE extended root *(s)k̑eu̯-bʰ. Klingenschmitt (2000: 205) *huu̯-apah- "gutes Werk verrichtend", cf. Old Ind. sv-ápas- 'gut wirkend' (Mayrhofer EWAia I 84), then identical with 3165.

Justification: Italic lexemes from PIE *mei̯H- 'to diminish' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:381-382, {ref Untermann 2000}:477-478, cf. {ref LIV²} 427). For Sardinian, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:459 s.v. 5594 Lat. minus.

Modern Indic lexemes as though from Vedic kumārikā́- 'girl', cf. Vedic kumārá- 'child, boy' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:170, no. 3303). Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} I:368-369 for various uncertain proposals).

In {ref ESSJa}: 3: 103 it is claimed that this word can be native. The support were East Slavic dialectal but referring to various kinds of 'onion' or 'beet', cf. also PS *buta, *butati, *butiti. However, it is possible that we deal with two different etymona here.

A probable North Caucasian loanword, cf. Khinalug k’ɨtʰ-ɨr 'nose' ({ref Asatrian 2014}:147-148). No etymology in {ref HAB} IV:577-578, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:783, {ref Olsen 1999}:942. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kʰitʰ-a-].

Comment: Loan from Latin
Justification: Generally regarded as a loan from Latin arēna 'sand' ({ref Demiraj 1997}:295, {ref Orel 1998}:370-371), but cf. {ref Holm 2011}:76-77 for a tentative proposal to the lexemes from PIE *h₁er- (cf. NHG Erde, etc. in /cognate/207).
Romance lexemes from Latin sentīre 'to sense, feel' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:645-646), further to PIE *sent- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:554, {ref LIV²} 533).

Most often interpreted as containing PIE *dʰeh₁- 'put' ({ref LIV²}: 136-138), cf. {ref Rejzek 2001}: 688, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 4: 255, see below. An alternative is to compare is with PIE *Hou̯Hdʰ-, cf. Russian udit' 'swell, fill with' and PS *vymę 'udder' and English udder, cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 149, {ref Derksen 2008}: 507, 534-535 and {Boryś 2005}: 663. This latter etymology seems to be more attractive, however in light of the shortness of the root (2 phonemes) and the lack of any IE cognates with a similar meaning, it remains speculative.

Similar to Iranic *kutī̆- 'dog', which first appears in Middle Iranic. The Indic forms have been hypothesised to be onomatopoeic (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:168, however given similar forms in Uralic (cf. Hungarian kutya 'dog'), it seems more likely to be a Wanderwört. The fact that the Indic and Iranic lexemes only appear in the later languages and are not reconcilable to a common proto-form are suggestive of independent borrowings from a third source. Cf. also {ref ESIJa} IV:413-415 s.v. Proto-Iranian *kuta- 'собака, пёс', *kūtī̆-.

Generally derived from a (collective?) formation *lēg-i̯a- to PIE *le⁽g̑⁾- 'to drip, trickle' ({ref Olsen 1999}:70, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:297, cf. {ref HAB} II:282-283, {ref IEW} 657, {ref LIV²} 397). Possibly cognate with Modern English lake if not a loanword from Old French (cf. further discussion in /cognate/5612/).

Comment: How do we know Megleno-Romanian was not directly borrowed from Turkish?

Justification: {ref Adams 2013}:219 suggests a possible connection to Proto-Germanic *klāwo- 'claw' but this remains uncertain. For the proposed Germanic cognates, cf. discussion in {ref Kluge 2011}:496-497, {ref Kroonen 2013}:292.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'to become warm, hot' ({ref LIV²} 219-220, {ref Derksen 2008}:178-179, {ref ESSJa} 7:42-43).

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Pace {ref Kluge 2011}:215, the etymologies of proposed Greek and Italic cognates are themselves quite uncertain (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1052, {ref Beekes 2010}:1400).

Generally derived as though from PIE *gʷʰe/oidʰ-i̯o- and connected with Slavic lexemes for 'liquid, watery', although some debate remains over the more precise aspects of the stem formation in Armenian (see {ref Martirosyan 2010}:210-211 for detailed discussion, cf. also {ref HAB} I:550-551, {ref Olsen 1999}:811).

Comment: IE *bu 'imitation of a muffled sound' (Buck 1930: 2.113)

Justification: Etymology uncertain, see {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:683 for a critical discussion of earlier proposals. {ref HED PE, PI, PU}:146 considers a connection to Lithuanian pùsti 'swell', but cf. {ref ALEW} 831-833 s.v. pùsti 'anschwellen' and pū̃sti 'wehen, blasen' against any clear correspondences outside of Baltic for the proposed comparandum.

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Medieval Greek ὀψές, with final -ς taken on analogy to (ε)χτές 'yesterday', from Ancient Greek ὀψέ 'a after a long time, at length, late' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1626), further from PIE *h₁op-s-, cf. *h₁ep- 'on' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1139).
Loanword from Germanic *brekan- 'break' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 15/1:267, cf. French broyer 'grind').

Comment: Perhaps an Iranian loan. Denominative of ուռ owṙ 'swelling, tumor', cf. CA ուռնում owṙ-nu-m (intr.) 'I am swollen, bloated; (fig.) grow proud"; ուռուցանեմ owṙ-owcʿ-an-e-m (tr.) 'I swell; stuff'; ուռոյց owṙ-oycʿ 'swelling; blister', etc.
Justification: Modern Armenian lexemes derived from Classical Armenian owṙnowm. Further etymology obscure. Probably to be connected with Armenian owrowk 'leprosy' according to {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:257, which in turn may plausibly be considered an loan from Iranian. cf. Sogdian βrʾwkʾ 'leprous' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:188; cf. also {ref HAB} III:606-607 for older hypotheses). [MM: Proto-Armenian *(u̯)uṙ-].
Romance lexemes from Latin petra ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:531), an old loanword from Ancient Greek πέτρα 'rock; cliffside' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:504)
Traditionally derived from Lith. pìlti 'to pour (out); to fill' and further to PIE *pleh₁- 'to fill, become full' ({ref ALEW} 773-775, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:460, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:592-593).
Loanword from Romance *fluctulāre < Latin fluctuāre ({ref Orel 1998}:101, cf. {ref Holm 2011}:63, {ref Demiraj 1997}:172-173, {ref Meyer 1891}:109).

Comment: identical with the Romanian word that was loaned from Turkish (6544)
Justification: Loanword from Modern Persian, ultimately from Turkish.

From Ancient Greek κύανος ({ref Andriotis 1974}:285), the name of a dark blue substance, 'enamel, lapis lazuli, blue copper carbonate', attested already in Mycenaean via ku-wa-no. Possibly an early loanword from an Indo-European Anatolian language, cf. Hittite kuu̯anna(n)- '(blue as) copper, ornamental stone' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:594-594, {ref Beekes 2010}:793).

First securely attested as Middle English dogge, generally considered to be of unknown etymology (cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}. Cf. {ref Gąsiorowski 2006} for a recent attempt to derive Old English *docga from the colour adjective dox (gloss) 'dark haired, dusky'.

Traditionally conjectured to be a derivative to PIE *h₂ek̄- 'to be(come) sharp' ({ref de Vries 1977}:632, {ref IEW} 18), but this etymology is no longer continued by the more recent handbooks (cf. {ref NIL} 287-300; not in {ref Orel 2003}, {ref Kroonen 2013}).
Identical to Standard Albanian trup 'body, trunk', a loanword from Slavic  *trupъ 'id.' (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:438-439, {ref Orel 1998}:467).

Continuing a derivative of Vedic √rap- 'to talk, chatter' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:614 no. 10620). Further etymology outside of Indic uncertain, possibly of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref EWAia} II:432-433, not in {ref LIV²}).
Celtic lexemes traditionally derived to PIE *leu̯k- (cf. {ref IEW} 687), but better to *leh₂p- after the analysis of {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:194fn40, cf. {ref LIV²} 402, {ref Lucht 2007}:76.

The etymology is considered as uncertain and relatively many different IE comparanda are given, cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 3: 315, {ref Boryś 2005}: 613, {ref Rejzek 2001}: 74. However, the hypothesis of {ref Derksen 2008}: 35, 466 is attractive and has been adopted here. For the semantic development see also /cognate/7765/.

As though from PIE *solH-i- ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:709-711). Cf. however {ref HED SA} alternatively considering connections to other vocabulary from a Hittite stem *sall- 'swell, expand' to be ultimately connected with Proto-Germanic *swellan- (but cf. 'swell' in /cognate/315/, generally considered without certain etymology). Cf. also Tischler Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar 2/1:767-775 for further discussion.

The etymology is disputable and not entirely clear, cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 1: 15, {ref Boryś 2005}: 28 or {ref Rejzek 2001}: 74. However, the hypothesis of {ref ESSJa}, considered also by {ref Derksen 2008}: 35, is attractive. For the semantic development see also /cognate/7765/.
The root of the Hittite formation is generally compared with Ved. párvata- 'mountain' < *pér-u̯n̥-to- (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:668-669, {ref HED PE, PI, PU}:23-26; cf. {ref EWAia} II:99).
Romance denominal verbs as though from Latin *mattea 'club' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:445), further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:366-367 for various proposals.

Generally connected with Baltic words for 'sea', cf. OLith. jū́ra 'sea', etc. ({ref Olsen 1999}:50, {ref ALEW} 423), although this etymology is disputed by {ref Kortlandt 1998}:15 (= {ref Kortlandt 2003}:122) on the grounds that the proposed Baltic cognates cannot be separated from Sanskrit vā́r 'water'. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}, cf. {ref HAB} IV:134-136.
No clear etymology outside of Italic, possibly a loanword from an unknown Mediterranean source (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:340-341, {ref de Vaan 2008}:326).

Albanian lexemes to be compared with OHG questa 'tuft', Serbian gvȍzd 'forest' and derived from PIE *gu̯osd(o)- ({ref Jokl 1912}:204, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:69, {ref Demiraj 1997}:187-188, {ref Orel 1998}:133-134, {ref Holm 2011}:69).
Derived from Tocharian B krāke 'dirt, filth', which may in turn be a loan from Khotanese khārgga- 'id.' ({ref Adams 2013}:229-230).

Cf. Standard Modern Greek ανασαίνω, from Medieval Greek ἀνασαίνω, formed as a denominal verb in -αίνω from the Ancient Greek abstract noun ἄνεσις 'loosening, relaxing' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:131), further to Ancient Greek ἵημι 'to send away, let go, throw' from PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'to throw' ({ref Beekes 2010}:581-582, {ref LIV²} 225).

Brythonic forms from Proto-Celtic *kalona- ({ref Deshayes 2003}:361). No certain etymology outside of Celtic. Not in {ref Matasović 2009}; no etymology given in {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, cf. {ref Henry 1900}:50-51 for various older proposals.

Comment: cf. Old Vedic káṇa- m. 'grain of corn' (AV), later 'drop of water' via 'particle', Turner 1962-66, no. 2661
Justification: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:133 no. 2661 s.v. Vedic káṇa- 'grain of corn', further etymology unclear ({ref EWAia} I:291.

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *kreu̯h₂- '(clotted) blood, blood outside of the body' ({ref NIL} 444-448, {ref ALEW} 520-521, {ref Derksen 2015:255}, {ref ESSJa} 13:67-70, {ref Derksen 2008}:254).

Cognacy in this class follows {ref ALEW} 423, but cf. {ref Kortlandt 1998}:15 (= {ref Kortlandt 2003}:122) who rejects the etymology with Armenian, assuming that Baltic initial j- is secondarily acquired (similarly cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:215).
Anatolian and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰedʰh₂- 'to pierce; to dig' ({ref LIV²} 66, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:654-655, {ref de Vaan 2008}:229).

The Modern Greek forms are from prefixed προ-ωθέω with various sound laws and analogical changes applied (cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:1317), ultimately to IE *u̯edʰh₁- 'push' ({ref LIV²} 660, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1676-1677). Reconstruction of the final laryngeal is not secure (cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).

Romance lexemes from Latin camba, gamba 'horse's ankle' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:143, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 2:111-120), most likely to be a loanword from Ancient Greek καμπή 'a bending, winding' in the technical language of horse veterinarians and breeders ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:267).

No certain etymology outside of Italic; previous proposals to Old Icelandic sax Old High German sahs 'knife' are unsatisfactory semantically and formally (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:597, {ref de Vaan 2008}:541 for further discussion).
Lexemes derived from Hittite ištamān- 'ear', further from PIE *stéh₃-mn, *sth₃-mén-s, cf. Gk. στόμα 'mouth', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:411-413).
From Classical Armenian hartʿ 'flat, even, level', further etymology uncertain ({ref Olsen 1999}:964, cf. {ref HAB} III:58-59).

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *mysliti, a denominal formation to Proto-Slavic *myslь 'thought, idea'. Within Slavic literature, *myslь is generally further compared to Ancient Greek μῦθος 'word, discourse, story' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:337, {ref ESSJa} 21:47-50, {ref Boryś 2005}:344), although within Hellenist literature Greek μῦθος is generally considered without certain etymology (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:718-719, {ref Beekes 2010}:976 for further discussion). The etymology of Proto-Slavic *myslь is remains therefore uncertain.

Comment: Original meaning "to find". Cheung (2007: 413) sorts Balochi under *u̯ai(H)n-, but does not explain the origin of -d-. Cognacy coding follows Korn (2005). Note that some Iranic forms of cognate set 1969 may actually belong here.

Justification: From Classical Armenian gawazan 'rod, stave', a loanword from Iranic *gavāzan- 'oxgoad' ({ref Olsen 1999}:872, {ref HAB} I:525-526). [MM: Proto-Armenian *gau̯azan-a-].
Loan from Old French dous ({ref Deshayes 2003}:199).

Comment: cf. IEW 951ff.

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:417, {ref Derksen 2015}:343-344, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:435-436).

Perhaps PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the Balto-Slavic acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾- ({ref Derksen 2008}:243, {ref Derksen 2015}:231-232), but connections outside of Balto-Slavic ultimately uncertain; perhaps PIE *kʷend- according to {ref ALEW} 464-465, but likewise extra-Balto-Slavic connections uncertain. Cf. also {ref ESSJa} 12:65-66.
To be derived from PIE *i̯et- 'to place oneself (firmly)' ({ref Orel 1998}:158, 343-344, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:979).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'become warm, hot' ({ref NIL} 196-199, {ref ESSJa} 7:42, 55-56, {ref Derksen 2008}:178-180; cf. {ref LIV²} 219-220).

Comment: Buck (1949: 1176f.) derives this word from "*noi-bho- from the root seen in Ir[ish] niam ‘brilliance’, Lat. nitēre ‘shine, glitter’.” For the inner-Iranic development with extension nai̯u̯aka- and accent shift see Klingenschmitt (2000: 212f.).

Justification: Probably an early loanword from Persian/Tajik (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:108).
Parallel loans from Modern Iranic, cf. Persian شیرین / širin 'sweet'.

Brythonic forms from Proto-Celtic *kalona- ({ref Deshayes 2003}:361). No certain etymology outside of Celtic. Not in {ref Matasović 2009}; no etymology given in {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, cf. {ref Henry 1900}:50-51 for various older proposals.

This class is coded for Walloon jambe, from Latin camba, gamba 'horse's ankle' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:143, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 2:111-120), most likely to be a loanword from Ancient Greek καμπή 'a bending, winding' in the technical language of horse veterinarians and breeders ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:267).
A derived adjective from Old French çucre 'sugar', in turn a loanword from Arabic sukkar 'sugar' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 19:161-164).

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Traditionally assumed to be a derivative in *-dʰro- to PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'to blow' and connected with OCS vedro 'nice weather' ({ref IEW} 82; cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:649, {ref Derksen 2008}:513), but cf. the discussion of {ref Kroonen 2013}:583-584.

Etymology uncertain. Traditionally connected with PIE *Horgʰi-, cf. Alb. ergjëz 'nit'; Lith. érkė 'tick, mite' ({ref IEW} 335, cf. {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:603). This is remotely plausible, but the development of the Armenian form is irregular or phonetically unexpected, presumably due to taboo deformation. Cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:81 and {ref ALEW} 265 respectively for the proposed Albanian and Lithuanian cognates. [MM: Proto-Armenian *odʒil-o-/-a-].

Comment: Note that the original Slavic meaning was 'good'. The meaning 'sweet' in some South Slavic languages is a later innovation.
Justification: Etymology outside of Slavic uncertain ({ref ESSJa} 2:174, {ref Derksen 2008}:51-52). Some attempts have been made to connect the root to the same found in 'white' < PIE *bʰelH- (cf. /cognate/1190), but the additional *-g- found on the stem lacks a convincing morphological explanation.

Exact derivation of the Tocharian B word from the PIE root debated, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:590 and {ref ALEW} 560 s.v. lãšišas. Cognates in other branches specifically mean 'salmon' (cf. {ref EIEC} 497 for further discussion).

Probably to Latin mīca 'small grain, crumb' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:456, {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further etymology difficult. The best recent proposal is of {ref Nyman 1987}, who argues for an original meaning 'grain of salt' and derives from the same root as Latin micō, -āre 'to quiver, dart, flash' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:378, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:402).

Comment: original meaning "to pour", Sarikoli with prefix *abi-

Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:424, {ref Orel 1998}:514-515 for various proposals and further discussion.

Etymology outside of Greek unclear; possibly with 'ice' in /cognate/4901/ (cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:28-29, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:588-589, {ref Beekes 2010}:786). {ref Adams 2013}:236 attempts to connect Tocharian B krośce to the Greek forms, but this is formally problematic (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:786).
Loanwords, either borrowed directly from Old French conter, or a denominal formation within Breton based on a loanword from Old French conte ({ref Deshayes 2003}:413)

Derived from PIE *u̯edʰ(h₁)- 'hit, strike' ({ref Malzahn 2010}:876-877, {ref Adams 2013}:641, cf. {ref LIV²} 660). Reconstruction of the final laryngeal is not secure (cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *stéh₃-mn, *sth₃-mén-s, cf. Hitt. ištāman- 'ear', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1058-1059, {ref Beekes 2010}:1408, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:411-413).
Slavic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' ({ref NIL} 185-189, {ref Derksen 2008}:563, {ref Lehmann 1986}:278).

Comment: cf. Morgenstierne (1974: 40): "kawg S[arikoli] (bur.) spring, well. - Lw. < W[akhi] kïk, kūk < *xāka-."
Justification: Quite regularly development of older *kōl from Turkic köl < *kȫl 'lake', either Uzbek (standard ko'l) or Kyrgyz (standard köl). Cf. Shughni qůl 'lake' with a similar development.
{ref Morgenstierne 1974}:82 gives no etymology outside of the Shughni group.

From Classical Armenian gēš 'corpse, carrion, dead body' (subst.); 'bad, ill' (adj.), further etymology uncertain ({ref Olsen 1999}:944; not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}, for older etymological proposals cf. {ref HAB} I:550, {ref IEW} 1134).

Etymology outside of Brythonic uncertain. Traditionally connected to a PIE root 2. *lem- ({ref IEW} 675), but not in {ref LIV²} or {ref Schumacher 2004}. For probable cognates in Breton cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Deshayes 2003}:459 (without comparing Welsh lexemes).
Hittite ḫātant- 'dry' is originally an participle derived to PIE *h₂ed- 'to dry up' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:328-329, {ref LIV²} 255).

The etymology is obscure, probably of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Skok 1971-1974} 1:84-85). No certain etymology outside of Slavic: the etymology proposed in {ref ESSJa} 1:118-120 is ingenious but speculative.
Probably of expressive or onomatopoeic origin ({ref DCECH} IV:484-486, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:544).
Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *du̯eh₂- ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:904-905, {ref EWAia} I:739, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:370 no. 6497).
Etymology in this class follows {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:974 to PIE *seh₂⁽g̑⁾-, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).

Comment: Original meaning probably "Hülle, Decke". Note that Persian requires accent shift to *páu̯astā- for *áu̯a > ō and au̯á > awa (Klingenschmitt 2000: 214f.).

Justification: Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *xšnau- 'to hear', further from PIE *ksneu̯- 'to whet, sharpen', presumably via an intermediary sense *'to sharpen (the ears)' ({ref Cheung 2007}:456-457, cf. {ref LIV²} 373).

Indo-Iranic lexemes generally connected to Proto-Germanic *agla- (cf. {ref EWAia} I:46, {ref Lehmann 1986}:10, {ref Kroonen 2013}:4-5). For the root etymology to PIE *h₂egʰ- 'become afraid, sad', cf. {ref LIV²} 257.

Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰau̯š- 'to hear, listen to' (cf. Vedic √ghoṣ- 'to sound'), further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ({ref Cheung 2007}:115-116, {ref EWAia} I:518-519; {ref LIV²} 200 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯s-).
No certain cognates outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} I:451-452, cf. {ref LIV²} 359-360). Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:203, no. 3865.

Hellenic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to see' ({ref LIV²} 665-667, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:379-380, {ref Smoczyński 2005}:403-404, {ref Derksen 2008}:521, {ref de Vaan 2008}:676).
Although some IE comparisons can be disputable, the link to PIE *gʷerH- is formally and semantically convincing.
Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)keu̯h₁- 'to apprehend, behold' ({ref LIV²} 561, {ref ESSJa} 4:134-136, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:91).
Loanword from Iranic (via Persian?), cf. /cognate/2456/, /cognate/9297/.
Not in {ref Deshayes 2003}, but an obvious recent loan from French poitrine (< Late Latin *pectorīnus 'belonging to the breast', a derivative of Latin pectus, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:521).

Probably of onomatopoeic origin; the older proposed loanword hypothesis from Old High German tūmōn (cf. e.g. {ref Buck 1949}:671) is questionable for formal reasons (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:747, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 13/2:403-409 for further discussion).

Connected by {ref Matasović 2009}:427-428 to Slavic and Germanic words for 'wood' (cf. /cognate/3130/) following {ref IEW} 1138-9, but since this explanation this on postulating different root-extensions to a base root *u̯el-, *u̯elə- in {ref IEW} this remains somewhat tenuous.

From Latin planta 'plant' (Giovanni Abete, p.c., cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:546), further to PIE *pleh₂- 'be flat, even' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:470, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:512, {ref NIL} 562-564).

Comment: original meaning "people"; Sarikoli with adjectival suffix *-aina-.

Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref ALEW} 480, {ref Smoczyński 2005}:191 for further discussion.

Anatolian, Hellenic, and Armenian lexemes from PIE *du̯ei̯- 'to fear, be afraid' ({ref Beekes 2010}:308, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:268). For the inclusion of Luvian k(u)u̯ai̯a- in this class, cf. {ref LIV²} 130.

Possibly cognate with Tocharian B yolo 'bad', Gk. ὀδύνη, Arm. erkn, OIr. idu (cf. {ref Schindler 1975}, {ref Watkins 1982}, {ref Adams 2013}:555-556), but these connections are uncertain (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:420-422, and more recently specifically regarding the Tocharian lexemes {ref Peyrot 2016} and further discussion in /cognate/7558/).
North Germanic lexemes from ON dáligr 'wicked, harmful, miserable' (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:73-74; no lemma in {ref Heidermanns 1993}, {ref Orel 2003}, {ref Kroonen 2013}.

Most of the scholars ascertain that the etymology of PS *kut- is obscure. The etymologies of {ref ESSJa} and {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989} assume PIE roots (root extentions) not supported by {ref LIV²}. The etymologies are also hardly convincing semantically (the issue is, however, caused to a great extent by the semantic span within attested Slavic lexemes belonging here). Thus, they are not accepted here.

Comment: possibly "to do under", then čēr < *hača adari 'from down'

Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Smoczyński 2005}:325-326, {ref ALEW} 896-897 for further discussion.

Cf. Old Lithuanian plùnksma 'feather' ({ref ALEW} 802). Generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic.

Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, perhaps to be further connected to Serbo-Croatian vlákno, Russian волокно 'fibre' ({ref EWAia} II:525-526, but cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:526). For Modern Indic forms in this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:666, no. 11418.

Etymology uncertain. Formerly compared with Hittite karawar 'horn', Tocharian A kror, Tocharian B (oblique stem) krorīyai 'crescent, horn of the moon' via PIE *gʰréh₁u̯r̥ (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:155, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:182), but these proposed cognates may also be derived from PIE *k̑er- (cf. /cognate/2457/). [MM: Proto-Armenian *(e)łdʒ-iu̯r-].

Probably continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *zai- 'to set in motion, impel' (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:109-110, {ref Cheung 2007}:461). Further connections outside of Indo-Iranic doubted by {ref EWAia} II:802-803, {ref LIV²} 174; cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:462 for proposed nominal cognates outside of Indo-Iranic. {ref LIV²} 174 mechanically reconstructs ?*g̑ʰei̯- 'to set in motion, drive'.

An Indic and Balto-Slavic isogloss ({ref EWAia} I:397-398, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:179 no. 3451, {ref ESSJa} 4:155-157, {ref Derksen 2008}:92, {ref Derksen 2015}:247). Because cognates are only found in languages that have undergone the satəm merger, the original identity of the velar as a plain velar *k or labiovelar *kʷ cannot be more precisely determined.

Origin uncertain, perhaps from *m(u̯)elh₂- 'grind' (cf. młel 'chaff, dust', mamowł 'press(ing machine))? Cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:953, {ref HAB} III:331-332. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *muł-].

Some sources assume a derivation from PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁- and a relationship to Latin moveō, movere, cf. the citations below.
However, this etymology is virtually not present in Slavic etymology dictionaries, cf. the citations below and {ref Rejzek 2001}: 398, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 185-186, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 3: 26 where a different set of IE comparanda is given. Although the proposed Greek comparanda rather do not belong here {ref Beekes 2010}: 950-951, 991, 974, 975-976, other IE comparisons as with Old Indic mū́tram 'urine', Proto-Celtic mūno- 'urine' and Lithuanian máudyti with a PIE reconstruction *meu̯H- (and without giving Latin moveō, movere etc. as a cognate) is accepted in branch-specific dictionaries, see {ref KEWA}: 663-554, {ref Matasović 2009}: 281, {ref Smoczyński 2007}: 378.
PS *myti could not derive directly from PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁-. An irregular phonetic change or another special change would have to be assumed here.
Thus, the connection to PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁- is not accepted here.

Comment: a loan, because **k̑lou̯ni- > *sr° > Sarikoli x̌

Justification: This cognate class codes Albanian hedh 'to throw' which may be regularly derived from PIE *skeu̯d- 'to propel (forth)' ({ref LIV²} 560); the Modern Albanian variant hjedh was semantically distinct in Old Albanian and is to be derived instead from *(s)kedh₂- 'to shatter, disperse' ({ref LIV²} 550, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} and {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:976 for further discussion. For older discussions connecting to PIE *(s)keu̯d-, cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:150, {ref Huld 1984} 72-73, {ref Demiraj 1997}:197-198, {ref Orel 1998}:143-144. For the Slavic forms attached to this class, cf. {ref ESSJa} 13:252-254, {ref Derksen 2008}:265 (not in {ref LIV²}). Regarding the proposed cognacy to Proto-Germanic *skeutan- 'to shoot, dash' ({ref LIV²} 560), cf. discussion in /cognate/8120/.

Comment: not found in Morgenstierne (1974) and Cheung (2007)

Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ({ref LIV²} 218-219, cf. {ref EWAia} II:800-801, {ref Cheung 2007}:244-245).

Comment: Uncertain etymology.
Justification: No certain etymology ({ref Demiraj 1997}:426-427, {ref Orel 1998}:520-521, {ref Holm 2011}:66-67).

To maintain the connection with Lat. albus, Gk. ἀλφός, etc. (cf. /cognate/955/), one must postulate reconstructing a fourth laryngeal that is a-colouring but lost in Anatolian (i.e. *h₄elbʰo-); alternatively one could reconstruct *albʰo- with an original *a in the root but this likewise a less satisfactory solution (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:169).
Etymology unknown (cf. {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).

Comment: unclear why Cheung suggests k instead of k̑ despite his reference to LIV; ki̯ > čy and k̑i̯ > ϑy/sy would both result in Sogdian š

Justification: Connections outside of Greek unclear; occasionally proposed to Arm. čʻor 'dry' (cf. /cognate/5006/), but this requires postulating a sound law in Armenian for which this is the only example (cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:182, {ref Beekes 2010}:1035-1036, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:546).
Loan from Balkan Romance *padulem (< Latin paludem 'swamp'), cf. Romanian pădure 'forest' ({ref Meyer 1891:360, {ref Orel 1998}:353).
Etymology uncertain ({ref KEWA} I:427).
Etymology outside of Greek uncertain; reminiscent of Lat. silva 'forest' but a common proto-form cannot be reconstructed. ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1154-1155, {ref Beekes 2010}:1529-1530).
Etymology uncertain; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:878-879 for a speculative proposal based on a possible etymological figure.

Comment: hrīsa- n. ‘brushwood’ http://iedo.brillonline.nl/dictionaries/lemma.html?id=21497

Justification: No etymology outside of Italic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:626, {ref de Vaan 2008}:564).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *truxlъ 'rotten' and ultimately derived from PIE *terh₁- 'to rub, bore' ({ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:239-240, cf. {ref LIV²} 632-633).

Origin uncertain. Traditionally thought to reflect PIE *sm̥-doru- lit. "together-tree/wood", which is, however, both formally and semantically quite speculative ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:95-96, {ref Olsen 1999}:939, cf. {ref HAB} I:211). [MM: Proto-Armenian *antaṙ-i-].
Germanic and Slavic lexemes generally derived from PIE *u̯ergʷ- 'to throw' (cf. {ref LIV² 689, {ref Derksen 2008}:515, {ref Kroonen 2013}:581).

From Old Norse kasta, generally connected to ON kasa 'to bury in a cairn', kǫs 'heap, kǫstr 'hill', without a clear etymology outside of (North-)Germanic ({ref de Vries 1977}:303, 342-343; cf. for various proposals in older literature). No lemma in {ref Kroonen 2013}.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9106; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

Justification: Possibly to be connected with Ancient Greek ἰσχίον 'hip-joint' ({ref HED A+E/I}:424-425), but this is disputed (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:602-603). In view of the phonological similarity and the areal proximity of the languages it could be possible that both Greek ἰσχίον and Hitt. iškiš- are both independent borrowings from a third source (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:402).

Etymology outside of Indic uncertain. Possibly to be connected with Proto-Slavic *ę̄drò 'kernel, core' ({ref EWAia} I:162), but cf. the scepticism of {ref Derksen 2008}:157-158. For Middle and Modern Indic, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:50, no. 1111.
This lexeme is derived from PS *šum- and has an onomatopoeic origin. Therefore, further IE cognates are uncertain.

Comment: on words ending in °x: Bailey (1979: 111a) assumes a -xa- suffix for this word. Klingenschmitt (2000: 203) calles this "Suffixtausch" of *-xa- and *-ka-.

Justification: Scots Gaelic can, from Old Irish canim 'sing' ({ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:68, further to PIE *⁽k̑⁾an- 'sing' ({ref LIV²} 342-343, {ref Schumacher 2004}:387-390, {ref Matasović 2009}:187-188).
Etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:975, {ref Beekes 2010}:1287-1288; cf. {ref IEW} 1159 for unconvincing older proposals to Germanic lexemes via OHG rīban, etc.).

Comment: original meaning is "strike"; Kurdish entries should be rechecked

Justification: Romance forms from Latin quirītare 'to make a public outcry' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 2:1484), a verbal derivative to Latin quirīs, -ītis 'name for Rome's citizens in their peacetime function'; further origins obscure (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:559, {ref de Vaan 2008}:509-510).

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek δασύς 'thick with leaves, thickly wooded' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:333).
