Often further compared to Lat. dēnsus 'thick, close, compact' but the comparison is formally problematic and therefore there is no clear etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:253, {ref Beekes 2010:305}).
Loan from Medieval Latin pāgānus 'non-Christian, pagan'. It is difficult, however, to determine when the lexeme was originally borrowed (cf. {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 4:472-473).

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *lixъ 'superfluous, incorrect' and generally further derived as though from PIE *lei̯kʷ-so- (cf. {ref ESSJa} 15:99-102, {ref Derksen 2008}:278, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 2:505, {ref NIL} 451-453).

Comment: Bailey (1979: 285) discussing Saka bīma- "rock" suggests a verbal root *vai- "to cut" (cf. Cheung 2007: 407). Cf. Av. vaēma- "Felsspalte, Felskluft".

Justification: Etymology outside of Goidelic difficult to establish with certainty. Cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:143-144 for previous proposals and further discussion.

Indic lexemes from Vedic bā́hya- ʻexternal, being outside' (AV), via 'foreign, strange' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:521, no. 9235. Further to PIE *bʰeg̑ʰ- according to {ref EWAia} II:220 on the basis of proposed Balto-Slavic comparanda (Lith. bè, Latv. bez, OCS bez 'without', cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:38a), but more recently cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:38, {ref ALEW} 101-102 without connection to the Indic lexemes.
Of uncertain origin ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Connections outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. {ref LIV²} 373, {ref EWAia} I:437, {ref KEWA} I:289 for discussion of potential Slavic comparanda). {ref LIV²} reconstructs as though from ?*k⁽ʷ⁾su̯ei̯bʰ- 'to swing (oneself)'.
Root cognacy outside of Slavic uncertain ({ref Derksen 2008}:494, cf. {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 4:183, {ref Boryś 2005}:77, 84 for various proposals.
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *goditi 'please', further derived from PIE *gʰedʰ- 'to fit together' ({ref ESSJa} 6:188-190, {ref Derksen 2008}:172, {ref Rejzek 2001}:206, cf. {ref LIV²} 195).
It is difficult to decide whether the Armenian forms continue PIE *nedih₂- or reflects *nēdih₂- ({ref Olsen 1999}:84), cf. also {ref Martirosyan 2010}:502-503 who reconstructs *ned-o-.
Derived from Proto-Germanic *minwizan- 'smaller', a derivative of PIE *mei̯H- 'become small, recede' ({ref Faltings 2010}:393-394, cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:412, {ref LIV²} 427).
Loanword from Turkish orman 'forest, woods'.
Loan from Arabic ورد / warad 'rose'.

As though from PIE *k̑éh₁k⁽ʷ⁾o- 'mowed grass'; The Old Prussian form shows some unexpected deviations from the East Baltic cognates (Lith. šė́kas 'grass, hay', Latv. sȩ̂ks 'freshly cut grass as cow-fodder'). Cf. {ref ALEW} 1017 for further discussion.

Comment: not found in Morgenstierne (1974) and Cheung (2007), the latter noting Sarikoli pïrx- "to vomit" (p.298)

Justification: Further connections outside of Slavic are uncertain ({ref ESSJa} 8:123, 160-161).

Derived from Vedic sr̥ṣṭá- 'released' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:783, no. 13578), further derived from Vedic √sarj- 'to let go or fly, discharge, throw, cast, hurl' and ultimately from PIE *selg̑- 'to release, throw' ({ref EWAia} II:709, {ref LIV²} 528-529).
Etymology uncertain, perhaps related to PIE *g̑ʰeu̯- 'to pour' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:171).

Simplified from the phrase 'ums Leben bringen', cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:940. Further IE root etymology uncertain. Traditionally analysed as a conflation of the roots *bʰer- 'to carry' and *h₁nek̑- 'take, receive' (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:136-137, {ref Kroonen 2013}:77).

Comment: lit. "milk", Iranic adjective formation *xšīraina-

Justification: Pace {ref Deshayes 2003}:687 who assumes a borrowing via French estachier, a direct borrowing from Germanic *staka- 'stake, picket' seems more likely from a phonological point of view (Britta Irslinger, p.c.).

Generally derived as a causative to the same root as Armenian ankanaim 'I fall' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:280, cf. {ref HAB} II:128), ultimately from PIE *sengʷ- 'to go down, sink'. Cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:280 for further discussion.

In works on Germanic etymology, the etymology outside of Germanic is generally considered uncertain (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:417-418, {ref Kluge 2011}:804, {ref Kroonen 2013}:445), but cf., however, {ref LIV²} 560 connecting with PIE *(s)keu̯d- '(vor)antreiben'.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *þrinhan-; further IE root reconstruction in this set follows {ref LIV²} 649, {ref Lehmann 1986}:365 to *trenk- 'to push', but cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:547 who argues for a root reconstruction *trenkʷ- on the basis of ON þryngva.

I find the etymology presented in {ref ESSJa} as to the underlying PIE root *kʷer- and its original meaning 'make, do, create' (probably derived from a more primitive meaning 'cut', see {ref LIV²}) convincing.
However, I think that the proposed order of the semantic development is unconvincing and that the reconstructed connotation of the *kresati with 'life' is unnecessary. Words referring to the look of humans and animals are very often derived from verbs meaning 'make, create, form, give birth', cf. PS *tvoriti 'make, create', Polish tworzyć 'make, create' and Polish twarz 'face' > twarzowy 'about a clothing a person looks pretty in' (cf. also Polish potwór 'monster' > potworny 'horrible, ugly'), PS ličiti 'to form, to shape' (< PIE *lei̯H- 'pour', also originally 'formed by casting', cf. /cognate/1223/) and PS *lico 'face', Polish śliczny 'beautiful', Macedonian ličen 'pretty' or PS *roditi 'give birth', Polish rodzić 'give birth' and Polish uroda 'look, beauty' (cf. also Russian urod 'monster, ugly person' > urodlivyj 'ugly'). We can assume a similar development in PIE *kʷer- > PS *krasa. The meaning 'red' in Russian is a later development from 'beautiful' and not the opposite way. It is limited to Russian, where the meaning 'red' is attested much later (11th century vs. 15th century) than 'beautiful' {ref Černyh 1999}: 1: 440.

In origin a verbal adjective to Tsakon. λεχούκ̔ου 'lay (a child) in bed; incubate, warm (smth.)' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.); the verb is derived from Ancient Greek λεχώ 'a woman in childbed, a woman who has just given birth' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:353). Further to be connected to Ancient Greek λέχος 'bed', λέχεται 'lie down in bed' from PIE *legʰ- ({ref Beekes 2010}:852-853, cf. {ref LIV²} 398).

Comment: *bʰeu̯t- violates IE root structure constraints. This etymology is impossible. (–MJCS, 11.07.2018).
Justification:
The etymology and further IE cognacy is not entirely clear.
The most Slavic etymology dictionaries point to a relationship to Latin re(-)futo and Old Norse bauta etc. However, there were a formal issue with the final consonant of the PIE root then, cf. {ref LIV²}: 82 and {ref de Vaan 2008}: 253-254. A root *bʰuH- 'hit' wit different extentions could be assumed here {ref de Vaan 2008}: 253, cf. also {ref Snoj 1997-2016} and {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} cited below. However, Kroonen points that "the original root-final consonant cannot be identified as *d, but only as *t or *dʰ" {ref Kroonen 2013}: 56. If the final consonant were *t, Slavic forms could be formally related without any additional assumptions (as root extentions). This view is addopted here.
Connections outside of Germanic uncertain ({ref Seebold 1970}:241, {ref Lehmann 1986}:160-161, {ref LIV²} 202), but cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:187-188 for proposed connections in Indic and Celtic.

Denominative verb to TochB śerwe 'hunter', further etymology disputed. A popular analysis (Jasanoff apud {ref Nussbaum 1986}:8, followed by {ref Ringe 1996}) considers TochB śerwe to a vr̥ddhi formation from PIE *k̑er-u̯o- 'stag' (*k̑er-, cf. 'horn' in /cognate/2457/, 'head' in /cognate/53/), but other analyses are possible (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:694-695). Proto-Tocharian root ref. form *śerwë follows Ringe (1996:11).

Comment: with Slavic
Justification: Related to Latvian makņa 'swamp, boggy place', cf. Lith. maknà 'id.' ({ref Fraenkel 1962–1965} I:399-400). Further connections outside of Balto-Slavic uncertain, possibly to Armenian mawr 'mud' (cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:301). Cf. also Proto-Slavic *mokrъ 'wet, damp' ({ref Derksen 2008}:322, {ref ESSJa} 19:144). [Not in {ref ALEW}].
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to flow, swirl' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:434, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref LIV²} 305-306).

Comment: Korn (2005: 142 fn. 348) discusses a derivation of *mū "to bind", Old Ind. mū́ta- "basket", but it is not certain whether MIr. has *mūd or *mōd (Klingenschmitt 2000: 196 argues for MP mūy).

Justification: Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:55, {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:273-274, {ref Derksen 2008}:114-115, {ref ESSJa} 5:99-100, {ref LIV²} 153).
Parallel loans from Arabic قديم / qadim 'old'.

The Germanic forms from PGmc. *wenistra- are in all likelihood derivatives from PGmc. *weni- 'friend' as a taboo replacement as 'the friendly side' (cf. similarly motivated replacements in Gk. ἀρίστερος 'left', Lat. sinister 'left'); cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:623, {ref Orel 2003}:455, {ref Kroonen 2013}:579. For the IE root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV²} 682-683.

Root reconstruction follows {ref LIV²} 676, {ref ALEW} 1242-1243; cf. {ref ALEW} 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and {ref Matasović 2009}:427 s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic.
From Old Norse pústr 'slap in the face' (n.) 'to pant, blow' (vb.). Probably further connected in some way with Middle Low German puster 'bellows', poesten, puysten 'blow' ({ref de Vries 1977}:429).

Generally attempted to be derived (as though) from IE *dʰrus-ko/eh₂- to a root *dʰreu̯s- 'herabfallen, abbröckeln', and cognate with a primary verb attested in Germanic (cf. Goth. driusan, OE drēosan, OS driosan 'to fall'), cf. {ref ALEW} 234, {ref Derksen 2015}:142, {ref LIV²} 157-158.

PIE root etymology uncertain. Traditionally compared with North Germanic lexemes in the meaning 'dust; small bits' etc., which with Slavic cognates (cf. OCS měla 'lime', Ru. mel' 'sand-bank, shoal') one may reconstruct a common root *(s)melH-. This root might be identical with PIE *melh₂- 'to grind' with s-mobile (cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:414-415), or alternatively connected with Germanic words for 'small' ({ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:842-843, 846-847; but cf. discussion in /cognate/5112/, without Baltic lexemes connected).
Romance forms from Latin spurcus 'dirty' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:676), further connections uncertain, perhaps to Latin spurius 'bastard'? (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:645).

Earlier literature (cf. {ref Buck 1949}:22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- /cognate/284/, Greek ἄμμος /cognate/8262/, and Lat. sabulum /cognate/8263/ together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in {ref EIEC} objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in /cognate/8261/ are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.
Etymology outside of Italic unclear ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:691-692, {ref de Vaan 2008}:620, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:724 no. 8737).
Parallel loans from Arabic قرمز / qirmiz 'kermes insect; red', ultimately a loan itself from Iranic (cf. /cognate/1163/).

Slavic lexemes considered cognate with Ancient Greek µῆλον 'small cattle, goat, sheep' < *meh₁lo- ({ref Derksen 2008}:300 arguing for the Slavic forms reflecting an o-grade root form *moh₁-lo-, cf. also {ref ESSJa} 17:173-177). Further connections with Proto-Germanic *smala- 'small' might be possible, but remain uncertain (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:517-518, {ref Kroonen 2013}:456 and further discussion in /cognate/8298/).

Lexemes from Proto-Celtic *slad-i̯o- 'to hit; to slay'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref Matasović 2009}:345), cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:583-587 setting up either PIE *sleHd- or *sleHdʰ- following {ref Schrijver 1995}:178. [Not in {ref LIV²}].
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:45 for various proposals). {ref Kroonen 2013}:39 considers a root etymology *h₂ed- for an old PIE word for a type of cereal grains.

Old Norse kasta is generally connected to ON kasa 'to bury in a cairn', kǫs 'heap, kǫstr 'hill', without a clear etymology outside of (North-)Germanic ({ref de Vries 1977}:303, 342-343; cf. for various proposals in older literature). No lemma in {ref Kroonen 2013}.

Originally 'stone' (cf. Lith. uolà 'rock') and traditionally connected with the same root as Lithuanian vélti 'to tumble, tousle' to PIE *u̯elH- (cf. {ref ALEW} 1214-1215, {ref Derksen 2015}:481 for further discussion).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:209-210, {ref ESSJa} 8:208-211, and {ref LIV²} 223 for further discussion).
Iranic and Slavic lexemes from PIE *tengʰ- 'to pull' ({ref Cheung 2007}:391-392, {ref Derksen 2008}:493). For the root reconstruction, cf. discussion in {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.
Probably to be connected with Latin stringere 'to bind fast, tighten' ({ref Kluge 2011}:891, cf. {ref LIV²} 603-604).

Etymology uncertain, perhaps a secondary full grade teik- to tik-, which could be the zero-grade form of PIE *tek- 'to stretch out the hand' (cf. {ref ALEW} 1084-1085). If so, perhaps further connected to 'right' in /cognate/7113/.

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Baltic, Germanic, and Sabellic lexemes derived from PIE *péh₂-u̯r̥, *ph₂-u̯én-, an inherited r/n-heteroclitic nominal stem (cf. {ref NIL} 540-545, {ref EIEC} 202, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:613-614, {ref Adams 2013}:421-422, {ref Beekes 2010}:1260-1261, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:426-427, {ref Kroonen 2013}:151, {ref de Vaan 2008}:500).
Denominal formation to a loanword from Latin campus 'field' in the sense of 'place for fighting' (cf. {ref EWA 5}:368-370, {ref Kluge 2011}:468).
Loanword from Polish ({ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-}:53).

Comment: cf. Turner 1931: 534, 1962-66, no. 10539 s.v. rakta- ʻcoloured, dyedʼ (ŚB), ʻredʼ (ŚāṅkhGr̥.), n. ʻbloodʼ (Mn.), °aka- ʻredʼ (VarBr̥S) (√rañj-), Pali Prakrit ratta-, Rom. rat m.; cf. /cognate/6611/
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from *rakta- 'coloured, dyed', the past passive participle to Ved. √raj-¹, Iranic *ra(n)ǰ- ultimately from PIE *(s)re⁽g̑⁾- 'to colour (smth.)' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:610, no. 10539; {ref EWAia} II:424-425, {ref Cheung 2007}:313-314 {ref Henning 1971}:46, {ref LIV²} 587).
Anatolian, Hellenic, and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ({ref LIV²} 218-219, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:485-486, {ref EWAia} II:800-801, {ref Cheung 2007}:224-225).

Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'to hear, sound'; possibly in origin an IE light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- *dʰeh₁- 'to give tidings' ({ref ALEW} 331-332). Root reference form follows {ref LIV²} 210-211.
Iranic lexemes reflecting denominal formations to PIE *(s)por-no- 'wing, feather' ({ref Cheung 2007}:297, cf. {ref EWAia} II:97).

Romance lexemes from Latin ūstulāre (on the unexpected initial br-, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:757, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 14:75-82), a secondary form of Latin ūrō derived from PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'burn, singe' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:755, {ref de Vaan 2008}:645, {ref LIV²} 245).
Continuing Middle English smellen, smüllen, further etymology uncertain ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Of obscure origin, probably a prehistoric loanword (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:420, {ref Beekes 2010}:530 for discussion of various hypotheses). The different dialectal forms point to either a Proto-Greek or borrowed source form *tʰalak⁽ʰ⁾i̯a (vel sim.).
Of obscure origin, perhaps to Ancient Greek ἐξ-(αν)αλίσκω 'consume' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Proto-Slavic *kŭrkŭ is occasionally compared to Vedic kŕ̥kāṭa- 'joint of the neck' (so {ref ESSJa} 13: 209-211, 218-219, {ref Rejzek 2001}:313, cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:223), although the etymology of the Indic comparandum is generally considered without certain etymology (cf. {ref KEWA} I:256-257 and {ref EWAia} I:388-389). Consequently the further connections of Proto-Slavic *kŭrkŭ must remain uncertain.

Comment: not found in Morgenstierne (1974)

Justification: Root reference form for this class tentatively follows {ref LIV²} 562, but cf. {ref ALEW} 933-935 for further discussion.

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *vyja 'neck'. Further etymology obscure ({ref Vasmer 1986-1987} I:373, {ref Polański 1962-1994}:1034). Possibly cognate with Hittite u̯eḫ- 'to turn (oneself); to patrol' (cf. {ref LIV²} 663), but cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:993-996 with an alternative etymology for the proposed Hittite comparandum.

Denominal verbs derived from Classical Armenian kar 'rope, string'. Further origins uncertain ({ref Olsen 1999}:955); perhaps originally a loanword from Caucasian, cf. Georgian ḳerva 'to sew' ({ref HAB} II:541-542). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kar-].

Comment: similarity to 5163 in using "night" for 'yesterday'

Justification: Modern North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse kortr, a loan from Middle Low German (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:327 s.v. kortr, kurtr).
Anatolian, Indo-Iranic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₃óh₁-s-, *h₃h₁-és-os 'mouth' ({ref NIL} 387-390, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:166-167, {ref EWAia} I:181-182, {ref de Vaan 2008}:436).

Romanian ceață, from Latin caecus 'blind' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further to be connected with Old Irish cáech 'one-eyed', Goth. haihs 'id.' via PIE *⁽k̑⁾eh₂i-ko- or similar ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:82, {ref de Vaan 2008}:79).

Verb derived from Spanish pelear 'fight' (n.), in turn derived from Spanish pelo 'hair' regularly from Latin pilus 'hair' ({ref DCECH} IV:461-463, 465). Further etymological connections uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:507, {ref de Vaan 2008}:465).
Anatolian and Italic lexemes from PIE *sekH- 'to divide, separate' ({ref LIV²} 524), cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:695-697, {ref de Vaan 2008}:545).

The IE root etymology of the Balto-Slavic forms in this class is disputed: the two main candidates are either to PIE *h₃eh₁-s-, *h₃h₁-és-os 'mouth' ({ref NIL} 387-390) or to ?*h₃óu̯st-o- 'mouth, lip' ({ref NIL} 390-391, {ref Derksen 2008}:509, {ref Derksen 2015}:481-482). The root reference form for this class tentatively follows the Balto-Slavic reconstruction of {ref Derksen 2008} and {ref Derksen 2015}.
Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯h₁- 'to look, seek after' ({ref LIV²} 668-669, cf. {ref EWAia} II:509-510, {ref Cheung 2007}:411).
No certain etymology, perhaps to be connected in some way with the lexemes from Latin ūstulāre in /cognate/9342/, but this remains uncertain (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:757).

Indic lexemes from Sanskrit kāla- 'dark-blue, black' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:157, no. 3083). Etymology uncertain, but probably a loanword from Dravidian ({ref KEWA} I:203, {ref EWAia} I:343, cf. {ref Burrow & Emeneau 1984}:139 for Dravidian parallels).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn around, roll' ({ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:351, {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} I:181-182, 212-213, cf. {ref LIV²} 691-692).

North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse hræðast 'to fear' (vb.) or light verb constructions based on Old Norse hræðr 'fear' (n.). No certain connections outside of North Germanic (not in {ref Orel 2003}, {ref Kroonen 2013}; {ref de Vries 1977}:263 reconstructs a Germanic stem *hrēð-).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *krīdlo- 'wing', further derived from PIE *(s)k⁽ʷ⁾rei̯- 'to describe a circle' ({ref Derksen 2008}:247, {ref ESSJa} 12:152-154, cf. {ref LIV²} 562).

Traditionally Lithuanian burnà 'mouth' and Armenian beran 'mouth' have been connected etymologically (cf. {ref {Hübschmann 1897}:429, {ref Olsen 1999}:297, {ref ALEW} 152, {ref Derksen 2015}:106). Although this etymology is accepted, further morphological analysis and the isolation of an IE root remains unclear; further connections have been postulated to derive an n-stem noun from the same root underlying Lat. forō, -āre 'bore' OHG borōn 'bore', from PIE *bʰerH- 'work with a sharp tool' ({ref LIV²} 80), but these connections are not fully clear (cf. {ref ALEW}). However, if with {ref Derksen 2015}:106), who notes that if the Slovak perna 'lip' belongs with the Baltic forms, then the usually reconstruction to a root *bʰrH- is in doubt. As {ref ALEW}, {ref Derksen 2015}, and {ref Olsen 1999} are in agreement about the cognacy, it has been accepted for this class, although the precise IE root etymology is in question. [NB: Arm. beran 'mouth' is not discussed in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.]

Generally considered to be of IE origin, but the precise IE etymology is disputed. From PIE *ment-, if {ref Kroonen 2013}:376-377's reconciliation of the two earlier possible etymologies from {ref IEW} (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:261) is correct. Etymology outside of Germanic otherwise uncertain; cf. {ref Boutkan & Siebinga 2005} for extensive discussion of alternative hypotheses.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4671ff.

Justification: Etymology uncertain. According to {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:300 to an Indo-European root *lel- 'to move, to shake' (not in {ref LIV²}) comparing Vedic lelāyati 'to move to and from; shake' (but cf. {ref EWAia} II:480 assigning to PIE *rei̯H-, also not in {ref LIV²}); Lithuanian leliúoti ‎'to swing', etc. (cf. {ref HAB} II:292).

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Perhaps to the PIE word for 'liver' *(H)i̯ekʷ-r/n-, if certain irregular sound changes took place (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:565, {ref Kroonen 2013}:336). An alternative possibility is an original meaning 'fat', if compared to the root of Gk. λιπαρός 'oily, fatty, greasy' if in Germanic an adjective was substantivised as similarly in Romance from Lat. (iēcur) fīcātum (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:565; {ref EWA 5}:1082-1084).
Romanian merge 'to go' from Latin mergere 'to sink' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, further to PIE *mesg- 'to plunge, sink' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:375, {ref LIV²} 441).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kъnęgъ 'ruler, duke, regent', a loan from Germanic *kuningaz 'king' ({ref Boryś 2005}:268-269, {ref Polański 1962-1994}:876-878).

North Germanic lexemes traditionally compared with PIE *tep- 'be warm, hot' ({ref IEW} 1069-1070, cf. {ref Orel 2003}:418, {ref de Vries 1977}:606-607), but not accepted by {ref LIV²} 629-630 s.v. 1. *tep-. Not in {ref Kroonen 2013}.

Comment: Sarikoli and Cappadocian Greek both loaned this word from a Turkic language, though obviously not the same

Justification: From Classical Armenian zist 'thigh, flank', probably to be interpreted as a compound of Proto-Armenian collocation *(ə)z- < PIE *h₂mbi̯V 'around, about' and *hist-o- < PIE *si-sd-e/o- 'to sit' ({ref HAB} II:96, {ref Olsen 1999}:72, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:275).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10459 s.v. yā́nam n. ʻgoing, vehicleʼ (RV), Prakrit jāṇa- n. ʻriding, driving, vehicleʼ; for le cf. /cognate/6587/ < PIE *lembʰ-

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Italic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:95, {ref de Vaan 2008}:89, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:153 no. 1628).

Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. {ref ALEW} 92-93, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:46 for further discussion. Older etymological works assumed a connection to PIE *h₃nebʰ- in /cognate/5026/, cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:33.

Comment: Uncertain etymology.
Justification: From Classical Armenian kangnem 'to raise, lift up; get up, rise again', further root etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:607, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:381 for various proposals. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kang-(u)n-].

Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷreu̯Hg̑ʰ- ({ref ALEW} 356, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}. This root is not reconstructed by {ref LIV²}, nor are any comparanda outside Balto-Slavic given by {ref Derksen 2008}, {ref Derksen 2015}, but the comparison with AGk. βρῡ́χω 'grind the teeth' < *gʷruHg̑ʰ- appears reasonable formally and semantically (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:244).

Comment: Originally based on a compound of må (< Lat. malum) + sir 'pur' (Walloon Wiktionary).

Justification: Cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} for {ref LIV²} 679 *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' separated into two roots *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' and *u̯elh₃- 'sterben'. The Celtic lexemes in this set have been tentatively assigned to the new root *u̯elh₂- 'beat, hit' assuming a semantic development 'beat, hit' > 'wound' > 'blood'. See further {ref Lucht 2007}:65, {ref Matasović 2009}:410.
Loanword from Low German kerl 'man' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:865-866).

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green'. Regarding the irregular correspondence of the initial velar in Lithuanian and Old Prussian, see {ref Derksen 2015}:169-170 (but cf. {ref ALEW} 309). For individual branches cf. {ref Dawkins 1916}:661, {ref Beekes 2010}:1638, {ref EWAia} II:805-806, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:809 no. 13990, {ref ALEW} 309, {ref Derksen 2015}:169-170, {ref Derksen 2008}:565-566, {ref Kroonen 2013}:174).

First attested via Very Old Latin duenos (CIL 1.4) prior to the Latin sound change *du̯- > b- (cf. also Faliscan duenas [gen.sg.f.]) permitting the reconstruction of Proto-Italic *du̯eno-; further connections uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:73, {ref de Vaan 2008}:73-74 for further discussion). For Romance lexemes, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:106 no. 1208.

Comment: From Lat. de 'from' parte (abl. of pars, partis 'part').
Justification: An adverb based on the Latin phrase dē parte ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), from Latin pars, partis 'part' a late inner-Latin derivative to the same root as Latin pariō 'to give birth to, bear' derived from PIE *perh₃- 'to provide' (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:485, {ref de Vaan 2008}:445-446, 448, {ref LIV²} 474-475).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 1858
Justification: Sinhalese osananavā 'to carry', as though from Sanskrit *ut-śrāpayati > ucchrāpayati 'raises' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:85), further derived from Sanskrit √śray- 'to lean' and ultimately from PIE *k̑lei̯- ({ref EWAia} II:665, {ref LIV²} 332-333).

For the root reconstruction, see {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} for {ref LIV²} 679 *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' separated into two roots *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' and *u̯elh₃- 'sterben', cf. also {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:945-946.

Etymology uncertain. Traditionally considered a derivative of a root *terp-, an extended form of the root *ter- 'to bore' exclusive to Balto-Slavic ({ref IEW} 1078, {ref Karulis 1992} II:376), but cf. {ref LIV²} 632-633 now reconstructing *terh₁- for the assumed base root.

Romance lexemes from Latin herba 'a small plant or herb' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:344), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:291-292, {ref de Vaan 2008}:269-270, 282 for further discussion).

Possibly cognate with Proto-Germanic *mūlan- 'mouth' and Proto-Germanic *munϸa- 'mouth' according to {ref Karulis 1992} I:611-612, although cf. discussion in /cognate/6017/, /cognate/262/ regarding uncertainties to the etymologies of the Germanic forms.

Attempts at an Indo-European etymology (cf. {ref IEW} 392, {ref HAB} II:446-447) are unconvincing ({ref Olsen 1999}:936). The best etymological proposal so far is the suggestion of a Hurro-Urartian loanword, cf. Urartian ṣârə 'orchard'; Hurrian sarme 'wood' (cf. {ref Diakonoff 1985}:600). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsar-o-].

Balto-Slavic lexemes, related to the common words for '(finger)nail' widely found elsewhere in Indo-European via a derived feminine stem *h₃nogʷʰ-eh₂ (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:354-355, {ref ESSJa} 25:161-164, {ref ALEW} 681-682, {ref Derksen 2015}:327).

Modern Greek βουνό 'mountain' from Ancient Greek βουνός 'mountain, hill' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:275), further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:190, {ref Beekes 2010}:231-232).

Germanic lexemes, generally considered a compound of Gmc. *ǣ- 'weg, fort' and the stem of the Germanic verb *maitan- 'schneiden', with a -jōn- suffix for forming a nomen agentis, cf. {ref EWA 1}:203-204, {ref Kluge 2011}:38, 613. Cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:24 for alternative hypotheses for the reconstruction of the initial prefix.

Comment: With nasal infix.
Justification: From Proto-Slavic *gręsti 'go' and usually further derived from a PIE nasal-infix present *gʰri-n-dʰ- (cf. {ref LIV²} 203, {ref Derksen 2008}:188, {ref ESSJa} 7:123-124).

Comment: Loan from Belarusian
Justification: Loan from Old Belarusian blagij 'shame, miserable, bad' prior to the spirantisation of /g/ > /h/, cf. Modern Belarusian благі / blahi 'bad' ({ref Smoczyński 2007}:65-66, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:45-46).
Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' (cf. {ref Smoczyński 2005}:192, {ref ALEW} 495-496, {ref LIV²} 559-560).

Germanic lexemes generally connected to Balto-Slavic lexemes, cf. RuCS dъlbsti 'to scoop, chisel', Lith. (nu-)del̃bti 'to cast down one's eyes', to PIE *dʰelbʰ- 'dig, excavate' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:92, {ref LIV²} 143), but cf. the reservations of {ref Seebold 1970}:153.

Denominal to Classical Armenian tʿiw 'number'. Further origins uncertain; either to be connected with Sanskrit tavá- 'strong, powerful' to a root *teu̯h₁- (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:23) or a borrowing from Hurro-Urartian, cf. Hurrian tiw- 'to say, speak', tiwə 'word; deed', (cf. {ref Diakonoff 1985}:599). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʰiu̯-].

From Proto-Tocharian *kər(ə)n-, proposed by {ref Adams 2013}:173-174 to be based on an unextended root variant *kreu̯- to PIE *kreu̯s- 'hit, beat' ({ref LIV²} 371, {ref IEW} 622), and accepted by {ref Malzahn 2010}:575-577.
Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:418, {ref LIPP 2}:639, cf. {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 5:577-581, 586-584).
Old Prussian lexeme derived from PIE *u̯orgʰó- 'outcast, ostracised' (cf. {ref ALEW} 1189-1191, {ref Derksen 2015}:489-490).
The dubious semantics of the Hittite lexeme make etymological identification difficult (cf. {ref CHD L-N}:253). For various uncertain proposals, cf. {ref Tischler 1991}:210-211, {ref HED M}:124-125.
Anatolian and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ({ref NIL} 706-715, {ref Kroonen 2013}:575-576, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:1015-1016).
Lexemes derived from a Proto-Balto-Slavic root *lop-; no certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic ({ref Derksen 2015}:273, {ref ESSJa} 16:56-57, 16:77).

Since {ref Jokl 1911}:14-15 generally derived from PIE *dʰeu̯b- and compared with Germanic 'deep' words, cf. Goth. diupiϸa, ON dýpt, although there is some uncertainty over the stem formation in Albanian (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:50, {ref Orel 1998}:61-62, {ref NIL} 124n16).
Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vārdala- vārdala- 'rainy day, bad weather' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:674, no. 11567), further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref KEWA} III:195 for various proposals.

Traditionally compared with Avestan pāšna- 'heel', Sanskrit pā́rṣṇi- 'id.' via a (dual?) preform *pāršnā, but the proposal is not without formal and semantic difficulties, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:67.

Hellenic lexemes traditionally considered a derivation to the same root as Ancient Greek τρέχω 'to run' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1130), but cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1501 considering this explanation semantically unconvincing, with aspects of the word formation also unclear from an IE point of view.

Generally derived to PIE *k̑eHs- 'to instruct, advise' ({ref LIV²} 318, {ref Holm 2011}:77, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1001, pace {ref Orel 1998}:480 who assumes a connection with PIE *k̑eNs- ({ref LIV²} 326, cf. /cognate/464/).

Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vr̥kká- 'kidney', apparently a semantic development from 'kidneys' > 'heart' > 'chest' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:698, no. 12064). Possibly further to Vedic √vart- 'turn, roll' < PIE *u̯ert- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:571-572).

Comment: "to darken, make dark, stain"; consider Turkic kül "ashes", but it is not clear whether Turkic #k can be rendered by Iranic #x (maybe via *q). Kurdish ɫ / ḷ point however to *rd/rz (if not secondary), which would make a derivation from *xwṛta- "consumed" possible. However, the Kurdish vowels point to a historically long vowel (if not loan). Cf. Classic New Persian xwāl "soot (for the production of ink)" < xwārϑa- "substance for colouring" (taken from Rastorgueva/Edelman 2007: 481, Etymological Dictionary of Iranian languages, hu̯ar- „smear“). Note, however, LIV p.609 *su̯el- "schwelen, brennen", which would be equally good.

Justification: derivation *u̯i-u̯āha-ka (cf. Nyberg 1974: 217 on Middle Persian), cf. Avestan vah- "weilen; to stay" (Bartholomae 1904: 1394)

Comment: Horn (1893: 201) suggests a derivation from the verbal root 'wart' "to turn". If so, all those languages that would preserve *#w would have to have loaned this word from languages like Persian.

Justification: A borrowing from Old French poldre, itself ultimately from Latin pulverem, ({ref Deshayes 2003}:596).
Loan from Syriac, cf. Classical Armenian hašiw < Syriac ḥəšīḇ, 'considered, calculated' ({ref HAB} III:43, {ref Olsen 1999}:932). [MM: Proto-Armenian *haʃiu̯-].

Etymology uncertain. Perhaps to be connected to Armenian cał- 'laugh' (< PIE *g̑elh₂-) 'to laugh' on the basis of the Hesychius gloss γελεῖν· λάμπειν, ἀνθεῖν 'shine, bloom', but this is uncertain (cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:128, {ref Olsen 1999}:459, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:336 for further discussion). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsał-ik(-u/an)-].

Indic lexemes from Sanskrit stabdha- ʻfirmly fixedʼ, originally the past passive participle to Ved. √stambh- 'to affix, secure' and ultimately from PIE *stembʰH- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:788, no. 13676; cf. {ref EWAia} II:754, {ref LIV²} 595-596).

Certainly to an IE root *men-, but it is not certain whether this is yet another independent root *men- or etymologically related to existing formations (cf. 1. *men- 'einen Gedanken fassen' ({ref LIV²} 435-436, {ref IEW} 726-8), 2. *men- 'bleiben, warten' ({ref LIV²} 437, {ref IEW} 729), or 3. ?*men- 'emporragen' ({ref LIV²} 437-438, {ref IEW} 726)).
East Romance lexemes for 'heart' from Latin animus 'soul, spirit, heart' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further from PIE *h₂enh₁-mo- 'breath' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:43, cf. {ref LIV²} 267-268).

Originally a denominal formation from Ancient Greek ταῦρος 'bull' in the sense of 'pull like a bull' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1446), further to be connected with Latin taurus 'bull', Lithuanian taũras 'auroch', Old Prussian tauris 'bison', OCS turъ 'buffalo', etc. ({ref Beekes 2010}:1455-1456, cf. also {ref ALEW} 1081-1082).

Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:68-69, {ref IEW} 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ({ref Matasović 2009}:205, cf. {ref ALEW} 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, {ref EWAia} II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this set).

Germanic lexemes appearing to continuing derivatives of a PIE root *greng̑ʰ- 'to turn', although the evidence for this root is restricted to Baltic and Germanic ({ref de Vries 1977}:330, {ref Kroonen 2013}:305-306, cf. {ref LIV²} 191).
No etymological information in {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:114.

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁eg̑ʰ-(e)r-o-, cf. Arm. ezr ‘edge, border, bank’ (cf. {ref ALEW} 271, {ref ESSJa} 6:33-34, {ref Derksen 2008}:148, {ref Derksen 2015}:158-159, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:247-248).

Etymology difficult. Comparisons are typically made with Proto-Germanic *hringa- 'ring, circle' ({ref Derksen 2008}:251, {ref ESSJa} 13:25-27, {ref Kroonen 2013}:247, {ref Kluge 2011}:768). As {ref Kroonen 2013}:247 points out, however, the necessary reconstruction of *krengʰ- violates IE root structure constraints and may well point to a post-PIE origin for the Germanic and Slavic lexemes. Inexplicably, Kroonen also appears to consider that the lexemes are also related to Proto-Germanic *kringa- < PIE *greng̑ʰ- (cf. /cognate/9606/). An alternative possibility would be that both the forms as though from *krengʰ- and *greng̑ʰ- were independent loan events from a third source although without any firsthand knowledge of a substratum source this solution is speculative.
Lit. 'not-good'. Further etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. discussion under 'good' in /cognate/678/.
Contrarary {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:275, probably an onomatopoeic formation (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 3:762-764).

From Ancient Greek λακτίζω 'kick with the heel or foot' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:347), a derivative to λάξ (adv.) 'with the heel or foot' without convincing IE etymology (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:619, {ref Beekes 2010}:831-832).

Anatolian, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *su̯ep- 'to fall asleep' ({ref LIV²} 612, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:787-789, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:667-668, {ref EWAia} II:791, {ref Cheung 2007}:145-147, {ref Derksen 2008}:481, {ref Kroonen 2013}:489, {ref Seebold 1970}:482-483).

Of unknown origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:964). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. For older, now untenable proposed etymologies to Germanic *narwa- 'narrow', cf. {ref HAB} III:439-440, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:565, and further comments by MM in the cognate class citations. [MM: Proto-Armenian *neɫ-o-].
Root etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:109, {ref Orel 1998}:386, {ref Holm 2011}:81, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:994-995 for various proposals and further discussion.

Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Indic *khucc-, possibly an extended form of the same root found in Vedic √skav- 'to tear, pluck'? ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:205-206, no. 3890; for Ved. √skav- cf. {ref EWAia} II:751). Further origins uncertain.

The etymology and further cognacy is obscure. It can be derived from PIE 2*(s)ker- 'scratch, cut off, shear' ({ref LIV²}: 556-557), cf. {ref EWAia}: 537 and {ref Kroonen 2013} or *ser- 'knot together' {ref LIV²}: 534, {ref de Vaan 2008}: 557-558 and {ref ESSJa}: 8: 75. See {ref Vasmer 1953-1958} for a summary of existing hypotheses.

From Proto-Slavic *morzъ 'frost' and to be connected with Albanian mardhë 'frost, ice', from PIE *merg̑⁽ʰ⁾-o- ({ref Derksen 2008}:326, {ref ESSJa} 20:10-14, 21:163-165, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:256, {ref Orel 1998}:245).

From Latin spīna 'thorn, prickle; spine' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:673). Further etymology uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:642, cf. {ref Untermann 2000}:692-693). {ref de Vaan 2008}:580-581 (following {ref IEW} 981-982) suggests a possibly cognate relationship to Slavic lexemes, e.g. Ru. спина 'back', but it is not certain whether these forms are actually root cognate or loanwords from Latin (cf. discussion in /cognate/2059/).

Cf. Lithuanian nókti 'to hunt, pursue; follow'. Etymology outside of Baltic disputed. According to {ref Kortlandt 1994} (followed by {ref Derksen 2015}:336) from PIE *h₂nek̑-, but this root etymology has not been met with widespread acceptance elsewhere (cf. {ref LIV²} 282-283; {ref ALEW} 708).

Derived from the Proto-Germanic. strong verb *reukan- ~ *rūkan- 'to smoke' {ref Seebold 1970}:379-380, {ref Kluge 2011}:748, {ref Kroonen 2013}:406, 410. There is with no further accepted etymology outside of Germanic, cf. further discussion in /cognate/299/.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'to beat' ({ref Derksen 2008}:41, {ref ESSJa} 2:99-100, {ref LIV²} 72).
Root etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:109, {ref Orel 1998}:386, {ref Holm 2011}:81, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:994-995 for various proposals and further discussion.
Etymology outside of (East) Baltic obscure, see {ref IEW} 986, {ref Karulis 1992} II:256 for various older proposals. Cf. also {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:859 s.v. Lith. spalvà 'colour'.
Loanword from Middle Low German swâr 'heavy' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:802).

The etymology of the East Slavic term is unclear. One of the most widely accepted hypotheses links it to Slavic *polx- 'fear, frighten' and further to PIE *pelh₁- (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:410). It is semantically convincing. However, a phonetically regular reflex should have -olo- then, e.g. Russian **polohoj. A solution is to assume a borrowing from Polish płochy (or a phonetic conforming at the Polish word). However, such a borrowing would be very isolated. Further, the Polish-like form of the root has been attested (in derivatives) already from 14th-15th centuries and it is spread in all East Slavic dialects. Another solution is to assume a contamination with ploskij 'flat'. The probability is disputable. Still another solution is to assume an irregular phonetic change driven or supported by the frequency. The phonetic circumstances are very favourable in this case. The (hipothetical) missing vowel was unstressed and East Slavic stress is dynamic and relatively strong (at least nowadays). Further, it stand between a stop and a liquid. In sequences / pR / there is always a short (prothetic, unphonological) vowel with a quality resembling the next vowel. An unstressed and therefore short, etymological vowel in / pVR / can be very easily interpreted as a prothetic, unphonological vowel articulation (and, in fact, vice versa), especially in cases as *polox- with two identical vowels. Further, we can deal with a dialectal, northern Russian feature in this case which could spread as a lexicalized inter-dialectal borrowing (cf. {ref Zaliznâk 2004}:39-41). Note that the oldest, precisely located attestations of plox-forms are found in texts from northern Russia. A combination of some of the given solutions is also conceivable.

A probable Greek-Albanian isogloss (cf. {ref LIV²} 362, {ref Orel 1998}:353-354, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:993, {ref Frisk 1960-1972} I:865, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:538 {ref Beekes 2010}:709).

Generally considered a zero-grade derivative of Proto-Germanic *bautan- 'to beat' with an original meaning 'blunt, truncated thing' ({ref EWNl}), further possibly to be derived from an IE root *bʰeu̯d- 'to beat' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:56, {ref LIV²} 82).

Root reference form for this class follows {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} to PIE *mei̯gʰ- 'to close the eyes, blink', cf. also {ref LIV²} 427, {ref ALEW} 644-645, {ref Derksen 2015}:315-316, {ref Smoczyński 2005}:240, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:395-396 for further discussion.

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed. Traditionally considered a labial-extension to the root *dʰu̯eh₂- 'make smoke' ({ref IEW} 247-248, {ref Orel 2003}:68, {ref Kluge 2011}:180; cf. {ref LIV²} 158). Alternatively {ref Kroonen 2013}:88 sets up a derived noun to PGmc. *dimpan ~ *dempan- 'to fog' < *dʰembʰ- (cf. MHG dimpfen 'to smoke, steam' Elfdalian dimba 'to smoke', Nw. demba 'to smoke'; but cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:180 who considers the MHG form a backformation to MHG dampf, not in {ref LIV²}.).

Comment: Uncertain etymology.
Justification: Etymology disputed; the best etymology would tentatively appear to be some sort of derivative to PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'burn, glow' (so {ref Huld 1984}:132, {ref Demiraj 1997}:206, but cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:460, {ref Orel 1998}:518 for alternative proposals).
Indic lexemes possibly to be connected with Vedic √khod- 'thrusts (penis) into' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:209, no. 3934; no certain etymology outside of Indic for Ved. √khod- cf. {ref EWAia} I:456).

Comment: proposed relation to PIE *u̯ebʰ- "to weave" rejected by Cheung (2007)

Justification: Traditionally postulated to a root *ser- 'red' ({ref IEW} 910-911, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:763), although this etymology is no longer accepted by {ref ALEW} 891. Cf. also {ref Smoczyński 2007}:534, {ref Karulis 1992} II:155-156.
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *kau̯p- 'to pound, beat'; further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:249-250, {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:570-571).
Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *gōda- 'suitable, good', a derivative of PIE *gʰedʰ- 'to fit together' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:162-163, 184, {ref EWA 4}:694-697, cf. {ref LIV²} 195).
Boeotian καλϝός shows that the Proto-Greek stem for the adjective was *kalu̯o-, but there is no secure etymology beyond of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:486-487, {ref Beekes 2010}:626-627).

Romance lexemes derived from French gauchir 'to warp, deform', originally a loanword from Old Low Franconian *wenkjan 'to waver, falter' (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 17:555-560 for further discussion).

Anatolian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'to make smoke' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:895, {ref EWAia} I:795, {ref ALEW} 243, {ref Derksen 2015}:145, {ref ESSJa} 5:203, {ref Derksen 2008}:132, {ref de Vaan 2008}:249, {ref Matasović 2009}:111, {ref Irslinger 2002}:61; cf. {ref LIV²} 158).

IE inherited status uncertain. Certainly there is enough comparative material between Italic, Germanic, Greek, and Albanian to posit a (European) IE word *skeh₂p-, but due to the geographical proximity of the branches the possibility of (independent?) early loanwords cannot be entirely excluded (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:408, {ref Huld 1984}:114, {ref Orel 1998}:421, {ref de Vaan 2008}:546, {ref Beekes 2010}:1350 for further discussion).

Comment: maybe < *dreuH-so- ? cf. Cheung (2007: 79-80)

Justification: Loanword from Polish budynek 'building', itself ultimately a loanword from Middle German buding 'building' ({ref Boryś 2005}:45).

IE root etymology disputed: either (1) to PIE h₂ek̑- 'sharp' and connected with OCS ostьnъ 'sharp point', or (2) to PIE *Host- 'bone' and cognate with Hitt. ḫāstai-, Skt. asthi-, Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, etc. ({ref Karulis 1992} I:80-81).

Etymology disputed. {ref Orel 1998}:496 and {ref LIV²} 620-621 assign the verb to *tekʷ-, against which cf. {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1001-1002. {ref Holm 2011:57} also rejects *tekʷ-, instead suggesting *dʰgʷʰei̯- 'hinschwinden, sterben' as a more plausible alternative. {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1001-1002 propose a speculative etymology to a root *dekʷs-.
Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek *ζαβρός / *ζαρβός (cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:530 for further discussion).
Romance lexemes from Latin (com)battuere ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:85, 196), of obscure origin ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:68).

Romance lexemes from Latin luctāre 'to fight' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:418), a frequentative verb based on PIE *lu⁽g̑⁾-to- 'bent' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:350, cf. {ref LIV²} 416 s.v. 2. *leu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'biegen').

Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin perna 'haunch, ham together with the leg' ({ref DCECH} IV:538-539). For the IE reconstruction given, cf. {ref EWAia} II:123-124; for a proposed derivation to a verbal root *TsperH- 'to kick with the foot', cf. {ref Lubotsky 2006} and the discussion of {ref de Vaan 2008}:460-461.
Loanword from Indic? (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:149 no. 2922).

Traditionally considered cognate with Proto-Germanic *hakan- 'hook' ({ref ESSJa} 10:109-110, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 2:275, cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:387), although extra-Germanic connections to the Germanic comparanda are doubted by {ref Kroonen 2013}:203 on the basis of formal difficulties. [Not in {ref Derksen 2008}].

Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *erþō-, generally considered a dental-stem to a PIE root *h₁er- seen elsewhere in Ancient Greek ἔρα 'earth', Welsh erw 'field', cf. also the Old High German hapax ero 'earth' ({ref Lehmann 1986}:18, {ref Kluge 2011}:253-254, {ref Kroonen 2013}:118-119, cf. also {ref Beekes 2010}:449).

Leaving the most unconvincing hypotheses (like the one linking to a hardly if ever attested interjection ps) aside, it still remains obscure which PIE root the Slavic lexeme belongs to. It applies also to a part of (potential) IE cognates, the differentiation between the reconstructed PIE roots relevant here is generally far from clear, cf. {ref NIL}. Therefore, it is most reasonable not to go beyond the Slavic in the reconstruction.

Modern Greek forms from Ancient Greek στρογγύλος 'round, spherical' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1343). Generally connected to Ancient Greek στράγξ 'squeezed out drop' and further to OHG strang ({ref Frisk 1960-1972}: II:810-811, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1064-1065}), although the semantic connection within Greek not overly persuasive ({ref Beekes 2010}:1415). Further etymology outside of Greek therefore uncertain.

The etymology and further cognacy is uncertain. For the discussion on the nativity of PS *melko 'milk' and its relationship to PIE *h₂melg̑- 'to milk' see {ref ESSJa}: 18: 87-88 (the authors claim that PS *melko 'milk' is not derived from / related to PIE *h₂melg̑- 'to milk').
Etymology outside Slavic uncertain, cf. {ref ESSJa} 3:44-45, {ref Boryś 2005}:40-41, {ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-} 1:381-382, {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 1:265 for various proposals.

Comment: Emmerick/Skjærvø (1982: 55) follow Henning's suggestion to derive the Khotanese word from *drigu- (cf. Avestan drigu- "arm, bedürftig, schwach"). The Avestan word is considered an Iranian innovation by Mayrhofer (EWAia I: 68): "Konträrbildung zu dem ererbten indoiran. *ádhri-gu-, aus irriger Auffassung *a-dhrigu-".

Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *met-. Further IE root etymology disputed: either to PIE ?1. *met- 'mähen' ({ref LIV²} 422) or ?2. *met- 'abmessen' ({ref LIV²} 422) ({ref Derksen 2015}:313-314, {ref ESSJa} 18:105-108, 112-115, {ref Derksen 2008}:308-309); {ref ALEW} 639-641 doubts connections outside of Balto-Slavic.

Comment: Cheung (2007: 20) mentions a suggestion by Rastorgueva/Edel'man (2003: 159) to sort the Khotanese verb to *bād < PIE *bʰēdʰ-, viz. *pati-/api-bād-. They also suggest (not mentioned by Cheung) that this word could derive from api-šad- "oppress" < had "sit" (cf. Emmerick 1968: 85).

Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Rejzek 2001}:638, {ref Králik 2015}:589 for discussion of various hypotheses.
Generally connected to PIE *sokʷo- 'juice of plants and fruit' ({ref Meyer 1891}:196, cf. {ref IEW} 1042, {ref Huld 1984}:67, {ref Demiraj 1997}:181-182, {ref Orel 1998}:129, {ref Holm 2011}:53).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *h₂stḗr-, *h₂ster- ́ 'star' ({ref NIL} 348-354, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:326, {ref Adams 2013}:701, {ref Beekes 2010}:156-157, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:120-122, {ref Clackson 2017}:110, {ref EWAia} II:755-756, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:330 no. 5798, {ref Lehmann 1986}:322, {ref Kroonen 2013}:478, {ref de Vaan 2008}:585, {ref Matasović 2009}:355). For a proposed deep etymological connection with PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry up/wither by heat' cf. {ref Pinault 2007}.

Comment: probably via New Persian غایب
Justification: Parallel loans from Arabic غایب, probably via New Persian غایب 'hidden'.

Two possibilities: Either (1) as a loan from Romance *notāre (with irregular root vocalism from Lat. natāre 'swim', so {ref Meyer 1891}:311, {ref Orel 1998}:301), or – perhaps better – (2) directly derived to PIE *(s)neh₂- (so {ref Huld 1984}:148, {ref Holm 2011}:83). No discussion in {ref Demiraj 1997} or {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}.
As though from Sanskrit *baluvā-, cf. Sanskrit baluha- only attested by lexicographers ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:535, no. 9407). Further etymology uncertain ({ref KEWA} II:483).

Root etymology disputed (cf. esp. {ref Demiraj 1997}:257-258); possibly related to cognates from PIE 2. *h₂er- ({ref LIV²} 270-271, so {ref Hamp 1965}:140, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:983), but alternative etymologies are also possible (cf. also {ref Meyer 1891}:261, {ref Jokl 1911}:53-54, {ref Huld 1984}:89-90, {ref Orel 1998}:246).
Loanword from Slavic trajati, cf. Serbo-Croatian trȁjati 'to last, continue' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).

Root etymology follows {ref LIV²} 274, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:975-976, tentatively also {ref Huld 1984}:72. However, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:140-141 who proposes to PIE *h₁ed- 'eat', and {ref Holm 2011}:59-60 who rejects all previously proposed etymologies.

Lexemes from PIE *trei̯- 'three' ({ref Eichner 1982}:142-297, {ref LIPP 2}:803-805, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:872-873, {ref Adams 2013}:339-340, {ref Beekes 2010}:1502, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:261-262, {ref Demiraj 1997}:387-388, {ref Orel 1998}:463, {ref EWAia} I:675-678, {ref ALEW} 1125-1126, {ref Derksen 2015}:471, {ref Derksen 2008}:449, {ref Kroonen 2013}:546-547, {ref de Vaan 2008}:628-629, {ref Matasović 2009}:390).

Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *uḍḍīyate ~ *uḍḍayate 'flies up' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:77, no.1697), further derived from Vedic √day-ⁱ (1) 'fly'; no further etymology ({ref EWAia} I:700, {ref KEWA} I:460).

Slavic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *tengʰ- 'to pull' ({ref Derksen 2008}:494, {ref Kroonen 2013}:551, {ref ALEW} 1110-1111) For the root reconstruction, cf. discussion in {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.
Cf. Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike; thresh; [inch., intr.] to become tired' with no certain etymology outside of Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:141-143).
No certain etymology outside of Indic ({ref EWAia} II:201-202), for Middle and Modern Indic cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:508, no. 9051).

A transferred adjective from the noun phrase iēcur fīcātum 'fig-stuffed liver' (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 3:490-493), further etymology uncertain; Latin fīcus 'fig' appears to be a Mediterranean Wanderwort, cf. Attic Greek. σῦκον, (Boeotian τῦκον )'fig', Armenian. tʻowz 'dried fig' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:232, {ref de Vaan 2008}:218). A similar lexical replacement also occurred in the history of Greek (cf. /cognate/1505/).
Originally a loanword in Old Norse from Middle Low German spīsen ({ref de Vries 1977}:536).

The forms in this class from Proto-Germanic *spīwan- are generally compared with similar verbs denoting 'to spit' found elsewhere among the Indo-European languages ({ref LIV²} 583-584, reconstructing *spti̯eu̯H-, cf. non-Jena 175 'spit' in /cognate/305/). Reconstructing a common IE root for these forms, however, is extremely difficult, as the forms in various branches likely underwent deformations or reformations among individual daughter languages due to onomatopoeia or phonotactic reasons. Within Germanic these forms are more-or-less regular from *spīwan- / *speiw-a- (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:450-452, {ref Kroonen 2013}:468).

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing an Ancient Greek denominal verb μυρίζω 'to salve, perfume', derived from Ancient Greek μύρον 'salve, perfume' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:903). Perhaps further cognate with Germanic Celtic words 'to smear, fat' (OHG smero 'smear', OIr. smi(u)r 'marrow') < *smer-u-, but a Semitic loanword may well be equally as likely; cf. AGk. μύρρα 'myrrh, sweet-smelling word of the myrrh plant', Aram. mūrā, Heb. mōr, Arab. murr 'myrrh' (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:983).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin strictus 'narrow' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:686 no. 8305, cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 12:298). The further PIE root etymology is difficult as Latin strictus, probably represents a blend / contamination of PIE *strig- 'to brush, strip', and *strengʰ- 'to tie' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:591-592, cf. {ref LIV²} 603-604).

Generally connected to Lith. vir̃bas 'twig, rod', Rus. верба (OCS връба) 'willow' from a zero-grade fromation *u̯r̥b-, and Lat. uerbera '(rods for) punishment', uerbēnae 'twigs of the laurel' from the full-grade *u̯erb- ({ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:636-637, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:964), but {ref Beekes 2010}:1269-1270 is inclined to believe the word is of substratum origin.

From Proto-Germanic *grundu- 'floor' (Old Frisian grund); further etymological connections problematic, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:161, {ref Orel 2003}:144, {ref Kluge 2011}:378, {ref Kroonen 2013}:192 for various proposals and further discussion.

Latvian lexemes generally connected with Lithuanian kúokas 'club, stick'; further etymology uncertain. Traditionally connected with PIE *keu̯- 'to bend' with a velar extension -k- ({ref Karulis 1992} I:413-414, cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:306, {ref IEW} 589), but more recently cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007}:324 regarding the etymology uncertain. [Not in {ref Derksen 2015}, {ref ALEW}].

Very similar in form and meaning to Latin dulcis 'sweet', but a common proto-form cannot be reconstructed. Perhaps the Italic and Greek lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:228-229, {ref Beekes 2010}:227-228). Cf. further discussion in /cognate/7772/.

In spite of numerous phonological and morphological difficulties, often assumed to be root-cognate with Latin lācrima 'tear', Armenian artaswr 'tear', OHG zahar 'tear', Ved. áśru-, TochA ākär, Hittite išḫaḫru 'tear(s)', etc., (cf. {ref Hamp 1972}). The Leiden dictionaries (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:322, {ref Beekes 2010}:299-300) generally follow the proposal of {ref Kortlandt 1985a}, assuming a common pre-form for the Greek and Latin forms as a nominal compound *dr̥k̑-h₂k̑ru- 'eye-bitter' containing the roots *derk̑- 'catch sight of, look at' and *h₂ek̑- 'be sharp'.

Comment: perhaps from vad- 'raise one's voice, sound, speak', vádati (RV)

Justification: A semantic extension from Proto-Germanic *burzda- 'board; table'. Further etymology uncertain. Traditionally compared to a root *bʰerdʰ- 'to cut' ({ref IEW} 138, {ref de Vries 1977}:50) but only uncertainly postulated as ?*bʰerdʰ- in {ref LIV²} 77-78. Alternatively {ref Kroonen 2013}:74, 86 proposes an etymology comparing a secondary zero-grade form *bruzda- > ON broddr 'tip, edge, shoot', OHG brort 'point, margin' and Old Irish brot 'goad, spike' from an o-grade formation to a postulated root *bʰrezdʰ-.
Generally derived from PIE *bʰerH- 'work with a sharp tool' ({ref LIV²} 80, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:43-44, {ref Orel 1998}:24-25, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:966).

Occasionally considered a loanword from Ancient Greek δάκρῡμα (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:336). Elsewhere, in spite of numerous phonological and morphological difficulties, often assumed to be root-cognate with Latin lācrima 'tear', Armenian artaswr 'tear', OHG zahar 'tear', Ved. áśru-, TochA ākär, Hittite išḫaḫru 'tear(s)', etc., (cf. {ref Hamp 1972}). The Leiden dictionaries (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:322, {ref Beekes 2010}:299-300) generally follow the proposal of {ref Kortlandt 1985a}, assuming a common pre-form for the Greek and Latin forms as a nominal compound *dr̥k̑-h₂k̑ru- 'eye-bitter' containing the roots *derk̑- 'catch sight of, look at' and *h₂ek̑- 'be sharp'.
Of uncertain etymology (Giovanni Abete, p.c.).

Etymology disputed. Originally proposed a loanword from Latin sequor 'follow' by {ref Meyer 1891}:408 and followed by {ref Holm 2011}:86; alternatively considered since {ref Jokl 1911}:80-82 to be connected with Albanian shteg 'path', cognate with Greek στοῖχος 'row, line' and derived from PIE *stei̯gʰ- (followed by {ref Huld 1984}:114, {ref Orel 1998}:421; cf. {ref LIV²} 593-594, without Albanian). [Not in {ref Demiraj 1997}, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}].
Of onomatopoeic origin from the interjection 'joj, joh' (cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}:232, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}).
Loan from Wakhi diγ̌ə́r, digə́r 'fingernail' ({ref Morgenstierne 1936}:662, cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:146-147).

Slavic forms from Proto-Slavic *koren- 'root' and generally connected within Balto-Slavic to Lith. kẽras 'tree-stump, stub, bush, shrub', etc. Further connections outside of Balto-Slavic are uncertain (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:237, {ref ESSJa} 11:62-65, {ref Derksen 2015}:238, {ref ALEW} 478 for discussion of various proposals).

SMG κολυμπώ, etc. from Ancient Greek κολυμβάω 'dive headlong (like a κόλυμβος-bird)' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:701), a denominal verb to κόλυμβος 'little grebe, podiceps minor'. Further etymology obscure ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:559, {ref Beekes 2010}:741).

Cf. also Lith. į́sas 'short'. Baltic lexemes from Proto-Baltic *insa-. Further etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, traditionally connected to Ved. iṣṇāti 'drive, propel' from PIE *h₂ei̯sh₂- 'to invigorate; to drive, propel' (cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007}:225, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:187). [Not in {ref ALEW}, {ref Derksen 2015}].

Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain. Appears to be a derivative from Lithuanian úodas 'mosquito', which is in turn traditionally derived from the same root of Lithuanian ė́sti 'to eat' < PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat', but many uncertainties remain regarding this etymological connection. Cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007}:704, {ref ALEW} 1150-1151, {ref Derksen 2015}:480 for further discussion.

The etymology is obscure. Although a single etymology of all Slavic lexemes listed in the citations below is formally and semantically possible, it can not be excluded that we deal here with more than one etymon (also with loanwords) with possible later mergers and contaminations. In any case, the hypothesis about an ordinary (Middle) German loanword in the case of the Sorbian, Polish and Czech lexemes for 'ball' seems to be at least an oversimplification.
However, even if we accept a single native etymon here, it is complicated to establish its further etymology and IE cognates without additional assumptions.
Cf. a semantically related PS leeme *gula, e.g. Polish gula 'bump'. Accordingly, expressive deformations are also possible.
In all likelihood a loanword but of uncertain origin (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:87-88, {ref Orel 1998}:234).
Denominal formations to Vedic mr̥gá- 'wild animal'; further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:370-371).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Albanian, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *leh₃u̯-'to pour; to wash' ({ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} and {ref Melchert 2011}:127-132; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:511-513, {ref Beekes 2010}:872-873, {ref Meyer 1891}:237, {ref Huld 1984}:85, {ref Demiraj 1997}:230-231, {ref Orel 1998}:210, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:980, {ref de Vaan 2008}:330-331).
Cf. Proto-Iranic *kau̯š- 'to fight, struggle, kill', further derived from PIE *keh₂u̯- 'to beat; to split' ({ref Cheung 2007}:251-252, {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:525-526, cf. {ref LIV²} 345-346).
From Latin gula, probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:284-285, {ref de Vaan 2008}:275 for further discussion).
Derivative from PIE *peu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'to pierce, sting', cf. {ref LIV²} 480, {ref de Vaan 2008}:499 for further discussion.
Identical to 'liver' in other Slavic languages ({ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1714, cf. {ref ESSJa} 6:72-73, {ref Derksen 2008}:158).

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing derivatives of Ancient Greek παλαίω 'to wrestle' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1024), and probably further to be derived from PIE *pelh₂- 'to approach, draw near' ({ref LIV²} 470-471, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1145).

The etymology is not entirely clear due to possible expressive deformations and contaminations.
I adopt here the view of {ref ESSJa}, see below. However, it has to be treated with caution. Another possibilities, proposed in {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} (see below), are a relationship to PIE *trenk- (cf. {ref Boryś 2005}: 641 and {ref LIV²}: 649) or to cognate/4961/ (without certain further etymology).
Modern Indic and Slavic lexemes from PIE *h₁enter- 'inner part' ({ref Derksen 2008}:158, {ref ESSJa} 6:72-73, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:16-17 no. 357, {ref EWAia} I:76-77, I:166-167).

Traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *kwasta- 'pine brush', Albanian gjeth 'foliage' < *gu̯osd-o- ({ref ESSJa} 7:185-186, cf. {ref Orel 2003}:227 and discussion to Albanian words for 'leaf' in /cognate/3390/), but considered to be of uncertain etymology according to ({ref Derksen 2008}:196). The traditional etymology has been tentatively accepted here.

The most promising etymology derives from a zero-grade form of PIE *seh₁- comparable to full-grade forms found in Celtic, Italic, and Germanic, cf. Old Irish sír 'long', Latin sērus 'belated, slow', Proto-Germanic *sīϸu- (so {ref Jokl 1911}:28, {ref Orel 1998}:133, but cf. the reservations of {ref Huld 1984}:68-69).

No certain cognates outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. Latv. dižs 'great'). Commonly conntected with PIE *dei̯h₂- 'to light up' (LIV² 108, IEW 183f.), which is however problematic, as Winter's lengthening is lacking ({ref ALEW} 204-205; not in {ref Derksen 2015}, cf. also {ref Smoczyński 2007}:107-108).

Etymology outside of Greek unknown, possibly to PIE *h₂eu̯- 'to perceive' if a de-adverbial formation as though from *h₂ou̯is-i̯é- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1059-1060, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:785-786).

Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂erg̑- 'brilliant, white' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:307, {ref Adams 2013}:52-53). For non-target Hellenic and Indic lexemes in this class cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:125, {ref EWAia} I:116.

Generally further connected to Greek ἀχλύς 'mist, darkness' and Armenian *ałǰ- in ałǰutʻiwnkʻ 'darkness' ({ref Derksen 2015}:555, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:184, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:37-39 for further discussion).
Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *sīro- 'long' < PIE *seh₁-ro- 'long lasting (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:115-116, {ref Matasović 2009}:337).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *treu̯H- 'to rub; to use' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:496-497, 499; {ref Boryś 2005}:640-641, 644).
From Ancient Greek *ἀνεμόω 'blow' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:110), a derivative to ἄνεμος 'wind', further to PIE *h₂enh₁- 'blow' (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:101-102, {ref LIV²} 267-268).

Etymology disputed. There are two main possibilities: either (1) to *kolso- underlying the Germanic and Italic lexemes in /cognate/265/, or (2) to PIE *kʷelh₁- ({ref LIV²} 386-388) as a reduplicated formation (cf. {ref ALEW} 433-434). The latter explanation is favoured by {ref Derksen 2015}:220. Both proposed etymologies are not precise correspondences and require special pleading to explain the deviations so that it is difficult to favour one etymology over the other (cf. {ref ALEW} 434 for further discussion).
Cf. 'take' in /cognate/5227/.

Greek, Armenian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes from an original m-stem noun *g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´-; based on the ablaut patterns attested among the daughter languages a basic root *g̑ʰei̯- can be abstracted ({ref NIL} 162-169, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1619-1620, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1599, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:434-435, {ref EWAia} II:815-816, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:815 no. 14096).

A derivative of Portuguese apertar 'tighten, press, clamp', from Latin appectorāre 'press on the chest' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:44), further derived from Latin pectus 'chest'. For connections elsewhere in Indo-European, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:491, {ref de Vaan 2008}:453, and further discussion in /cognate/4015/.

Slavic lexemes to be further connected with dialectal Lithuanian pìršys 'chest (of a horse)', but further connections outside of Balto-Slavic remain uncertain. Traditionally further compared to Vedic párśu- 'rib' (cf. e.g. {ref Boryś 2005}:431), but this connection remains unclear for formal reasons ({ref Derksen 2008}:429, {ref Derksen 2015}:358, cf. {ref EWAia} II:100-101).

Cf. {ref LIPP 2} s.v. *g̑ʰés- 'gestern' for extensive discussion of the attempted reconstructions of forms in this class, also {ref NIL} s.v. *dei̯-, *di- under ?*(g̑ʰ)-di-es (with discussion in footnotes 6-18). The cognacy of the lexemes in this class is not disputed, however there remains much disagreement in the literature how the forms are derived in the attested languages from a common reconstruction. The two most commonly held hypotheses include (1) derivations related to the Germanic word for 'day' (cf. /cognate/200/, not without its own problems in derivation) as *dʰg̑ʰ-i̯es- (zero-grade root + comparative suffix or endingless locative) or (2) a compound of the Indo-European deictic *g̑ʰo- ~ *g̑ʰ- (cf. LIPP 2 275-276) in the zero-grade + the root *dei̯- ~ *di- 'shine' ({ref NIL} 69-81, cf. esp. fn6), which underlies words for day in many other branches (cf. /cognate/375/). For a recent extensive discussion of these and other hypotheses, cf. LIPP 2 269-270. For individual branches, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1692, {ref Demiraj 1997}:138, {ref Orel 1998}:68, {ref EWAia} II:822, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:313-314, {ref Kroonen 2013}:175-176, {ref de Vaan 2008}:283, {ref Matasović 2009}:155). Cf. also {ref Schindler 1977} and {ref Puhvel 1987} for further discussion on aspects of the IE reconstruction.
No certain etymology outside of Slavic, cf. {ref ESSJa} 14:249-252, {ref Derksen 2008}:274, {ref Boryś 2005}:280 for further discussion of various hypotheses.

Connections outside of Albanian unclear. The two main hypotheses connect the word either (1) to Germanic and Balto-Slavic words for 'sound' < *g(o)l-so- (so {ref Orel 1998}:138, cf. {ref IEW} 350), or (2) with the IE inherited word for 'tongue' *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- (so {ref Huld 1984}:71, {ref Holm 2011}:85).
Slavic lexemes generally derived from PIE *kreu̯H- 'to heap up; to cover' ({ref LIV²} 371, {ref Derksen 2008}:254). For older hypotheses, cf. {ref ESSJa} 13:71-72.

Modern Greek χρονιά 'year' from Ancient Greek χρόνος 'time' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1613-1614), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1277-1278, {ref Beekes 2010}:1613-1614 for discussion of older but unconvincing attempts at an IE etymology).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fahsa- 'hair of the head' as though from PIE *pok̑-s-o-, cf. Ancient Greek Gk. πέκος 'fleece' < *pek̑-es-, derived from PIE 1. *pek̑- 'to pluck (wool or hair)' ({ref Orel 2003}:89, {ref Kroonen 2013}:122, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1164, {ref LIV²} 467).

There is no consensus etymology outside of Slavic (cf. {ref ESSJa} 7:146-149, {ref  Rejzek 2001}:216, {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:353, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 1:463, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}). Against the older proposed comparisons to Latin grandis 'big', Ancient Greek βρένθος 'pride', cf. respectively {ref de Vaan 2008}:270, {ref Beekes 2010}:237-238.
Probably of onomatopoeic/imitative origin (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:511, no. 9090; {ref KEWA} II:307).

Since {ref Meyer 1892}:18 compared with Armenian jag 'small bird' with various proposed reconstructions to reconcile the comparison (for further discussion cf. {ref IEW} 409 s.v. *g̑ʰāgʷʰ-, {ref Demiraj 1997}:429-430, {ref Holm 2011}:52-53, and {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:239 most recently proposing a pre-form *g̑ʰu̯eh₂gʰV-). Alternatively {ref Huld 1984}:135-136, {ref Orel 1998}:525 assume that the forms are an Oriental Wanderwort comparing also Persian zāq 'chough', but cf. {ref Holm 2011}:52 rejecting this hypothesis on the grounds that it is not a typical case of a Wanderwort. {ref Demiraj 1997}:430 remains unconvinced and instead suggests an onomatopoeic origin.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰeHbʰ- 'to be fitting, suitable' ({ref Derksen 2008}:109-110, {ref LIV²} 135-136, cf. {ref ESSJa} 5:45-46).

Comment: Sims-Williams (2000: 232f., quoted from Korn 2005: 132) suggests *su̯l̥g̑ʰ-su- in order to explain Bactrian χοζο. Korn (l.c.) assumes *su̯elk̑s for xwaš-forms.

Justification: Loanword from Turkish χob 'beautiful', ultimately from Persian hūb 'beautiful' ({ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 4:284).

It is unclear whether Josef Elfenbein apud {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:38 is implying that Pashto kāl 'year' is cognate with the Indic lexemes in this class, or that it is a loanword. If cognate, together with the Indic lexemes from Vedic kālá- 'time, point in time' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:157, no. 3084) they would point to a Proto-Indo-Iranic *kālá-. The cognacy of these forms has been tentatively accepted here for now. No further certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic, cf. {ref EWAia} I:343 for a discussion of the main possibilities.
A probable loan from Wakhi ({ref Morgenstierne 1936}:662, cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:188).
Slavic lexemes generally derived from a causative-iterative stem *sod-éi̯e- to PIE *sed- 'to seat (oneself)' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:202-203, {ref ESSJa} 8:49-52, {ref LIV²} 513-515).
Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-European *mleu̯h₂- 'to speak' ({ref LIV²} 446-447, {ref EWAia} II:235-236, {ref Cheung 2007}:274-275).

The vast majority of Slavic etymology dictionaries assume or accept the etymology presented in {ref ESSJa}: 112, cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 2: 508; {ref Rejzek 2001}: 351; {ref Boryś 2005}: 302-303; {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 2: 152; {ref Snoj 1997-2016}; {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012}: 277-278; {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-}: 3: 449; {ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-}: 6: 25; {Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}: 772-773. The hypothesis of {Machek 1968}: 328, assuming a relatedness to Polish polować 'hunt' does not stand up scrutiny (it is impossible phonetically, morphologically and philologically).
According to the mainstream hypothesis, PS *loviti is related to Lithuanian lavùs 'dexterous', Greek Attic λεία (*λᾱϝιᾱ), Doric λᾱία 'gain', Latin lucrum 'gain', Gothic laun, Old High German lôn 'reward' and Old Irelandic folad 'richness', lúag 'praise' and derived from PIE *leh₂u 'aquire by fighting' (for the root reference form see {ref de Vaan 2008}: 349-350 or {ref Kroonen 2013}: 329).
However, {ref Derksen 2008}: 286 does not mention this etymology at all, claiming "To my knowledge, there are no cognates outside Balto-Slavic". The Slavic lexeme is not listed among cognates of the relevant words by {ref Kroonen 2013}: 329, {ref de Vaan 2008}: 349-350 and {ref Matasović 2009}: 397-398. According to {ref Beekes 2010}: 188, who compares Greek ἀπολαύω with Latin lucrum and Gothic laun, "the appurtenance of OCS lovъ 'catch, chase', loviti 'to catch, chase' would require *lh₂eu-, which is an improbable formation".
The etymology is accepted by {ref de Vries 1961}: 347-348 and {ref Lehmann 1986}: 228-229. The mainstream hypothesis is accepted here, although the case needs further investigation.

Derivatives from Proto-Slavic *poļe 'field' (cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:460, {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012}:486-487, 506, {ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-} 8:137), and further to PIE *pleh₂- 'flat, wide' ({ref NIL 562-564, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:411). Taking into account the distribution and a rather non-trivial semantic derivation, one could expect, that this form developed in one of these languages and was diffused into the other. However, the source language is impossible to determine phonetically or morphologically.
Etymology uncertain (cf. {ref ALEW} 1269 for further discussion). [Not in {ref Derksen 2015}. cf. also {ref Smoczyński 2007}:765].

Anatolian, Hellenic, Albanian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *u̯et- 'year' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:1014-1015, {ref Beekes 2010}:476-477, {ref Huld 1984}:129-130, {ref Demiraj 1997}:419-420, {ref Orel 1998}:509, {ref EWAia} II:495).

The precise root and stem reconstruction for this form in Indo-European is debated (cf. esp. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:819-821, {ref EWAia} I:728-729), the cognacy of the lexemes in this class to each other is, however, generally agreed (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:819-821, {ref Demiraj 1997}:184-185, {ref Orel 1998}:130, {ref EWAia} I:728-729, {ref ALEW} 392-393, {ref Derksen 2015}:199-200, {ref Derksen 2008}:133, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:360-361, {ref Kroonen 2013}:327, {ref de Vaan 2008}:348). The reconstructed root form for this class follows {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.

Romance forms from Latin cīrcā, an adverbial form of Latin cīrcus 'circle; circus' ({ref DCECH} II:42). Further probably a loanword from Ancient Greek κίρκος, κρίκος 'ring' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:122-123, {ref de Vaan 2008}:115).

Hittite āššu-/āššau̯- 'good' is generally connected to Ancient Greek ἐΰς 'good, brave, noble' and Ved. sú- 'good' < *h₁su-, but the details of the inner-Anatolian stem formation is still debated ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:223-225).

The link to PIE *terkʷ- is formally and semantically attractive. An alternative etymology points to PIE *(s)ter- 'hard(en)', cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}, however it has formal and semantical issues (cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 4:227)

Romance lexemes from Latin gȳrāre 'to turn around in a circle' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:335), a denominal verb from Latin gȳrus 'circle', a technical term borrowed from Ancient Greek γῦρος 'ring, circle' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:286).
IE root etymology difficult. This class tentatively follows {ref Beekes 2010}:1503-1504, {ref LIV²} 650 s.v. *trep-, but cf. also {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1132-1133.

Neapolitan avutà as though from Latin *voltāre 'to turn' (Giovanni Abete, p.c., cf. Meyer-Lübke 1935}:789), an unattested intensive/iterative formation to Latin voluō 'to turn' and further to PIE 2. u̯el- 'to turn, roll' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:752, {ref de Vaan 2008}:689-690, {ref LIV²} 675).

No certain etymology outside of Baltic; perhaps to be connected with Lithuanian leĩlas 'slender', but the semantics of the comparison are difficult (cf. {ref ALEW} 580). Traditionally to a root 2. *lei̯- 'eingehen, abnehmen, schwinden; mager, schlank' in {ref IEW} 661-662, cf. {ref Karulis 1992} I:525.
Generally connected with Vedic ásita 'dark coloured, black' and Young Avestan āhita- (if meaning 'spotted, unclean'). Further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:482, {ref EWAia} I:146).
Etymology obscure (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:200 for discussion)

As {ref Derksen 2008}: 228-229 points out, there are two candidates for the root etymology: PIE *kelH 'rise, rise above' {ref LIV²}: 349 and *kʷelh₁- 'turn, rotate' {ref LIV²}: 386-388 (reconstructed as *kʷel(H) by Derksen). From the formal, phonetic point of view there can not be any clue in Slavic. Moreover, the proximity of two proto-meanings (having the concept of movement in common) makes it in my opinion impossible to raise any convincing semantic arguments even in external comparisons with other IE forms. Cf. {ref ESSJa}: 10: 133. Therefore, any strict decision would be speculative.
Authors of the Slavic etymology rather tend to see *kʷel(H) here, see {ref Boryś 2005}: 243 or {ref Snoj 1997-2016}.

Etymology disputed. Possibly to PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- ({ref IEW} 541-2) if one follows {ref Orel 1998}:200, 482 to Alb. thyej 'break' (cf. {ref LIV²} 319-320, without Albanian lexemes listed); older etymologies (e.g. {ref Meyer 1891}:185, {ref Jokl 1911}:94) suggest a borrowing from Lat. convertere. The verb is not discussed in {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}.

Two variants *kʷr̥mi- and *u̯r̥mi- in the same meaning 'worm' are generally reconstructed for PIE. The variant *u̯r̥mi- attested in Germanic and Italic might have been secondary from *kʷr̥mi- (cf. {de Vaan 2008}:665), but it may also be possible that the two lexemes were a rhyming pair already in Indo-European poetic language (cf. {ref Watkins 1987}:288). Cf. also {ref Demiraj 1997}:225-226, {ref Orel 1998}:197, {ref EWAia} I:394-395, {ref ALEW} 493-494, {ref Derksen 2015}:246, {ref ESSJa} 4:171-172 {ref Derksen 2008}93-94, {ref Matasović 2009}:181-182.

Iranic and Italic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *dʰeh₁(i̯)- 'to suckle' ({ref MacKenzie 1990}:110, {ref EWAia} I:797, {ref de Vaan 2008}:210, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:281, cf. {ref LIV²} 138-139).

Parallel loans from Indic lexemes continued by Sanskrit haḍḍa- 'bone' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:807 no. 13952, {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:35). The Pashto form represents a diminutive and matches Gawarbati haḍoki.
