Loan from Iranic *ā(w)yak ({ref Morgenstierne 1936}:666).

Indic and Albanian lexemes derived from PIE 2. *(s)kend- 'to shine' ({ref EWAia} I:528-529, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:252 no. 4661, {ref Demiraj 1997}:199-200, {ref Orel 1998}:146-147, {ref Holm 2011}:70-71; cf. {ref LIV²} 554).

Comment: This seems to be a compound with the first part "or" being the actual word for "cloud" (given variously as orǝ́, owrǝ́, warǝ́, which derives from common *nebʰ- (cf. NP abr).

Bielmeier (1979: 189 in: Historische Untersuchung zum Erb- und Lehnwortschatzanteil im ossetischen Grundwortschatz, Frankfurt/Bern/Las Vegas: Lang) argues against the assumption that lenk is a loan from Caucasian languages and discusses the possibility of an IE origin by comparing it with Lithuanian leñgvas 'light' and Germanic *lenhw-ta-z (cf. Gothic leihts).

Justification: An i-stem adjective derived to PIE *pleh₂- 'flat, wide' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:620-621, {ref NIL} 562-564).

Traditionally connected with Lithuanian al̃pti 'to be weak; to crave, to yearn after', but without any certain correspondences outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 35-36, {ref Derksen 2015}:52, {ref Karulis 1992} I:264-265).

From Ancient Greek σαχνός 'tender' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), often further assumed to be connected to σώχω, ψώχω 'to rub down' but the details of the derivation are unclear; further etymology outside of Greek lacking ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:991, {ref Beekes 2010}:1314).

Comment: Loan from Dravidian

Justification:
The ingenous and popular etymology as *dus-di̯u- 'bad sky, bad day' is kept here. However, is should be born in mind that this etymology is considered to be doubtful or at least not the only thinkable by many scholars, cf. the citations below and {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 1: 521-522, {ref Rejzek 2001}: 129, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 1: 100.
One of the most widespread alternative etymologies assumes a relationship to PG *duska- 'drizzle(?)', see {ref Kroonen 2013}: 111.

Baltic and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- are traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from putative PIE *dʰeb- 'thick, firm, solid' ({ref IEW} 239). Due to the rarity of PIE *b and the areal proximity of the languages, however, these cognates might not be of Indo-European date, if they even are cognate at all. Note that because the Leiden school doubts the existence of PIE *b, the Leiden dictionaries reconstruct a *dʰebʰ-. This, however, causes problems for formal correspondences with the Germanic (although cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:89 attempting to save the etymology by invoking analogy with the Germanic iterative stem *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' as though from *dʰobʰ-néh₂-). Cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:97-98, {ref Derksen 2015}:530-531, {ref Kroonen 2013}:89, {ref Kluge 2011}:907 for further discussion.

No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:763). For Modern Indic forms cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:792 no. 13734. Cf. parallel loans from Sanskrit into Modern Indic in /cognate/5789/.

From Latin repōnere 'to put back, down; replace' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 10:269-270), further probably derived from PIE *tk̑ei̯- (cf. {ref LIV²} 643-644, {ref de Vaan 2008}:479 for discussion of the stem formation in Italic).
Cf. Latvian sēta 'fence', generally considered to be a derivative of PIE *seh₂(i̯)- 'to tie, bind' ({ref Karulis 1992}:175, for further discussion on the root reconstruction, cf. /cognate/3055/).

It is assumed of the Polish word to be a loanword from Czech (which can be further a loan from German). If it is true, the Kashubian word is most probably a loanword from Polish. An additional survey would be needed here. The Czech lexemes have probably also a complicated history. A contamination of two different etymona (on of which can be a loanword) is probable. Cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:677, {ref Rejzek 2001}:698.

Comment: *č > Sarikoli c (ts)
from root *k̑eh₃-, expected output would be hīne etc.

Justification: Possibly to IE *kʷu̯ap- (or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-) if to be compared with Lat. vapor 'steam, exhalation', Lith. kvė̃pti 'breathe' ({ref ALEW} 545-546, {ref Derksen 2015}:268), but these connections are not fully certain due to several irregular sound-changes needed to justify the comparison (cf. Chantraine 1968–1980}:494-495, {ref Beekes 2010}:638-639).
Romance lexemes with nominal *ped- (from Lat. pēs, pedis) as semantic-bearing morpheme in a light verb construction. For further etymological discussion, cf. 'foot' in /cognate/225/.

Romanian alerga, as though from Latin *allargāre, a verbal derivative of lārgus ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:28, {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further etymology uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:342, {ref de Vaan 2008}:327).

A derived verb from Modern Greek γούλα 'throat, neck' (cf. SMG αναγουλιάζω 'feel sick, be inclined to vomit', {ref Babinotis 2010}:116), in turn a loanword from Latin gula 'throat' (cf. 'neck' in /cognate/6065/).

Derived from the same root as Proto-Slavic *drāpati 'scratch', ultimately from PIE *drep- 'to cut off, tear off' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 1:465, {ref Derksen 2008}:115, 136, cf. {ref LIV²} 128-129).
Possibly a compound of σ̌ομό (< θερμό) ‘food’ + ἐλατός ‘driven’, cf. Tsak. γαϊδουρο-άτα (< -ἐλάτης ‘driver’) (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). Further etymology uncertain.

Often connected with the family of Ancient Greek πείρω 'pierce, run through' (cf. {ref LIV²} 472-473 s.v. 1. *per- 'hindurchkommen, durchqueren') with a velar extension to the root, but the root and stem formation remains nonetheless obscure (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:934-935, {ref Beekes 2010}:1229-1230).

Etymology uncertain. For a conjectural proposal to the family of words surrounding Lithuanian ùpė 'river' < PIE *h₂ep- 'water', cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:1169. [Not in {ref ALEW} or {ref Derksen 2015}.]

Comment: derived *-tá- participle/adj. from Proto-Indo-Iranian *d(ʱ)arj́(ʱ)- '(be/become/make) fix, solid', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 371, no. 6508, Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 706f.
Justification: Indic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *d⁽ʰ⁾arjʰ- 'to fix; be firm, strong', further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:371 no. 6508, {ref EWAia} I:707-708).

Hellenic and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived traditionally assigned to a root *peth₁- 'to fall' ({ref LIV²} 477-478, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:905-906, {ref Beekes 2010}:1195-1196). See now {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} considering a more basic PIE root *pet- 'to fall; to fly' merging also 2. *peth₂- 'to fly' ({ref LIV²} 479). Cf. also {ref EWAia} II:71-72).

From Latin ex-pōnere 'to put out, set forth' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further probably derived from PIE *tk̑ei̯- (cf. {ref LIV²} 643-644, {ref de Vaan 2008}:479 for discussion of the stem formation in Italic).

Comment: original meaning "dirt, dust"

Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'to blow' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:368, {ref Adams 2013}:546, {ref EWAia} II:542, {ref ALEW} 1226-1227, {ref Derksen 2015}:496, {ref Derksen 2008}:519-520, {ref Kroonen 2013}:587, {ref de Vaan 2008}:662-663, {ref Matasović 2009}:47, cf. {ref LIV²} 287).

Comment: *č > Sarikoli c (ts)

Justification: Root etymology in this class follows the proposal of {ref Jokl 1911}:61-62 to an inner-Albanian connection with dhjes 'shit (on), ruin' to PIE *g̑ʰed- ({ref IEW 423; tentatively followed by {ref LIV²} 172, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:290-291); cf. alternatively {ref Orel 1998}:287 following {ref Meyer 1891}:301 assumes a connection to Albanian ndyj 'to make dirty, soil, to dip, immerse' connecting to Gk. δύω 'to sink, cause to sink, to plunge in' < *du̯eH- (cf. {ref LIV²} 129-130, without Albanian).

From Ancient Greek ξηρός (adj.) 'dry' ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:355), further connections outside of Greek unclear; occasionally proposed to Arm. čʻor 'dry' (cf. /cognate/5006/), but this requires postulating a sound law in Armenian for which this is the only example (cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:182, {ref Beekes 2010}:1035-1036, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:546).

Comment: Mayrhofer (EWAia I 415) mentions doubtful relation with an OInd. root kroḍ and Wurzelerweiterungstypus *°EU̯-s-d-. It may fit to Celtic *krou̯di- and Slavic *krǫt-?

Kroonen writes that the Germanic words may either be related to forms such as Greek κρατύς and Sanskrit krátu- (with Germanic showing Schwebeablaut) or related to Lithuanian kir̃sti 'to turn sour'. According to ALEW, this verb is derived from the PIE root *(s)kert- 'to cut, to cut in two'.In the EWA, the two explanations Kroonen mentions are actually unified, the root reconstruction being "uridg. *(s)kret- (oder [s]kert- [?])".The LIV² only has a root *(s)kert-.
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Germanic *hardu- to be derived from PIE *kortú- from PIE *(s)kert- 'cut (up)' (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:280-282, {ref Kroonen 2013}:211).

No certain etymology. Traditionally compared to Lithuanian garbinỹs, garbìnis 'lock of hair', but the semantic distance makes this etymology doubtful ({ref ALEW} 295-296, cf. {ref IEW} 387 reconstructing *gerb-, but note that this reconstruction violates the known restriction on IE roots beginning and ending with voiced-unaspirated stops).
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:219 no. 4104, {ref KEWA} I:332, {ref EWAia} I:480).
Generally connected with Lithuanian šùlas 'post, pole, stave' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:767, {ref Beekes 2010}:1037-1038; cf. {ref ALEW} 1053-1054) from PIE *ksúlo- 'block of wood'.

Etymology uncertain. {ref Orel 1998}:30 considers a loan from Latin molere; {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:967 consider the lexemes inherited, possibly but not certainly to be connected with PIE *melh₂- since the stem formation remains unclear.

Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:150-151 for discussion of various proposals. {ref Orel 1998}:79 wants a connection to PIE *déru- ~ *dóru- ~ *dru- on the basis of the dialectal variant drusk 'oak', but the priority of this form is uncertain and could well be a contamination with the word for 'tree' in /cognate/503/ (cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:151).
Generally connected with Germanic words for 'dark' < *dʰerg- ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:57-58, {ref Matasović 2009}:96; cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:153, {ref IEW} 251).

Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain. Sometimes compared to Lithuanian gaĩla 'painful, unfortunate, pitiable', although the connection is uncertain due to the diverging semantics ({ref ALEW} 280-281, cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:161, accepting the etymology).

Lexemes in the meaning 'red' derived from IE *kʷr̥mi- 'snake, worm' adopted from the use of insects to produce red dye. For Sogdian kyrm- 'snake, worm' > qyrmyr, cf. {ref EWAia} I:394-395. There are some formal difficulties in reconciling Proto-Slavic *čьrvь 'worm, maggot' to PIE *kʷr̥mi-, but the cognacy is generally agreed (cf. {ref ESSJa} 4:149-150, 169-170; {ref Derksen 2008}:91-93 for further discussion), cf. also /cognate/1163/. See 'worm' in /cognate/172/ for further etymological discussion.

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pleth₂- 'become wide, spread oneself out' ({ref NIL} 564, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1205, {ref Hübschmann 1897}:451, {ref Olsen 1999}:767, {ref EWAia} II:162-163, 179, {ref ALEW} 787-789, {ref Derksen 2015}:362, {ref Matasović 2009}:135, {ref LIV²} 486-487).
Generally connected with Lithuanian šùlas 'post, pole, stave' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:767, {ref Beekes 2010}:1037-1038; cf. {ref ALEW} 1053-1054) from PIE *ksúlo- 'block of wood'.

Italic and Romance lexemes from Latin umbra, possibly to be further connected to Lithuanian ùnksna 'shade, shadow' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:639, {ref Derksen 2015}:479, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:1164) but cf. {ref ALEW} 1147, 1149-1150, doubting connections outside of Lithuanian and with further discussion. Further connections outside of Italic consequently unclear.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; may be a formal match to Ancient Greek ῥίπτω 'throw' but the semantic match is quite difficult (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:565, {ref Kluge 2011}:755, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:975, {ref Beekes 2010}:1287-1288 for further discussion).

Cf. Lithuanian ràkti 'to stab, dig'; no further etymology outside of Baltic (cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007}:498-499); traditionally compared to Vedic r̥kṣá- 'bald, bare' ({ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:694, {ref Karulis 1992} II:103, {ref IEW} 335) but cf. {ref EWAia} I:248 considering the proposed Vedic comparanda of dubious etymology. [Not in {ref ALEW}, {ref Derksen 2015}].

Two variants *kʷr̥mi- and *u̯r̥mi- in the same meaning 'worm' are generally reconstructed for PIE. The variant *u̯r̥mi- attested in Germanic and Italic might have been secondary from *kʷr̥mi- (cf. {de Vaan 2008}:665), but it may also be possible that the two lexemes were a rhyming pair already in Indo-European poetic language (cf. {ref Watkins 1987}:288). Cf. also {ref Lehmann 1986}:397, {ref Kroonen 2013}:600).

The connection of the Baltic and Slavic lexemes to each other is generally agreed upon, but extra Balto-Slavic connections, and subsequently any precise IE root reconstruction, remain debated. {ref ALEW} (90-91 s.v. OLith. *bálti 'weiß, blass, bleich werden') suggests that a connection with PIE *bʰeh₂- 'shine' is not inconceivable; {ref Derksen 2008}:40 and {ref Derksen 2015}:80 postulate a root *bʰelH-. The reconstructed PIE root ref. form for this class follows that of Derksen, but it should be borne in mind that this form remains provisional as the morphological analysis of the Balto-Slavic forms and their proposed further IE connections have yet to be satisfactorily explained. Cf. also {ref ESSJa} 2:79-81.
Gk. κοντός 'short' appears to derive from the same root as Ancient Greek κεντέω 'to sting, goad', for further discussion cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:563, {ref Beekes 2010}:672-673.

Cf. Latin *tāliare 'to cut' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:704-705), a derivative to Latin tālea 'a cutting, piece of wood'. No further etymology ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:673-674, {ref de Vaan 2008}:605).

Etymology uncertain. {ref Meyer 1891}:365 proposed a loan from Latin grandis 'large', rejected by {ref Jokl 1911}:74 considering Alb. rëndë a participle of a now lost verb cognate with Lith. rė́ju 'put together' (followed by {ref Huld 1984}:108. {ref Orel 1998}:370 supposes a connection with a stem *raunta- derived from rashë, the aorist stem of bie 'fall', although his proposed further IE connections for this verb are uncertain (cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:343 "Eine sichere etymologische Deutung für dieses ohne Zweifel uralte suppletive Verb ist nicht in Sicht.").
Loan from Turkic.

Despite some morphological difficulties, the formal and semantic relationships make a common origin of PS *xolkŭ, *xolstŭ, *pa-xolŭ and *xoliti ver plausible.
According to {ref Smoczyński 2007}: 554-555 the etymology of Lithuanian skaláuti 'wash, flush' is not entirely clear; it can belong to skeliù, skélti 'chop, split', derived from PIE *skelh₁- (cf. *skelH- {ref LIV²}: 553). Smoczyński gives here only PS *ščelĭ 'aperture' as a Slavic cognate. The etymology is mentioned but not accepted by {ref KEWA}: 288.
Thus, even if we accept an underlying *xol-, its further etymology is obscure.

Romance lexemes based on a denominal verb from Latin fīlum 'thread, string' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:286-287, {ref DCECH} III:361-362); further from PIE *gʷʰiH-(s-)lo- 'sinew, sinew thread'. The Italic forms require the reconstruction of initial voiced-aspirated *gʷʰ-, but other proposed cognates from Indo-Iranian and Greek suggest initial *gʷ- without aspiration (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:220; listed in {ref IEW} 489 with only Italic, Celtic, and Balto-Slavic lexemes connected).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:426-427, {ref Orel 1998}:521, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1009-1010 for various possibilities and further discussion.

Comment: no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974: 111)

Justification: From Proto-Germanic *kwēda- 'shit, excrement' (n.). 'bad' (adj.) ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:348-349), generally considered to continue a derivative from a PIE root *gʷeh₁dʰ- 'disgusting, gross' ({ref EWNl}, {ref Orel 2003}:229, cf. ALEW} 303-304, {ref Derksen 2008}:160-161 [not in {ref Kroonen 2013}]).

Comment: not found in Morgenstierne (1974)

Justification: Etymology outside of Albanian uncertain. {ref Orel 1998}:137-138 prefers a connection to Old High German jagōn (cf. /cognate/243/), which has no certain etymology outside of Germanic itself; {ref Demiraj 1997}:191-192 who rejects the connection with the Germanic lexemes and suggests instead a connection with Lat. sāgiō 'spüren, ahnen, wittern', OIr. 'nachgehen einer Sache, suchen' to PIE *seh₂g- '(witternd) nachspüren'. If so, perhaps to be connected within Albanian to 'hear' in /cognate/8546/. Undiscussed, however, in connection to Albanian gjegj in {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:974-975.

From Hellenistic Greek πιάζω, analogically remodelled into the -νω class inflection ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1189, Nikos Liosis, p.c.). Further to Ancient Greek πιέζω, of uncertain etymology (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:899-900, {ref Beekes 2010}:1189 for various proposals).

Comment: probably via Persian

Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing a derivative of PIE *keh₂- 'to desire' ({ref Cheung 2007}:227, cf. {ref EWAia} I:334, {ref LIV²} 343).

Taking into account lexemes like Polish ryj 'snout' and Russian rylo 'snout' (that can be expressively used also for human mouth), both derived from PIE *reu̯H- 'dig' (the original meanig was probably 'pig snout'), there is no reason to doubt on the relationship of PS *rŭtŭ to PIE *reu̯H-. The alternative etymology is much worse from the semantic point of view.
Etymology outside of Anatolian uncertain ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:554).

The best IE etymology, is a derivation to *h₂u̯ers- 'rain' (so {ref Wackernagel 1888}:129 = Kl.Schr. 1.632, tentatively accepted by {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:838-839, {ref Beekes 2010}:1128). The hypothesis of substrate borrowing is a possibility but, given that there is no concrete extra-Greek comparison for it, gratuitous. For the purposes of cognacy Wackernagel's etymology has been followed here.

Comment: onomatopoetic? but cf. Turkish kuš "bird"

Uncertain if all of these belong together. Iberian lexemes are of uncertain origin, von Wartburg FEW suggests Lat. lixare for Fr. lexemes. Initial g- for Franco-Provençal seems unexpected for the suggested etymologies for other branches (isolated blend?). We may also be dealing with contamination/blending/expressive distortions. Class needs careful reviewing language by language (-MJCS 31.10.2017).

Justification: A derivative of Hittite iškii̯e/a- 'to daub, salve'. Further etymology unclear, cf. {ref Tischler 1983}:404, {ref HED A+E/I}:426-428 for various proposals.

Etymology outside of Hellenic uncertain, possibly to be connected with verbs φλέω 'to teem with abundance, abound' and φλύω 'to boil over, bubble up' as derivatives of PIE *bʰleu̯H- 'to overflow'; cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1214, {ref Beekes 2010}:1580, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1546-1547.

Related to Luvian īš(ša)ra/i- 'hand' via an unattested derivative *išaru-/išaru̯a- 'right-hand' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:471-472, cf. {ref NIL} 170-173). For further etymological details cf. 'hand' in /cognate/411/.

Comment: This is obviously a complex predicate with an element 'war' + light verb "to do". 'war' could mean "there" (< *awáϑra) and 'kawǝl' in the sense of "put" (cf. German 'hineintun' : "to put in").

Justification: Possibly to *h₁u̯ers-, if cognate with Vedic varṣá- 'rain', and Ancient Greek ἐέρση 'dew' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:971-972).

The etymology is disputable.
Greek σπόγγος and Latin fungus are considered to be (parallel) loanwords from a non-IE language (*spʰong-), cf. {ref Beekes 2010}: 1385 and {ref de Vaan 2008}: 250. Greek γαμφηλαί may be Pre-Greek or related to γόμφος, a cognate of PS *zǫbŭ 'tooth' {ref Beekes 2010}: 260, 282.
Lithuanian lexemes like gùbti, gum̃ba, gùbo; gaũbti, gaubiù, gaubiaũ; gum̃bas with derivatives, referring, in general, to 'bending, folding' and various 'protrusions, bulges', are related to PS *gŭb-, *ɡub-, *ɡyb- {ref Smoczyński 2007}: 161-162, 207, 77 (addenda). (However, {ref Smoczyński 2007} does not point to PS *gǫba directly.) Slavic and Baltic forms are derived from PIE *gʰeu̯bʰ-. As this root is limited to Balto-Slavic, it has been proposed, that is is a metathese-deformation of PIE *bʰeu̯gʰ-, cf. Gothic biugan 'bend' and Vedc paribhuját 'enfold'. See {ref Smoczyński 2007}: 162 and {ref LIV²}: 85-86, 188.
As it is convincing formally and semantically, I assume that PS *gǫba is derived from PIE *gʰeu̯bʰ-. Its further relationship to PIE *bʰeu̯gʰ- is not excluded but remains speculative.

Comment: Sarikoli with prefix *awa-?

Justification: An derivative of the root *u̯eh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'to break' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:939-940, {ref LIV²} 664-665).

Comment: Iranic forms that derive from MIr. *wind- would belong to cognate set 8643
Justification: The Iranian forms in this set are based on a secondary root *u̯ai(H)n- 'to see' of denominal origin, already attested in Old Iranian (Avestan vaēnaiti, Old Persian vainatiy; cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:412-413). For the primary verbal root, cf. {ref LIV²} 668-669 s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁-.

Etymology in this class follows {ref Oettinger 1979}:523-524, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:195-196 to *h₃er-; but cf. {ref LIV²} assigning to *h₁er- (although {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} also listing *h₃er- as a possible root etymology).

Comment: From Old French escorce which itself either goes back directly to Latin or is a loan from Medieval Latin scorcia, cf. http://www.etymologiebank.nl/trefwoord/schors. Thus ultimately connected to /cognate/182/.
Cheung (2007: 375) seems to prefer a derivation from *teh₂- "to flow, stream; to melt" partly "(certainly influenced by *tač)".

Justification: Romance forms from Latin computāre ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:199), further to PIE *pi̯eh₂- ({ref LIV²} 481-482), cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:451-452, 502 for an account of the stem formation within Italic.
Romance lexemes derived from Latin plānus 'level, flat' and further derived from PIE *pleh₂- 'id.' (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 9:27, {ref de Vaan 2008}:470, {ref NIL} 562-564).
Root etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:313, {ref Orel 2003}:347, {ref Kroonen 2013}:452 for further discussion.

Comment: Morgenstierne (2003: 64) *para-azna-

Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin dorsum 'back' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:247). The etymology as though from Latin *dē-uorsum is based on a popular etymology from Festus, but there are no better suggestions. If so, then the lexemes continue a derivative of PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn around' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:184, {ref de Vaan 2008}:180, 667).

Comment: duuaraiti suggested to be derived from *dreu̯- with metathesis (also suggested by Cheung 2007: 84, or ϑu̯ar/tūr). However, since this root is also attested in its expected form drauu-/drūta- (daevic), this seems less likely. [but Schwartz JRAS 1966: 119ff. considers the latter to belong to dhreu̯- “deceive”]
Justification: Continuing Proto-Iranic *du̯ar- 'to run', further etymology difficult (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:83-84 for discussion).

The further connections of the Germanic adjective *ubila- 'bad' are debated. It is generally agreed that OIr. fel 'bad, evil' may be formally identical with the Germanic lexemes from earlier *upelo-, if the Celtic lexemes are not borrowings from Old French fel 'faithless, unfaithful, disloyal' (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:637-638, {ref Matasović 2009}:396, {ref Kluge 2011}:938, {ref Kroonen 2013}:557). Debated remain the further proposed connections to Hitt. ḫuu̯appa-, connected since {ref Juret 1942}:71 and further advocated by {ref Watkins 1969}:30, {ref Melchert 1988}:233n1, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:369-371, but doubted or rejected by {ref Lehmann 1986}:371, {ref Kluge 2011}:938, {ref Kroonen 2013}:557. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} tentatively reconstructs *h₂u̯óbʰh₁-/h₂u̯(é)bʰh₁- for the proposed Anatolian cognates.
From Ancient Greek μόλω, the aorist subjunctive to Ancient Greek βλώσκω 'go, come' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:381), further to PIE *melh₃- 'to come' ({ref Beekes 2010}:223, {ref LIV²} 433-434).

Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑eh₂u̯- 'to kindle; to burn' ({ref LIV²} 345, {ref Beekes 2010}:618, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:480-481). For the root reconstruction with initial palatovelar *k̑- (rather than plain velar *k-) cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.

Etymology uncertain ({ref EWNl}). Often assumed to be connected in some way with Proto-Germanic *dragan- 'to draw, pull, carry' (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:506-507, {ref Kroonen 2013}:522) but the sound changes necessary to make this connection are irregular.
Further etymology not yet ascertained (cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:596).

Despite of the formal similarity of Polish miano and Kashubian miono with doubtless reflexes of PS *jĭmę, *jĭmene, the relationship of the former to the latter is far from clear. The main formal problem is the root vowel (*-ě- vs. *-e-). The lack of initial i- in miano, miono is, in general, not a crucial issue.
Some sources entirely ignore the formal problems {ref Derksen 2008}, {ref ESSJa}. Vasmer proposes a protoform *jĭměn- for Polish miano {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 130, however he does not explain the nature of this irregular lengthening.
Polish etymologists assume that imię and miano are two distinct etymona, the former being a reflex of a common IE lexeme for 'name' and the latter being a derivative of a verbal root referring to 'thinking', 'mentioning', 'considering as', 'giving a name' etc. Cf. {Boryś 2005}: 320. The formal anlysis is hindered by morphological levellings and conaminations. If Kashubian miono is derived from PS *měno, -o- has been taken from plural forms of *jĭmę, *jĭmene, cf. Polish imiona 'names'. According to the general policy, a cautious view is adopted here. As to the root reference form *men-, see {ref LIV²}: 435-436.

Comment: original meaning "to smell badly, stink", note the MP term gannāg mēnōg "evil spirit" and note that the Zoroastrian hell is stinking badly.

Justification: Generally compared with Latin badius 'bay, chestnut brown', but without any further correspondences elsewhere in Indo-European; cf. {ref Lucht 2007} for extensive discussion of alternative proposed etymologies (cf. also {ref Matasović 2009}:70, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:113, {ref de Bernardo Stempel 1999}:358, {ref IEW} 104-105).

A Germanic and Balto-Slavic isogloss, therefore postulating a root reconstruction *skeu̯bʰ- to PIE remains uncertain ({ref Lehmann 1986}:6, {ref LIV²} 560. Cf. also {ref Kroonen 2013}:444-445 who additionally compares Sanskrit kṣóbhate 'to shake, tremble' and postulates a root *kseubʰ- with a metathesis occurring in the Balto-Slavic and Germanic forms; more skeptical to extra-Germanic connections cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:416-417).

Comment: Gharib (1995: 217 §5434) translates the Sogdian word mrγ by "wood, meadow" and relates it to mrγ- "straight, flat".

Justification: Romance forms from Latin plōrāre 'to cry, weep' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:548-549, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 9:76-79, {ref DCECH} III:732-733), further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:516, {ref de Vaan 2008}:473-474).

An adjective derived to Standard Modern Greek βρόμα 'stench', considered by {ref Babinotis 2010}:279 to be a derivative of Ancient Greek βρομέω 'I make a noise' with a semantic change via the sense 'I smell bad' → 'I stink' perhaps via an intermediary sense 'I farted'. No further etymology.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:484, {ref Orel 2003}:333 for a tenuous proposal to Av. kamna- 'few, little'. No lemma in {ref Kroonen 2013}.

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek βοάω 'to cry, shout' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:185), a denominal verb to Ancient Greek βοή 'cry, shout'. No certain further etymology, possibly an onomatopoeic formation (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:182-183, {ref Beekes 2010}:224).
From Proto-Iranic *nau(H)- 'to cry, wail', further to PIE *neu̯(H)- 'to cry out, shout' ({ref Cheung 2007}:284, {ref EWAia} II:23-24, cf. {ref LIV²} 456-457).
Loanword from Arabic (via Persian).
Uncertain, perhaps cognate with Ossetic xwyr, xwyra 'gravel, pebble' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:476, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:266).
Denominal adjective from Classical Armenian ałt 'filth'. Further etymology outside of Armenian disputed, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:39-40 for various proposals.

East Romance lexemes from Latin *sappere ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), originally a denominal verb from Latin sappa 'a kind of mattock'. Further etymology obscure; an Illyrian loanword? (Cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:801, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:594).

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek στεγνός 'watertight, waterproof', originally as a substantive τὸ στεγνόν 'covered dwelling' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1325). Further derived from PIE *(s)teg- 'to cover' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1046, {ref Beekes 2010}:1393, cf. {ref LIV²} 589).

Comment: the Sarikoli development of PIE *skobʰ- > PIr. *kap/f- is čov-/čift- (see Cheung 2007: 235)

Justification: A loan from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Norse skinn), already attested in Old English schynn, scynn, scin ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed. Traditionally considered a labial-extension to the root *dʰu̯eh₂- 'make smoke' ({ref IEW} 247-248, {ref Orel 2003}:68, {ref Kluge 2011}:180; cf. {ref LIV²} 158). Alternatively {ref Kroonen 2013}:88 sets up a derived noun to PGmc. *dimpan ~ *dempan- 'to fog' < *dʰembʰ- (cf. MHG dimpfen 'to smoke, steam' Elfdalian dimba 'to smoke', Nw. demba 'to smoke'; but cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:180 who considers the MHG form a backformation to MHG dampf, not in {ref LIV²}.).

Iberian Romance lexemes derived from Latin amārus 'bitter' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:31-32, {ref DCECH} I:233-235). Further traditionally compared to Sanskrit amlá- 'sour, acid', Old Icelandic apr 'sharp, cold', but many formal details remain unclear (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:25, {ref de Vaan 2008}:37; cf. {ref EIEC} 69).

Comment: 'kindle, burn'
Justification: Secondary semantic shift from 'dry' > 'hard'. Etymology here follows {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1000 and {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}, but be aware some scholars {ref Orel 1998}:471, {ref Holm 2011}:58-59, following {ref Meyer 1891}:88 consider this set cognate with *h₂seu̯s- ({ref LIV²} 285, without Albanian cognates listed) in /cognate/7551/ (cf. the skepticism of {ref Demiraj 1997}:392).

Romance lexemes from Latin brūtus 'heavy, brute; brutish' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:121-122), generally considered to be a dialectal loanword from Sabellic with a labial reflex of initial *gʷ- from PIE *gʷr̥h₂-, cf. Latin grauis 'heavy' in /cognate/6470/ ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:76-77, {ref de Vaan 2008}:76).

Etymology here follows {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1000 and {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}, but be aware some scholars {ref Orel 1998}:471, {ref Holm 2011}:58-59, following {ref Meyer 1891}:88 consider this set cognate with *h₂seu̯s- ({ref LIV²} 285, without Albanian cognates listed) in /cognate/7551/ (cf. the skepticism of {ref Demiraj 1997}:392).

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek μακρός 'long' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:810), ultimately a zero-grade derivative *mh₂k̑-ró-, derived from PIE *meh₂k̑- 'long, thin, tall' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:660-661, {ref Beekes 2010}:895, {ref NIL} 478-481).

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek χῶμα 'earth thrown up, bank, mound' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1619), an abstract noun derived to the same root as Ancient Greek χώννυμι 'to heap up, raise, stuff with rubbish or earth' from PIE *g̑ʰeu̯- 'to pour' (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1654, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1281, {ref LIV²} 179).

Comment: Bailey (1979: 478) relates the Saka word hāysiñä "fountain (?)" to the Sogdian word ʾwʾz, which he relates to Ossetic awazun etc. "to dam up". The latter is given by Cheung as a cognate of *waz-, which also means "to swim" in some Iranic languages.

Justification: The etymology pointing to PIE *si̯eu̯H- 'sew' is not commonly accepted, cf. also {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 41-42 and {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 4:434-435. It is, however, convincing formally and semantically (and has parallels).

Comment: loan from Pashto
with prefix apa-
Cheung (2007: 368) assumes a root su(m)p/b "to make up, beautify" together with the prefix ni- "down"
PIE form tentatively suggested by Cheung (2007: 361)

< Old Marathi tāṁbaḍā ʻredʼ, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 329, no. 5779 s.v. Vedic tāmrá- adj. ʻdark red, copper-colouredʼ (VS), n. ʻcopperʼ (Kauś), tāmraka- n. Yājñ. (√tam-), cf. PIE *tmHró- from *temH- 'be dark, dull, wan, mat, lacklustre, beamless, dim, tarnished' and 'faint', cf. ²LIV, p. 624 with note 1

Justification: Hellenic lexemes from a zero-grade derivative *mh₂k̑-ró-, derived from PIE *meh₂k̑- 'long, thin, tall' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:660-661, {ref Beekes 2010}:895, {ref NIL} 478-481, cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:810).
Based on a loanword from Italian largo ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:291). Tsakonian αλάργα is treated as a separate loan event in /cognate/6167/.

Derived from PIE *pleh₃- 'swim, flow' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:147-148; as a verbal root cf. {ref LIV²} 485); in earlier literature reconstructed as a lengthened grade of *pleu̯- 'swim, float' (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:118-119).

Comment: Bailey (1979: 420) connects the Saka word samuvā "covering parts" with CS sʾpt 'left (< crooked) side' and derives both from PIE *k̑am- "bend over, cover" with reference to *kamp- (cf. LIV p.342, not in Cheung 2007). Bailey also puts NP čap here.

Justification: Loanword from French foie 'liver' (not in {ref Deshayes 2003}).
Loanword from Turkish sarı 'yellow' ({ref Meyer 1891}:379).

Comment: Sanskritism, cf. Vedic varṣā́ḥ m. pl. ʻthe Rainsʼ (AV) (root vr̥ṣ-)
Loan from Middle Low German

Justification: Based on Bret. bou(n)t, a loanword from Old French boute (deverbal from Old French bouter 'hit, push').

Comment: Cf. Meyer-Lübke 1935 9355 viria 'Armband'?

Justification: No precise correspondences outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:589, {ref Beekes 2010}:786-787). The closest possible correspondences are in Balto-Slavic (cf. OCS kryti 'hide', Lith. kráuti 'heap' in /cognate/5275/), but the connection is uncertain.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4969
Via Lat. restāre?

Justification: Romance lexemes from Lat. fuscus 'dark-coloured, dusky' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:308), further derived from PIE *dʰeu̯s- ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:263-264, {ref de Vaan 2008}:252).
Loanword from Italian contare 'to count'.
Loanword from Italian lordo 'dirty, filthy'.

Comment: Sarikoli PRS.STEM birēz-

Justification: Usually considered a loanword into Romance from West Germanic *bosk- 'forest' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:131, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 15/1:192-210).
Loan from Kâta-vari pařʹas 'dust'

Nuristani lexemes as though from Old Indic *ākṣundati 'tramples' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:46 no. 1030, {ref Strand 1998}), derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic √kšud- 'to disperse, scatter', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} I:439).

Modern Greek lexemes derived from Ancient Greek φῶς, -τός 'light', ultimately a derivative of PIE *bʰeh₂- 'to shine' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1575, {ref Beekes 2010}:1551-1552, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1168-1170, cf. {ref LIV²} 68-69).
Khowar kan < Old Indic kāṇḍa- 'single joint of plant' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:154, no. 3023), further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:336-337).
Parallel loan event from Middle Low German denken 'to think, remember' (cf. {ref EWA 2} 579).

Comment: cf. Sanskrit buk-kāra- m. 'the roaring of a lion, cry of any animal', bukkati 'barks' (Dhātup.)

Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:264, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:422, {ref Kroonen 2013}:384 for various proposals.

From Latin saltus 'jump, leap; narrow passage, woodland' ({ref DCECH} V:321), further to PIE *sel- 'jump' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:590, {ref de Vaan 2008}:535-536; for the root reconstruction cf. {ref LIV²} 527-528).

Comment: not found in Morgenstierne (1974); cf. Khwarazmian ǝkǝk

Justification: Brythonic lexemes based on a denominal formation (cf. Breton kouez m. 'a fall'), from Proto-Celtic *kei̯d- according to {ref Deshayes 2003}:420) but with no correspondences given from Goidelic. Further etymology uncertain.
No known etymology ({ref ALEW} 663, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:406-407).

Cf. Latin ex-cutere ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:263 no. 2998), further to PIE *(s)ku̯eh₁t- 'to shake thoroughly, to startle' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:504-505, {ref LIV²} 563-564, cf. also {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:552-553).

From Latin tostum, cf. It. tosto ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:731 no. 8814), originally the past passive participle of Latin torreō, -ere 'to scorch, roast' from PIE *ters- 'become dry' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:624-625, cf. {ref LIV²} 637-638).
No certain etymology outside of East Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 1118-1119).
Of uncertain origin, perhaps a loan from early Scandinavian ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *h₃erg- ({ref LIV²} 301, {ref Matasović 2009}:300), formerly reconstructed as *perg- ({ref IEW} 819, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} O:30).
Loan from Kâta-vari: Ktivi bʹos 'stem; gas; power'

Comment: not finally clear
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic kāṣṭhá- 'piece of wood', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:159 no. 3120, {ref EWAia} I:345-346).

Romance lexemes from Latin fūstis 'stick, rod' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:308-309), no certain etymology outside of Italic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:264; cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:253 for discussion of some recent proposals).
Loanword from Calabrian ficatu 'liver'.
As though from Sanskrit chadana- 'cover; leaf', a derivative of Vedic √chad- 'to cover', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:272 no. 4979, {ref EWAia} I:554-555).

Perhaps root cognate with Western IE words for 'tear' (Gk. δάκρυ, OHG zahar, Arm. artaswr, etc.), if both are based on earlier *h₂k̑ru- 'bitter' as a derivative from PIE *h₂ek̑- 'be/make sharp' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:391, cf. {ref Kortlandt 1985a}:59-61 and further discussion in /cognate/5111/).

Of uncertain origin (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:153-154, {ref HAB} IV:337-338), perhaps an Iranic loanword according to {ref Bailey 1979}:387, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:711). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯iz-].

Etymology unclear. The proposal of {ref Orel 1998}:115) is rather implausible from a semantic point of view. The etymology is otherwise uncertain (cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:177-178 for further discussion).

Possibly related to TochB oko in /cognate/2653/, and Balto-Slavic and Celtic words in meanings variously 'fruit (of a tree), berry, acorn', but the exact etymological connection is uncertain because of problems in formal reconstruction. Cf. further discussion in {ref Kroonen 2013}:18-19, {ref ALEW} 1151-1152, {ref Derksen 2008}:27, {ref Lehmann 1986}:25.
Root ref. form and analysis follows {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:358-360. For older proposals cf. {ref HED H}:363-368.

Denominal to Classical Armenian mart 'fight, battle, combat'. Connections outside of Armenian uncertain, cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:81, {ref Olsen 1999}:90. {ref HAB} III:289 for tentative speculations. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.
Modern Greek lexemes continuing a loanword from Latin gula 'throat, gullet' into Hellenistic Greek, cf. Standard Modern Greek γουλιά ({ref Babinotis 2010}:318).

Comment: maybe related to śikyà- n. (AV) 'rope-sling for carrying things', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12427f, see also s.v. *śikyadhara- m. 'hook at the end of the pole which carries the looped cord for holding the strings of a balance' or *śikyākāra-, Bi. Mth. sikahar 'net for hanging up pots &c. in a house'

Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek κοπτερός ({ref Babinotis 2010}:689). Further root etymology in this class follows {ref LIV²} 555 to PIE *(s)kep- 'to chop', but cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:748-749.

A derivative of Latin campus 'field', cf. Italian campare 'to live' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:145-146 no. 1563). Traditionally further to an Indo-European root *kamp- 'bend, curve' in the sense 'broad, curved (valley)' > 'field' (cf. {ref IEW} 525, {ref LIV²} 342n1 'fraglich'). The necessity of reconstructing PIE *a (a root structure *kh₂mp- appearing unusual) has renewed the hypothesis that Latin campus is in fact a European substratum word from agricultural terminology ({ref de Vaan 2008}:86, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:632-633).
Romance lexemes as though from Latin *mattea 'club' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:445), further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:366-367 for various proposals.

Originally a passive participle of Ancient Greek χυλόω 'convert into juice; extract the juice from' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). Further etymology difficult; traditionally connected the same root as χέω 'pour' < *g̑ʰeu̯, but long -ῡ- is unexpected for the zero-grade of this root and difficult account for (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1280, {ref Beekes 2010}:1653).

Comment: Bailey (1979: 412 "ṣṣai") relates the Sogdian word to Yaghnobi čukēr-. Not in Cheung (2007).

Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *xudъ 'small, thin' and generally further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾seu̯d- 'to scatter, to crumble into small pieces' (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:111-113, {ref Derksen 2008}:205, {ref Polański 1962-1994}:198-199, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}).
From Ancient Greek ἑστία 'hearth, fireplace, altar' ({ref Dawkins 1916}:600), no further etymology (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:379, {ref Beekes 2010}:471-472 for further discussion).

PS *guľati does not have a commonly accepted etymology. From the semantic perspective the hypothesis of {ref Boryś 2005}: 196 (*geu̯h₂-, cf. {ref Snoj 1997-2016} and {ref LIV²}: 189) looks most convincinɡ, the -l-/-ľ-, however, needs a formal explanaition.
No certain etymology outside of Italic (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:686, {ref de Vaan 2008}:615).

Comment: Loanword from Slavic.
Justification: A loanword into Medieval Greek from Old Slavic logŭ ({ref Babinotis 2010}:786).
Loan from Turkish meyva 'fruit', ultimately from Persian mäyva 'fruit' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 3:718-719).

Comment: Loanword from Italian
Justification: Certainly a borrowing from Latin gula or Italian gola 'throat' ({ref Meyer 1891}:126, although aspects of the loan chronology remain disputed (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:66, {ref Orel 1998}:120, {ref Holm 2011}:72).
Loanword from Anglo-Norman, cf. Old French, Middle French pousser 'to push' ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Loanword from Italian destra 'right'.
As though from Vedic √bhal- 'to expound, describe', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:535 no. 9406, cf. {ref KEWA} II:482-483).
Loanword from English sharp.

Possibly from IE *smei̯d- 'to smear', cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:459, {ref LIV²} 569. See {ref Seebold 1970}:437-438 for older unconvincing proposals to Lat. mittere (ruled out as phonologically implausible by {ref LIV²}).
No certain etymology, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:654 no. 11225, {ref KEWA} III:130 for further discussion.

Comment: no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974: 26)

Justification: Of uncertain origin, unattested in Classical Armenian ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:366). [MM: < ⁽*⁾kəloɾ].

Pontic Greek άψιμο(ν) a derivative of the aorist stem ἄψ- to Ancient Greek ἄπτω 'to join, attach; kindle', cf. Medieval Greek άψιμο ‘fever’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c.; not in {ref Andriotis 1974}), further to PIE *h₂ep- 'to join, fit' ({ref Beekes 2010}:120-121, cf. {ref LIV²} 269).

Comment: Original meaning is "claw", which develops to "hand" and "arm" / "wing".

Justification: Parallel loans from Persian بد bad 'bad'

Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *cappayati 'chews', imitative of the sound of chewing ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:253, no.4675). Cf. cf. Pāli capucapukāra- ʻmaking the sound of chewing'. No further etymology outside of Indic

Latin and Romance lexemes, traditionally compared to Sanskrit amlá- 'sour, acid', Old Icelandic apr 'sharp, cold', but many formal details remain unclear (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:25, {ref de Vaan 2008}:37; cf. {ref EIEC} 69). For Modern Romance forms, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:31-32.
Apparently as though from Sanskrit aru- 'sun', only attested in lexicographical works ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:27, no. 612).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *stauba- 'dust', a derivative of the strong verb steuban- 'to scatter, drift', further etymology generally considered uncertain (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:474, {ref Lehmann 1986}:328, {ref Kluge 2011}:878, 884, {ref Kroonen 2013}:475). Cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:478 s.v. *steuban- ~ *stūban- proposing a connection to Lithuanian siaũbti 'to dash about' via *tséubʰ-ié- (with metathesis of initial *ts- > *st-).
Probably to be derived from Vedic √sthā- 'to stand' ({ref EWAia} II:764-767).

Comment: PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split'

Justification: Loan from French pousser 'to push'.
Loan from English

As though from Sanskrit *gandhapūrikā-, an substantivised form of an adjective derived from gandhá- 'smell', and pūra- 'filling, making full' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:215, no. 4015. This class is coded for Proto-Indo-Iranic *gandʰá- 'smell', which appears to be the semantic bearing head of the original compound. Further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:461-462).
Possibly a Dravidian loanword, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:353 no. 6173.
Generally derived to PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'to chew' ({ref Adams 2013}:691, 706, cf. {ref LIV²} 168).

Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑u̯es- 'to pant, breathe heavily'. In this class Pāli sasati continues the primary verb < Sanskrit śvasati 'breathe heavily' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:677, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:740 no. 12761), the modern Indic forms are light verb constructions with the nominal semantic-bearing morpheme deriving from Skt. śvāsá- 'breath' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:740, no. 12769). For Elfdalian, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:266.

Many irregular developments, often assumed to be due to taboo deformation, but all the lexemes are generally assumed to come from a common Indo-European source. The metathesised stem *u̯orm- as found in Vedic, etc. is generally assumed to be a taboo-deformation while the forms found in Avestan maoiri-, Old Irish moirb are often assumed to be most closely reflect to the original ({ref EIEC} 24). For individual branches, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:630, {ref Beekes 2010}:982, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:482-483, {ref EWAia} II:507, {ref ESSJa} 19:241-249, {ref Derksen 2008}:326, {ref Kroonen 2013}:359, {ref de Vaan 2008}:243, {ref Matasović 2009}:278.

Iranic lexemes from PIE *h₃ems- 'shoulder, upper part of the arm' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:461, II:227-228, cf. {ref EWAia} I:37). Cf. Proto-Germanic *amsa- 'shoulder' ({ref Lehmann 1986}:30, {ref Kroonen 2013}:25), Ancient Greek ὦμος 'shoulder' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1679-1680).

Italic and Albanian lexemes from PIE *(s)ken(H)- ({ref Meyer 1891}:152, {ref Huld 1984}:74, {ref Orel 1998}:147, {ref de Vaan 2008}:115). Pace {ref de Vaan 2008} lexemes from Tocharian B kentse 'rust' are not to be connected (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:207). For Romance lexemes from Latin cinis, cineris, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:182 no. 1929. Cf. Ancient Greek κόνις 'dust' in /cognate/6166/.

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *meg̑- 'big' ({ref NIL} 468-478, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:917-918, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:458-460, {ref Demiraj 1997}:250-251, {ref Orel 1998}:240, {ref EWAia} II:337-338, {ref Kroonen 2013}:361-362, {ref de Vaan 2008}:358-359, {ref Matasović 2009}:253). For Tocharian lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this class, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:479-480.

Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Vedic *āpula- 'abundant' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:55, no. 1211), cf. Vedic vipula- 'extended, wide'. Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} II:557-558).

Umbrian pelmner from a Proto-Italic stem *pelp-men-, cf. Latin pulpa 'meat', pulmentum 'meat dish' < Proto-Italic *pelp-men-to-, pointing to a Proto-Italic root *pelp-. No further known cognates outside of Italic, however (cf. {ref Untermann 2000}:528, {ref de Vaan 2008}:497-498).
Loanword from Dutch vlees 'meat'.

Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Italic lexemes generally considered cognate, but the specific root reconstruction is difficult. Cf. {ref EWAia} I:216, {ref ALEW} 1204, {ref Derksen 2015}:494, {ref de Vaan 2008}:647, 662 for further discussion.
Slavic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰreu̯s- ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:99-100, {ref Matasović 2009}:81, {ref ESSJa} 3:33-34, {ref Derksen 2008}:63).
Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰelg̑ʰ- 'to swell' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:49, {ref Matasović 2009}:70, cf. {ref LIV²} 73-74).
Parallel loans from Persian (Arabic 'destruction')

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(H)regʰ- 'to straighten oneself'. For the root reconstruction, cf. {ref ALEW} 835-836, {ref LIV²} 498. See also {ref Derksen 2008}:438, {ref Derksen 2015}:374-375.

Armenian, Albanian, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived to PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:286-287, {ref Meyer 1891}:413, {ref Huld 1984}:154, {ref Orel 1998}:315, 429, {ref de Vaan 2008}, {ref Schrijver 1991}:212, 495, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:516 no.6268, {ref DCECH} IV:342-343, {ref Matasović 2009}:126, 129).

Indo-Iranic and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₂eu̯-i- 'bird' ({ref EWAia} II:507-508, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:659 no. 11304, {ref de Vaan 2008}:65-66, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:65-66, nos. 827, 828, and 831). For Hellenic and Armenian lexemes attached to this class not in the target meaning, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:35, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:398-399).
Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *deu̯k- ({ref LIV²} 124, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:181, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:250 no. 2785, {ref  {ref Matasović 2009}:108).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'to prick, be pointed' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:330 no. 5806, {ref Bailey 1979}:129, {ref EWAia} I:668-669; cf. {ref LIV²} 592-593).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₁ésh₂-r̥, *h₁sh₂-én-, a heteroclitic r/n-stem, generally assumed to be the inherited Proto-Indo-European word for 'blood' ({ref EIEC} 71, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:256-260, {ref Adams 2013}:525, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:138, {ref EWAia} I:149, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:42 no. 971, {ref Derksen 2015}:526, {ref de Vaan 2008}:527-528, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:627, no. 7574)

Hellenic and Baltic lexemes generally connected with Indic lexemes in the meaning 'dirty' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:680-681, {ref Beekes 2010}:923-924; cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:554, {ref EWAia} II:332-333).
Light-verb constructions construed with (parallel) loans of Arabic نفس / nafs 'breath'.

Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂enh₁- 'to breathe' ({ref LIV²} 267, {ref NIL} 307-311, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:12-13, {ref EWAia} I:72, {ref Seebold 1970}:78-79, {ref Kroonen 2013}:26-27, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:38 no. 473, {ref de Vaan 2008}:43, {ref Matasović 2009}:35).
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁nek̑- 'to take, to obtain' ({ref LIV²} 250-251, {ref Derksen 2008}:350, {ref ESSJa} 25:19-23, {ref ALEW} 698-700).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived to Vedic √grabh- 'to take, seize' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:227 no. 4236), further to PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize, grasp' ({ref EWAia} I:505-506, {ref LIV²} 201).

Tocharian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, and Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'to incinerate, consume by fire' ({ref LIV²} 133-134, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:802, {ref Demiraj 1997}:138-139, {ref Orel 1998}:68, {ref Holm 2011}:55, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:970, {ref EWAia} I:712-713, {ref ALEW} 187-189).

Hellenic, Iranic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *deh₂u̯- ({ref Andriotis 1974}:200, {ref Beekes 2010}:298-299, {ref Cheung 2007}:67-68, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:111-112). The connection of Irish: Gaelic dóigh to this class assumes that it is cognate with OIr. dó- 'burn' (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:111-112, {ref LIV²} 104-105). There remains the possibility that there may have been contamination in the Middle Irish period with OIr. daig 'flame, blaze' derived from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:8-9 s.v. daig, {ref Matasović 2009}:93).
Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰreu̯s- ({ref Lehmann 1986}:82, {ref Kroonen 2013}:76, 80, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:99-100, {ref Matasović 2009}:81).

Italic and Celtic lexemes generally assumed to continue earlier *pe⁽k̑⁾tu- 'chest', although the Celtic forms would appear to continue *pu⁽k̑⁾tu- with secondary *-u- vocalism in the lexical root (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:491, {ref de Vaan 2008}:453, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} U:14-15, {ref Matasović 2009}:130).
Assumed to be cognate with PIE *pe⁽k̑⁾tu- in /cognate/4015/ by Klingenschmitt (1968: 67).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ- '(finger)nail' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:723-725, {ref Beekes 2010}:1086-1087, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:254-255, {ref EWAia} II:4-5, {ref ALEW} 681-682, {ref Derksen 2015}:327, {ref ESSJa} 25:161-164, 170-173, {ref Derksen 2008}:355, {ref de Vaan 2008}:641, {ref Matasović 2009}:36). Indo-Iranic forms go back to an aberrant *(H)nákha-; Indo-Aryan forms go back to nakhá- ~ *nakkha-; some show early nasalization due to blend with aṅgúri- ~  aṅgúli- 'finger, toe' (°-aṅgulá-) or aṅguṣṭhá- 'thumb'; aṅká- 'hook' (RV) and later aṅkurá- 'hooked' may also have played a role, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}, no. 6914 + 134f. 137f., 100, 109; Addenda 6914
Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑elH- 'to become cold, freeze' ({ref Matasović 2009}:185, cf. {ref NIL} 416-417, {ref LIV²} 323).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Balto-SlavicLexemes derived from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'to go' ({ref LIV²} 232-233, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:992-993, {ref Andriotis 1974}:437, {ref Beekes 2010}:388, {ref EWAia} I:102, {ref Cheung 2007}:154-157, {ref ALEW} 259-261, {ref Derksen 2015}:151, {ref ESSJa} 8:247-248, {ref Derksen 2008}:216).

Comment: denominal derivative, cf. Vedic gaṇá- m. 'row, crowd, entourage, a number of fellows' (RV+); see also 'think' in /lexeme/25989/; cf. JB+ gaṇáyati, Sanskrit gaṇayati ʻcountsʼ (MBh.), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3993
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Sanskrit gaṇáyati 'counts' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:213 no.3993), a denominal formation to Sanskrit gaṇá- 'multitude, number, series', without further certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} I:458-459).

Anatolian, Indo-Iranic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry out (by means of heat)'. The Germanic forms in this class are generally connected to this group although the morphological derivation remains obscure, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:54, {ref EWA 1}:365-366, {ref Kluge 2011}:64, 260, {ref Kroonen 2013}:38. Cf. also {ref Lubotsky 1985}:6. For the IE root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV²} 257-258, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:318-319; see also {ref EWAia} I:182-183). For Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes connected to this class cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:67 no.1476.

Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷem- 'to go, come' ({ref LIV²} 209-210, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:170-171, {ref EWAia} I:465-466, {ref Cheung 2007}:98-101, {ref Seebold 1970}:315-317, {ref Kroonen 2013}:316, {ref de Vaan 2008}:661, Meyer-Lübke 1935}:767 no. 9200).

Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑elH- 'to be cold, freeze' ({ref NIL} 416-417, cf. {ref EWAia} II:641, {ref Cheung 2007}:336-337, {ref ALEW} 1008-1009, {ref Derksen 2015}:439-440, {ref LIV²} 323).
Probably loans from Old Indic kiṭṭāla- 'copper vessel' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:161 no. 3157).

Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑elH- 'to be cold, freeze' ({ref LIV²} 323, cf. {ref EWAia} II:641, {ref Cheung 2007}:336-337, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:64, {ref ALEW} 1008-1009, {ref Derksen 2015}:439-440, ref NIL} 416-417).
Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pisk- 'fish', cf. {ref IEW} 796, {ref Kroonen 2013}:142, {ref de Vaan 2008}:467-468, {ref Matasović 2009}:142.
Indo-Iranic lexemes generally derived from PIE *h₃moi̯gʰ-o- ({ref EWAia} II:374-375, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:117).

Many attempts have been made to try to relate the Indic words for 'day' from Ved. áhar ~ áhan- with the Germanic words for day (cf. esp. the heteroclitic stem common in North Germanic from PGmc. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- 'a full day, twenty-four hours' in ON dœgr, dœgn, Sw. dygn, Nw. døger, døgn, Da. døgn, etc.). The loss of the initial dental in Indo-Iranian is, however, anomalous. Cf. {ref EWAia} I:154 and {ref Kroonen 2013}:97 s.v. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- for further discussion. For Middle and Modern Indic forms from Vedic áhar, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:44, no. 993.

Hellenic and Armenian lexemes as though from a PIE stem *Heh₂m-, an exclusive Greek-Armenian lexical isogloss ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:412, {ref Beekes 2010}:518, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:156, cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:96-97).

Many attempts have been made to try to relate the Indic words for 'day' from Ved. áhar ~ áhan- with the Germanic words for day (cf. esp. the heteroclitic stem common in North Germanic from PGmc. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- 'a full day, twenty-four hours' in ON dœgr, dœgn, Sw. dygn, Nw. døger, døgn, Da. døgn, etc.). The loss of the initial dental in Indo-Iranian is, however, anomalous. Cf. {ref EWAia} I:154 and {ref Kroonen 2013}:97 s.v. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- for further discussion.

Albanian lexemes generally connected with Germanic *tīdi- 'time', derived from PIE *deh₂(i̯)- 'to divide, split into parts' (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:51-52, {ref Orel 1998}:516 with references to further literature; {ref Orel 2003}:407, {ref Kroonen 2013}:516); for verbal derivatives to the same root, cf. {ref LIV²} 103-104.

Indo-Iranic, Slavic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *tep- 'to be warm, hot' ({ref NIL} 698-700, cf. {ref EWAia} I:623-624, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:323 no. 5679, {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:81, {ref Derksen 2008}:490, {ref Matasović 2009}:375, {ref LIV²} 629-630).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *i̯eu̯- (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:607 no. 10507, {ref EWAia} II:402-403, {ref LIV²} 314, cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:423).

No certain etymology outside of Germanic. Earlier assumed to be from an IE root *b⁽ʰ⁾(e)ū̆- with an extension -g- (cf. {ref IEW} 100). For various other uncertain proposals, cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:96, {ref EWNl} 1:395.
Modern Indic lexemes as though from *pēṭṭa- (with variant *pōṭṭa-) (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:475, no. 8376). No further etymology.

Comment: Cheung (2007: 345) suggests a derivation from PIE *skep- ‘to cut, split (with a sharp tool), make a crack’

Justification: Of uncertain origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:942, cf. {ref HAB} IV:519). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰor-o-/-i-].
No certain etymology outside of Celtic ({ref Matasović 2009}:385). For older proposals, cf. {ref IEW} 1024.
Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *wambō- 'womb, belly'. No certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Lehmann 1986}:393, {ref Kroonen 2013}:572, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:674).
Romance lexemes from Latin pantex 'belly, paunch' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:510), no further etymology (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:479-480).

Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *latyo- 'day', as though a *-i̯o-stem derived from PIE *leh₁t-. Alternatively, an analysis as a secondary derivative to a primary t-stem from a hypothetical root *leh₁- remains possible; cf. note by Scarborough in the cognate class citations below for more extensive discussion.

Nuristani lexemes derived from a base *gharasya- 'sun's heat' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:239 no. 4440), ultimately to PIE *gʷer- 'to become warm' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:513, {ref NIL} 196-199, {ref LIV²} 219-220).
Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *rau̯k/č-, from PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:316, {ref EWAia} II:463-464, {ref LIV²} 418-419).
Modern Indic lexemes as though from *choṭṭa- 'small', further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:279 no. 5071).
Etymology uncertain, possibly identical with Proto-Germanic *baina- in 'bone' (/cognate/191/) and 'leg' (/cognate/71/), cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:113.
Loanword from Persian kōbal, gōpal 'cudgel' (cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:393).

Etymology outside of Greek difficult; probably to IE *gres- (or *gras-) 'devour' (cf. {ref LIV²} 192, {ref IEW} 404) with dissimilation of *-r- in the root from the suffix *-tēr- (so {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:211-212); but cf. the objections of {ref Beekes 2010}:262.
Usually derived to PIE *bʰer- 'carry' {ref Meyer 1891}:27, {ref Huld 1984}:40-41, {ref Orel 1998}:18 (but cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:92, {ref Holm 2011}:51-52 with some skepticism).

Comment: with variants, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 316f., no. 5589ff., 5598f.; substrate?

Justification: Loanword from Old French ({ref Deshayes 2003}:405).
Tsakonian lexemes as though from Ancient (Doric) Greek *φοῦσκα 'lower abdomen, stomach'; no certain further etymology ({ref Andriotis 1974}:589), {ref Beekes 2010}:1599-1600).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *červo 'belly, intestine' ({ref ESSJa} 4:82-83, {ref Derksen 2008}:85-86) and further derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'to shear, scratch, cut off').

Comment: Cf. Semitic *lib-/lub- "heart"; *lap "spleen, liver, heart"
< *nāf 'navel' ?

Justification: From Latin follis 'bag, sack' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:294). Further connections outside of Italic not fully certain (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:230).
No satisfactory etymology (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:538, {ref KEWA} II:491-492, {ref EWAia} II:243-244).
Etymology unknown (cf. {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
Loan from Middle High German wamp ({ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}:279, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}).

Comment: The PIE root means "to swell". Mayrhofer groups a number of lexemes together which match the semantic field of "(leiblilche) Auswüchse, Schwellungen" [protuberances].

Justification: The only plausible etymology outside of Anatolian is the proposed connection with Armenian argand 'womb' with the proviso that the Armenian sound laws permit it ({ref Čop 1955}, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:733), but this proposal rejected by {ref Martirosyan 2010}:130-131.
Semantic shift from Ancient Greek καρδία 'heart' ({ref Dawkins 1916}:607), cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:644, {ref NIL} 417-423, and 'heart' in /cognate/6458/ for further etymological connections.

Etymology uncertain. Three main possibilities: Either (1) connected with Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist' (so {ref Orel 1998}:269) ultimately derived from *h₃mei̯gʰ- /cognate/42/), or from PIE *mergʷ- (so {ref Demiraj 1997}:271-273), alternatively a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'mist, fog' (suggested by {ref Meyer 1891}:283-284, cf. /cognate/2150/). Either of these sources could also have been contaminated with one another (cf. the discussion of {ref Huld 1984}:93). Ultimately unclear.
Probable (parallel) loanwords from (Gascon) Occitan barrique 'barrel, wine cask' (cf. {ref DCECH} I:524-525).
Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. also {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:528).
See also the independent loan of the same ultimate Greek source lexeme, via Latin and Norman 'French' into English at https://cobl.info/cognate/9719.

Lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ({ref EWAia} II:655-656, {ref LIV²} 331, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:208-210).
Loanword from Old French brum ({ref Deshayes 2003}:144).
North Germanic lexemes continuing a basic stem *dim-, comparisons outside of Germanic are uncertain ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:151-152, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:77, {ref Kroonen 2013}:96, 108).
Etymology outside of Tocharian obscure, probably connected within Tocharian to Tocharian A kātse 'near'. Cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:112, {ref Adams 2013}:165-166 for various further discussion.

Indo-Iranic lexemes from Vedic áṅgāra- 'glowing charcoal' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:6-7, no. 125), probably further from a PIE nominal formation *ángol-/*angl- or *Héngol-/*Hengl- (cf. {ref ALEW} 41 s.v. OLith. anglìs 'coal'). A further connection to Vedic agní- 'fire' could be possible, but the details remain uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} I:48). For Nuristan languages, cf. {ref Strand 1998}.

The widely accepted etymology linking the Slavic lexeme to uncertain PIE ?*lek- 'move the limbs' (cf. {ref ESSJa} 14:145-148) is not entirely convincing. There is no internal Slavic evidence for *k and the hypothesis needs to assume an intensive morphological levelling. Cf. also {ref ALEW} 567-568, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:343, {ref Derksen 2008}:271, {ref Kroonen 2013}:323.

Certain comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic are lacking ({ref ALEW} 933, cf. {ref LIV²} 562). Identical to 'run' in /cognate/6359/. On the possibility of the connection of Lithuanian skrìsti 'fly_V' to this class, cf. discussion in /cognate/9622/.
Loanword from English '(to) fly' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).

Comment: Regular development of *bazu(ra)- is bāzul and bāsk in Balochi. The word for heart "zird" shows that *rd/rz does not develop to l in Balochi.

Justification:
Root reference form for this class tentatively follows {ref LIV²} 563, but cf. {ref ALEW} 933-934 regarding the possibility that the lexeme goes back to a secondary neo-root *(s)krei̯-dʰ- and connected to Latvian skrìet 'fly_V' in /cognate/2273/.
'
Brythonic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:537-538, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:145-146, cf. {ref LIV²} 572-573).

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃mei̯gʰ- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1077, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:466, {ref EWAia} II:374-375, {ref ALEW} 649, {ref Derksen 2015}:317, {ref ESSJa} 21:93-94, {ref Derksen 2008}:338-339, {ref EWNl} 3:140, {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Romance lexemes derived from Old French breu, a loanword on Germanic *brod- 'broth' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002}:297, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:118; elsewhere in Romance cf. It. brodo 'broth', broda 'soup', etc.)
Continuing a derivative of PIE *lei̯kʷ- 'to leave' via Indic udrēcayati 'causes to increase' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:96-97 no. 2061, cf. {ref EWAia} II:457-458, {ref LIV²} 406-408).
Tocharian and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ({ref LIV²} 487-488, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:462-462, {ref Malzahn 2010}:745-746, {ref Lucht 2007}:165).

Lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:732 no. 12620, {ref EWAia} II:655-656, {ref LIV²} 331).
Loan from Italian volare 'to fly'.
Nuristani forms refect Old Indic *ut-sthā-ti (-Strand).
Light verb constructions, whose semantic heads are loans from Persian parvāz 'flight'.
Etymology outside of Iranic uncertain, the earlier proposal by {ref Bailey 1979}:168 to PIE *der- 'to run' via an extended form *dr-ep(h)- is no longer tenable (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:75).
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:615, {ref Kroonen 2013}:549).
Parallel loans from Turkic (cf. {ref Vasmer 1953-1958} III:152, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 4:119).
Parallel loans from Middle Indic bána- 'forest' (< Vedic vána- 'forest') (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:657 no. 11258).

Comment: from *kuha- 'fog, mist' according to Turner 1962-66, p. 175, no. 3386, perhaps related to guh- 'hide, conceil' (?); unclear
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing a stem *kuha-, further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:175 no. 3386).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall' ({ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}; cf. {ref LIV²} 476, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:655-660, {ref Beekes 2010}:1181-1182, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:286-287, 294, {ref EWAia} II:71-72, {ref Matasović 2009}:129)

Many sources link the Slavic lexeme to PIE *kʷer- 'cut, (do/make)' {ref LIV²}. The meaning 'to heat' in Lithuanian kùrti is assumed to arise through an ellipisis of the objects in phrases like 'make a fire'. The Slavic lexeme and the Germanic ones are, however, not listed in LIV {ref LIV²}.
Nor the Slavic lexeme, neither the possible Germanic cognates show any traces of the 'make/do' meaning. Moreover, PS *kuriti has a specified meaning and refers clearly to burning with smoke (pleas note that the Gemanic meaning referring to the 'coal' fits here semantically very well). The Baltic etymology seems to have some formal issues. It seems reasonable to join the view of {ref Derksen 2008} and {Kroonen 2013} and assume a root distinct from *kʷer- 'cut, (do/make)', *kerH- or *kerh₃-.
From Latin boreās 'north wind; north' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:107, cf. {ref DCECH} I:614), an old loanword from Greek βορέας 'north wind; north' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:73-74).

A register-loanword into Standard Modern Greek from Katharevousa (expected †μίχλη, vel sim.). A reflex of the expected word might be found in SMG μούχλα 'mould, mildew' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.); cf. also respective entries in {ref Andriotis 1999}.
From Old Norse mjǫrkvi 'thick fog', a variant of myrkvi 'id.', to be derived from PIE *mergʷ- (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:390, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:409-410, {ref Kroonen 2013}:366).
From Ancient Greek δεῖσα 'slime, filth' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:202). Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:259, {ref Beekes 2010}:311 for references to conjectural hypotheses).

Italiot καμουλία < Medieval Greek καύμα, κάμα ‘excessive heat’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c.; cf. also {ref Rohlfs 1964}:192). Further connected to the same root as Ancient Greek καίω 'to burn', to which cf. 'burn' in /cognate/1461/ for further etymological discussion.

Possibly to IE *kʷu̯ap- (or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-) if to be compared with Lat. vapor 'steam, exhalation', Gk. καπνός 'smoke' ({ref ALEW} 545-546, {ref Derksen 2015}:268), but these connections are not fully certain due to several irregular sound-changes needed to justify the comparison.

Nuristani lexemes, to be connected with Vedic kákṣa- 'undergrowth' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:128 no. 2589). No certain further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:288).

Connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:660-661; cf. {ref KEWA} III:383-384 for various older proposals). For Kashmiri šuh, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:723 no. 12485 śītá- 'cold' (i.e. the regularly past passive participle formed to Vedic √śyā-), for Nuristan languages cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:731 no.12614.
Romance lexemes from Latin gelāre 'to freeze', derived from Latin gelus, -ūs 'cold, frost, ice' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:317), further to PIE *⁽g̑⁾el- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:256).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'become firm' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:894-895, {ref Beekes 2010}:1184, {ref LIV²} 461).
Etymology uncertain. [Not in {ref Morgenstierne 1974}].
Etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword from Germanic (cf. {ref ALEW} 878-879, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:524).
Loanword from Turkish pus 'fog, haze'.
Brythonic lexemes generally assumed to be loanwords from Latin nūbilus 'cloudy, overcast' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref NIL} 502n15, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} N:8).

The Iranic lexemes in this class represent light verb constructions with Proto-Iranic *ai̯xa- 'ice' ({ref ESIJa} I:140-143) constituting the semantic head. Cf. 'ice' in /cognate/5932/ for further etymological discussion.

Germanic and Celtic lexemes from PIE *preu̯s- ({ref LIV²} 493-494). The connection of the Celtic lexemes to this class follows {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Falileyev 2000}:137, {ref Matasović 2009}:140, but cf. doubts in {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:24-25, {ref EIEC} 287. For Germanic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:154-155.

Comment: There might be another root *merk⁽ʷ⁾- with a meaning pertaining to the same semantic field, cf. e.g. Ukrainian dialectal morokvá 'quagmire, swamp', Lith. mer̃kti 'to wet, to moisten (flax, linen)' and maybe as a cognate Latin marceō 'to be withered, droop', cf. also Derksen, EtymDictSlav 325f. s.v. *morky, ALEW 637 and de Vaan, EtymDictLat 364f. (Freiberg).
Justification: Albanian and Slavic lexemes from PIE *merg̑⁽ʰ⁾- ({ref Demiraj 1997}:256, {ref Orel 1998}:245, {ref ESSJa} 20:10-14; 21:163-165, {ref Derksen 2008}:326, 342-343).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *deh₃- 'to give' ({ref LIV²} 105-106, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:331-332, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:595, {ref Demiraj 1997}:154-155, {ref Orel 1998}:157, {ref Rohr 2000}:42-43, {ref EWAia} I:713-715, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:489 no. 8655, {ref Cheung 2007}:45-47, {ref ALEW} 246-248, {ref Derksen 2015}:146-147, {ref ESSJa} 4:194-195, {ref Derksen 2008}:96, {ref de Vaan 2008}:174-175). The connection of Gaulish dede to this class is tentatively accepted (so {ref Matasović 2009}:86), but cf. the discussion of {ref Delamarre 2003}:138-139 regarding the possibility alternatively deriving the Gaulish form from PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to put, place'.

Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'to limp' via a secondary nominalisation of Proto-Germanic *skanka- 'crooked' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:446, {ref Orel 2003}:334, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:485). The 'Schenkel' from Middle High German onwards are diminutive formations ({ref Kluge 2011}:800). For the root, cf. {ref LIV²} 555).

Romance lexemes derived from Latin glācies 'ice' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:322); Latin glaciēs 'ice' and Romance descendants superficially appear to be related to *⁽g̑⁾el- but it is difficult to establish a clear etymological relationship (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:275, {ref de Vaan 2008}:263 for further discussion).

Derived from Armenian saṙn 'ice' and generally connected to Germanic and Balto-Slavic lexemes for 'frozen snow' or 'hoarfrost', although the precise nominal stem formation in Armenian is not fully understood ({ref Olsen 1999}:137, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:567-568; cf. {ref HAB} IV:176-177 for older proposals). Note, however, {ref ALEW} 1019, {ref Kroonen 2013}:223 not do not explicitly connect the Armenian lexemes.
A derivative of OIr. secc (adj.) 'stiff, rigid, hard', originally a loanword from Latin siccus 'dry' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:60), cf. /cognate/4358/.
Connections outside of Albanian disputed (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:306-307, {ref Jokl 1911}:63-64, {ref Orel 1998}:296 for various proposals).

Traditionally reconstructed as *i̯eg- ({ref IEW} 503) but the connection of Indo-Iranic *yaja- 'cold' points to *i̯eg̑- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:601; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:234-235, {ref HED A+E/I}:257-259, {ref Matasović 2009}:435).

Traditionally reconstructed as *i̯eg- ({ref IEW} 503) but the connection of Indo-Iranic *yaja- 'cold' points to *i̯eg̑- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:601; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:234-235, {ref HED A+E/I}:257-259, {ref Matasović 2009}:435).
Baltic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃eu̯g̑- 'cold' ({ref ALEW} 76, {ref Karulis 1992} I:22, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} U:8, {ref Matasović 2009}:301).

No certain etymology outside of Slavic ({ref Derksen 2008}:471, cf. {ref LIV²} 601-2 s.v. ?2. *steu̯d- 'kalt werden'). A connection with the more common homophonous root 1. *steu̯d- 'stoßen', 'to hit' might be possible, but is difficult to justify semantically (cf.  {ref LIV²} 601-602). The root reference form as PIE ?*steu̯d- tentatively follows {ref LIV²}.
Origin uncertain, cf. {ref HAB} IV:463-464, {ref Olsen 1999}:42, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:630-631 for various proposals. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsʰurt-o-].

Etymology in this class follows {ref Orel 1998}:105 and {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:974 to PIE *teh₂- 'melt, thaw', but cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:173-174, {ref Holm 2011}:56-57 for proposals to PIE *tep- 'be warm, hot'. Cf. also {ref LIV²} 616, 630.

Comment: no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974: 79)

Justification: Derived from Old Indic √oṣ- 'to burn' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:125), further to PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'to burn' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:281, {ref LIV²} 245).
No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. {ref ALEW} 565, {ref Derksen 2015}:277, {ref ESSJa} 14:91-92, {ref Derksen 2008}:270).
Connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:660-661; cf. {ref KEWA} III:383-384 for various older proposals).

Because the morphology of the related forms within Greek conform to the Caland system is suggestive that they are inherited from Indo-European, but there are no known cognates outside of Greek (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1295-1296, {ref Beekes 2010}:1672-1673).
Albanian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´- (cf. {ref NIL} 162-169, {ref Derksen 2008}:544-545, {ref Demiraj 1997}:133, {ref Rohr 2000}:124-125).

Further etymology outside of Tocharian unclear. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:182-183, {ref Adams 2013}:236 attempt to connect Tocharian B krośce to the Greek forms, but this proposal is formally problematic (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:786).

Latin glaciēs 'ice' and Romance descendants superficially appear to be related to *⁽g̑⁾el- but it is difficult to establish a clear etymological relationship (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:275, {ref de Vaan 2008}:263 for further discussion). For the Romance lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:322.
Nuristani lexemes derived from the same root as Vedic yávasa- 'grass' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:603 no. 10436), further derived from PIE *i̯éu̯-o- ({ref EWAia} II:404).
Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Vedic amā́ 'at home, in the house' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:25 no. 560). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref EWAia} I:95.

Nuristani lexemes as though from Vedic rúh 'growth, spurting' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:624 no.10795), further to Vedic √rudh- 'to grow' from PIE *h₁leu̯dʰ- 'to rise, row' ({ref EWAia} II:467-468, cf. {ref LIV²} 248-249).
From Proto-Romance *pettia ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:532), generally regarded as a borrowing from Celtic (cf. Welsh peth 'thing, object')
Of uncertain etymology, perhaps a derivative to the same root as Latvian galēt 'to kill' (cf. /cognate/2302/) with an original meaning 'killed animal' ({ref Karulis 1992} I:285).

Comment: cf. Vedic nī́la- adj. 'dark coloured, dark blue, black blue, indigo' (also 'dark GRUE' = dark blue-green); further etymology unclear, cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 51, Turner 1962-66, p. 426, no. 7563; some forms analogically influenced by *lohila-, cf. Vedic róhita- ~ lóhita- 'red'
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Vedic nī́la- 'dark blue, dark green, black' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:426 no. 7563). Further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:51).
