Indic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes, generally accepted as cognates, but a precise reconstruction of the original Indo-European proto-form remains difficult and controversial, cf. {ref EWAia} I:44-45 {ref Turner 1962–1966}:3 no. 55, {ref ALEW} 1145-1146, {ref Derksen 2015}:478, {ref ESSJa} 32:30-33, {ref Derksen 2008}:364, {ref de Vaan 2008}:297 for further discussion. Possibly further connected to *Hengl- in /cognate/6119/, but the details remain uncertain.

Celtic lexemes from PIE *preu̯s- following {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Falileyev 2000}:137, {ref Matasović 2009}:140, but cf. doubts in {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:24-25, {ref EIEC} 287. Cf. 'freeze' in /cognate/226/.
Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)per- 'to fly' ({ref Adams 2013}:383, {ref EWAia} II:97, {ref Derksen 2008}:396, {ref Vasmer 1953-1958} II:343, cf. {ref LIV²} 579-580).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *sáras-, an s-stem to a root *sel- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:708, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:765 no. 13254).

Comment: cf. 9360 "freeze"; 9359 "cold"; 9361 "ice" and Cheung (2007: 39): "On *či̯aH³/čiH < (?) PIE *ḱi̯-, cf. *ǰi̯auH ‘to chew’ < PIE *ǵi̯euH-, see Rasmussen 1989: 114, no. 5. The variant *saiH/siH may derive from the variant *ḱ(e)iH-."
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Indo-Iranic *či̯aH-; further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:660-661; cf. {ref KEWA} III:383-384 for various older proposals).

Lit. 'congealed/frozen water'. Cognacy in this set is coded for Sinhalese දිය diya 'water' < Vedic udaká- 'water', further derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:89 no. 1921, {ref EWAia} I:215-216, cf. {ref NIL} 706-715). For the modifer 'congealed/frozen', cf. 'freeze' in /cognate/7652/.

Etymology uncertain. Possibly a loan from Germanic *jakulaz 'icicle, glacier' (so {ref Orel 1998}:3-4), but cf. objections from {ref Demiraj 1997}:74-75); cf. {ref Huld 1984}:37-38 for various unconvincing alternative hypotheses.
Loanword from Arabic ǰamad 'ice, ice floe' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:486).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *flaiska-, without certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref EWA 3}:370-371, {ref Orel 2003}:104, not in {ref Kroonen 2013}).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *kreu̯h₂- '(clotted) blood, blood outside of the body, gore' ({ref NIL} 444-448, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:580, {ref Beekes 2010}:774).

Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Old Indic *nigāti (ni- 'down' + √gā- 'to take a step'), cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:410 no. 7165. Root etymology further to PIE *gʷeh₂- 'to take a step' ({ref EWAia} I:482, {ref LIV²} 205).

Etymology uncertain, the lexemes have been attempted to be related to PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall', however this is phonologically problematic since one expects PIE *pe- to develop to he- in Classical Armenian, however cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:293-294 attempting to maintain the traditional etymology. Perhaps a loanword from an Indo-European Anatolian language (cf. Hitt. pattar- 'wing, feather')? See also {ref HAB} IV:498.

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ({ref NIL} 526-540), cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:653-654, {ref Adams 2013}:432, {ref Beekes 2010}:1227-1228, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:534-535, {ref EWAia} II:77-78 {ref Kroonen 2013}:152, {ref de Vaan 2008}:462, {ref LIV²} 458).

Derivatives from Proto-Indo-Iranic *pau̯š- 'to blossom, bloom' ({ref EWAia} II:153, 171-172). No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic. For the Modern Indic forms, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:470, no. 8303 and 8306.

Hellenic, Albanian, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *mus- 'fly, gnat', cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:976, {ref Demiraj 1997}:270, {ref Orel 1998}:268, {ref ALEW} 673-674, {ref Derksen 2015}:326, {ref ESSJa} 20:170-172, {ref Derksen 2008}:330-331, {ref de Vaan 2008}:397).
Indo-Iranic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'to make smoke' ({ref EWAia} I:795, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:392 no. 8649, {ref de Vaan 2008}:249, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:305 no. 3572).

The reflexes found in the individual languages reflect different generalised accent/ablaut classes of PIE *kʷetu̯or-, *kʷ(e)tu̯r̥-, *kʷ(e)tur- 'four'. For extensive discussion cf. {ref Eichner 1982}:298-382, cf. also {ref Adams 2013}:703, {ref Beekes 2010}:1471-1472, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:546-547, {ref Orel 1998}:173-174, {ref EWAia} I:526-527, {ref ALEW} 483-485, {ref Derksen 2015}:241, {ref ESSJa} 4:97-98, {ref Derksen 2008}:87, {ref Kroonen 2013}:133, {ref de Vaan 2008}:505-506, {ref Matasović 2009}:179.
Iranic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:6-10, {ref Bailey 1979}:499, {ref MacKenzie 1990}:112, {ref Matasović 2009}:62).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'to go' ({ref LIV²} 232-233, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:616-618, {ref Adams 2013}:64-66, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1002-1006, {ref EWAia} I:102, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:23 no.497, {ref ALEW} 259-261, {ref Derksen 2015}:151, {ref ESSJa} 8:247-248, {ref Derksen 2008}:216, {ref de Vaan 2008}:191-192).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *pénkʷe 'five', generally considered to be the Indo-European inherited numeral for 'five' (not attested in phonetic spellings in Anatolian languages). See {ref Eichner 1982}:383-569 for extensive discussion, cf. also {ref Adams 2013}:415-416, {ref Beekes 2010}:1172-1173, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:409, {ref Demiraj 1997}:315-316, {ref Orel 1998}:316, {ref EWAia} II:65-66, {ref ALEW} 756-767, {ref Derksen 2015}:351, {ref Derksen 2008}:400, {ref Kroonen 2013}:140, {ref de Vaan 2008}:509, {ref Matasović 2009}:176-177.

Armenian, Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *dṓm, (gen.sg. *dém-s) 'house' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:618, {ref EWAia} I:697, {ref ALEW} 684-686, {ref Derksen 2015}:328, {ref ESSJa} 5:72-73, {ref Derksen 2008}:113, {ref de Vaan 2008}:178-179).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pleh₁- 'to fill, be(come) full' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1191-1192, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:309-310, {ref Demiraj 1997}:327, {ref Orel 1998}:335, {ref EWAia} II:156-157, {ref ALEW} 772-773, {ref Derksen 2015}:356, {ref Derksen 2008}:426, {ref Kroonen 2013}159, {ref de Vaan 2008}:472-273, {ref Matasović 2009}:132).

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'green, yellow' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1638, {ref EWAia} II:805-806, {ref ALEW} 1285-1286, 1296, {ref Derksen 2015}:511-512, {ref Derksen 2008}:541, {ref Matasović 2009}:160).
Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing different derivatives from PIE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:70, {ref de Vaan 2008}:227-228, {ref Matasović 2009}:67-68, cf. {ref LIV²} 88).

Comment: 'loins'
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *lendʰ-u- ({ref Derksen 2008}:276, {ref ESSJa} 15:48-50).
Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *h₁u̯és-u- ({ref EWAia} II:533-534, {ref Starke 1990}:352-353).
Lexemes from Proto-Celtic *klēyo- 'left', further derived from PIE *k̑lei̯- 'to lean' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:114-115, {ref Matasović 2009}:207, cf. {ref LIV²} 332-333).

Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from Vedic khyā- 'to see', ultimately from PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of' ({ref EWAia} I:420-421, I:456-457; {ref LIV²} 383-385). For Marathi, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:48 no. 1074 *ācikhyati 'communicates'; for Nuristan languages, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:745 no. 12842 sáṁkhyāti (*saṁkśāti) 'reckons'.

Balto-Slavic lexemes, generally considered to be cognate with Armenian glowx 'head' ({ref ALEW} 289-290, {ref Derksen 2015}:162-163, {ref Derksen 2008}:176). The Balto-Slavic lexemes can be transparently derived from a reconstructable PIE *golH-u̯eh₂-, but many details of the Armenian form remain unclear (cf. further discussion and references in /cognate/8243/).

Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *ha(u)beda- ~ *ha(u)buda- 'head' and Italic lexemes from Latin caput, generally considered root and suffix cognate, but further identification of an Indo-European root etymology remains controversial. A frequent suggestion is to PIE *keh₂p- 'to grasp, seize' found in Latin capiō, -ere 'id.' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:215, {ref de Vaan 2008}:91). Alternatively a frequent comparison is made to Sanskrit kapā́la- 'cup, skull' with a different nominal suffix, but this cognate relationship remains uncertain ({ref Kluge 2011}:530-531, {ref KEWA} I:155, {ref EWAia} I:300).

Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE 1. *k̑el- 'to hide' ({ref LIV²} 322-323, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:252-253, {ref Kroonen 2013}:218, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:53-54, {ref Matasović 2009}:199).

Tocharian and Slavic lexemes from PIE *k̑leu̯s- 'to hear, to listen to' ({ref LIV²} 336, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:250-251, {ref Derksen 2008}:455-456). The root is probably a secondary verbal root abstracted from a desiderative formation from *k̑leu̯- 'hear' already in the protolanguage (cf. {ref LIV²} 336).

Lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰau̯j́ʰ- 'to hide', no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:502-503, {ref Cheung 2007}:117). {ref LIV²} 199 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯g̑ʰ- 'verbergen'.

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from a basic PIE root *k̑er- (cf. {ref Nussbaum 1986} for extensive discussion of formations in the meaning 'head' and 'horn' derived from this root). Cf. also {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:456-457, {ref Adams 2013}:235 [but cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:182 deriving to *gʰreh₁-u̯r̥], {ref Beekes 2010}:676-677, {ref EWAia} II:653, {ref Kroonen 2013}:259, {ref de Vaan 2008}:136-137, {ref Matasović 2009}:190-191).

Hellenic, Albanian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from a basic PIE root *k̑er- (cf. {ref Nussbaum 1986} for extensive discussion of formations in the meaning 'head' and 'horn' derived from this root), cf. also {ref Beekes 2010}:641, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:237, {ref EWAia} II:638-639.
Baltic lexemes to be connected with PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' (cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007}:260, {ref Derksen 2015}:229-230, 247-248, cf. {ref LIV²} 559-560).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, and Italic reflecting different derivatives from PIE *gʷerh₂- (cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:173-174, {ref Adams 2013}:230-231, {ref Beekes 2010}:202-203, {ref EWAia} I:490-491, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:91 no.1962, {ref Karulis 1992} I:321, {ref Kroonen 2013}:312, {ref de Vaan 2008}:272, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:328 no. 3855).
Baltic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷelH- 'to suffer; to prick' ({ref LIV²} 207, cf. {ref ALEW} 286, 309, {ref Derksen 2015}:170, {ref Seebold 1970}:313-314, {ref Kroonen 2013}:315).
Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, and Slavic lexemes from PIE *(H)seu̯-i̯o- 'left' ({ref Adams 2013}:767, {ref EWAia} II:716, {ref Derksen 2008}:487-488).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)per- 'to fly' ({ref EWAia} II:97, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:446 no. 7918, cf. {ref LIV²} 579-580).

Tocharian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE 2. *keh₂u̯- 'to hit, split' ({ref LIV²} 345-346, cf. {ref Hackstein 1995}:54-56, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:115-116, {ref Malzahn 2010}:606-607, {ref Adams 2013}:222, {ref Cheung 2007}:251-252).
Nuristani and Iranic lexemes fom Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰand- 'to laugh' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:200 no. 3815, {ref Cheung 2007}:442-443).
Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *kok̑s-h₂- 'limb, joint' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:140, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:212 no. 2292, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:214, {ref Matasović 2009}:220).

Latin flāuus 'yellow', from PIE *bʰleh₃-u̯o-, a derivative of PIE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:225, cf. {ref LIV²} 88). For Old Irish blá attached to this class not in the target meaning, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:54-55).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑enu, *g̑neu- ({ref IEW} 381-382, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:467-468, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:129-130, {ref Adams 2013}:205-206, {ref Beekes 2010}:283, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:343-344, {ref Demiraj 1997}:190-191, {ref Orel 1998}:137, {ref EWAia}: I:584-585, {ref Kroonen 2013}:296, {ref de Vaan 2008}:259, {ref Matasović 2009}:162).
Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pekʷ- 'to become ripe; to cook' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:430 no. 7641, {ref EWAia} II:46, {ref Matasović 2009}:180, cf. {ref LIV²} 468).

Tocharian and Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯- ({ref Beekes 2010}:843-844, {ref Adams 2013}:614). The Tocharian lexemes are generally considered to be based on an *mn-stem neuter to an IE root *lei̯- ({ref Ringe 1996}:109, {ref Adams 2013}:614), and connected to the complex of words surrounding Gk. λειμών 'wet, grassy place, meadow' λίμην 'harbour', and λίμνη 'lake', but cf. {ref van Windekens 1976}:271-272 for older hypotheses.

The Tocharian, Hellenic, and Germanic lexemes in this class are generally considered derivations from PIE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom', although certain derivational details remain disputed. Root ref. form follows {ref LIV²} 88, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:415, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1232-1233, {ref Beekes 2010}:1596-1597, {ref Kroonen 2013}:66). It is possible, but uncertain that Latin folium and the Romance lexemes continuing it belong here, cf. further discussion in /cognate/8247/.

Modern Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Proto-Indo-Iranic kʰaru̯á- 'mutilated, imperfect' (cf. Ved. kharvá- 'mutilated' {ref Turner 1962–1966}:201 no. 3832), possibly further connected within Indo-Iranic to Avestan kauruua- if the term means 'mutilated', further connections outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ({ref EWAia} I:448-449).

Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯h₁- 'to look, seek after' ({ref LIV²} 668-669, cf. {ref EWAia} II:509-510, {ref Cheung 2007}:411, {ref Bailey 1979}:309, {ref de Vries 1977}:650-651, {ref Orel 2003}:441, {ref Kluge 2011}:978).

Armenian and Italic lexemes generally admitted to be cognates from a PIE s-stem *k̑ruH-s-, vel sim. In principle, however, the Armenian lexemes might be a loan from Iranic (cf. Av. sraoni- 'buttock, hip'). Cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:79, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:585-586, {ref de Vaan 2008}:147 for further discussion.

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, and Sabellic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂nér- 'man' ({ref NIL} 332-335, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:103-104, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:61-62, {ref Huld 1984}:100-101, {ref Orel 1998}:304, {ref EWAia} II:19-20, {ref de Vaan 2008}:406-407, {ref Untermann 2000}:495-497).

Tocharian, Armenian, Albanian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes from PIE *mē(m)s- 'meat' ({ref NIL} 486-488, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:498, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:469-470, Demiraj 1997}:269-270, {ref Orel 1998}:267, {ref EWAia} II:343-344, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:574 no. 9982, {ref ALEW} 638-639, {ref Derksen 2015}:312-313, {ref ESSJa} 19:7-11, {ref Derksen 2008}:315, {ref Kroonen 2013}:369).
Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Vedic ánna- 'food' reflecting PIE *h₁éd-no-, cf. PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:18 no. 395, {ref EWAia} I:79-80).

Armenian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear; to die' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:452-453, {ref EWAia} II:318-319, 327-328, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:596 no. 9888, cf. {ref LIV²} 439-440).

Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *u̯iH-ró- 'young, powerful man' ({ref NIL} 726-729, cf. {ref EWAia} II:569-570, {ref ALEW} 1252-1253, {ref Kroonen 2013}:588, {ref de Vaan 2008}:681, {ref Matasović 2009}:423).

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Italic lexemes continuing PIE *i̯e/okʷ-r/n-, generally presumed to be the PIE inherited word for 'liver' ({ref NIL} 392-395, {ref EIEC} 356, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:522, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:306-307, {ref EWAia} II:391, {ref ALEW} 413-414, {ref de Vaan 2008}:296).

Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *meh₁- 'to measure' ({ref Adams 2013}:503, {ref EWAia} II:352-353, {ref ALEW} 634-635, {ref ESSJa} 18:191-194, {ref Derksen 2008}:312-313, {ref Kroonen 2013}:365, {ref de Vaan 2008}:373).
Tocharian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- ({ref Adams 2013}:399-400, {ref EWAia} II:232, {ref Bailey 1979}:299, {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:8).

Celtic lexemes generally connected to PIE *leu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'bend' ({ref Matasović 2009}:248), but cf. {ref Schrijver 1995}:332 for a speculative proposal to *leu̯s- in connection to Lat. lūridus 'pale (yellow)' (Schrijver himself admits "a mere possibility").
Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'to be(come) high, to rise up' ({ref NIL} 30, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:60, {ref Delamarre 2003}:87, {ref Matasović 2009}:77, {ref LIV²} 78-79).
Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷerH- ({ref EWAia} I:487, {ref ESSJa} 7:29-31, {ref Derksen 2008}:177-178, cf. {ref ALEW} 332-333).

Tocharian, Greek, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' ({ref LIV²} 215-216, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:683-684, {ref Beekes 2010}:505, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:356-357, {ref EWAia} I:594, {ref Cheung 2007}:222-223, {ref ALEW} 338-340, {ref Derksen 2008}:652, {ref de Vaan 2008}:685-686, {ref Matasović 2009}:67).
Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯p- 'to stick' ({ref LIV²} 408-409, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:326-327, {ref Kroonen 2013}:335-336).

Comment: < 'cooked'.
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *pekʷ- 'to make ripe; to cook' ({ref ALEW} 477-478, {ref Derksen 2015}:237-238, {ref Derksen 2008}:393, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:255-256, cf. {ref LIV²} 468).

Armenian, Indic, Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ- 'to hinder, restrict' ({ref NIL} 301-303, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:94-95, {ref EWAia} I:39, {ref Derksen 2008}:388, {ref Kroonen 2013}:28-29, {ref de Vaan 2008}:42, {ref Matasović 2009}:36, 214)

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃nebʰ- 'navel' ({ref NIL} 385-387, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1080, {ref EWAia} II:13-14, {ref Derksen 2015}:562, {ref Kroonen 2013}:380, {ref de Vaan 2008}:639, {ref Matasović 2009}:33)
Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *men- 'to rise, stick up' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:388, {ref Deshayes 2003}:502, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, cf. {ref LIV²} 437).

Comment: cf. Vedic purāṇá- 'prior, former, old', from purā́ adv. < *pr̥h₂éh₁ (instrumental, cf. purás < *pr̥h₂és etc.)
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from a PIE root *perh₂-, secondary to PIE *pr̥-, *pró-, *prí 'forwards, to the front' ({ref EWAia} II:146-147, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:469 no. 8283, {ref EWA 3}:300-301, {ref Kroonen 2013}:161, cf. {ref LIPP 2}:653, 633).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *neu̯- 'new' ({ref NIL} 524-526, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:605, {ref Adams 2013}:287-288, {ref Beekes 2010}:1009, {ref Hübschmann 1897}:479, {ref EWAia} II:25, {ref ALEW} 690-691, {ref Derksen 2015}:330-331, {ref ESSJa} 26:9-13, {ref Derksen 2008}:357, {ref Kroonen 2013}:389, {ref de Vaan 2008}:416, {ref Matasović 2009:293)

Hellenic, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *nógʷt-/*négʷt- 'evening, night', a dental-stem derivative of PIE *negʷ- 'to become dark, dawn' ({ref NIL} 504-513, {ref LIV²} 449, cf. {ref {Beekes 2010}:1027, {ref Demiraj 1997}:283-284, {ref Orel 1998}:282-283, {ref EWAia} II:2-3, {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:242, {ref ALEW} 683-684, {ref Derksen 2015}:327-328, {ref ESSJa} 25:175-177, {ref Derksen 2008}:355, {ref Kroonen 2013}:381, {ref de Vaan 2008}:416-417, {ref Matasović 2009}:293-294). The Brythonic lexemes in this class are sometimes considered to be (parallel?) loanwords from Latin (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:293-294, {ref Deshayes 2003}:539-540), but by others to be inherited (cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Falileyev 2000}:121, {ref NIL} 509n10). The assumption that these lexemes are inherited has been followed here.

Comment: Vedic -:nas(-a)- as a second member in compounds confirms *H in root onset, ergo PIE *Hnas-
Justification: Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes continuing an Indo-European word for 'nose' traditionally reconstructed as *(H)nā̆s- ({ref EIEC} 395, cf. {ref IEW} 755), although Leiden school of Indo-European reconstructs an ablauting s-stem *neh₂-s- (cf. {ref Kortlandt 1985b}:119). The traditional reconstruction has been followed here for the purpose of a root reference form. For individual branches cf. {ref EWAia} II:30-31, {ref ALEW} 711, {ref Derksen 2015}:336-337, {ref ESSJa} 25:212-216, {ref Derksen 2008}:357, {ref Kroonen 2013}:383, {ref de Vaan 2008}:400)

Anatolian, Tocharian, Greek, and Armenian pexemes derived from PIE *sem- 'one (collective)' ({ref LIPP 2}:671-679, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:750-751, {ref Adams 2013}:721-722, {ref Beekes 2010}:394, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:467-468).
Parallel loans from Persian تنگ / tang 'narrow'.

Celtic lexemes generally connected to Lat. pūrus 'clean, pure, undefiled', Skt. pūtá- 'purified', etc. since {ref Pedersen 1909}:91 (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} U:26-27, {ref Matasović 2009}:143). The PIE root is now reconstructed as *peu̯H- (cf. {ref LIV²} 480 s.v. 1.*peu̯H- 'reinigen, läutern'), but cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:143 who alternatively suggests a connection to PIE *peh₂-u̯r̥- 'fire' and with an original meaning 'purified by fire', but this proposal has not been widely accepted.

The cognacy of these Germanic lexemes are difficult to assign. A majority view of scholars assign them with derivatives of one of the PIE *men- roots in /cognate/76/, alternatively a minority view of scholars places it with other Germanic, Italic, and Celtic words for 'human' < *dʰg̑ʰ-mon- *'earthling' /cognate/907/. The cognacy decision for these lexemes has therefore been to split these lexemes from the majority set into their own separate set, which has been appropriately indexed to the other existing sets.

Albanian and Indic lexemes derived from PIE *ten- 'to stretch' ({ref LIV²} 626-627, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:284-285, {ref Orel 1998}:283, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:985, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:328 no. 5762, {ref EWAia} I:618-619).

Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *nebʰ- '(to become) wet, cloudy, vaporous' ({ref NIL} 499-504, cf. {ref EWAia} II:13, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:400 no. 6955c, {ref Kroonen 2013}:386, {ref de Vaan 2008}:404).

Indo-Iranic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *nebʰ- '(to become) wet, cloudy, vaporous' ({ref NIL} 499-504, cf. {ref EWAia} I:94, II:13, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:400 no. 6955c, {ref de Vaan 2008}:299, {ref Untermann 2000}:95-96).

Anatolian, Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Celtic derivatives from PIE *nebʰ- 'become damp, cloudy, misty' ({ref NIL} 499-504; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:603-604, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:71-72, {ref ALEW} 186-187, {ref Derksen 2015}:118, {ref ESSJa} 24:101-104, {ref Derksen 2008}:347-348, {ref Matasović 2009}:288-289).
Slavic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to flow, swirl, seethe' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:606, {ref de Vaan 2008}:524-525, {ref Derksen 2008}:434-435, cf. {ref LIV²} 305-306).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- '(to make) red' ({ref NIL} 580-584, {ref EIEC} 480-481, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:570-571, {ref Beekes 2010}:465-466, {ref EWAia} II:471, {ref ALEW} 847, {ref Derksen 2015}:376-377, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Kroonen 2013}:406, {ref de Vaan 2008}:527, {ref Matasović 2009}:315, {ref LIV²} 508-509).

Hellenic, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes reflecting different derivations from PIE *dek̑s- 'to be suitable' ({ref Beekes 2010}:316-317, {ref Demiraj 1997}:137-138, {ref Orel 1998}:67-68, {ref EWAia} I:690-691, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:349 no. 6119, {ref ALEW} 199, {ref Derksen 2015}:124, {ref ESSJa} 4:218-219, {ref Derksen 2008}:100-101, {ref Kroonen 2013}:512, {ref de Vaan 2008}:168, {Matasović 2009}:97, cf. {ref LIV²} 112)

Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' ({ref EWAia} I:252-253, II:425, {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:459, {ref Lehmann 1986}:231, {ref Kroonen 2013}:408, {ref de Vaan 2008}:517-518, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:241 no. 2648, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 3:87-91, cf. {ref LIV²} 304-305).

Germanic and Italic lexemes reflecting PIE *h₂ekʷ-eh₂- 'water' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:7, {ref EWA 1}:99-103, {ref de Vaan 2008}:48, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:46). Pace {ref Kroonen 2013}, the different morphology of the Germanic-Italic lexemes on one hand and the Indo-Iranian, and Baltic lexemes on the other does not favour the view that PIE *h₂ekʷ- and *h₂ep- were variants of one another (Martin Kümmel, p.c.). Likewise it is not clear whether the Germanic and Italic lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (as advocated by {ref Beekes 1998}), but in view of the regular correspondences between Italic and Germanic, gratuitous. Further proposed connections are less certain (cf. {ref EWA 1} 99-103 for a thorough discussion). Less certain is the connection of the Celtic and Anatolian lexemes (cf. discussion in /cognate/1735/).

Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *peu̯H- 'to rot, to stink' ({ref EWAia} II:155, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:141, {ref ALEW} 834, {ref Derksen 2015}:374, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:219, {ref Kroonen 2013}:132, 158, {ref de Vaan 2008}:501, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:570 no. 6878, 6887, cf. {ref LIV²} 480-481).

Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰegʷ- 'to run away, flee' via the causative-iterative stem *bʰogʷ-éi̯e- 'to make run, flee' (cf. {ref LIV²} 67, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1183-1184, {ref Beekes 2010}:1559).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *sal- 'salt' ({ref NIL} 586-590, {ref EIEC} 498, {ref IEW} 878-879, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:742, {ref Beekes 2010}:177, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:24, 40-41, {ref ALEW} 887-888, {ref Derksen 2015}:548-549, {ref Derksen 2008}:461, {ref Kroonen 2013}:425, {ref de Vaan 2008}:535, {ref Matasović 2009}:319). The root is difficult to reconstruct; the traditional reconstruction as *sal- has been followed here after {ref NIL}, but note in order to avoid reconstructing PIE *a the Leiden school reconstructs a hysterokinetic l-stem: nom.sg. *séh₂‑l‑s, acc.sg. *sh₂‑el‑m, gen.sg. *sh₂‑l‑ós ({ref Kortlandt 1985b}:119, {ref Beekes 1995}:177, cf. also {ref Rieken 1999}:424n2103). The Germanic forms in this set show an extension in *d which may be on analogy to *su̯eh₂d- 'sweet' /cognate/5109/, alternatively the *-d- might be explained as a compound with the root *deh₃- 'give' (cf. {ref ALEW} 886-887 s.v. Old Lithuanian saldùs 'sweet' and further discussion in /cognate/5157/).

Originally in the sense 'delta, confluence of (river) waters' with preverb sam- 'together with, along with' + *udra- 'water' ({ref EWAia} II:705, I:215-216, {ref NIL} 706-715; cf. the Skt. n-stem udan- abstracted from the original heteroclite -r/n-stem derived from PIE *u̯ed-). For the Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:764, no. 13236.
Baltic lexemes generally considered derived from PIE *kes- *'to arrange, put in order' → to comb, scratch' ({ref LIV²} 359, {ref ALEW} 463-464, {ref Derksen 2015}:231).

Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *seh₁- 'to press in' → 'to sow' ({ref ALEW} 906-907, {ref Derksen 2015}:392, {ref Derksen 2008}:446, {ref Kroonen 2013}:428-430, {ref de Vaan 2008}:557, {ref Matasović 2009}:336, cf. {ref LIV²} 517).

Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *kes- *'to arrange, put in order' → to comb, scratch' ({ref Derksen 2008}:238, {ref ESSJa} 11:133-135; cf. {ref LIV²} 357). Perhaps also connected to Proto-Germanic *hēra- 'hair' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:220 and further discussion in /cognate/9647/).

Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *si̯eu̯H- 'to sew' ({ref LIV²} 545, cf. {ref EWAia} II:734, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:766 no. 13444, {ref Cheung 2007}:136-137, {ref ALEW}  917-918, {ref Derksen 2015}:400, {ref Derksen 2008}:487, {ref Kroonen 2013}:437-438, {ref de Vaan 2008}:600, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:203 no. 2174).

Hellenic and Albanian lexemes derived from PIE *sper- 'to spread, scatter' ({ref LIV²} 580). The connection of Albanian lexemes to this class follows {ref Demiraj 1997}:56, {ref Orel 1998}:93, but more skeptically cf. {ref Holm 2011}:78; for Hellenic, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1035-1036, {ref Beekes 2010}:1379-1380, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1316).

Germanic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *pel-. The Germanic forms in this class reflect *pel-no- ({ref EWA 3}:122-126, {ref Kroonen 2013}:135), while the Italic/Romance forms reflect an i-stem *pel-ni- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:455, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:525 no. 6377).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11348 s.v. *varta- 'round stone', *'rolled / rolling stone', from PIE *uert- 'roll, rolled; turn, spin', cf. Skrt. vartula- 'round, circular', Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 156
Justification: Modern Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Indo-Iranic *varta- *'turning around, circular object' → 'round stone', further to be derived from PIE *u̯ert- 'to revolve' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:661 no. 11348, {ref KEWA} II:154-156, cf. {ref LIV²} 691-692).

Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from PIE *slegh₂snó- ({ref EWAia} II:673, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:25-26), probably to be abstracted to a more basic root *(s)legh₂- (cf. Ancient Greek λαγαρός 'slack, loose'). Considered by {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:25-26 to be a variant of PIE *(s)lei̯- with a root-extension *-g̑-, but this conjecture remains uncertain.

The cognacy of the Germanic, Celtic, and Italic (cf. Lat. natrīx) lexemes is generally agreed, but the IE root etymology is debated. More commonly ascribed to PIE *(s)neh₁- 'twist, spin' ({ref LIV²} 571-572, {ref IEW} 973). Also possible, but less likely to *(s)neh₂- 'bathe, swim' ({ref LIV²} 572-573, {ref IEW} 971-972). Cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:403, {ref Lehmann 1986}:262, {ref Kroonen 2013}:381, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} N:4-5, {ref Matasović 2009}:284, {ref de Vaan 2008}:402).

Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *kʷr̥mi- 'worm' ({ref EWAia} I:394-395, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:569, {ref Matasović 2009}:181-182). Perhaps connected to PIE *u̯r̥mi- 'worm' (cf. /cognate/172/ for further discussion).

Within Hellenic the root of the noun, *γλῶχ- / *glōkʰ 'point', is attested via γλωχίς 'end of a yoke strap, barb of an arrow, etc.', but there are no known cognates outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:229-230, {ref Beekes 2010}:278).

Tocharian, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *snei̯gʷʰ- 'to stick, adhere to' ({ref NIL} 622-625 {ref EIEC} 530, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:689-690, {ref ALEW} 951, {ref Derksen 2015}:416, {ref Derksen 2008}:457, {ref Kroonen 2013}460, {ref de Vaan 2008}:409-410, {ref Matasović 2009}:349, {ref LIV²} 573).

Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' ({ref EWAia} I:252-253, II:425, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:350-352, {ref Kroonen 2013}:408-409, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:566, {ref de Vaan 2008}:517-518, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:241 no. 2648, {ref Thurneysen 1946}:119, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:96, {ref Matasović 2009}:308).
Anatolian, Albanian, and Celtic derivatives from PIE *mel(it)- 'honey' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:580-581, {ref Demiraj 1997}:169-170, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:50-51).
Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *melino- 'yellow', a derivative based on PIE *melit- 'honey' ({ref Matasović 2009}:263, cf. {ref EIEC} 271).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʰrebh₂- ({ref LIV²} 201, {ref EWAia} I:505-507, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:227 no. 4236, {ref Cheung 2007}:119-121).

Indic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯kʷ- 'to leave' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:492, no. 8743, {ref EWAia} II:457-458, {ref Broaderick 1984b}:451-452, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:161, {ref Matasović 2009}:240, cf. {ref LIV²} 406-408).
Probably to be derived from the inherited word for 'honey' μέλι < PIE *melit- ({ref Andriotis 1974}:370, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:925-926). Regarding the IE 'honey', cf. {ref EIEC} 271.

Tocharian, Indic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *su̯eh₂d- 'to make/become tasty' ({ref NIL} 670-675, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:795-796, {ref EWAia} II:788-789, {ref Kroonen 2013}:503, cf. {ref LIV²} 606-607).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *men- 'to think' ({ref EWAia} II:305-306, cf. {ref LIV²} 435-436).

Albanian, Indic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *serp- 'to creep' ({ref Demiraj 1997}:183-184, {ref Orel 1998}:130, {ref EWAia} II:710, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:766 no. 13271, {ref de Vaan 2008}:558, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:648, cf. {ref LIV²} 536).

Albanian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷerH- ({ref Huld 1984}:66-67, {ref Demiraj 1997}:181, {ref Orel 1998}:127, {ref Holm 2011}:82, {ref EWAia} I:487, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:223 no. 4161, {ref ESIJa} 3:191-193 {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:187). Note Sinhalese gala appears to be a contamination of the inherited lexeme with Tamil kal 'stone'.

Anatolian and Baltic lexemes whose cognacy is generally agreed, but root reconstruction difficult. Cf. comments of {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:392-393. LIV¹ reconstructs *seh₂(i̯)-, {ref LIV²} *sh₂ei̯-. As a compromise between the two versions of LIV and {ref Kloekhorst 2008}, we give *seh₂(i̯)- as the root ref. form for this class. See also {ref Derksen 2015}:397-398. For Indo-Iranic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this set, cf. {ref EWAia} II:720-721.

Traditionally connected to Vedic khā́dati 'to chew, bite, eat, devour' ({ref HAB} III:317-318, {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:210), but there are no certain cognates for Vedic khā́dati outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:451-452). See {ref Martirosyan 2010}:323-324 for further discussion.

Comment: fr. ie. ken- 'scratch, scrape', ultimately cognate with Gr.: κὀνισ 'ashes' (Pokorny) and maybe also with 'scratch' in /lexeme/18887/

from PIE *h₂ek̑  'sharp, pointed; stone, rock'; cognate with 'stone' /cognate/1179/ - NB. sky (and daylight) was mythically seen as coming out of the rock (cf. the Vedic Vala-myth) and thus as originating from/being made from rock/stone.
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *h₂ék̑-mon- 'stone' (gen.sg. *h₂k-n-és-), an *mn̥-stem nominal derivative of PIE *h₂ek̑- 'to be(come), make sharp' ({ref EWAia} I:137-138).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:658-659, {ref Beekes 2010}:1248, {ref EWAia} II:75-76, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:435-436 no.7721, {ref Kroonen 2013}:138-139, {ref de Vaan 2008}:458, {ref Lucht 2007}:151-152, {ref Matasović 2009}:129). For the root reconstruction *pet-, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.

Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Sanskrit khúra- without certain etymology, possibly loans from Dravidian (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:207 no. 3906; {ref KEWA} I:310, {ref EWAia} I:454, cf. {ref Burrow 1948}:376). Perhaps further connected with lexemes as though from Sanskrit *khuṭṭa- 'peg, post' in /cognate/9630/, but these could also be parallel loans.
Nuristani lexemes as though from Indic *ḍagga- (2) 'defective' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:310 no. 5524).

Hellenic lexemes, traditionally connected with Baltic lexemes (Lith. ver̃pti, 'spin', Latv. virpêt 'spin with a spindle' ({ref IEW} 1156), but the evidence of Myc. e-ra-pe-me-na without initial *w- makes this etymology impossible ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:967, {ref Beekes 2010}:1275-1276). Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain.

Hellenic lexemes whose root etymology is traditionally disputed between the near-homophonous roots *peth₁- 'to fall', 1. *peth₂- 'to spread out', and 2. *peth₂- 'to fly' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:931, {ref Beekes 2010}:1225-1226, cf. {ref LIV²} 477-479). See now, however, {ref  LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} merging *peth₁- 'to fall' and 2. *peth₂- 'to fly' into a single, more basic root *pet- 'to fly; to fall'. In view of this, the basic etymology to *pet- has been tentatively accepted here.

Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic √pat- 'to fall; fly' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:436, no. 7722), further from PIE *pet- 'to fall; fly' ({ref EWAia} II:71-72, {ref LIV²} 436, {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8792 s.v. právahati, cf. pravāhayati 'causes to swim away'; for Kashmiri cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11612 (?) - different derivations
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing different derivatives and light-verb constructions derived from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to carry, drive' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:494 no. 8792, p.677 no. 11612, {ref EWAia} II:535-537, {ref Cheung 2007}:429-432).

Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from or in light-verb constructions with PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth'. The root etymology is traditionally considered to be to PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', however difficulties regarding the Greek comparanda (ὀδών 'tooth', νωδός 'toothless') have led the Leiden school of Indo-European reconstruction to consider an underlying root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' (cf. {ref Kortlandt 2003}:77). If the traditional etymology is followed, then these lexemes would also be cognate with Old Irish ithid 'to bite, to eat' in /cognate/6370/ which is clearly derived from PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat'. For the lexemes in this class, cf. {ref EWAia} I:693-694, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:352 no. 6152, {ref Deshayes 2003}:170, {ref Matasović 2009}:90). For further details regarding the etymology of PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth', cf. further discussion in /cognate/328/.

Greek and Indic lexemes derived from PIE *denk̑- 'to bite' ({ref LIV²} 117-118, {ref EWAia} I:688, {ref Beekes 2010}:299). Sometimes connected to these lexemes are also  Tocharian AB tsāk- 'to bite', but these lexemes are probably better explained via PIE *dʰei̯Hgʷ- 'to sting' (cf. {ref LIV²} 142, {ref Ringe 1988-1990}:71).

Comment: The q-forms make a loan from Turkic likely (cf. kapmak 'to snatch'). Abaev (apud Cabolov) suggestes an onomatopoetic formation and Vasmer (apud Cabolov) noted Slavic verbs like Ukrainian хапати 'to grab, snatch' considering them a continuation of a PIE root *khap-. On this see also Cheung (2007: 234f.) *kop-.

Justification: Probably a loanword from Latin capessere 'to seize, snatch at' ({ref Meyer 1891}:176, {ref Orel 1998}:164, {ref Holm 2011}:53), but other Latin loan sources are theoretically possible.

Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Nuristani, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pet- 'to fly, to fall'. For the root reconstruction cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}. For individual branches cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:658-659, {ref Beekes 2010}:1248, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:286-287, {Turner 1962–1966}:437 no. 7733, {ref Kroonen 2013}:138-139, {ref de Vaan 2008}:458, {ref Matasović 2009}:126).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4711 s.v. Sanskrit carvati, carvayati ʻchewsʼ (Dhātup.); further etymology unclear (< *kerH-?), cf. Mayrhofer KEWA I, p. 379, EWAia I, p. 547
Loan from English 'bite'.
Justification: A borrowing from English 'bite, bit' ({ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:36).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *h₂ost-, the inherited Indo-European word for 'bone' ({ref EIEC} 77, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:325-326, {ref Adams 2013}:48-50, {ref Beekes 2010}:1119, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:533, {ref Demiraj 1997}:82-83, {ref Orel 1998}:11, {ref EWAia} I:150-151, {ref ESIJa} 1:232-234, {ref de Vaan 2008}:436-437, {ref Matasović 2009}:44-45). Perhaps cognate with the lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kost- with /cognate/1114/ but the explanation of the initial k- is unclear (cf. further discussion in that cognate set). The PIE stem is usually reconstructed with initial *h₂- on the basis of Greek ἀστραγαλός 'knucklebone' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:129), but the etymological connection of this word to the lexemes in this class is rejected by {ref Beekes 2010}:157-158 who prefers to see Greek ἀστραγαλός as a substratum loanword.

Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Sanskrit khúra- without certain etymology, possibly loans from Dravidian (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:207 no. 3906; {ref KEWA} I:310, {ref EWAia} I:454, cf. {ref Burrow 1948}:376). Perhaps further connected with lexemes as though from Sanskrit *khuṭṭa- 'peg, post' in /cognate/9629/, but these could also be parallel loans.

Hellenic lexemes of uncertain etymology, perhaps from a PIE root *pneu̯- if cognate with Germanic lexemes attested by, e.g., Old Norse fnýsa 'sniff, snort' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:920, {ref Beekes 2010}:1213-1214, {ref LIV²} 489).
West Germanic lexemes probably originally based on an onomatopoeic formation ({ref Kluge 2011}:414, {ref EWNl} II:475).
Possibly parallel loans from Dravidian, see {ref Turner 1962–1966}:206 no. 3894, cf. also 'knee' in /cognate/2792/, 'leg' in /cognate/9630/.

Brythonic lexemes, probably continuing a loanword from Latin cumulus 'heap' although the conservation of medial *-m- in phonetically difficult (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:422, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Albanian, Iranic, Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *déru- ~ *dóru- ~ *dru- 'wood, tree' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:849-850, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:262-263, {ref Beekes 2010}:315-316, {ref Demiraj 1997}:146-148, {ref Orel 1998}:76, {ref EWAia} I:721, {ref ESIJa} 2:357-365, {ref ESSJa} 4:211-213, {ref Derksen 2008}:99, {ref Kroonen 2013}:522-523, cf. {ref IEW} 214-217).

Lexemes continuing PIE *du̯o-, *du̯i- 'two' ({ref Eichner 1982}:1-141, {ref LIPP 2}:168-174, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:826-827, {ref Adams 2013}:651, {ref Beekes 2010}:359, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:268-269, {ref Demiraj 1997}:151-152, {ref Orel 1998}:79, {ref EWAia} I:761-763, {ref ESIJa} II:481-490, {ref ALEW} 235-237, {ref Derksen 2015}:143, {ref ESSJa} 5:185-186, {ref Derksen 2008}:130, {ref Kroonen 2013}:529, {ref de Vaan 2008}:183, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:6, {ref Matasović 2009}:110)
Iranic and Germanic lexemes from a PIE heteroclite stem *i̯eh₁-r/n- ({ref EWAia} II:98-99, {ref ESIJa} 4:130-131, {ref Kroonen 2013}:273).

Indo-Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eH(i̯)- 'to sing' ({ref EWAia} I:482-483, {ref Cheung 2007}:94, {ref ALEW} 320-321, {ref Derksen 2015}:174, {ref LIV²} 183). The Baltic forms show an extra *-d- added to the basic root, sometimes considered a root enlargement, but may be also accounted for via various other explanations (cf. {ref ALEW} 320-321 for further discussion).
Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *⁽k̑⁾an- 'to sing, sound' ({ref LIV²} 342-343, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:87-88, {ref Schumacher 2004}:387-390, {ref Matasović 2009}:187-188).

Comment: unclear why Parthian bāšēd is sorted into this set (TJ)

Justification: Extra-Germanic etymology unclear. Possibly from PIE *gʷet- if comparable to Arm. kočʻem 'to call, invite', but the comparison is not entirely clear; cf. {ref LIV²} 212, {ref Kroonen 2013}:319, {ref Lehmann 1986}:277-278, {ref Seebold 1970}:318-320, {ref Olsen 1999}:811.

Baltic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *nem- 'to portion out'. Cognacy in this class follows {ref LIV²} s.v. 1. *nem-, {ref Lehmann 1986}:266-267), but {ref LIV²} 236 s.v. *h₁em-. It is possible that these two roots formed a rhyming pair in PIE (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:357-359); cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:387 for an attempt to reconcile the Germanic lexemes to *h₁em- by assuming a reanalysis of the compound verb *gan-eman- < *kom-h₁em-e- as containing the perfective prefix *ga-: *ga-neman-.

Tocharian, Albanian, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ek̑- 'to be(come), make sharp' ({ref NIL} 287-300, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:5, {ref Orel 1998}:86, {ref ALEW} 62, {ref Derksen 2015}:64, {ref ESSJa} 36:63-66, {ref Derksen 2008}:379, {ref de Vaan 2008}:22, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:11 no. 134, 135).
Possibly parallel loans from Dravidian, see {ref Turner 1962–1966}:206 no. 3894, cf. also 'knee' in /cognate/2792/, 'foot' in /cognate/9629/.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *su̯an-na- 'to sound, play an instrument', further to PIE *su̯enh₂- 'to sound' ({ref LIV²} 611, {ref Schumacher 2004}:607-609, {ref Matasović 2009}:360-361).

Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *h₂ék̑-mon- 'stone' (gen.sg. *h₂k-n-és-), an *mn̥-stem nominal derivative of PIE *h₂ek̑- 'to be(come), make sharp' ({ref EWAia} I:137-138, {ref ALEW} 28-29, {ref ESSJa} 9:137-140, {ref Derksen 2008}:220, {ref Derksen 2015}:47-48, {ref Delamarre 2003}:30-31).

Hellenic lexemes as though from PIE *ken(H)-is- ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:562, {ref Beekes 2010}:746-747, {ref Babinotis 2010}:706, 1284, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:115). The connection of Albanian hi 'ash' to this class (cf. /cognate/850/) presupposes the reconstruction of an s-mobile root *(s)ken(H)- (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:74, {ref Orel 1998}:47).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *druko- 'bad', further connections uncertain (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996 D:198-199, {ref Matasović 2009}:105-106).

The root etymology in this set tentatively follows {ref LIV²} 238 to PIE *h₁er- 'to get (somewhere)' via a stem formation *h₁r̥-sk̑é-, although formally the Hellenic lexemes may also reflect a secondarily thematised present stem *h₁erg̑ʰ-/h₁r̥g̑ʰ- to *h₁erg̑ʰ- 'to climb, ascend' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:377, {ref Beekes 2010}:468).

The root etymology in this set tentatively follows {ref LIV²} 238 to PIE *h₁er- 'to get (somewhere)' via a stem formation *h₁r̥-sk̑é-, although formally the Hellenic lexemes may also reflect a secondarily thematised present stem *h₁erg̑ʰ-/h₁r̥g̑ʰ- to *h₁erg̑ʰ- 'to climb, ascend' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:377, {ref Beekes 2010}:468).

Comment: seng- 'thin, slender' and suffix -an
Justification: Goidelic lexemes from Old Irish sengán 'ant'. Etymology uncertain, perhaps to be connected with Proto-Germanic *swengwan- 'to swing' (so {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:85-86, but proposed connections for this verb outside of Germanic are rejected by {ref Seebold 1970}:493, cf. {Kluge 2011}:836).
Etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:163 no. 3193, {ref EWAia} I:355-356).

Ossetic lexemes as though from Proto-Iranic *pa(s)nu-ka-, cf. Av. pąsnu, Ved. pāṃsu- 'soil, dust, sand' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:449), further probably to PIE ?*pē(n)s- ({ref EIEC} 499, but cf. {ref EWAia} II:114-115).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *peh₃(i̯)- 'to drink' ({ref LIV²} 262, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1194-1195, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:277-279, {ref Orel 1998}:324-325, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:990, {ref EWAia} II:113-114, {ref Derksen 2015}:563, {ref Derksen 2008}:401, {ref de Vaan 2008}:71-72, {ref Matasović 2009}:130).
Romance lexemes continuing *skĭna-, a loanword from Germanic *skĭna- 'small piece of bone, shin', cf. Germanic scina 'thin strip, shin' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:659 no. 7994, {ref DCECH} II:761-762).
Hellenic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *pleth₂- 'be(come) wide, broad' ({ref NIL} 564-566; cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1205, {ref Derksen 2008}:404).

Romanian spathe is originally from Latin spatha 'beater, spatula', originally a loanword from Greek σπάθη 'broad blade (of wood or metal)', while the Iberian Romance forms are from Latin spatula, the diminutive of spatha  (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1930–1935}:612, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:638-639, {ref DCECH} II:733-734).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic.
Modern Indic lexemes as from Vedic pāṁsú- 'soil, dust, sand' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:452 no. 452, further probably to PIE ?*pē(n)s- ({ref EIEC} 499, but cf. {ref EWAia} II:114-115).

Connections outside of Armenian uncertain. Within Armenian probably to be connected with Classical Armenian kuṙn '(anatom.) back; side', which in turn – if the original semantic meaning was 'curved/bending body-part' – may be related to Classical Armenian kor 'curved, crooked' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:376, cf. id. 382, 373-374). {ref HAB} II:669 offers no etymology. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kuṙ(-tʰ)-un-].

Root_Gloss: back side, something that is at the back side

Justification: Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:640 for discussion and suggestions.
Loan from Saṇu-viri gutʹu 'rump'.
No certain etymology outside of East Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 714, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:429).
Romance lexemes continuing Latin rēnēs 'kidneys' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:596), further etymology obscure ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:569-570, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:519 for various suggestions).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:78 for suggestions.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *elhja- 'evil'; further etymology uncertain ({ref de Vries 1977}:285). More recently cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:637-638 suggesting a connection to PGmc. *ubila- 'bad' in /cognate/2195/ under the assumption of some irregular sound changes; alternatively cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:117 tentatively suggests a connection with OIr. elc 'mischievous, capricious' via ?*h₁elk-o-. Root ref. form follows the reconstruction of {ref Kroonen 2013}.

Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *wanda- 'turned, twisted', further derived from PIE u̯endʰ- 'to twist, wind' ({ref Seebold 1970}:554-555, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:654-655, {ref Kroonen 2013}:573, 587, cf. {ref LIV²} 681-682).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin reus 'defendant, accused' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}) and also related to Latin rēs 'property, goods; thing, matter, affair', further to PIE *(H)reh₁- (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:521-522 for discussion of the Italic stem formation; for the root reconstruction cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:520-521, {ref LIV²} 499).

Derivatives from PIE *(s)kert- 'cut (to pieces)' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:144-145, {ref de Vaan 2008}:138, cf. {ref LIV²} 559-560), often considered to be a dental-enlarged form of PIE 2. *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' (cf. {ref LIV²} 556-7).

No certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Kroonen 2013}:346, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:375). Occasionally compared to Balto-Slavic lexemes, e.g. Lith. mãkas 'purse, pouch, scrotum', but the connection remains uncertain (cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:399).

Comment: from PIE *gʰreu̯d- 'to pound, to mash' (Kroonen 2013:187, Kluge 2002:375, ALEW 374; not in LIV²).
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *grauta- 'strong, thick, big', further from PIE *gʰrou̯d-o-, cf. the Germanic strong verb *greutan- 'to grind, crush' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:187, 189, {ref Kluge 2011}:376-377, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:256, {ref Seebold 1970}:242, cf. {ref ALEW} 374).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:47 for further discussion. For proposed connections to Wakhi lup and Indic and Nurstani lexemes, cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:227.

Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂merd- 'to hurt, mistreat' ({ref LIV²} 280, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:414, {ref de Vaan 2008}:389, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:465 no. 5679, cf. {ref DCECH} III:143-145, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 6/3:126-129).

Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *hu̯aǰ-, from Proto-Indo-Iranic *su̯aǰ-, cf. Ved. √svaj- ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:152-154). Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:788, cf. {ref LIV²} 610-611 reconstructing ?*su̯eng- on the basis of the comparison of Old Irish seng 'schlank' < *'biegsam').

There are several different nominal derivations within Germanic here that are based on PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split' ({ref LIV²} 70-71); cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:66, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:115, 126-127, {ref Kluge 2011}:127, {ref Lehmann 1986}:58-59, {ref de Vries 1977}:30).
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *pik̑-ro-, a derivative to PIE *pei̯k̑- 'to cut out, carve out' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:900-901, {ref Beekes 2010}:1190, cf. {ref LIV²} 465-466).
Cognacy in this class follows {ref Demiraj 1997}:200-201 deriving to PIE *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'to kindle, ignite (smth.)', but cf. {ref Orel 1998}:147.
Lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kortъkъ 'short', further derived from PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' ({ref Derksen 2008}:236, {ref ESSJa} 11:99-104, cf. {ref LIV²} 559-560).

Tocharian lexemes, possibly to PIE *h₁ergʷ- via a derived stem *h₁r̥gʷ-ont- 'dark' (cf. Skt. rájanī- 'night', Gk. ἔρεβος 'darkness of the underworld', Arm. erek 'evening', Goth. riqis 'darkness'), but ultimately uncertain ({ref Adams 2013}:101).
Iranic lexemes, ultimately derivatives from PIE *temH- 'to be dark' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:82, {ref EWAia} I:627). Cf. Avestan tąθra- ᾽darkness᾽.
Iranic lexemes reflecting Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćar(a)d-, cf. Vedic śarád- 'autumn; year'; no further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:616, cf. also {ref NIL} 415n7).

According to {ref Bailey 1979}:469, to be connected with Baltic adjectives meaning 'red, ruddy' from a basic root *ser- ({ref IEW} 910-911). The extra-Baltic connections to the proposed comparanda in Lithuanian sar̃tas 'red-brown, chestnut (of a horse)', etc.  have been recently doubted by {ref ALEW} 891, but cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007}:534.
Brythonic lexemes as though from Proto-Celtic *u̯ait-o- 'blood', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Schrijver 1995}:130, {ref Deshayes 2003}:295, {ref Lucht 2007}:67n7).
Ossetic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *tau̯ká-, further etymology uncertain (cf.  {ref EWAia} I:670, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:309-310).
Tocharian A wräṣ 'breathe', a derivative of PIE 3. u̯er- 'to observe, perceive' ({ref LIV²} 685-686, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:892).

Pontic Greek ανασμαίνω from Ancient Greek ἀνασθμαίνω 'to breathe with difficulty', a denominal verb to Ancient Greek ἄσθμα 'short-drawn breath, panting' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:148). Older attempts to connect Ancient Greek ἄσθμα to ἄνεμος 'wind' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:122-123) are formally impossible ({ref Beekes 2010}:148) as one would expect a base ἄνε- from the root *h₂enh₁-. Consequently, there is currently no known etymology outside of Greek.

From Sanskrit śoṇita- 'blood' created to Vedic śóṇa- 'red, crimson; purple' with the suffix -ita- on analogy to Sanskrit lohita- 'blood' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:732 no. 12625), further from PIE *k̑óu̯-no- 'shining' ({ref EWAia} II:656-657).
Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √yā- 'to drive, move oneself', ultimately to PIE *(H)i̯eh₂- (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:58 no. 1288, {ref EWAia} II:407-408, {ref LIV²} 309-310).

Derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ({ref EWAia} II:655-656, {ref LIV²} 331).
Lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *baina- 'bone, leg' (unattested in Gothic), further etymology obscure (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:105-106, {ref Kroonen 2013}:48).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *knuk(k)an- 'knuckle', perhaps a root-extended variant *g̑nu-g- to PIE *g̑enu-, *g̑neu- 'knee' but this is not certain (cf. discussion in {ref Kluge 2011}:507-508, {ref Kroonen 2013}:298).

Goidelic lexemes continuing an Indo-European stem *konh₂m-, cf. Ancient Greek κνήμη 'leg', Old English hamm 'ham' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:129-130, {ref Matasović 2009}:211, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:723).
The root etymology in this set follows {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:673-674, assuming a prefix pe- 'away, thither' to verbal dā- 'take' < PIE *deh₃- (cf. {ref LIV²} 105-106).
Denominal formation from Welsh cri 'cry', respectively a loanword from English cry ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).

Albanian lexemes generally derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'to become warm' ({ref NIL} 196-199, {ref LIV²} 219-220), although the stem formation of Albanian zjarr is uncertain (cf. {ref Holm 2011}:62, {ref Orel 1998}:525 and especially the detailed discussion of {ref Demiraj 1997}:428-429).

Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn' (Proto-Iranic *sauč- 'to burn, emit flames'). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ({ref EWAia} II:655-656, {ref LIV²} 331, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:338-340, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:208-210).

{ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:195 suggested a connection to a basic root *ges- and to be compared with Latin gerere 'to carry, bear about' (past participle gestum), however the root etymology of Latin gerō, -ere is disputed. {ref Schrijver 1991}:18-19 tentatively rehabilitates an old proposal by Osthoff to *h₂eg̑- via a perform *h₂g̑-és-, and this followed by {ref de Vaan 2008}:259, but cf. the skepticism of {ref Walde & Hofmann 1938–1954} I:595-596, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:273-274. If the connection of Scottish Gaelic giùlain to a neo-root *ges- (< *h₂g̑-és-?) is to be maintained, this would be a unique Italo-Celtic lexical(-morphological) isogloss. Given the multiple degrees of speculation required to posit an ultimate root etymology to PIE *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' for this exclusively Scottish Gaelic cognate set, the root reference form has been given as the Gaelic form itself.

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₁urH-ú- 'broad, wide', presupposing a full-grade root *h₁u̯erH- (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:483-484, {ref EWAia} I:227, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:90-91, {ref Untermann 2000}:310, {ref de Vaan 2008}:645).

Root reconstruction follows {ref LIV²} 676, {ref ALEW} 1242-1243. Cf. {ref ALEW} 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and {ref Matasović 2009}:427 s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic cognates. Cf. also {ref Kluge 2011}:994-995.

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek πάγος 'that which is fixed or firmly set; rock, ice' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1016), further derived from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm, stiff' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1141, 1184, cf. {ref LIV²} 461).
Iranic lexemes probably reflecting derivatives from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm, stiff' ({ref Bailey 1979}:229-230, {ref Sims-Williams 2007}:250-251, {ref EWAia} II:116, cf. {ref LIV²} 461).
East Romance lexemes from Latin recēns 'of recent origin, fresh' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further to PIE *ken- 'fresh, recent' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:516, cf. {ref LIV²} 351).

Etymology disputed. Either to PIE *k̑elH- (cf. 'cold' in /cognate/14/, 'freeze' in /cognate/1857/) or to PIE *g̑el- (cf. 'cold' in /cognate/196/, 'ice' in /cognate/6560/); cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:60.
Baltic lexemes, probably derivatives from PIE *kreu̯H- 'to heap up, cover' ({ref ALEW} 531-532, {ref Derksen 2015}:256, 261, cf. {ref LIV²} 371).

Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *garj́ʰ- 'to lament'. Connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:475, 495, {ref Cheung 2007}:111-112). {ref LIV²} 187 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾eRg̑ʰ-.

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ- '(finger)nail' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1086-1087, {ref EWAia} II:4-5, {ref ALEW} 681-682, {ref Derksen 2015}:327, {ref ESSJa} 25:161-164, 170-173, {ref Derksen 2008}:355 {ref de Vaan 2008}:641, {ref Matasović 2009}:36). Indo-Iranian forms go back to an aberrant *(H)nákha-; some show early nasalization due to blend with aṅgúri- ~  aṅgúli- 'finger, toe' (°-aṅgulá-) or aṅguṣṭhá- 'thumb'; aṅká- 'hook' (RV) and later aṅkurá- 'hooked' may also have played a role, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}, no. 6914 + 134f. 137f., 100, 109; Addenda 6914

Comment: original meaning "to sharpen" via "peak" > "breast, chest"
Justification: Lexemes as though continuing Proto-Iranic *sainaka- (cf. Avestan saēni- 'top, peak'), ultimately derivatives from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'to sharpen' via an intermediate sense 'peak; protuberance, top part' ({ref Korn 2005}:384, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:199-200, {ref EWAia} II:627, cf. {ref LIV²} 319-320).
No certain etymology (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.), {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:414-415 proposes connections to PIE *(H)rebʰ-ró- (cf. Old Church Slavonic reboro 'rib, side', Old High German rippi, ribbi 'rib').

The IE root underlying the Germanic forms in this class is generally reconstructed as *⁽g̑⁾el- on the basis of Germanic and Italic correspondences (cf. {ref LIV²} 185). The reconstruction of a palatovelar or plain velar depends on whether one additionally accepts cognacy with Balto-Slavic forms (cf. Lith. gelumà 'frost', Ru. gólotь 'Glatteis'), cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:288-289, {ref Ringe 2017}:109. The Germanic forms are considered by some scholars (cf. {ref Orel 2003}:209) to be related to Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *xoldъ 'cold', but the correspondences of Slavic initial *x and medial *d to Germanic *k and *d is irregular. Consequently the connection of Slavic *xoldъ to the Germanic and Italic lexemes from IE *⁽g̑⁾el- must remain at least uncertain, if not outright rejected.
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *tekti 'to flow, run', and further derived from PIE *tekʷ- 'to flow, run' ({ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:159, {ref Derksen 2008}:489, {ref LIV²} 620-621).

Italic lexemes continuing Latin numerāre 'to count', a denominal verb to Latin numerus 'number' and ultimately a derivative to PIE *nem- 'to apportion, allot' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:450-451, {ref de Vaan 2008}:419, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:492, cf. {ref LIV²} 453).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *ai̯xa- 'ice' ({ref ESIJa} I:140-143). Traditionally connected by {ref IEW} 301 to Proto-Germanic *īsa-, but this proposed cognacy remains uncertain, cf. {ref EWA 5}:195-199, {ref Kroonen 2013}:271.

Comment: For the onset cf. Persian *ai̯u̯a-ka- > yak.
Justification: Adjectival derivatives from Proto-Iranic *ai̯xa- 'ice' ({ref ESIJa} I:140-143). Further connections disputed, cf. further discussion in /cognate/5932/.
Derivatives of Proto-Iranic *tač- 'to flow, run, walk', further to PIE *tekʷ- 'to run, flow' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:286-287, {ref Cheung 2007}:373-374, {ref EWAia} I:610-611, {ref LIV²} 620-621).

A preverbal derivative of Ossetic cæwyn | cæun 'to go', from Proto-Iranic *či̯au̯- 'to move, go', and ultimately from PIE *kʷi̯eu̯- 'to set oneself in motion' cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:307-308, {ref Cheung 2007}:40-42, {ref EWAia} I:552-553, {ref LIV²} 394-395).

As though from Vedic ā́sadati 'sits near, approaches' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:67 no. 1483), a derivative of Vedic √sad- 'to sit' and ultimately to PIE *sed- 'to seat oneself' ({ref EWAia} II:692-693, {ref LIV²} 513-515).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *sed- 'to sit (down), seat onself' ({ref LIV²} 513-515, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:926-927, {ref Beekes 2010}:376, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:506, {ref EWAia} II:692-693, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:422 no. 7467, {ref Cheung 2007}:125-126, {ref ALEW} 895-896, {ref Derksen 2015}:391, {ref Derksen 2008}:445, {ref Kroonen 2013}:434, {ref de Vaan 2008}:551-552, {ref Matasović 2009}:325-326).

Comment: The Avestan form *(š)mar- is attested with the meaning "remember".
Justification: Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *hmar- 'to remember, recall; recount', further to PIE *(s)mer- 'to think about, remember' ({ref Cheung 2007}:137-138, {ref EWAia} II:78-79, {ref LIV²} 569-570).

Derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *i̯at- 'to take up a position', arguably further to a PIE root *i̯et- ({ref Morgenstierne 1974}:105, {ref Cheung 2007}:214-215, {ref LIV²} 314-315, but cf. {ref EWAia} II:394-395 skeptical of connections outside of Indo-Iranic).

Comment: The Pashto form ra-tlal literally means "to go hither" (cf. rā in Morgenstierne 2003: 69).
Justification: A derivative of Proto-Iranic *tač- 'to flow, run, walk' + preverb rā- 'hither' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:81-82, {ref Cheung 2007}:372-374), further to PIE *tekʷ- 'to run, to flow' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:610-611, {ref LIV²} 610-611).
West Germanic formation probably of onomatopoeic origin, cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:540 s.v. Standard High German kreischen.
Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *tekti, in turn derived from PIE *tekʷ- ({ref Derksen 2008}:489, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:159, cf. {ref LIV²} 620-621).

Lexemes reflecting Proto-Germanic *wai̯nōn-, a weak verb presumably derived from Proto-Germanic *wai- 'woe'. Further connections among the Indo-European languages going back to a PIE interjection *u̯ai 'woe!' (e.g. Latin vae, Old Irish fae, Welsh gwae, etc.) may be possible, although parallel onomatopoeic formations cannot be ruled out in principle ({ref Kluge 2011}:979, 975, {ref Kroonen 2013}:566-567; cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:650, {ref Matasović 2009}:405, {ref IEW} 1110-1111).

West Slavic lexemes as though from Proto-Slavic *ogonъ and derived from *o(b)-goniti sę 'keep off, drive off' in the sense of 'a part of the body an animal can swat away insects with' (cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:383-384). Further derived from an o-grade form of PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ({ref ESSJa} 7:23, 196-197; {ref Derksen 2008}:177, {ref LIV²} 218-219).

A derivative from Proto-Iranic *gard- 'to call', from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'to hear, sound' ({ref Cheung 2007}:106); possibly originally an IE light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- *dʰeh₁- 'to give tidings' ({ref ALEW} 331-332). Root reference form follows {ref LIV²} 210-211.

{ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:591 supposes a connection to Sanskrit káuti 'cries'. The Indo-Iranic forms are traditionally connected to a wide range of sound-imitative words from a root *kā̆u-, *kē̆u-, *kū- according to {ref IEW} 535-536, but a parallel onomatopoeic origin may well be possible (cf. {ref KEWA} I:274). [Not in {ref Cheung 2007}.]
Loan from Sanskrit pr̥thivī́- 'earth'.

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Iranic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'to become warm' ({ref NIL} 196-199, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:541-542, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:556-557, {ref Demiraj 1997}:298, {ref Orel 1998}:303, 525, {ref EWAia} I:513, {ref Kroonen 2013}:575). Most lexemes in this class (Greek, Armenian, Iranic, Germanic) reflect a PIE adjectival stem *gʷʰer-mó-. Albanian is only root-cognate with the rest of the forms and has a distinct stem formation (cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:298 for further discussion).
Old Prussian lexeme, generally derived from PIE *lou̯k-sneh₂-, a derivative of PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' ({ref Derksen 2015}:561, cf. {ref LIV²} 418-419).

Armenian, Slavic, and Italic lexemes reflecting PIE *lou̯k-s-neh₂, a derivative of PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine, be(come) bright' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:320, {ref ESSJa} 16:173, {ref de Vaan 2008}:352, cf. {ref LIV²} 418-419).
Derived from Proto-Slavic *goniti 'chase, persecute', ultimately derived from *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ({ref ESSJa 7:23, 196-197, {ref Derksen 2008}:177, {ref LIV²} 218-219).

Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *bānu-, connected with Vedic bhānú- 'light, beam' and ultimately derivatives from PIE *bʰeh₂- 'to sparkle, to shine' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:265-266, {ref ESIJa} 2:157-158, {ref EWAia} II:259-261, cf. {ref LIV²} 68-69, {ref NIL} 7-11).

According to {ref Bailey 1979}:447, from Proto-Iranic *harta- or *hr̥ta- to an Iranic base *har- 'go up; pass'. Further root etymology uncertain: {ref Bailey 1979}:447 suggests either to PIE *h₁er- 'to get (somewhere)' ({ref IEW} 326-9, {ref LIV²} 238) or *h₃er- 'to set oneself (forward) in motion' ({ref IEW 326-9, {ref LIV²} 299).

Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰenh₂- 'to set in motion; to move off' ({ref LIV²} 144-145, {ref Beekes 2010}:533-534). Older etymologies (cf. {ref Buck 1949}:287) compare forms related to Skt. dhvān- 'dark', however the internal structure of the Greek derivatives θάνατος, θνῄσκω must be accounted for in terms of preforms *dʰn̥h₂-eto-, *dʰn̥h₂-sk̑e/o- respectively, thus {ref LIV²} reconstructs *dʰenh₂-.  The Modern Greek present πεθαίνω was backformed from Ancient/Medieval Greek aorist (ἀ)πέθανον, with replacement of -ανον with present morph. -αίνω and regular loss of initial unstressed ἀ-.

Precise root identification uncertain. {ref LIV²} 399 suggests a connection to *leh₁- 'nachlassen, (zu)lassen', but cf. {ref ALEW} 576 which also suggests the possibility of connections to the root *leu̯H- 'abschneiden, lösen' (cf. {ref LIV²} 681-682) with a laryngeal metathesis.

Etymology outside of Tocharian disputed (cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:972). Several possible etymological proposals: {ref Adams 2013}:792 derives the root from PIE *streu̯g- 'streichen, abwischen' ({ref LIV²} 605, without Tocharian); {ref Meillet 1911}:461 assumed a k-extension of *sreu̯- 'fließen, strömen' ({ref LIV²} 588, without Tocharian); {ref Hackstein 2003}:84 has preferred *su̯ergʰ- 'krank sein, sich sorgen' ({ref LIV²} 613-614, without Tocharian).
Loanword into Middle English from Old Norse deyja 'to die', replacing various Old English expressions steorfan, sweltan, or periphrastic wesan déad ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *graban- 'to dig', generally postulated to continue a PIE root *gʰrebʰ- 'to dig' ({ref LIV²} 201-202, {ref Kroonen 2013}:185-186, {ref Seebold 1970}:235-236). This lexical isogloss is, however, restricted to cognates in Germanic and Balto-Slavic and consequently it's PIE status remains uncertain. The potential relationship of this root to PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize' remains unclear (cf. {ref LIV²}).

Modern Romance forms from Latin (ex-)cavāre 'to dig (out)' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:172, 262), originally a deadjectival verb to Latin cavus 'hollow, excavated' < PIE *k̑ou̯H-ó- (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:101-102).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *sweltan- 'to dwindle, starve, perish'. Further etymology uncertain, possibly to a PIE root ?*su̯eld- 'to starve, die' if to be connected with Armenian  kʻalcʻ 'hunger' < ?*su̯l̥d-sk̑o- (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:336, {ref Kroonen 2013}:499, cf. {ref LIV²} 610).

The root etymology in this set follows {ref LIV²} 549 and the latter of the two possible etymologies suggested by {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1011 to a PIE root *skabʰ- 'to scratch, shave'. Cf. however {ref Beekes 2010}:1342-1343 favouring a substrate origin.

A denominal formation to Welsh twrch 'hog, (wild) boar; mole' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}), further to Proto-Celtic *tworko- 'boar' from PIE *tu̯ork̑-o- 'cutter, boar', a derivative to PIE *tu̯erk̑- 'to cut' ({ref Matasović 2009}:395, {ref EIEC} 425, cf. {ref LIV²} 656).
Derived from Old French crues, cf. French creux 'hollow'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps Gaulish? (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 2:1362-1365).
The root reconstruction in this cognate set follows {ref LIV²} 307, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:828-829, {ref Beekes 2010}:1113 for additional discussion.

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek κοιλία 'cavity of the body; thorax with abdomen', further derived from Ancient Greek κοῖλος 'hollow, hollowed out, spacious, deep' < PIE *k̑eu̯H- 'hollow' (cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:690, {ref Beekes 2010}:730-731).

Comment: Formerly identical with Lat. tālis 'such', but probably formed independently from the same morphemes.
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *teh₂li- 'as such' ({ref ALEW} 1115-1116).

Nuristani lexemes continuing a derivative of the same root found in Vedic turá- 'quick' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:335 no. 5874), further to PIE *tu̯er- (cf. {ref EWAia} I:684-685, {ref LIV²} 655).

Indo-Iranic lexemes, probably to be further derived from the same root as Vedic √vas- 'to live, reside, spend the night', and further to PIE 2. *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:300, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:676 no. 11591, {ref EWAia} II:531-532, cf. {ref LIV²} 293-294).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *kʷis-e/o- 'to see', a derivative of PIE *kʷei̯s- 'to perceive' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:431-434, {ref Matasović 2009}:180, {ref LIV²} 381-382).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *drinkan- 'to drink'. Further etymology uncertain; a proposal to connect it with Lithuanian drė́gti 'to become moist, to thaw' to a basic root *dʰreg- ({ref Kroonen 2013}:103) has not been widely accepted ({ref Seebold 1970}:165-166, {ref Lehmann 1986}:94-95, {ref ALEW} 226-227).

The etymology of this root is not entirely clear.
The hypothesis about a borrowing from Gothic is rather speculative because the Gothic form *gataws itself is not attested and only reconstructed (as a nominal derivative of gataujan 'fulfil, act, accomplish') {ref ESSJa}. The Albanian gat 'ready' etc. is most probably a loan from Slavic {ref Orel 1998}, note also a suspiciously similar set of meanings {ref ESSJa} here.
The idea about a derivation of the Slavic lexemes from PIE *gʷeh₂- 'walk, go' with a semantic development '(get) ready to go, prepare(d) for a journey' > '(get) ready, prepare(d)' (> 'do, make') has good IE parallels (cf. German bereit and fertig with secondary derivatives as vorbereiten, zubereiten 'prepare, make', anfertigen 'make', English ready). An issue is that the meaning 'go' is hardly (if ever) attested in Slavic. Its hypothetical traces in Old Russian are very sparse and not unambiguous: negotovami dorogami 'untrodden roads'. However, this etymology seems to be reasonable and is adopted here.

Lexemes continuing Proto(-Insular)-Celtic *bā- 'to die' (cf. OIr. baïd 'die'), further derived from PIE *gʷeh₂- 'to take a step' ({ref LIV²} 205, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:1, {ref Schumacher 2004}:214-216, {ref Matasović 2009}:52, 59).
Lit. 'not-clean', cf. Lithuanian švarùs 'clean', of uncertain etymology ({ref Smoczyński 2007}:654, cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:1040 for older proposals). [Not in {ref Derksen 2015}].
Loanword from Arabic اخسأ

Romance lexemes continuing Latin horridus 'standing on end, rough, shaggy, bristly, prickly' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:350, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 4:486-487), further derived from Latin horreō 'to be stiffly erect, shudder' and ultimately derived from PIE *g̑ʰers- 'to bristle, stiffen' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:290, {ref LIV²} 178).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *un-hraini- 'un-clean', an old verbal adjective to the nasal-present stem *kri-né/n-h₁- to PIE *kreh₁(i̯)- 'to sift, to separate'; but the verbal stem *hrinan- is not attested in Germanic ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:302-303, {ref Kroonen 2013}:241, cf. {ref LIV²} 366-367, {ref Lehmann 1986}:190).
Root reference form follows {ref LIV²} 499-500 to PIE *reh₁dʰ- 'to successfully accomplish', but cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:432, 437.
Adjective derived from Proto-Germanic *hurhwa- 'dirt, mucus'. Further connections unclear, perhaps to Middle Irish corcach 'moor'? (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:258).

Lit. 'not-clean', etymology outside of Baltic uncertain ({ref Smoczyński 2007}:679; for older proposals cf. {ref Karulis 1992} II:413, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:1109-1110). [Not in {ref ALEW} or {ref Derksen 2015}].

Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes continuing PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to put, place, to set up; to do' ({ref LIV²} 136-138; {ref ESSJa} 4:231-232; 5:7-8, {ref Derksen 2008}:102-103, {ref Seebold 1970}:157-160, {ref Kroonen 2013}:98, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:209-213, {ref de Vaan 2008}:198-199, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:271-272 no. 3128). The Italic forms in this class are generally agreed to be cognate, although exhibiting an extension *-k- of unclear origin (listed as a separate lemma ?*dʰeh₁k- in {ref LIV²} 139).

Modern Greek lexemes derived from Ancient Greek κάμνω 'exert oneself, build; be tired (from work)' → 'make something (using technical means)' → 'make, do' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:629), ultimately derived from PIE *k̑emh₂- via a nasal-present stem *k̑m̥-né/n-h₂- ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:490, {ref Beekes 2010}:632, {ref LIV²} 323-324).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *k̑u̯ón-, *k̑un-, *k̑u̯n̥-, the inherited Indo-European word for 'dog' ({ref NIL} 436-440, {ref EIEC} 168, cf. {ref Melchert 1989}, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:505-506, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:187, {ref Adams 2013}:190, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:520-522, Beekes 2010}:811, {ref EWAia} II:674-675, {ref ALEW} 1054-1055, {ref Derksen 2015}:455, {ref Kroonen 2013}:256, {ref de Vaan 2008}:87, {ref Matasović 2009}:181).
Loan into East Slavic from Iranic *sabāka- 'dog' ({ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:702-703, cf. {ref Černyh 1999} 2:183, {ref Šanskij et al. 1975}:419).

Brythonic Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *u̯reg-e/o- 'to make, do', ultimately from PIE *u̯erg̑- 'to act, do' ({ref LIV²} 686-687, cf. {ref Falileyev 2000}:76, {ref Schumacher 2004}:707-711, {ref Matasović 2009}:429-430).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *gn-ii̯o- 'to beget; to make, do', a derivative of PIE *g̑enh₁- 'to produce, beget' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:149, {ref Schumacher 2004}:339-347, {ref Matasović 2009}:163-164, {ref LIV²} 163-165). The Goidelic lexemes in this set continue a compound with the preverb de-, di- 'from, away from'.

From α- (privative prefix) + the verbal adjective of (α)παλαίνω 'to wet', i.e. 'not wet' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.); The verb (α)παλαίνω is a variant of ἁπαλύνω 'to soften', which is in turn derived from Ancient Greek ἁπαλός 'tender, weak', with no further etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:95, {ref Beekes 2010}:113).

Romance forms from Latin exsūctus 'sucked out, dry' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:268 no. 3074), the past passive participle to Lat. (ex)sugere 'to suck (out)', further to PIE *seu̯k̑- 'to suck' ({ref LIV²} 539-540, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:664, {ref de Vaan 2008}:598).

Comment: Klingenschmitt (2000: 216 fn. 86) sets these words together with Pashto caṣǝl in relation to Old Ind. *cakṣ.
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *čaš- 'to drip; to drink, eat'? ({ref Cheung 2007}:35-36).
Etymology uncertain, either to be grouped with Vedic pāṁśu- 'crumbling soil, dust, sand' or púrīṣa- 'fullness(?)' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:452 no. 8019, 469 no. 8287).

Comment: {Kashmiri form after pyonu dat. pĕnas ʻto drink' (cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3867)?, cf. Armenian kc(an)em "bite" (5942)}
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes likely to be continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰād-, further connections outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:445, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:203-204 no. 3865, 3867, {ref EWAia} I:451-452, {ref LIV²} 559-560).

Modern Indic cognates to be connected with Vedic khād- 'chew, bite; eat' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:203, no. 3865). No certain cognates outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} I:451-452, cf. {ref LIV²} 359-360).

Iranic and Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *sek- 'to run dry, dry out' ({ref Bailey 1979}:414, {ref EWAia} II:687-688, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:623, {ref de Vaan 2008}:562, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:651 no. 7897, cf. {ref LIV²} 523-524). For the Goidelic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this set, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:96, {ref Matasović 2009}:337.

Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *ters- 'to dry out, become thirsty' ({ref NIL} 701-704, {ref Lehmann 1986}:358, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:632-633, {ref Kroonen 2013}:554, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:74-75, {ref Matasović 2009}:379-380, {ref LIV²} 637-638).
