Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰau̯š- 'to hear, listen to' (cf. Vedic √ghoṣ- 'to sound'), further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ({ref Cheung 2007}:115-116, {ref EWAia} I:518-519; {ref LIV²} 200 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯s-).

Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑leu̯s- 'to listen to' ({ref Matasović 2009}:209, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:126-127). This root is very likely to have been abstracted from a desiderative verb form of *k̑leu̯- ({ref LIV²} 334-335) already in the protolanguage, cf. {ref LIV²} 336n1.

Tocharian lexemes generally derived from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear', although some uncertainty remains over the precise nominal stem formation ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:145-146, {ref Adams 2013}:249, cf. {ref LIV²} 336-337).

Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *ters- 'to dry out; become thirsty' ({ref NIL} 701-704, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:687-688, {ref Untermann 2000}:736, 745, {ref de Vaan 2008}:616, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:74-75, {ref Matasović 2009}:379-380).
Loan from Sanskrit pr̥thivī́- 'earth'.
Cf. Vedic sú-mahānt- 'very great, huge' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:778, no. 13493), for further etymology ultimately to PIE *meg̑- 'big' cf. {ref EWAia} II:337-338, {ref NIL} 468-478).

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek τρώγω 'to gnaw, nibble, munch' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1461). Generally considered to continue a thematic present stem *tréh₃⁽g̑⁾-e- to a root *treh₃⁽g̑⁾- 'to gnaw away' on the basis of comparison with Tocharian B treṣṣäṃ 'to chew (up)' < *tr̥h₃⁽g̑⁾-sk̑é- ({ref LIV²} 647, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1141-1142); alternatively {ref Beekes 2010}:1514-1515 prefers a 'Pre-Greek' origin.

Brythonic Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic preverb *tu- + *ag- 'to drive', ultimately cognate with PIE *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:189-193, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:27, {ref LIV²} 255-256).

Hellenic and Celtic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1097, {ref Beekes 2010}:18-19, {ref Falileyev 2000}:3, {ref Schumacher 2004}:189-193, cf. {ref LIV²} 255-256). The Tsakonian lexemes in this class might instead go back to AGk. ἥκω 'I have come' (so {ref Andriotis 1974}:270), but a derivation from AGk. ἄγω 'go, drive' is more plausible (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Ossetic lexemes connected with other Indo-Iranic words for 'sand, dust' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:187-188). The correspondence of Indic *s- with Iranic *θ-, *s- is irregular, suggesting a possible parallel loan from a third-source or lexical contamination within Indic or Iranic (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:772, no. 13386); {ref EWAia} II:728, however, considers the Indic and Iranic forms not to be separated.

Italic lexemes continuing Latin mandūcāre 'to chew, bite' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:431 no. 5292, cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 6/1:160-161). Latin mandūcāre is a secondary derivative to a primary verbal formation attested in Latin mandere 'to chew, bite' (cf. mandūcō 'glutton'). Traditionally attributed to a root *meth₂- 'to tear off' via a semantic development to *'tear (prey)' → 'to lacerate' → 'to devour' → 'to chew' ({ref LIV²} 442-443), alternatively {ref de Vaan 2008}:361-362 sees a development from *menth₂- 'to stir, whirl' ({ref LIV²} 438-439) via a nasal-infix stem *mt-n(é)-h₂-. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:382 consider a word of expressive origin.
From Middle English egge, a loan from Old Norse egg 'egg', replacing Old English ǽg 'egg' which continued the inherited lexeme ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Comment: from Sanskrit (Mbh.) phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers),Pali phulla- 'blossoming', Prakrit phulla- 'opened, blossoming', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 511, no. 9092
Justification: As though continuing Sanskrit phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:511 no. 9092), perhaps continuing a past passive participle *phal-na- to Sanskrit phálati 'to burst' ({ref KEWA} II:398).

As though continuing Sanskrit phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:511 no. 9092), perhaps continuing a past passive participle *phal-na- to Sanskrit phálati 'to burst' ({ref KEWA} II:398).

Comment: cf. Vedic síkatā-, later sigatā- unlike Old Persian θikā- 'pebbles', cf. also cognate/7858/
Justification: The correspondence of Indic initial *s- with Iranic *θ-, *s- is irregular, suggesting a possible parallel loan from a third-source or lexical contamination within Indic or Iranic (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:772, no. 13386); {ref EWAia} II:728, however, considers the Indic and Iranic forms not to be separated.

Two possible etymologies: Either identical to Lat. porrō 'forward' if from *p(o)rsōd, alternatively from *πόρσω, derived from πρός 'towards' (< PIE *próti) with a commonly found liquid metathesis. Since both derivations have similar semantic paths of derivation it is difficult to choose between the two possibilities ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:929, {ref Beekes 2010}:1223).

Comment: Fr. Lat. laxius, comparative to laxus.
Justification: Ibero-Romance lexemes derived from Latin laxius 'more widely, more freely', the comparative adverb to Latin laxus 'spacious, wide' ({ref DCECH} III:626-627, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:403 no. 4956), further derived from PIE *sle⁽g̑⁾- 'to slacken, go limp' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:331, cf. {ref LIV²} 565).

Cf. Standard German Boden, continuing PIE *bʰudʰ-men-; the root appears to only be attested in the zero-grade. It is unclear whether the full-grade form would be *bʰeu̯dʰ- or *bʰu̯edʰ- ({ref EWA 2}:222-225, {ref Kluge 2011}:137, {ref Kroonen 2013}:82, cf. {ref EWAia} II:228-229).
Comparable to Avestan spəṇta- 'beneficent' and further to PIE *k̑u̯eh₁- 'to swell up' ({ref Bailey 1979}:394-395, {ref EWAia} II:678, 623-624; cf. {ref LIV²} 339-340).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Iranic, Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *h₂ōu̯ió- 'egg', which may be a vr̥ddhi-derivative to the Indo-European word for 'bird' *h₂eu̯-i- ({ref EIEC} 176, cf. /cognate/856/); alternatively {ref Schindler 1969} reconstructs an adpositional construction *ō-h₂uiom 'towards the bird'. For individual branches, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1681, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:439, {ref Orel 1998}:497, {ref Holm 2011}:60, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:41, {ref Bailey 1979}:30, {ref ESSJa} 1:61-64, {ref Derksen 2008}:27, {ref Kroonen 2013}:17, {ref de Vaan 2008}:438, {ref Matasović 2009}:50.

A nominal compound, lit. 'bird-produce'. Cognacy in this set is coded for Armenian Arm. haw 'bird', continuing PIE *h₂eu̯-i- 'bird' (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:398-399). PIE *h₂ōu̯ió- 'egg' is considered by some to be a vr̥ddhi-derivative of this stem (cf. 'egg' in /cognate/28/ for further discussion).
Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of' ({ref EWAia} I:523-524, {ref ESIJa} II:238-242, cf. {ref LIV²} 383-385).

As though from Latin *stancus ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:679, {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further to Latin stant-, the participle of stāre 'to stand' (cf. /cognate/309/ for further etymological discussion).
Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *derk̑- 'to look at, catch sight of' ({ref Delamarre 2003}:139-140, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:55-56, cf. {ref LIV²} 122).

According to {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:77, as though from an Iranic diminutive *str̥-kā, and in view of the meaning 'planet' (cf. Avestan star- 'star', Vedic stár- 'id.) probably to be further connected to the Indo-European word for 'star', *h₂stér- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:755-756). The same semantic development is also attested in Modern Indic (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:330 no. 5798).
Derived from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'to burn' ({ref Bailey 1979}:164, cf. {ref LIV²} 133-134).

As though from Sanskrit dōla- 'swinging' ({ref Turner 1962–1966} no. 6582). Further etymology less certain, but probably a loanword from an Austroasiatic language (cf. {ref KEWA} II:67 for further discussion).

Germanic lexemes continuing preverb *pe-/po- + PIE *h₃elh₁- 'to decay, perish' ({ref Neri 2007}, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:125-126, {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}; formerly reconstructed as *peh₃lH- 'to fall' in {ref LIV²} 463-464).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes continuing or derived from PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'to catch sight of, behold' ({ref NIL}, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:78-79, {ref Beekes 2010}:1077-1078, {ref Babinotis 2010}:826, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:22-23, {ref Orel 1998}:405, {ref Holm 2011}:60-61, {ref EWAia} I:42-43, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:2 no. 43, {ref ALEW} 25-27, {ref Derksen 2015}:47, {ref ESSJa} 32:41-42, {ref Derksen 2008}:365, {ref de Vaan 2008}:425)

Armenian, Indo-Iranic, and Baltic lexemes from a PIE derived stem *stuh₂ró- (< *sth₂-ur-ó-) to PIE *steh₂- ({ref NIL} 639, cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:199, {ref EWAia} II:768-769, {ref ALEW} 979, {ref Derksen 2015}:430).
Usually interpreted as based on PIE *pro- 'forward, to the front' with adverbial suffixes ({cf. {ref LIPP 2}:490, 643; {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:537-538, {ref de Vaan 2008}:491-492).

Tocharian and Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *preK- 'to be afraid' ({ref LIV²} 491, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:711-712, {ref Adams 2013}:402, {ref Lehmann 1986}:111, {ref Kroonen 2013}:402). The identity of the root final velar is not certain.
Probably loans from East Caucasian, cf. Lezgian rug 'dust', Tabasaran rug 'earth' (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.). {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:443-444 suggests Iranic *ru-ka- but gives no Iranic cognates.
Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Cech. kog, Tush. kok, Ing. kog, etc. ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:619).
Etymology uncertain. No etymology given in {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}; not in {ref Falileyev 2000}, {ref Matasović 2009}, {ref Schumacher 2004}, or {ref Stokes 1894}.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11456 s.v. vahana- n. 'carrying' (MBh.)
Justification: Light verb construction, coded for Bengali bahan < Sanskrit vahana- 'a carrying' derived from Vedic √vah- 'to drive, ride (a cart, chariot)' and further to PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to float, drive' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:668 no. 11456, {ref EWAia} II:535-537, {ref LIV²} 661-662).
Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *ni-waz- 'to carry/flow downwards', further to PIE *u̯eḡ- 'to float; to drive' ({ref Cheung 2007}:429-432, cf. {ref EWAia} II:535-537, {ref LIV²} 661-662).
Lexemes from Proto-Iranic *u̯az- 'to carry, drive', further to PIE *u̯eḡ- 'to ride, drive' ({ref Cheung 2007}:429-432, cf. {ref EWAia} II:535-537, {ref LIV²} 661-662).

The original meaning was 'cart with a tent, living cart, tent' > 'house', a derivative of Proto-Slavic *vezti 'drive, carry', ultimately from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'move, go (by a vehicle)'. (cf. {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1608, cf. {ref LIV²} 661-662),

Italic lexemes from Latin ruere 'to rush, hurry on; tumble down, collapse' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:613 no. 7423), further to PIE *h₃reu̯- 'to run, hurry', perhaps further derived from PIE *h₃er- 'to set (oneself) in motion'? (cf. {ref Meiser 2003}:613, {ref de Vaan 2008}:530). [Verbal root not in {ref LIV²} or {ref {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}].

The precise root and stem reconstruction for this form in Indo-European is debated, but the cognacy of the lexemes in this class to each other is generally agreed. For the Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref ESSJa} 4:184-187, {ref Derksen 2008}:133, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:360-361, {ref Kroonen 2013}:327, {ref de Vaan 2008}:348, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:415 no. 5116, 5119. The reconstructed root form for this class follows {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.
Armenian and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *per- 'through, beyond, over; very' ({ref LIPP 2}:607-614, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:404, {ref Kroonen 2013}:137).

Modern Greek forms to be derived from Ancient Greek εὐθύς 'straight' (via εὐθειάζω with various analogical re-characterisations of the present stem, cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:1565-1566 for further discussion); no further satisfactory etymology outside of Greek; for some possible explanations within Greek cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:384-385, {ref Beekes 2010}:479.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:678-679 and {ref Kluge 2011}:980 for several possibilities of formal correspondences with Vedic forms vītá-  (from different etymological sources); the etymology to a compound *h₁uei-dʰh₁-o- 'set apart' favoured by {ref Lubotsky 1994}:203-204, {ref Kroonen 2013}:584-585 requires the assumption of a glottalic model of interpretation for the PIE voiceless stops within the framework of the Leiden School, where traditional *d is assumed to have been pre-glottalized *[ˀd], and susceptible to dissimilation to *h₁, which is interpreted as glottal stop *[ʔ].

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:678-679 and {ref Kluge 2011}:980 for several possibilities of formal correspondences with Vedic forms vītá-  (from different etymological sources); the etymology to a compound *h₁uei-dʰh₁-o- 'set apart' favoured by {ref Lubotsky 1994}:203-204, {ref Kroonen 2013}:584-585 requires the assumption of a glottalic model of interpretation for the PIE voiceless stops within the framework of the Leiden School, where traditional *d is assumed to have been pre-glottalized *[ˀd], and susceptible to dissimilation to *h₁, which is interpreted as glottal stop *[ʔ].

Germanic and Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *h₂egʰ- 'to get scared, become distressed' ({ref LIV²} 257, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:270, {ref Kroonen 2013}:3, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:23, {ref Matasović 2009}:26).
From PIE *u̯ei̯k- 'to overcome, conquer' ({ref LIV²} 670-671, cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:683-688, {ref Matasović 2009}:421).

Albanian and Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *trem- 'to tremble (in fear)'. The Romance lexemes apparently continue Latin tremere 'to tremble' contaminated with the Celtic root *krit-, cf. Old Irish crith 'trembling, shaking' ({ref LIV²} 648-649, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:388-389, {ref Orel 1998}:463, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:738 no. 8877, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 13/2:238-240, {ref de Vaan 2008}:628).

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:112-113, {ref Orel 2003}:102, {ref EWA 3}:67-68. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)} for various proposals. No lemma in {ref Kroonen 2013}.

Root etymology in this class follows {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:970-971 to *dʰreh₂s-, a parallel root to dʰreh₂gʰ- 'aufgewühlt werden, in Aufruhr geraten' (LIV² 154f.). For older proposals, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:76.

Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish ecla 'fear, dread', cf. ecal 'timorous, fearful' < *eks-gal, to which Old Irish gal 'valour' < Proto-Celtic *galā 'valor, ability', ultimately a derivative of PIE *gelH- 'to have power over' ({ref Electronic Dictionary of the Irish Language (eDIL)}, {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:149, {ref Broaderick 1984b}:5, {ref Matasović 2009}:149, cf. {ref LIV²} 185-186).

West Germanic lexemes in light verb constructions with derivatives of PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ- 'to restrict, hinder' as the nominal semantic-bearing head. ({ref Kluge 2011}:45, {ref Kroonen 2013}:28-29). The Dutch and Frisian lexemes are prefixed with initial *be- ({ref EWNl} I:216). For the PIE root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV²} 264-265.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'to beat, strike, slay', usually compared to Middle Irish slacc 'sword' and slahta 'struck' to a root *slak- as a Celtic-Germanic isogloss. Whether such a root may be postulated for Proto-Indo-European remains uncertain ({ref Seebold 1970}:425-427, {ref Lehmann 1986}:314, {ref Kroonen 2013}:452, cf. {ref LIV²} 564).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing a stem *laḍ(h)- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:633 no. 10920). Further etymology uncertain.

Comment: The Avestan word varǝδa- refers to a plant "v[ie]ll[eicht] Rose" (Bartholomae 1904: 1369). The Sogdian word "ward" means "rose", which is a common meaning of 'flower' in most modern Iranic languages. Also attested in Parthian as wār.
Justification: Lexemes reflecting Proto-Iranic *u̯arda-, traditionally further connected to Vedic √vardh- 'to increase, grow' and further to an IE root *u̯erdʰ- (cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:399-400, {ref IEW} 1167), but cf. {ref EWAia} II:520-521, {ref LIV²} 228 against connections of this proposed root outside of Indo-Iranic.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯az- 'to carry, drive (chariot, vel sim.)', further from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to ride, drive, transport, fly' ({ref Cheung 2007}:432, cf. {ref LIV²} 661-662).
Parallel loans from Hindi लड़ना / laṛnā ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:633 no. 10920, {ref Turner 1931}:548).

Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Indic *uddrāti 'flees, flies' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:93 no. 2001), further connected to Vedic √drā- 'to run, make haste' and ultimately to PIE *dreh₂- 'to run (away)' ({ref EWAia} I:757, {ref LIV²} 127).
Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰég̑ʰ-om- 'earth' ({ref NIL} 86-99, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:195, {ref de Vaan 2008}:287-288, {ref Matasović 2009}:156, {ref ALEW} 1323).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fleugan- 'to fly', continuing a derivative from a root *pleu̯k- that is generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:146, {ref EWA 3}:385-388).

No consensus etymology outside of Greek (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:673-674, {ref Beekes 2010}:916-917); {ref Malzahn & Peters 2010} propose a connection to Tocharian B mäk- 'run', but the meanings are divergent (cf. 'run' in /cognate/7203/). {ref LIV²} 422 assigns to *magʰ- 'to be able'.
Loan from Turkish, cf. Turkish dövüş 'fight' (n.), dövüşmek 'to fight'.

From Ancient Greek *συμπιάζω (AGk. συμπιέζω), cf. {ref Andriotis 1974}:528. Further etymology disputed, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:899-900, {ref Beekes 2010}:1189, for references to further literature.

From Ancient Greek ἐμπλέκω ‘to entwine’ ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:145, further from Ancient Greek (ἐμ)πλέκω 'to braid, knit, wind, twine' and ultimately derived from PIE *plek̑- 'to braid, twine' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:914-915, {ref Beekes 2010}:1206-1207, {ref LIV²} 486).
Without certain etymology ({ref Smoczyński 2005}:382).

Comment: Old Persian ham-arana- "zusammenwogend"
Justification: Light verb construction with Old Persian ham-arana- 'fight' < *'coming together' as a the semantic head. The root etymology of the semantic-bearing element of the compound ºarana- is to the Indo-Iranic verbal root *ar- < PIE *h₃er- 'to set oneself (forward) in motion' ({ref Schmitt 2014}:187-188, {ref EWAia} II:702, I:105-106, cf. {ref LIV²} 299-301).

Possibly continuing a formation (as though) from PIE *trud-no- according to {ref Pedersen 1909}:160, comparing Latin trudō 'to thrust, push', Gothic us-ϸriutan 'to maltreat' (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:148-149, {ref LIV²} 651-652). The etymology of {ref IEW} 1026 to a dental-enlarged root *streu- is less likely. [Not in {ref Matasović 2009}].

Lexemes denominal from Proto-Celtic *kando- 'white', with the sense of 'to bleach laundry (by beating)' > 'to beat; to fight' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:336), further derived from PIE *skend- 'to shine' (cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} s.v. Welsh cann 'white', {ref de Vaan 2008}:87, {ref LIV²} 554; not in {ref Matasović 2009}).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *part- 'to fight, struggle', perhaps further related to PIE *per- 'to beat' with a dental extension? (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:298, {ref EWAia} II:160, {ref LIV²} 447).

Cf. Middle Welsh lladd 'to kill', further derived from Proto-Celtic *slad-i̯o- 'to hit; to slay'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref Matasović 2009}:345), cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:583-587 setting up either PIE *sleHd- or *sleHdʰ- following {ref Schrijver 1995}:178. [Not in {ref LIV²}].

Derived from Proto-Slavic *mog-/*mag- 'to be able' ({ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-} 3:336-337), further generally derived to an IE root *magʰ- 'to be able' (cf. {ref LIV²} 422, {ref Derksen 2008}:321, {ref ESSJa} 19:107-111).

Identical to Irish cogadh ({ref Broaderick 1984b}:56), from Old Irish cocad 'war; means of waging war', a compound of com- + cath 'battle' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:137. The extent to which there are further Indo-European connections is debated; generally further connected to Hitt. kattu- 'enmity, strife' (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:466), and Proto-Germanic *haϸu- 'battle' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:214-215), and perhaps further to Sanskrit śátru- via a different stem formation (but cf. the reservations of {ref EWAia} II:607). Traditionally reconstructed as *k̑atu- ({ref IEW} 534, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:195), but because the Leiden school denies the reconstruction of an Indo-European phoneme *a, alternative reconstructions *k̑h₂et- and *⁽k̑⁾h₃-tu- are proposed respectively by {ref Kloekhorst 2008} and {ref Kroonen 2013}. Here the traditional reconstruction of {ref IEW} has been tentatively followed.
Loan from Standard German kämpfen 'to fight'.

Comment: Czech lexeme (which is also attested in other Slavic languages in a similar (but not-Swadesh) meaning) are derived from the Slavic word for 'belt' (it primarily denoted a kind of a fight in which one tries to down the other on the ground pulling parts of his clothes, like Judo).
Bailey (1979: 56) suggests a relation to *kap- "grey" in O.Ind. kapila- and to the blue/grey word *kapauta-, weiter dazu EWAia I: 303
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kapā̆- 'fish', generally found in Eastern Iranic as a replacement for inherited Proto-Indo-Iranic *matsi̯a- 'fish' ({ref ESIJa} 4:241-242, cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:56, {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:458). Perhaps further to an Indo-Iranic root *kap- 'grey', maybe in Vedic kapila- 'tawny, brown, reddish', but cf. {ref EWAia} I:300-303.
Loanword from Dardic, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:37.
Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *tep- 'to be warm, hot' ({ref NIL} 698-700, {ref Matasović 2009}:375, cf. {ref LIV²} 629-630).

Indic lexemes from Vedic himá- 'cold, frost' ({ref EWAia} II:815-816). From the ablaut patterns attested among the daughter languages a basic root *g̑ʰei̯- can be abstracted, to which was derived an original m-stem noun *g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´- ({ref NIL} 162-169).
Parallel loans from Persian گل / gol 'flower'.
Loanword from Latin piscātus 'a catch of fish' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).

Tocharian forms, according to {ref Adams 2013}:440, to be connected with PIE *pei̯H- 'to swell up' via a Schwebeablaut variant *pi̯eH- and connected with Vedic √pyā- 'to swell' but the existence of this variant remains uncertain, cf. {ref EWAia} II:84, II:172; {ref KEWA} II:349, {ref LIV²} 464-465.

Comment: mālikā- f. derived from Late Vedic mā́la- f. 'wreath, garland', cf. Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 628; Turner 1062-66, p. 580, no. 10092; ultimately of Dravidian origin
Justification: From Late Vedic mā́la- 'wreath, garland', probably a loanword from Dravidian, cf. Tamil mālai 'wreath, garland' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:580 no. 10092, cf. {ref KEWA} II:628, {ref EWAia} II:351).
Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *sp⁽ʰ⁾erh₂g- 'to hiss, crackle'(?) (cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:315, {ref Cheung 2007}:198, {ref LIV²} 586).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fleugōn 'fly', continuing a derivative from a root *pleu̯k- that is generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:146, {ref EWA 3}:385-388).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11384 s.v. vardhita- 'increased, strengthened' (MBh.), Pali vaḍḍhita
Justification: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:664 no. 11384 Skt. vardhita 'increased, strengthened, gladdened', a derivative of Vedic √vardh- 'to increase, grow'. Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} II:520-521; {ref LIV²} 228 mechanically reconstructs ?*Hu̯eRdʰ-).

The PIE root underlying these lexemes is generally reconstructed as *(s)per- 'to fly' ({ref ALEW} 955-956, {ref EWAia} II:97, cf. {ref LIV²} 579-580; without s-mobile {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:646-647). {ref Derksen 2008}:396 and {ref Derksen 2015}:419 favour a reconstruction *perH- in view of the Baltic acute accent in forms such as Lithuanian papártis and Latvian papãrde (cf. also {ref Derksen 1996}:79).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian магла 'fog'.
Hellenic, Iranic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *mr̥g̑ʰ-ú- 'short' ({ref NIL} 497-499, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:236, {ref EWAia} II:364-365, {ref de Vaan 2008}:75).
Romance lexemes from Latin coxa 'hip' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:212), further to PIE *kok̑s-h₂- 'limb, joint' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:140).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *koxsā/o-, further connected to PIE *kok̑so- ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:214, {ref Matasović 2009}:220).
Loanword from Catalan or Occitan bǫsc 'forest' ({ref DCECH} I:636-637).
To be connected with Avestan gaδā-, Old Indic gadā- 'club', but no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:281-282, {ref EWAia} I:460).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √yam- 'to sustain, hold, hold up, support', further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:603 no. 10428, {ref EWAia} II:399-400, cf. {ref LIV²} 312).
Loan from Old French forest (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:297, {ref DCECH} II:919).

An Indo-European root etymology outside of Celtic for Proto-Celtic *treget- 'foot' is controversial, cf. esp. {ref Irslinger 2002}:60 for further discussion. Older hypotheses suppose a root *tregʰ- 'to walk' and a connection to Latin trahere 'to drag' (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:387, 389 following {ref IEW} 1089, {ref Schumacher 2004}:635-636)
Baltic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eu̯g- 'to grow, become strong' ({ref ALEW} 67-69, {ref Seebold 1970}:532-533, {ref Kroonen 2013}:566).

Comment: first part would nearly fit with 7747 *leh₁g̑ʰ- which would give rāz-
Justification: Traditionally with PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' according to {ref IEW} 855, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:398-399, {ref LIV²} 304-305).

Italic and Romance lexemes continuing nominal derivatives of PIE ?*bʰreu̯H⁽g̑⁾- 'to enjoy, use' ({ref Untermann 2000}:297-298, {ref de Vaan 2008}:244-245, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:303). The attestation of this lexical root is restricted to Italic and Germanic (cf. {ref LIV²} 96).

Comment: Morgenstierne (2003: 53) quotes Henning (BSOAS 12/1: 56) for *migda-, cf. Sogdian mγδˀk. The COBL comment on Sogdian "fruit" considers it possible for this word to be a Semitic loanword. The reason that Sogdian in COBL does not show mγδˀk is that the source that was used to fill the Sogdian list uses another word instead.
Justification: As though continuing a Iranic stem *migda(ka)- 'fruit'; a probable loanword from West Semitic, cf. Biblical Hebrew מֶגֶד 'choice produce', Syriac maγδā 'fruit', etc. (cf. {ref Henning 1947}:56).

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic  *sadъ 'plant', cf. Proto-Slavic *saditi 'to plant' from the causative-iterative stem *sod-éi̯e- to PIE *sed- 'to sit' ({ref Derksen 2008}:442-443, {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1263, 1279-1280, {ref NIL} 590-600).

Root ref. form follows {ref LIV²} 559; cf. also {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:200, {ref Beekes 2010}:649, and {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:452-453 (s.v. Hitt. karp(ii̯e/a)- 'to take (away), take up, lift, pluck').

The lexeme is doubtless a loanword whose the ultimate source is Latin frūctus. However, the direct source is disputable. Some scholars assume Polish {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 208, {ref Šanskij et al. 1975}: 474, some German or Dutch {Černyh 1999}: 2: 325, some mention the ultimate source only {ref Šapošnikov 2010} 2: 485, {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 6: 134.

Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish mes(s) 'tree fruit, mast' ({ref Broaderick 1984b}:298, {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:246). Further IE root etymology in this set follows {ref NIL} 463-465 to PIE *med- 'to become full, sated', but cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:268-269.

{ref Adams 2013}:115 prefers to connect the Tocharian B forms with Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Celtic words in meanings variously 'fruit (of a tree), berry, acorn'. The proposed etymology is certainly attractive but is not fully certain, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:27, {ref Kroonen 2013}:18-19, {ref ALEW} 1151-1152.
Loan from Persian (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:53).
Traditionally with PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' according to {ref IEW} 855, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:398-399, {ref LIV²} 304-305).
Maybe to be connected with Hittite šiš- 'to prosper, proliferate', but no further etymology outside of Hittite ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:749, 756-757).
From Classical Armenian mirg, a loan from Iranic, cf. Sogdian mγδʾk 'fruit' ({ref Olsen 1999}:895, {ref Benveniste 1964}:5). [MM: Proto-Armenian mirg]
Loanword from Turkish yemiş 'fruit' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 1:496).

Comment: If the proposed etymology of {ref Neri 2007} holds, then cf. 'take' in /cognate/5158/.
Justification: Etymology outside of Latin traditionally considered uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:520). A recent proposal by {ref Neri 2007}:71 plausibly considers *h₁e/om-o- 'what is to be taken', combined with a preverb *po- in Proto-Italic as *po-e/omo- 'taken off, picked' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:188-189; 479).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bhar- 'to carry', further to PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:535 no. 9397, {ref EWAia} II:246-249, cf. {ref LIV²} 76-77).
Germanic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives of PIE *g̑ʰengʰ- 'to stride' ({ref LIV²} 175-176, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:213-216, {ref Kroonen 2013}:166-167).
Germanic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives from PIE 1. *per- 'to cross, go through' ({ref LIV²} 472-473, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:186-188, {ref Kroonen 2013}:128).

Comment: probably derived from verb "bar" : "to carry"
Justification: Iranic lexemes probably to be derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry', as though via Proto-Iranic *baraka- ({ref ESIJa} 2:100, cf. {ref Henning 1971}:33-34, {ref Benzing 1983}:201).
Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √gam- < PIE *gʷem- 'to go, come', present stem gaccha- < *gʷm̥-sk̑e/o- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:211 no. 3955, {ref EWAia} I:465-466, cf. {ref LIV²} 209-210).

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *nei̯gʷ- 'to wash' ({ref LIV²} 450, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1020-1021, {ref EWAia} II:54, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:410 no. 7167, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} N:16-17, {ref Matasović 2009}:290-291).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12961
Justification: Continuing Vedic sáṁbharati 'brings together, prepares, rolls up' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:751 no. 12961), a derivative of Vedic √bhar- < PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ({ref EWAia} I:246-249, cf. {ref LIV²} 76-77).

Comment: cf. Vedic mála- n. 'dirt'; cf. *mel- 'black', presumably originally *mel- 'earthy' (RP); cf. also *mel- 'soft'
Justification: Indic lexemes generally connected with Greek and Baltic lexemes designating dark colours ({ref EWAia} II:332-333; cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:680-681, {ref Beekes 2010}:923-924, {ref Derksen 2015}:544). For the Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:569, no. 9905.

Brythonic lexemes derived from Proto-Celtic *luk-ati- 'seer', a derivative of Proto-Celtic *luk-e/o- 'to look at', ultimately a derivative of PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:460, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:248, {ref Falileyev 2000}:103, {ref Deshayes 2003}:447, {ref LIV²} 418-419).

Anatolian, Greek, Armenian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat' ({ref LIV²} 230-231, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:261-263, {ref Beekes 2010}:375, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:644, {ref EWAia} I:61-62, {ref ALEW} 269-270, {ref Derksen 2015}:157-158, {ref Smoczyński 2005}:183-184, {ref ESSJa} 6:53-54, {ref Derksen 2008}:154, {ref Kroonen 2013}:119, {ref de Vaan 2008}:185-186, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:196, {ref Matasović 2009}:113).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4094 s.v. *gavatta- ʻcattle-fodderʼ, gáv- 'cow' + *atta- 1 'eaten'
Justification: As though from Sanskrit *gavatta- 'cattle-fodder', a compound containing Skt. gáv- 'cow' + *atta- 'eaten' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:219 no. 4094). The cognacy in this cognate set reflects the element *atta- 'eaten' continuing a derivative of PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat' (cf. 'eat' in /cognate/210/).

As though continuing Sanskrit cāra- *'grazing, fodder' (< 'motion, course'), cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:258 no. 4471. Further derived from Vedic √car-ⁱ 'to move oneself, go, walk, move, stir, roam about, wander', ultimately from PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, turn oneself around' ({ref EWAia} I:534-535, cf. {ref LIV²} 386-388).

Scottish Gaelic gorm 'green', continuing Old Irish gorm 'blue, green'; within Celtic cf. also Middle Welsh gwrm 'brown', Old Breton uu(o)rm- 'brown'. Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain: Previous proposals have included (1) {ref Stokes 1894}:114, {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:202 as a derivative of PIE *gʷʰer- in the sense 'the warm colour', (2) {ref IEW} 1152 considering a loanword from Anglo-Saxon wurma 'Purpurschnecke; woad; purple'. {ref Matasović 2009}:169 does not consider any IE etymology to be viable.

Modern Greek πράσινος 'green' was originally a derived adjective 'leek-green' based on Ancient Greek πράσον 'leek'. Compared with Lat. porrum, one could assume a common pre-form *pr̥som, but the maintenance of intervocalic *-s- in Greek is unexpected. For this reason it is more likely we are dealing with independent loanwords from a third source ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:934, {ref Beekes 2010}:1129; cf. s.v. Lat. porrum in {ref de Vaan 2008}:481-482).

To be related to Tocharian A motarts- (a colour term) but it is not possible to reconcile these two forms to a common Proto-Tocharian stem. Outside Tocharian some Slavic and Germanic comparanda are possible but remain uncertain (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:511-512 for further discussion).
Loan from East Caucasian (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.).

For Khowar, cf. Vedic akṣa- 'blue vitriol' only attested in lexicographical works, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:2, no. 24; for Pashto from Proto-Iranic axšai̯na- 'dark coloured, dark blue', cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:79. For the probable cognate relationship between the two on the basis of Proto-Indo-Iranic *akša-, cf. {ref KEWA} I:543, {ref EWAia} III:3.

Comment: Further Indo-European cognates uncertain. The root is probably dialectal (North Slavic). Variants with a/u s/x can coexist in one single language or its dialects, normally with slightly different meaning (probably the variant with -a- is a result of a contamination with another root).
Kathās., cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4564
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit caṅga- 'of good understanding; handsome' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:247 no. 4564). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a Dravidian loanword ({ref KEWA} I:267).

The Goidelic forms from OId Irish nél cannot reflect an inherited formation based on IE *nebʰ-l- and consequently a loanword from Latin is generally assumed, possibly via Brythonic (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} N:8, {ref IEW} 315).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ({ref LIV²} 76-77, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:397-398, {ref Beekes 2010}:1562-1564, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:176, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:965, {ref EWAia} I:246-249, {ref Cheung 2007}:6-10, {ref Seebold 1970}:104-106, {ref Kroonen 2013}:59, {ref de Vaan 2008}:213-214, {ref Matasović 2009}:62).

Comment: connection with Sanskrit pinaṣṭi, piṁṣati is not clear, cf. /cognate/6111/
Justification: As though from Sanskrit *prabhindati 'splits' from Vedic √bhid- 'to split; to break, cut (to pieces)', perhaps influenced in its semantics from Sanskrit piṁṣáti, cf. /cognate/6111/ ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:491 no. 8714, cf. {ref Turner 1931}:379). Further to PIE *bʰei̯d- 'to split' ({ref EWAia} II:273-274, {ref LIV²} 70-71).

Lexemes continuing Indo-Iranic *drau̯- ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:400-401, {ref Bailey 1979}:170). Further etymology uncertain, conjecturally connected in older literature (cf. {ref IEW} 276) to Gk. θρίξ, τριχός via root IE *dʰreu̯- with the assumption of root extensions *dʰr-ei̯-gʰ-, *dʰr-ei̯-kʰ-.

From Hellenistic Greek μαλλί(ον), the diminutive of Ancient Greek μαλλός 'flock of wool' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:811-812); further etymology outside of Greek unclear ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:663, {ref Beekes 2010}:889).

Indic lexemes from Sanskrit kapā́la- 'cup, skull'. The Proto-Indic base *kap- is often considered to be cognate with Lat. caput, OEng. hēafod, etc., but there is some uncertainty over the etymology of the Modern Indic lexemes from Ved. kapā́la-, and of Ved. kapā́la- itself, cf. discussion in Mayrhofer {ref EWAia} I:300, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:137 no. 2744).
Continuing Proto-Germanic *skufta- 'hair of the head', further connections uncertain ({ref Kroonen 2013}:449, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:313).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4883 cūḍā- 3 f. ʻtopknot on headʼ
Justification: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:266 no. 4883 cūḍā- 'topknot on head', probably a Middle Indic formation as though from a participle *kṣur(i)ta- to Vedic kṣuráti 'to cut, scrape' from Vedic kṣurá- 'razor', a nominal derivative of PIE *kseu̯- 'to scrape, to whet' (cf. {ref KEWA} I:292, 397, {ref LIV²} 372).
Cf. Gurani raq 'hard', Luri riiq 'wet-hardened in the cold', 'starched clothes', 'dried out in the cold', Shugni. rāx 'numb' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010}:192).

Traditionally connected to PIE *meh₁- 'to measure (out)' in the sense 'measure' > 'body part used as measure unit' > 'length of hair used as a measure unit' > 'hair' ({ref Karulis 1992} I:572-573; cf. for the root reconstruction cf. {ref LIV²} 424-425).

Cf. Standard Albanian lesh 'wool; hair; fleece'; further etymology uncertain. A popular hypothesis considers a derivative to the same root as the Indo-European word for 'wool', *Hu̯l̥h₁neh₂-, if to be morphologically segmented *Hu̯l̥h₁-neh₂- via an alternative preform *Hu̯l̥h₁-so- (so {ref Demiraj 1997}:238-239, similarly {ref Huld 1984}:85-86). {ref Orel 1998}:219-220 considers a connection to the Balto-Slavic word for 'foliage'; against which cf. {ref Holm 2011}:65.

Brythonic lexemes as though from Proto-Celtic *blou̯i- 'hair, wool'. Further etymology uncertain: {ref Lane 1931}:279 attempted to derive from a preform *ml̥-eu̯-s comparable to Ancient Greek μαλλός 'flock of wool' (< *ml̥-nó-), but this conjecture has not been widely accepted (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:115, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Falileyev 2000}:16, {ref Fleuriot 1964a}:85, {ref IEW} 721 [without Brythonic forms given as cognates]). The proposed comparandum in Ancient Greek μαλλός, moreover, is generally considered without satisfactory etymology ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:663, {ref Beekes 2010}:899; cf. /cognate/1492/). [Not in {ref Matasović 2009}].

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hēra- 'hair'. Further etymology disputed, either (1)  with Lithuanian šerỹs 'bristle' < *k̑er(H)- ({ref Kluge 2011}:382, cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:443), or (2) from PIE *k̑es- 'to arrange in order; comb' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:220; if so, cf. lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *kosa 'hair, braided hair' in /cognate/8240/). A third option considered by {ref EWNl} II:360 is the possibility of a European substratum loanword.
Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *stembʰH- 'to support, to lift' ({ref EWAia} II:754, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:788 no. 13676, {ref Cheung 2007}:362, cf. {ref LIV²} 595-596).

Iranic and Italic lexemes continuing PIE *duh₂-ró- ({ref Bailey 1979}:161, {ref EWAia} I:739, {ref de Vaan 2008}:184; for the root *du̯eh₂- 'to remove, separate from' cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda})
Identical with 'hair' in East Germanic. Possible comparisons outside of Germanic, but ultimately uncertain. Cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:338, {ref Kroonen 2013}:504 for further discussion.

Etymology disputed. There are two main possibilities: either to (1) pre-form *kuHso- '(place of) protection', a derivation from the IE verbal root *(s)keu̯H- 'to cover', or to (2) pre-Proto-Germanic *kudʰso- to the IE verbal root *keu̯dʰ- 'to hide' cf. {ref EWA 4}:1288-1290 for further details of either etymology, with references; cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:260.

Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *k̑erd- 'heart' ({ref NIL} 417-423, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:469-471, {ref Beekes 2010}:644, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:576-578, {ref EWAia} II:818, {ref ALEW} 1032-1034, {ref Derksen 2015}:448-449, {ref Derksen 2008}:485, {ref de Vaan 2008}:134-135, {ref Matasović 2009}:223-224). The irregular correspondence of Proto-Indo-Iranic word-initial *j́ʰ- (> Ved. h-, Av. z-) is presumably due to contamination with Proto-Indo-Iranic outcome of PIE *g̑ʰórh₁-/g̑ʰr̥h₁- 'guts', cf. /cognate/2672/.

Comment: cf. Sanskrit mastaka- m. n. (Up+) 'skull, head', related to Vedic mastr̥han- m. 'brain' < Proto-Indo-Iranian *mastr̥gʱan- (cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 326).
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit masta-, more commonly Sanskrit mastaka- 'skull, head' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:571 no. 9926. The stem appears to continue an r/n-stem with the Sanskrit stem masta- continuing earlier *mastn̥-, while the r-stem is preserved in Vedic mastr̥han- 'brain', YAv. mastərəγan- 'brain'. Further connections uncertain, perhaps a derivative of PIE *mosgʰ- 'marrow'(?), cf. {ref EWAia} II:336 for further discussion.

Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *u̯i-u̯ai̯d-, further to PIE *u̯oi̯d- 'to know', to perfect stem of PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to see' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:174, {ref Cheung 2007}:408-409, cf. {ref LIV²} 665-667).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bodh- 'to wake up; to perceive, become aware; to know' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:525 no. 9279), further to PIE *bʰeu̯dʰ- 'to awaken, become alert' ({ref EWAia} II:233-235, {ref LIV²} 82-83).
Loan from Latin pēnsum (cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} s.v. Welsh pwys).

Celtic lexemes generally derived from PIE *treu̯d- 'to thrust, push', although the specific stem-formation is disputed ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:149-151, {ref Matasović 2009}:391, cf. {ref LIV²} 651-652).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ou̯s-os-, *h₂au̯s-os-, *h₂us-es- 'ear' ({ref NIL} 339-343, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1130-1131, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:637-638, {ref Demiraj 1997}:415, {ref Orel 1998}:501, {ref ALEW} 74, {ref Derksen 2015}:71, {ref Derksen 2008}:507, {ref de Vaan 2008}:63, {ref Matasović 2009}:48-49).

Comment: original meaning "ear" + verbaliser: k-oš-kēnīt
Justification: Probably a light verb construction involving PIE *h₂us-i- 'ear' (cf. Young Avestan uši- 'ear') as the semantic head ({ref Korn 2005}:350). For the Indo-European comparanda cf. {ref NIL} 339-343.

Italic lexemes generally compared to Ancient Greek ἀΐω 'to perceive, hear', possibly from a root ?*h₂u̯ei̯s- 'to hear', but the details of the Latin stem-formation remain obscure, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:55, {ref de Vaan 2008}:61, {ref LIV²} 288 for further discussion. For Romance cognates, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:61 no. 779.
Denominal formations to Proto-Celtic *kowdo- 'hiding place' < PIE *k̑ou̯dʰo- ({ref Matasović 2009}:219, cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:442); for the root *keu̯dʰ- 'to hide' cf. {ref LIV²} 358-359.

West Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *habiga- 'weighty, heavy', a derivative from the root as the Germanic strong verb *hafjan- 'to raise, lift', and further derived from PIE *keh₂p- 'to seize, snatch' ({ref Seebold 1970}:244-246, {ref Orel 2003}:147-148, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:198, {ref LIV²} 344-345).
Loanword from Italian pesante 'heavy'.

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bhar- 'to carry' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:539 no. 9459 and 9465), cf. further PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ({ref EWAia} II:246-249, cf. {ref LIV²} 76-77).

Comment: cf. Lith. smagùs 'strong, heavy'
Justification: The Baltic adjective is to be connected with the root of Lithuanian smõgti 'to hit, strike' whose root is generally further connected to Polish smagać 'to whip', etc. < Proto-Balto-Slavic *smāg-, further etymology uncertain ({ref Smoczyński 2007}:579, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:837-838, 848; cf. {ref Karulis 1992} II:235-236).

Etymology uncertain. If {ref Kroonen 2013}:167 is correct, then the traditional etymology (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:165-166, {ref Lehmann 1986}:151) within Germanic to Proto-Germanic *gawēn- (and perhaps further to OCS gověti 'to revere and Latin faveō 'to be favorable' < *gʷʰou-eh₁-) is to be abandoned. {ref Kroonen 2013}:167 alternatively proposes cognacy to the Indo-Iranic root ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯g̑ʰ- (cf. {ref LIV²} 199), but this proposal has not yet met with widespread acceptance (not in {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).

Since {ref Jokl 1912}:192-195 generally connected with Ancient Greek σκέπω 'to cover, protect' from PIE ?2. *(s)kep- 'to cover', cf. {ref Orel 1998}:104, {ref LIV²} 555 (without Albanian cognates listed).

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, and Baltic derivatives from PIE *nebʰ- 'become damp, cloudy, misty' ({ref NIL} 499-504). Cf. also {ref ALEW} 186-187, {ref Derksen 2015}:118, {ref Beekes 2010}:1012, {ref EWAia} I:94, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:49-51).
Italic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)neu̯dʰ- ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:448-449, {ref de Vaan 2008}:417, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:491).

Connections outside Tocharian unclear. {ref Adams 2013}:297-298 proposes connections to PIE *dʰerg- comparing Lithuanian dérgia 'there is bad weather', Middle Irish derg 'red', Old English deorc 'dark', but these connections are not fully certain ({ref ALEW} 195-196 rejects extra-Baltic connections for the proposed Lithuanian cognates; the appurtenance of the Germanic and Celtic forms to a root *dʰerg- may well be possible, cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:153, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:57-58, but the connection of Tocharian forms to this root are questionable. {ref Matasović 2009}:96 regards the connection of the Tocharian forms to this etymon doubtful; cf. further discussion in /cognate/1734/).

Comment: Further connection unknown.
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Three main possibilities: Either (1) connected with Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist' (so {ref Orel 1998}:269) ultimately derived from *h₃mei̯gʰ- /cognate/42/), or from PIE *mergʷ- (so {ref Demiraj 1997}:271-273), alternatively a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'mist, fog' (suggested by {ref Meyer 1891}:283-284, cf. /cognate/2150/). Either of these sources could also have been contaminated with one another (cf. the discussion of {ref Huld 1984}:93). Ultimately unclear.

Continuing Latin colligere 'to gather, collect; read' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:194 no. 2048), in origin a compound con-legere, further to PIE *leg̑- 'to gather, pick up' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:332-333, {ref LIV²} 397).

Comment: For the IE reconstruction, see ALEW.
Justification: The root assignment for this set follows {ref ALEW} 674-675 in connection to Vedic muṣṭi- 'fist', Young Avestan mušti.masah- 'fist-sized', and Tocharian B maśce 'fist', cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:326-327 dismissing earlier proposals to Ancient Greek ἀμύσσω 'scratch, tear, lacerate', ἀμυχή 'rent, wound', and Latin mūcrō f. 'point (of a sword etc.)' from a putative root *h₂meu̯k̑-, also {ref Smoczyński 2007}:413.

From Proto-Iranic *abi- or *apa- + *snaH- 'to wash, swim', via an intermediate meaning 'to clean up', further to PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:111-112, {ref Cheung 2007}:348-349, cf. {ref LIV²} 572-573).

Cf. Latv. glabât 'keep, guard, protect; bury, hide', from PIE *gleh₁bʰ- 'to encompass, cover' according to {ref ALEW} 343, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:187 assumes *glebʰ-. Cf. also discussion of {ref Derksen 2015}:180-181. (Not in {ref LIV²}).
Derived from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'to beat' ({ref LIV²} 7, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:32-34, {ref Schumacher 2004}:226-232, {ref Matasović 2009}:65-66, {ref LIV²} 72).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'to beat, strike, slay', possibly from a root ?*slak- 'to hit, beat' only otherwise attested Celtic, cf. Middle Irish slacc 'sword' ({ref Seebold 1970}:425-427, {ref Lehmann 1986}:314, {ref Kroonen 2013}:452, {ref LIV²} 564).

Modern Greek lexemes from Hellenistic Greek δίδω 'give' (Ancient Greek δίδωμι) with the present stem re-characterised as a nasal present stem δίνω ({ref Babinotis 2010}:374), further to PIE *deh₃- 'give' ({ref Beekes 2010}:331-332), cf. {ref LIV²} 105-106).

Italic and Romance lexemes continuing PIE *bʰerH- 'to work with a sharp tool' ({ref LIV²} 80, {ref de Vaan 2008}:213; for Germanic lexemes in this set not in the target meaning, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:53).
From Proto-Iranic *paiš 'to crush, grind', further connected to PIE *pei̯s- 'to pound, beat' ({ref Cheung 2007}:292-293, {ref EWAia} II:169, {ref LIV²} 466-467).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 6216
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit dálati 'cracks, splits', probably an l-form of the same root as Vedic √dar- 'to scatter, split' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:355 no. 6216, {ref KEWA} II:24), further to PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split' ({ref EWAia} I:701-703, {ref LIV²} 119-121).

Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *bando- 'top, peak', as though from Proto-Indo-European *bn̥d-no- which may be further connected to a PIE root *bend-, a root exclusive to Celtic and Germanic (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:54, {ref Delamarre 2003}:66, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:35).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *haita- 'hot', no certain etymology outside of Germanic ({Heidermanns 1993}:271-272, {ref Kroonen 2013}:202, cf. {ref EWA 4}:887-888, 915-916).
Slavic lexemes as though from PIE *steh₂-ro-, derived from PIE *steh₂- 'to stand' ({ref Derksen 2008}:476, cf. {ref NIL} 637-659).

Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑el- 'warm' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:83), cf. {ref Nussbaum 1999} for a detailed discussion of the Latin stem formation; for Romance lexemes cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:139 no. 1506 (Lat. caldus 'warm'). For Germanic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this set, cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:294, {ref Kroonen 2013}:231.

Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit vi-stara- 'spread-out', a derivative of Vedic √star-ⁱ 'to spread out, strew' and ultimately to PIE *sterh₃- 'to spread out' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:693 no. 11987, {ref EWAia} II:756-757, {ref LIV²} 599-600).

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Hellenistic or Roman period Greek *ὀσπίτιον, via Medieval Greek σπίτι(ν), either a Hellenistic or Late Antique loan from Latin hospitium 'lodging, guest-house' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1314).

Continuing Latin hospitalis, -e 'hospitable' in a nominalised sense of 'accommodation; house' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 4:493-498). Latin hospitalis is further a derived adjective from Latin hospes, itis 'guest, visitor; host, entertainer', probably an old compound containing the roots of hostis 'foreigner; enemy' < PIE *gʰosti- and potis, -e 'having power' < PIE *poti- 'master, in control of' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:291, {ref Untermann 2000}:336, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:300-301).

Tocharian lexemes, generally compared with  Vedic vā́stu- 'residence, abode' and Ancient Greek ἄστυ 'town', which may continue a proto-form *u̯ā̆stu- (< *u̯éh₂stu- ~ *uh₂stéu̯-?). Further root etymology unclear. A connection with PIE *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' (cf. {ref IEW} 1170-1171, {ref LIV²} 293-294) is semantically attractive but uncertain (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:134, {ref EWAia} II:549, {ref Beekes 2010}:158-159 for discussion and references to further literature).

Cf. Old Lithuanian butà 'building, house, dwelling'; these Baltic lexemes are not to be separated from Proto-Celtic *butā- 'house' (cf. Old Irish buth, Middle Welsh bod); perhaps a derivative of PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'to grow, originate, become', although the short vowel found in the Baltic forms is problematic and has led some to consider an old loanword from Continental Celtic into Proto-Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 153, {ref Derksen 2015}:107, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:83, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:68).

Cf. Old Lithuanian klùpti 'to fall on the knees, stumble', traditionally connected to an IE root *kleu̯b- 'to stumble, hop' ({ref LIV²} 364, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:293, 301-302), but cf. {ref ALEW} 510-511 objecting to the comparative semantics. [Not in {ref Derksen 2015}]. Cf. also 'run' in /cognate/6948/ and 'walk' in /cognate/332/ for the proposed Germanic comparanda in Gothic us-hlaupan, etc.

From Vedic sthūlá- 'large, thick', a variant of Vedic sthūrá- 'id.' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:795 no. 13776), ultimately from a PIE derived stem *stuh₂ró- (< *sth₂-ur-ó-), a derivative of PIE *steh₂- 'to position (oneself), stand' ({ref EWAia} II:768-769, {ref NIL} 639). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'big' in /cognate/7106/.

Continuing Vedic goṣṭhá- m. 'cow-house', a compound of Vedic gav- 'cow, steer' < PIE *gʷou̯- 'id.', and *steh₂- 'to stand', lit. 'standing place for cows' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:232 no 4336, cf. {ref EWAia} I:502, I:478-480, II:764-766). This cognate set is coded for *steh₂- 'to stand' (> ºṣṭá- ºṣṭā́(na)- 'standing place').
As though from *ἐξ-ίστημι > Tsakon. τσ̔ιτ̔αίνου, i.e. τσ̔ι- 'un' < ἐξ- + τ̔αίνου 'to get up' < ἵστημι 'stand' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). For further etymology, cf. 'stand' in /cognate/309/.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'to dig, bury', probably via a periphrastic formation *kl̥h₂-dʰh₁-o- 'to make a stroke/stab' to PIE *kelh₂- 'to hit, break' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:410-413, {ref Matasović 2009}:206, Britta Irslinger, p.c., cf. {ref LIV²} 350, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:111-112)

Celtic lexemes, denominal verbal formations based on Proto-Celtic *selgā 'hunt', a derivative of PIE *selg̑- 'to let go, release, send away' ({ref Matasović 2009}:329, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:80-81, {ref Falileyev 2000}:82, {ref Deshayes 2003}:325, cf. {ref LIV²} 528-529).

Light verb construction with Ossetic cwan | cawæn 'hunt, chase' as the semantic head, from Iranic *či̯āu̯ana- from *√či̯au̯- 'to move, go', further to PIE *kʷi̯eu̯- 'to set oneself in motion' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:318, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:40-42, {ref EWAia} I:552-553, {ref LIV²} 394-395).
Light verb construction with Arbëresh kaça 'hunt' (n.) as the semantic head, a loanword from Italian caccia 'hunt'.

Light verb constructions with nominal 'wild animals, quarry, hunting' as the semantic-bearing head. The etymology of Middle Persian naxčīr was originally interpreted by {ref Bailey 1946}:774n1 as though from Iranic *naxti-čiθra- 'originating in the night' (cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:36-37). {ref Bailey 1958}:44 later revised his view in light of new Middle discoveries and alternatively considered as though from Middle Persian *naxa-čarya- 'moving about in the expanse, open spaces, the wilds'. If so, we could consider to either *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, arrive' → Iranic *naxa- 'expanse, wilderness', or to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to move, turn' > Proto-Iranic *carH- ({ref Cheung 2007}:33-34) depending on which morpheme is best considered the original semantic head of the nominal compound.
Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:330-335).

Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *ǰan- 'to kill, slay, strike' ({ref Cheung 2007}:224-225); Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *goniti ‘chase, persecute’ and further to PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ({ref Derksen 2008}:177, {ref ESSJa} 7:23, 196-197, cf. {ref LIV²} 218-219).

Comment: cognate with 'stick' cognate/1680/
Justification: Cf. s.v. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:350 no. 6130 *daṇḍakakarman- 'forest-work'; the semantic head coded for cognacy in this set is Vedic daṇḍá- 'stick', without further etymology outside of Indic ({ref EWAia} I:692, {ref KEWA} II:11-12).
By internal reconstruction, possibly from a nasal-infix stem *h₂ur-n-H to a root *h₂u̯erH- although there are no certain cognates outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:372; not in {ref LIV²}).

According to {ref Kroonen 2013}:257, Old English huntian continues a Proto-Germanic weak verb *hūnton- as though from PIE *⁽k̑⁾n̥t-néh₂-, an iterative formation to Proto-Germanic *hinϸan- 'to reach for' and connects further to Proto-Germanic *handu- 'hand' as though from PIE *⁽k̑⁾ont-ú-, although there are no certain cognates outside of Germanic; cf. also {ref Lehmann 1986}:122 and discussion to Proto-Germanic *handu- 'hand' in /cognate/234/.

Cf. Standard German hauen, from Proto-Germanic *hawwan- 'to hew, chop' and further derived from PIE 2. *keh₂u̯- 'to beat, to split' ({ref LIV²} 345-346, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:251-252, {ref Kluge 2011}:399, {ref Kroonen 2013}:218).

The IE root etymology of Proto-Germanicc *daujan- given here follows {ref LIV²} to *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen'. For an alternative etymology attempting to connect the Germanic words to Hitt. tuḫḫuš- 'to end', cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:90-91 (but cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:893-894, who does not give an IE etymology for Hitt. tuḫḫuš-). For older etymologies attempting to connect the words to PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'rauch machen' (cf. {ref LIV²} 158) and hypothesised variants, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:147-149 (followed in Seebold's revised version of {ref Kluge 2011}:919 s.v. Tod).

Comment: Morgenstierne (1974: 82) derives this word from the verb ϑāw- 'to burn', which derives from *tep-, while Cheung (2007: 68) from *deh₂u-.
Justification: Root etymology disputed. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:82-83 derives from Proto-Iranic *tap/f- < PIE *tep- 'to be warm, hot' (cf. {ref LIV²} 629-630); {ref Cheung 2007}:67-68 derives from Proto-Iranic *dauH- 'to burn' < PIE *deh₂u̯- 'to kindle, catch on fire' (cf. {ref LIV²} 104-105).

{ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:88-89 interprets the Ossetic lexemes as from a *warāka- to a root *war- 'bent', although good correspondences within Iranic are lacking; there are similar East Caucasian terms which Abaev interprets as loanwords from Alanic (cf. Bats varang 'shoulder', Ingush voruv, Chechen vare 'thigh'), but it is possible the loans occurred in the opposite direction (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.).

Comment: Although Common Iranic would continue *g̑ʰ as /z/ (as with Avestan), Klingenschmitt (2000: 200, fn. 30) emphasises that /d/-forms are not a sign of loans from Persian, but the result of an early dissimilation of *d͜zasta- > *dasta-: "Die Bedeutung des Wortes und die weite Verbreitung der Lautform *dasta- schließen aus, daß es sich um eine Entlehnung aus dem Persischen (ap. dasta-, mp. dast) handelt. Die Lautform *dasta- muß vielmehr durch Dissimilation entstanden sein (vgl. Morgenstierne, EVP, S. 39)."
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *g̑ʰes- *'grasp'(?), 'hand', 'grip' ({ref NIL} 170-173). Indo-Iranic cognates reflect *g̑ʰes-to- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:812), other languages reflect an r-stem g̑ʰes-r- or thematised r-stem *g̑ʰes-r-o- ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:471-472, {ref Adams 2013}:711-712, {ref Beekes 2010}:1620-1621, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:431-432, {ref Demiraj 1997}:140, {ref Orel 1998}:70).
Celtic lexemes derived from a stem *pl̥h₂-mo/eh₂- to PIE *pleh₂- 'flat, broad' (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:132, {ref NIL} 562-564).

Baltic lexemes continuing denominal verbs based on nominal formations in the meaning 'tree, wood; forest' continuing PIE *medʰi̯o- 'middle' ({ref ALEW} 625-627, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:382, cf. {ref NIL} 465-466).

Generally considered a derivative of Ancient Greek κρύος 'cold' in the older literature (cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:28-29, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:588-589), although the stem-formation is obscure. {ref Beekes 2010}:787 therefore has rejected the older proposed etymology in favour of assuming a substratum borrowing from a 'Pre-Greek' language. A third possibility is that there has been some degree of contamination or blending of the lexical root underlying Ancient Greek κρύος with some other (substratum?) lexical material (cf. note by Scarborough in this class), although this too is a speculative solution.

Traditionally reconstructed as *i̯eg- ({ref IEW} 503) but the connection of Indo-Iranic *yaja- 'cold' points to *i̯eg̑- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:601 no. 10396; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:234-235, {ref HED A+E/I}:257-259, {ref Matasović 2009}:435).

Comment: Nu. forms from OIA. vi-str̥-ta- ‘spread; wide’  T. 12011 (-Strand).
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from *vi-str̥ta- 'spread, expanded, wide', Sanskrit vistr̥ta- 'id.' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:694-695 no. 12011), a derivative of Vedic √star-ⁱ 'to spread out, strew', and ultimately further to PIE *sterh₃- 'to spread out' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:756-757, {ref LIV²} 599-600).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 497, no. 8857 s.v. prastará- m. 'anything strewn, grass to sit on' (RV), later 'flat surface' Mn., 'plain', 'rock, stone' Hit.; Pali Prakrit patthara- m. 'stone', from PIE 'strew' cf. LIV, p. 599
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic prastará- 'anything strewn, grass to sit on' (RV.), later 'flat surface', 'stone', a derivative of Vedic √star-ⁱ 'to spread out, strew' and ultimately to PIE *sterh₃- 'to spread out' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:497 no. 8857, {ref EWAia} II:187, II:756-757, {ref LIV²} 599-600).
Parallel loans from Persian (شكار (كردن / šekār (kardan) 'to do a hunt; hunt'

Comment: cf. Parthian iškar- and Zoroastrian Middle Persian wiškar "hunting ground, wilderness"; Cheung (2007: 345) puts this verb to an Iranic root *skar- "pursue, drive, look for (the cattle)".
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives and light-verb constructions continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *skar- 'to pursue, drive'; no known etymology outside of Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:346).

Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish greimm 'seizure, hold, grasp, profit, advantage, sway', ultimately nominal derivatives continuing Proto-Celtic *gremmen-, a derivative to PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize' ({ref Matasović 2009}:167-168, cf. {ref LIV²} 201).

Compound verb with preverb ad- + claidid 'dig'. The verb continues Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'to dig, bury', probably via a periphrastic formation *kl̥h₂-dʰh₁-o- 'to make a stroke/stab' to PIE *kelh₂- 'to hit, break' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:410-413, {ref Matasović 2009}:206, Britta Irslinger, p.c., cf. {ref LIV²} 350, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:111-112)

Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:318 no. 5605 s.v. Indic *ḍhōṅga- 'projecting part of body', probably to be further connected with various words beginning with *ḍh- in the meaning 'lump' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:316 no. 5580) but further etymology obscure.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *mari- 'lake, sea', further from PIE *mor-i- 'id.'. Generally considered a western Indo-European isogloss, but cf. a possible further attestation in Iranic via Ossetic mal 'deep standing water' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:354-355, cf. {ref EIEC} 503-504, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:68-69).
Loanword from Persian (if inherited, expected Anlaut z-, cf. zangun 'knee' < *zānukāna- derived from PIE *g̑enu-).

Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *dʰalh₁- 'to spring up, sprout' ({ref NIL} 83-85, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:216-217, {ref Matasović 2009}:102-103, cf. {ref LIV²} 132). It is possible, but uncertain that Latin folium and the Romance lexemes continuing it belong here, cf. further discussion in /cognate/8247/.

Possibly to IE *teuto- if cognate with Lat. tūtus 'safe', Goth. ϸiuϸ 'good' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:164-165; cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:387 with some doubts). The proposed connections with the Italic and Germanic lexemes are judged difficult by {ref Lehmann 1986}:362-363 and not considered by {ref de Vaan 2008}:632-633. For possible semantic parallel for a euphemism, cf. Greek ἀριστερός in /cognate/1504/.
Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *grabH- 'to grab, seize, take', further from PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize' ({ref Cheung 2007}:119-121, cf. {ref EWAia} I:505-507, {ref LIV²} 201).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5539; non-Indo-Aryan
Justification: A loanword from Dravidian, cf. Telugu eḍama 'left, left-hand, left-hand side', Tamil iṭai, iṭam 'left side' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:311 no. 5539, cf. {ref Burrow & Emeneau 1984}:44 no. 449).

Iranic lexemes probably to be related to Vedic valká- 'bark' ({ref EWAia} II:525-526, cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:275, {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:123). Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, perhaps to be further connected to Serbo-Croatian vlákno, Russian волокно 'fibre', but cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:526.
Generally considered to be an *-mn̥-stem noun derived to *steh₂- 'stand' ({ref Adams 2013}:776-777, {ref NIL} 639).
Latin dīcere, from PIE 1. *dei̯k̑- 'to indicate, show' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:169-170, {ref LIV²} 108-109). For the Romance lexemes attached to this class, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:240.
Continuing a derivative of PIE *Hei̯k̑- 'to take possession of' ({ref LIV²} 223, {ref Malzahn 2010}:543-544, {ref Adams 2013}:107-108).
Loanword from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian блато 'marsh, swamp, bog' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), see also Albanian baltë 'swamp, marsh'.

From Ancient Greek στρεβλός (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), perhaps further to be derived from Ancient Greek στρέφω 'to twist, turn' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1062-1064, {ref Beekes 2010}:1412), but otherwise of obscure origin.

Comment: For the discussion on the Slavic cognates cf. /cognate/5209/ and /cognate/5149/.
Justification: Tocharian, Hellenic, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, and Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of a PIE root *s⁽k̑⁾eH- where the indeterminate laryngeal is probably *-h₂- on the basis of Ancient Greek σκηνή (West Greek σκᾱνᾱ́) 'tent' < *'cloth to provide shade' < *s⁽k̑⁾eh₂-néh₂ ({ref Beekes 2010}:1350-1351). Also attested in Greek is σκότος 'darkness, gloom' which must formally continue *s⁽k̑⁾h₃-to- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1359-1360). It is probably best to separate these as distinct roots, although formally they may well be (sandhi?) variants of one another at the PIE level. For further discussion cf. {ref Adams 2013}:773, {ref Beekes 2010}:1350-1351, {ref Andriotis 1974}:498, {ref Demiraj 1997}:201, {ref Orel 1998}:147-148, {ref EWAia} I:559-560, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:275-276 no. 5027, {ref Derksen 2008}:447).

The cognacy of the Hellenic, Germanic, Italic, Celtic, and Albanian lexemes in this set is generally agreed, but the precise root reconstruction is disputed, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1271, 1285, {ref Vine 1999}:5-30, {ref Demiraj 1997}:350-351, {ref Orel 1998}:384, {ref Holm 2011}:76, {ref Kroonen 2013}:601, {ref de Vaan 2008}:512, {ref Matasović 2009}:430).

As though from Latin *dē-ramāre 'to dismember' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:236), a derivative of Latin rāmus 'branch, twig' which is traditionally further connected to the root of Latin rādix 'root' if *rādmo- < *wrād-mo-, cf. Ancient Greek ῥάδιξ, -ικος 'branch, twig' (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:564, {ref de Vaan 2008}:513).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *su̯ar-i̯e/o- 'to laugh', a derivative of PIE 1. *su̯er- 'to sound' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:608-609, {ref Matasović 2009}:361, cf. {ref Falileyev 2000}:64, {ref Deshayes 2003}:162, {ref LIV²} 613).
As though from Indic *goḍḍa- 'foot, leg, knee'; further connections unclear, perhaps related to *khuṭṭa- 'leg' in /cognate/9629/ ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:229 no. 4272).
Lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *baina- 'bone, leg' (North and West Germanic, but no attestation from Gothic), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:48, {ref Kluge 2011}:105-106).

Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *g̑ar- (?*g̑eh₂r-) 'to sound, call' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:331-334, {ref Matasović 2009}:153, {ref LIV²} 161, cf. {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:186, {ref Broaderick 1984b}:187).

Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'to limp' via a secondary nominalisation of Proto-Germanic *skanka- 'crooked' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:446, {ref Orel 2003}:334, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:485, {ref Kluge 2011}:800). For the root, cf. {ref LIV²} 555). The semantics of Luxembourgish Schank appear to have shifted from the sense 'leg, thigh, shinbone' found elsewhere in Germanic.

Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes from a PIE derived stem *stuh₂ró- (< *sth₂-ur-ó-), a derivative of PIE *steh₂- 'to position (oneself), stand' ({ref NIL} 639, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:795 no. 13776, {ref EWAia} II:768-769, {ref Sims-Williams 2007}:266, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:158-159, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:557-558, {ref Kroonen 2013}:482).

Germanic and Celtic lexemes continuing a root *s⁽k̑⁾eh₃-, probably lexically distinct from PIE *s⁽k̑⁾eH- on the basis of both forms having reflexes in Greek (cf. Ancient Greek σκηνή (West Greek σκᾱνᾱ́) 'tent' < *'cloth to provide shade' < *s⁽k̑⁾eh₂-néh₂ ({ref Beekes 2010}:1350-1351 versus Ancient Greek is σκότος 'darkness, gloom' which must formally continue *s⁽k̑⁾h₃-to- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1359-1360). It is probably best to separate these as distinct roots, although they may well have been (sandhi?) variants of one another in PIE. For further discussion cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1350-1351, {ref Kroonen 2013}:438, {ref Matasović 2009}:340).

According to {ref Bailey 1979}:437 to be connected with Ancient Greek σκαιός 'left, western', Latin scaeuus 'left, inauspicious' < as though from *skeh₂-i-uo- 'shaded; left' (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1339, {ref de Vaan 2008}:541-542). For further discussion regarding the root reconstruction cf. 'shadow' in /cognate/5058/.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10666 s.v. *rahati ʻremainsʼ, *rahyati, cf. raha- m. (RV, BhP.), rahas- n. (MBh.) ʻisolation, secrecyʼ - from 'be isolated, left over' via 'remain' and 'stay' to 'live' - compare the meaning of the root of /cognate/255/
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing a Vedic verbal stem *rahati, cf. Sanskrit ráhas- 'loneliness, solitude, secrecy' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:617 no. 10666). There are comparanda in Iranic, cf. Middle Persian rāz, Parthian rʾz 'secret, mystery' etc., but connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} II:442).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *gamala- 'old', of uncertain etymology. Cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:154, {ref Orel 2003}:125, {ref Kroonen 2013}:166 for various proposals.

Armenian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑erh₂- 'to wear down, make old' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:338, {ref EWAia} I:576, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:304-305, cf. {ref LIV²} 165-166). For non-target Modern Hellenic lexemes attached to this set, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:268-269, {ref Babinotis 2010}:296.

Comment: Bailey (1979: 50f.) connects the house word kata- and the city word kanthā- in Saka with a verbal root 'kan' "to cover, hide". Cheung (2007: 232) notes the Sogdian city word knδh (and variants) with the root 'kanH' "to dig". This would not work with the hourse word because kn̩Hta- would give kāta-. It may rather be the root 'kan'  "to throw, place, put; destroy' (Cheung 2007: 229, although the 'destroy' meaning may rather derive from 'kanH' "to dig"). Note Old Ind. khánāmi, which if deriving from *kh₂ would account for the other Iranic house word xān-.
Justification: Etymology disputed. {ref ESIJa} 4:340-348 groups Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' together with Proto-Iranic *xāna- 'house', both as derivatives from Proto-Iranic *kanH- (1) 'to dig' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:232-233), although this etymology is rejected by {ref Bartholomae 1904}:432. Alternatively {ref Bailey 1979}:50 considers to a verb *kat- 'to cover, hide' (rejected by {ref ESIJa} 4:340-341). If from a PIE root *kenH- 'to dig', the aspiration found in xāna- is difficult to account for in Iranic except by comparison with Vedic khan- 'to dig', although this is usually explained by contamination with kha- 'canal, opening, hole', khā́- 'source, spring' within Indic ({ref Cheung 2007}:233). In view of the formal difficulties, Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' and *xāna- 'house' have been split into separate cognate sets. For further discussion regarding the difficulties of the reconstruction of the Indo-Iranic root 'to dig', cf. /cognate/7327/.

Comment: Note Old Ind. khánāmi, which if deriving from *kh₂ would account for the Iranic ‘house’ word xān- (besides the kadag-forms). If it is related to “dig”, the question remains, why this verb usually appears with #k and not #x (cf. Mayrhofer 1992: 445), cf. also Cheung (2007: 231) “In many Iranian languages the roots *kan1 ‘to throw’, *kanH1 ’to dig’ and *kan2 ‘to fill’ forms are homonymous and therefore often show mutual interference.”
Justification: Etymology disputed. {ref ESIJa} 4:340-348 groups Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' together with Proto-Iranic *xāna- 'house', both as derivatives from Proto-Iranic *kanH- (1) 'to dig' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:232-233), although this etymology is rejected by {ref Bartholomae 1904}:432. Alternatively {ref Bailey 1979}:50 considers to a verb *kat- 'to cover, hide' (rejected by {ref ESIJa} 4:340-341). If from *kenH-, the aspiration found in xāna- is difficult to account for in Iranic except by comparison with Vedic khan- 'to dig', although this is usually explained by contamination with kha- 'canal, opening, hole', khā́- 'source, spring' within Indic ({ref Cheung 2007}:233). In view of the formal difficulties, Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' and *xāna- 'house' have been split into separate cognate sets. For further discussion regarding the difficulties of the reconstruction of the Indo-Iranic root 'to dig', cf. /cognate/7327/.

Etymologically connected with the family of words surrounding Vedic pipīlá-, etc. 'ant' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:463 no. 8201). Further etymological connections remain unclear, probably of substratum origin (cf. {ref KEWA} II:284-285, {ref EWAia} II:132-133).

Root ref. form for this class follows the reconstruction of {ref LIV²} 344 ?*k⁽ʷ⁾eh₂- 'to dig', but cf. {ref EWAia} I:455-456 and {ref Cheung 2007}:232-233. We may be dealing with a specifically IIr. root *kanH- (< ?*kenh₁-, if the comparison to Phrygian keneman (a monument or part of it) is correct). {ref LIV²} 344n1 assumes the creation of a neo-root within Indo-Iranic on the basis of the nasal-present stem *k⁽ʷ⁾-né/n̥-h₂-.

The Bulgarian form goes back to the *korkŭ variant. The etymology of the Slavic lexeme and its further IE cognates are not entirely clear. Lithuanian kárka is rather a cognate but the other words linked to PS *korkŭ not.

These Tocharian lexemes are probably better explained via PIE *dʰei̯Hgʷ- 'to sting' (cf. {ref LIV²} 142, {ref Ringe 1988-1990}:71), although are sometimes considered derivatives of *denk̑- 'to bite'. Cf. also {ref Malzahn 2010}:975-976, {ref Adams 2013}:800.

Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *dāsá-, cf. Vedic dāsá- 'non-Aryan; fiend, demon, evil-being; slave, servant', further connections uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:723-724, {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:162-163, cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:155).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian црн дроб, Bulgarian черен дроб 'liver'.
Tocharian lexemes as though from *n̥k̑-u̯-o- 'mortal', derived from PIE *nek̑- 'to disappear, go missing' ({ref Adams 2013}:82-83, cf. {ref LIV²} 451-452).

From Latin barbatus 'bearded' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), a derivative of Latin barba 'beard'. For the IE reconstruction see {ref ALEW} 97, but cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:69 considering a European loanword on the basis of having to reconstruct PIE *a.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10951 lamba- ʻpendentʼ MBh. (ʻlongʼ in lamba-karṇa-); PIE *lemb(H)- 'hang loosely, droop, sag, cf. LIV, p. 411
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √ramb- ~ √lamb- 'hang down, dangle', cf. Sanskrit lamba- 'pendent', 'long' in lamba-karṇa- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:636 no. 10951), further to PIE *lembH- 'to hang slack' ({ref EWAia} II:436-437, {ref LIV²} 411).

Generally connected to PIE *k̑eh₂u̯- 'to ignite, burn' ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:118-119, {ref Adams 2013}:225-226). For the root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} (formerly {ref LIV²} 345 1. *keh₂u̯-).

Generally derived from Indo-European *gʰer- 'to desire, be delighted' ({ref LIV² 176-177 s.v. *g̑ʰer-, cf. now *gʰer- in {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}, {ref Adams 2013}:208-209, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:135-136, {ref van Windekens 1976}:188), but cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:604-605 with some doubts and possible alternative proposals.

Anatolian, Tocharian, Albanian, Iranic, and Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰég̑ʰ-om-, etc. 'earth' ({ref NIL} 86-99, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:858-863, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:128, {ref Adams 2013}:205, {ref Demiraj 1997}:155-156, {ref Orel 1998}:80-81, {ref EWAia} I:424-425, {ref ALEW} 1296-1298, {ref Derksen 2015}:516, {ref Derksen 2008}:542).

Tocharian, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- 'tongue'. The forms as attested appear to have undergone multiple contaminations in several daughter languages: (1) The Tocharian forms reflect *ĝn̥dʰu̯éh₂- ← PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- by metathesis of place of articulation (cf. {ref Ringe 1996}:45-6, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:79, {ref Adams 2013}:147). (2) Balto-Slavic lexemes appear to have lost initial *d- already at a common Balto-Slavic stage ({ref Derksen 2008:159}, {ref Derksen 2015}:285, cf. {ref ESSJa} 6:74-75). (3) Armenian, Italic, and Lithuanian lexemes appear to have independently contaminated with initial l-, probably under influence of their respective regular reflexes of PIE *lei̯g̑ʰ- 'to lick' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:307-308, {ref de Vaan 2008}:343, {ref Derksen 2015:285). (4) Celtic forms appear to have undergone a distance assimilation *dengʷāt- > *tengʷāt-  ({ref Matasović 2009}:368). (5) Indo-Iranic forms have a similar preform *ºg̑ʰu̯eh₂-/*ºg̑ʰuh₂- to the form *dn̥g̑ʰu̯eh₂- found in other branches, but instead appears to i-reduplicate the initial syllable (cf. notes to Ved. jihvā́- in {ref EWAia} I:591-593). Additionally, the Iranian forms appear to show a different Anlaut from the Indic ones (Indic *j-, Iranian *s-). This small deviation aside, the Indo-Iranic forms appear to go back to basic form *ji-ju̯aH-/*ji-juH- (vel sim.) in Proto-Indo-Iranic. This apparent reduplication could be secondary reanalysis of an original *dn̥g̑ʰu̯eh₂-/*dn̥g̑ʰuh₂- > *daju̯aH-/dajuH- as a reduplicated form *ji-ju̯aH-, (cf. forms such as *kʷe-kʷl-o- > cakra- 'wheel'), cf. {ref Mallory & Adams 2006}:175. For the purposes of root-cognacy, The Indo-Iranic forms are treated in this class as cognate with the other forms which are more clearly from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰ-u̯eh₂-/*dn̥g̑ʰ-uh₂-. The least disturbed forms appear to be found in Germanic, for which see {ref Lehmann 1986}:349, {ref Kroonen 2013}:526-527.

Generally connected to PIE *k̑eh₂u̯- 'to ignite, burn' ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:118-119, {ref Adams 2013}:225-226). For the root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} (formerly {ref LIV²} 345 1. *keh₂u̯-).
Precise semantics uncertain, therefore etymological comparisons remain speculative (cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:87, {ref Adams 2013}:151).
