Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *gʷen- 'woman' ({ref NIL} 177-185, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:501-505, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:157-159, {ref Adams 2013}:242, {ref Beekes 2010}:291-292, {ref Martirosyan 2010}363-364, {ref EWAia} I:568-569, {ref Derksen 2015}:558, {ref Derksen 2008}:558, {ref Kroonen 2013}:317, {ref Matasović 2009}:61).
Similar to nursery words for 'meat' in Caucasian languages, cf. Gruz. čičia, Svan. ʒiʒil, Chech., Ing. žižig ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:397).
Parallel loans from the Sanskrit compound candrá- 'bright' /cognate/2338/ + mā́ḥ 'moon' /cognate/2232/.

East Romance lexemes continuing Latin geusiae 'throat' (cf. {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), a probable loanword from Continental Celtic (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:320 no. 3750, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:274).

Italic lexemes continuing an n-stem to PIE *(s)kerH- 'to split, separate' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:94, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:101, {ref LIV²} 558). For Romance lexemes, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:162 no. 1706.

{ref Matasović 2009}:118-119 connects to Balto-Slavic lexemes (OCS iskra 'spark', Lith. áiškus 'bright') via PIE *h₁ei̯sk-, however the etymology of these proposed Balto-Slavic cognates are disputed (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:214, {ref Derksen 2015}:45 connecting instead to *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'kindle' assuming a connection with OIc. eiskra 'rage with heated excitement; {ref ALEW} 24 assuming no clear cognates outside of Balto-Slavic). Consequently only a Proto-Celtic root ref. form has been given for this cognate set.

Traditionally connected to the root *g̑ʰeh₁i̯- 'to gape, open up (the mouth)', although aspects of the stem-formation remain disputed (cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:171-172, {ref Adams 2013}:216-217, {ref LIV²} 173-174).

Generally derived from PIE *k̑lei̯- 'to lean' ({ref LIV²} 332-333, {ref Malzahn 2010}:592-593, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:69-70, also Ron Kim p.c.), less likely {ref Adams 2013}:184-186 derives to *kel(h₁)- 'raise up', cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:593 for further discussion.
Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *kers- 'to cut (off)' ({ref LIV²} 355-356, {ref Malzahn 2010}:579-581, {ref Adams 2013}:176-177, cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:92).

Etymology outside of Celtic obscure ({ref Matasović 2009}:60, cf. Deshayes 2003}:98-99). {ref Delamarre 2003} suggests an etymology to an onomatopoeic IE root *buk- 'bark, scream', although the vocalism of Gaulish bocca rather than *bucca is unexpected.

Anatolian, Armenian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dei̯-, di- 'be bright; shine' ({ref NIL} 69-81, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:766-767, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:616, {ref EWAia} I:750-752, II:304, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:362 no. 6328, {ref ALEW} 205, {ref Derksen 2015}:127, {ref ESSJa} 5:213-214 {ref Derksen 2008}:134-135, {ref de Vaan 2008}:170, 315-316, {ref Untermann 2000}:352, 868, {ref Matasović 2009}:101).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic jyótsnā- 'moonlight night' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:292 no. 5301), derived from Vedic √jyot- 'to shine' a phonetic variant of Vedic √dyot- 'to shine', a neo-root further to the same root as Vedic dyáv- 'sky', itself a derivative of PIE *dei̯- 'shine' via *di̯-éu̯- (cf. {ref EWAia} I:604-606, II:750-754, {ref NIL} 69-81).

Pontic ρασ̌ί(ν) 'mountain' < Ancient Greek ῥάχις 'spine, backbone' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:477). Further traditionally compared with Lithuanian ražis 'stubble' to a putative PIE *u̯rā̆gʰ- ({ref IEW} 1180, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:968-969), but the necessity to reconstruct *a ~ *ā ablaut to account for the Greek forms is suspicious from an IE point of view ({ref Beekes 2010}:1277-1278). Perhaps the assumption of a prehistoric loanword is a better hypothesis.

Comment: cf. Ossetic kom and NP kām „gums, palate“
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kāhman- 'mouth, opening', further connected in Indo-Iranic to the Vedic root √kas- 'to burst, split, break' according to {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:598-599, {ref ESIJa} 4:169-170, although cf. the scepticism of further connections to Vedic √kas- in {ref EWAia} I:332-333.

Romance lexemes from Latin bucca ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:122). Possibly a loanword from Celtic (cf. Proto-Celtic *bek(k)o- in /cognate/6204/), but ultimately unclear ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:77, {ref de Vaan 2008}:76).

Korn (2005: 88) assumes a (dialectal?) substitution of f > h; cf. Avestan zafar/n-. She follows Bailey (1979: 351b) in connecting this word with "tooth", cf. Old Ind. jámbʰa-. This evidence suggests an input *g̑m̩bʰ- > *zaβ- > *zaf- and > *δaβ- > (*daf- >) dah- respectively. Avestan shows cases of β > f, e.g. “navel” nāfa- vs. Vedic nā́bʰi- (Hoffmann/Forssman 1996: 98). I [TJ] don't see the need to assume a root without nasal for the Iranic forms (cf. Bailey, l.c.; but see Pokorny 1959: 382).

Albanian and Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *gʷerh₃- 'to devour' (cf. {ref LIV²} 211-212). Albanian Arbëresh gríka 'mouth' is equivalent to Standard Albanian grýkë 'throat' ({ref Rohr 2000}:31; for the root etymology see {ref Demiraj 1997}:297-298; cf. {ref Orel 1998}:126). The Modern Indic lexemes are as though from Sanskrit gilana- 'swallowing', continuing a derivative of Vedic √gar-ⁱ (2) 'to devour' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:223 no. 4164, {ref EWAia} I:469-470).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic kaṇṭhá- 'throat' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:134 no. 2680). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword from Dravidian (cf. {ref EWAia} I:292, {ref Burrow & Emeneau 1984}:127).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5853 s.v. tuṇḍa- n. ʻbeak, trunk, snoutʼ (TĀr. MBh.); cf. ibid. no. 10163 s.v. mukhatuṇḍaka m.n. (?) ʻmouthʼ Divyāv. (múkha- + tuṇḍa-) cf. /cognate/6016/
Justification: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:509-510 s.v. tuṇḍa- 'beak, trunk, snout'. Etymology uncertain, probably a loanword of non-Indic origin (cf. {ref KEWA} I:509-510).

A Brythonic word without certain external correspondences (cf. {ref Schrijver 1995}:52n1 against an earlier proposal of {ref Pedersen 1909}:63 to connect to Gothic gatwo 'street'). The reconstruction of a common proto-form is difficult, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} and {ref Deshayes 2003}:288 for attempts at a Proto-Celtic reconstruction.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hnekkan- ~ *hnakka(n)- 'neck', perhaps further comparable with Tocharian A kñuk 'neck' although there is some uncertainty the formal aspects of this proposed etymology. For further discussion cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:646, {ref Kroonen 2011}:167-169, {ref Kroonen 2013}:234, {ref van Windekens 1976}:225-226, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:162-163.

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes reflecting the Indo-European inherited word for 'name' (cf. {ref EIEC} 390-391). Certain details of the reconstruction of the PIE word are disputed (cf. {ref Stüber 1998}:53-59), but a general shape *Hneh₃-mn̥ with different ablaut variants of the root and suffix tend to be agreed upon. Debate on the identity of the initial laryngeal as *h₁ or *h₃ hinge on interpretation of the Doric Greek forms in ἐνυμα- versus the ὄνομα forms more commonly found elsewhere (cf. esp. discussions of {ref EWAia} II:35-37, {ref Beekes 2010}:1084-1085). Cf. also {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:517-519, {ref Adams 2013}:288, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:96-97, {ref Demiraj 1997}:165, {ref Orel 1998}:87, {ref Derksen 2015}:556-557, {ref Derksen 2008}:212, {ref Kroonen 2013}:382-383, {ref de Vaan 2008}:412-413, {ref Matasović 2009}:38).

East Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *u̯ordʰo- 'word'. In East Baltic the o-grade of the root was generalised, although Old Prussian wīrds, wirds 'word' reflects a zero-grade < *u̯r̥dʰ-o-, also found in Germanic (Gothic waurd 'word' etc.). The stem is also attested with e-grade vocalism in Latin verbum 'word' ({ref ALEW} 1188-1189, {ref Derksen 2015}:489).

Variants among the Ancient Greek dialects point to an original u-stem *stenu- that was later thematised as *stenu̯o- (with subsequent loss of medial *-u̯-), but further connections outside of Greek remain unclear ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1051-1052, {ref Beekes 2010}:1399).

North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *maiwa- 'slim, narrow', as though from PIE *moi̯H-u̯o-, a derivative of PIE *mei̯H- 'to diminish' ({ref de Vries 1977}:399, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:397-398, {ref Kroonen 2013}:349, cf. {ref LIV²} 427).

Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Indo-Iranic *(H)nār-, probably to be further to a root *(h₁)ner- on the basis of the comparison to Ancient Greek νέρθεν, ἔνερθεν 'from below', cf. also Sabellic 'left' in /cognate/3315/. Cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:156-157, {ref EWAia} II:37 for further discussion.

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic pátra- 'wing, feather' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:436, no. 7733). Further to PIE *pet- 'to fall, fly' ({ref EWAia} II:71-72, 75-76; cf. {ref LIV²} 476, {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing adjectival derivatives of Vedic pátra- 'wing, feather; leaf' in the sense 'leaflike, thin' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:437 no. 7736). Further to PIE *pet- 'to fall, fly' ({ref EWAia} II:71-72, 75-76, cf. {ref LIV²} 476, {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).

Comment: cf. cakkavāḷaŋ atisambādhaŋ Brahmaloko atinīcako 'the World is too narrow and Heaven too low' DhA i.310; iii.310 = VvA 68
Justification: Cf. Sanskrit sambādha- 'contracted, narrow' ({ref Pali Text Society 1921–1925}:693), further to Vedic √bādh- 'to press, force', probably further to PIE *bʰeh₁dʰ- 'to press, oppress' ({ref LIV²} 68, however more sceptically {ref EWAia} II:222).

The lexemes in this set continue a basic root *Hoi̯- 'single, alone' with different adjectival suffixes ({ref LIPP 2}:587-591): (1) *Hoi̯-ko- (Indic, cf. {ref EWAia} I:262-263, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:119 no. 2462); (2) *Hoi̯-u̯o- (Iranic, cf. {ref ESIJa} I:134-136, {ref EWAia} I:262-263); (3) *Hoi̯-no- (Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, Celtic, cf. {ref ALEW} 1233-1236, {ref Derksen 2015}:501, {ref ESSJa} 6:11-13, {ref Derksen 2008}:138-139 212-213, {ref Kroonen 2013}:11, {ref de Vaan 2008}:642, {ref Matasović 2009}:304-305),

Germanic and Italic lexemes as though from PIE *kólso- 'neck' (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:95, {ref Kroonen 2013}:205, {ref EWA 4} 777-780, {ref de Vaan 2008}:125). Root etymology disputed. Root reference form for this set follows the reconstruction of {ref Ringe 2006}:95. If ultimately from PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to turn' ({ref LIV² } 386-388), then these lexemes may be root-cognate with the Baltic lexemes in /cognate/1868/, but the etymology of the Baltic lexemes is less than certain; cf. further discussion in that cognate class. Alternatively a root etymology has been proposed to PIE *kelH- 'to tower, soar' (cf. {ref EWA 4} 477-480).
Indo-Iranic lexemes probably reflecting PIE *gʷriH-u̯eh₂- ({ref EWAia} I:509). It is difficult to isolate a further root etymology.

Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *gart- 'to turn', without any clear correspondences outside of Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:104-105, 110-111, cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:78, {ref ESIJa} III:196-203).

Nuristani lexemes as though from *mârâṇik and probably to be connected with Sanskrit maṇi- 'hump; Adam's apple' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:557 no. 9732), further considered as though from PIE *monh₂-i- (~ *moneh₂-) 'neck' by {ref EWAia} II:293-294 and connected with Vedic mányā- (cf. /cognate/1728/), although this etymology is doubted by {ref Turner 1962–1966}:557 no. 9732 on semantic grounds, cf. also discussion in {ref KEWA} II:556-557.

Generally agreed to continue a derived n-stem to PIE *k̑er-h₂- 'head' ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:175, {ref Adams 2013}:230). For further etymological discussion regarding the basic root *k̂er- cf. 'head' in /cognate/53/ and 'horn' in /cognate/2457/.

According to {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:15 to be connected with Latin umerus 'shoulder', Ancient Greek ὦμος 'id.', Goth. amsa 'id.', Skt. áṃsa- 'id.', although without clear antecedents in earlier Celtic. If so, then to PIE *h₃ems-o- (cf. 'back' in /cognate/7111/). [Not in {ref Matasović 2009}].

While the cognacy between Lat. vesper, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ, etc. is generally agreed, a morphological analysis of the proto-form from which these lexemes arose is not generally agreed upon. For the purposes of providing a root reference form for this cognate set, we have followed the analysis of {ref Beekes 2004}, cf. also {ref Beekes 2010}:470-471) s.v. Ancient Greek ἕσπερος. Exceptionally against the these lexemes forming a class, cf. {ref LIPP 2} s.v. †*u̯é-kʷsp-ero-. Cf. also {ref Derksen 2008}:513, {ref ALEW} 1174-1175, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:215-216. If *k⁽ʷ⁾sep- is the lexical root underlying this formation, then these lexemes may ultimately be cognate with Hittite išpant-, Vedic kṣáp- 'night', etc. in /cognate/87/.
Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *steh₂- 'to stand', cf. Vedic stā́na- 'place for standing' ({ref EWAia} II:764-766, cf. {ref LIV²} 590-592).

Continuing Proto-Iranic *stūnā-, cf. Young Avestan stūnā-, Old Persian stūnā- 'pillar', and probably further connected with Vedic sthūrá- 'big, strong, thick' < *stuh₂-ró-, a derivative to PIE *steh₂- 'to stand' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:282, {ref EWAia} II:768). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'big' in /cognate/7106/.

Modern Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *mr̥j́u- 'vertebra' (cf. YAv. mərəzu- 'vertebra', Old Persian *mr̥du- implied by Middle Persian mrdʾ 'throat' and other reflexes among modern West Iranic languages), further etymology unclear ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:656-657, {ref Bartholomae 1904}:1173-1174).

Baltic lexemes, generally analysed as containing a PIE noun for 'life, lifetime, life expectancy' *h₂ei̯-u-, *h₂oi̯-u-, *h₂i̯-eu̯- combined with the derivational suffix *-h₃en-, i.e. transponat *h₂i̯-eu̯-h₃n-ó- > Old Lithuanian jáunas 'young, new' ({ref NIL} 277-287, {ref ALEW} 408-409, {ref Derksen 2015}:209). The nominal stem *h₂ei̯-u-, *h₂oi̯-u-, *h₂i̯-eu̯- which serves the basis of this formation appears to have inflected as an ablauting u-stem but a corresponding verbal root *h₂ei̯- has not yet been identified (cf. {ref NIL} 279n1 for further discussion).

This cognate class is based on the assumption that ModIr. scáil f. 'shadow' continues OIr. scál m. 'phantom', involving a semantic shift and a change of gender or MIr. scáile masc. and fem. 'shadow, reflexion, image, illusion'. 
If one rejects this connection, it would be possible to postulate *skeh₃-lā- vel sim. for Ir. scáil, Sc. sgàil and connect them with /cognate/8269/. However, this has not been suggested so far, probably because there does not seem to be any evidence for a feminine word denoting 'shadow' before Late Middle / Early Modern Irish.

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √vas- 'to live, reside, spend the night' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:667 no. 11435), further to PIE 2. *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' ({ref EWAia} II:531-532, cf. {ref LIV²} 293-294).
Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE 2. *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' ({ref Adams 2013}:566, cf. {ref LIV²} 293-294).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2450
Justification: Continuing Vedic r̥ñjáti 'makes straight, pulls, stretches' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:117 no. 2450), a derivative of Vedic √raj- 'to direct, stretch, attain' and further to PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to make straight, stretch out' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:425, {ref LIV²} 304-305).

Comment: Middle and New Iranic languages exhibit an additional nominal suffix (e.g. Middle Persian -īg).
Justification: The Iranian forms in this set are based on a secondary root *u̯ai(H)n- 'to see' of denominal origin, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:412-413). For the primary verbal root, cf. {ref LIV²} 668-669 s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁-.
Etymology not yet satisfactorily ascertained, cf. {ref Karulis 1992} I:206-207 for various hypotheses.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *laikan- 'to jump', further derived from PIE *lei̯⁽g̑⁾- 'to jump' ({ref Seebold 1970}:321-322, {ref Kroonen 2013}:323, {ref LIV²} 405).

Comment: Cf. Vedic (RV) píṇḍa- m. 'lump, clod, piece' *piṇḍara-, Turner 1962-66, no. 8171, 8168; Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 128; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing *piṇḍara- 'round like a lump' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:462 no. 8171), derived to Vedic pinḍa- 'lump, clod'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:128).

According to {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:14-15, from Proto-Iranic *nas- 'to take' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:183-184 s.v. *Hnas- 'to reach, attain, take'), if so further to PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, obtain' (cf. {ref LIV²} 282-284).

Continuing Vedic dhamáni- 'vein, nerve; throat, neck', ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:385 no. 6733), further derived from Vedic √dham-ⁱ 'to blow' probably via an intermediate meaning 'pipe' and further to PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ({ref KEWA} II:92-93, {ref EWAia} I:775, cf. {ref LIV²} 153).

Romanian împinge continues Latin im-pingere ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:358 no. 4309), the remaining Romance lexemes continue Latin ex-pingere ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:266 no. 3048). The non-prefixed verb, Latin pāngere 'to beat, strike' continues a nasal-present stem formation to PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:442-443, {ref LIV²} 461).

Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though continuing a derivatives of Vedic mr̥ṣā 'in vain, wrongly' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:594 no. 10298, {ref Strand 1998}, further derived from Vedic √marṣ- 'to forget' and further to PIE *mers- 'to forget' ({ref KEWA} II:678-679, {ref EWAia} II:332, cf. {ref LIV²} 440-441).

Albanian lexemes generally connected to PIE *(s)teu̯d- 'to strike, beat' ({ref Demiraj 1997}:379-380, {ref Orel 1998}:444, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:999, cf. {ref LIV²} 601 [without Albanian]). For Germanic lexemes not in the target meaning in this set, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:476.
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *kap/f- 'to (be)fall, strike down', further connected to PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, hew' ({ref Cheung 2007}:234-235, cf. {ref LIV²} 555).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *pьxati 'push, shove', a derivative of PIE *pei̯s- 'to pound, crush' ({ref Derksen 2008}:420, {ref Boryś 2005}:420, {ref LIV²} 466-467).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of a root √dhakk- (cf. Sanskrit dhakkayati 'destroys, annihilates', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:383 no. 6701, {ref KEWA} II:88).

According to {ref Bailey 1979}:466, probably from the same root as Khotanese ajs- 'to cling to, pursue' (with the semantic development in the sense of 'cling to the scent of' vel sim.). Further probably to PIE 1. *seg- 'to adhere, cling to' ({ref Cheung 2007}:128-129, {ref EWAia} II:688-689, {ref LIV²} 516).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *kotto- 'old', possibly an old substratum borrowing from a non-IE language (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:425, {ref Delamarre 2003}:127, {ref Sims-Williams 2006}:67-69, {ref Matasović 2009}:218-219).

Comment: cf. Vedic varṣám n. 1. ʻrain ʼ (RV+), m. pl. varṣā́ḥ ʻthe Rainsʼ (AV), 2. ʻyear' (ŚB) (root vr̥ṣ-), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 446, no. 1139: Pali vassa- m. n. ʻrainʼ, pl. ʻthe Rainsʼ, Prakrit vāsa- m. (or < vārṣa-), varisa- m. n. - ultimately cognate with 'year' in /cognate/1634/; for Marathi pāūs < pra-vŕ̥ṣ- f. 'rainy season' cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8964
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂u̯ers- 'to rain' ({ref EWAia} II:522-523, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:664 no. 11392, cf. {ref LIV²} 291-292)
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *regna- 'rain', further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:284, {ref Kluge 2011}:753, {ref Kroonen 2013}:408).

Iranic lexemes continuing a PIE r-stem *u̯eh₁-r-, *uh₁-r- 'water', cf. Vedic vā́r- 'water'. The root *u̯eh₁- is possibly a variant of PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:544-545, {ref NIL} 715-717).

Italic lexemes continuing Latin pluvia 'rain', a derived noun to Latin pluō, -ere 'to rain' and further to PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ({ref LIV²} 487-488, {ref de Vaan 2008}:474-475, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:550).

Brythonic lexemes generally agreed to be cognate, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}. {ref Deshayes 2003}:274 reconstructs Proto-Celtic *u̯olau̯o- which has been tentatively followed here as a root reference form for this cognate set.
East Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE 2. *lei̯H- 'to pour' ({ref ALEW} 581-582, {ref Derksen 2015}:284, cf. {ref LIV²} 405-406).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic meghá- 'cloud' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:595 no.10302), further generally derived from PIE *h₃moi̯gʰ-o- ({ref EWAia} II:374-375).

Middle Indic lexemes from Vedic vr̥ddhá- 'grown, large', a derivative to Vedic √vardh- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:699, no.12073), further connections outside of Indo-Iranic are difficult (cf. {ref EWAia} II:520-521; {ref LIV²} 228 mechanically reconstructs ?*Hu̯eRdʰ-).

According to {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:306, as though from Proto-Iranic *dam-na- > *dav-n > *dafn, derived from Proto-Iranic *damH- 'to blow, breathe; to swell' and consequently ultimately to PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:55-56, {ref EWAia} I:775, {ref LIV²} 153).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:385 no. 6732, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:381-383, cf. {ref EWAia} I:775-776, {ref Cheung 2007}:55-56, {ref LIV²} 153).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit pānīya- 'water' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:456 no. 8082), a derivative of Vedic √pā- 'to drink' and further to PIE *peh₃(i̯)- 'to drink' ({ref EWAia} II:113-114, {ref LIV²} 262).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *bitra- 'biting, bitter', an adjectival derivative to PIE *bʰei̯d- 'to split' ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:126-127, {ref Kroonen 2013}:65-66, cf. {ref NIL} 11-12, {ref LIV²} 70-71).
Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ({ref Cheung 2007}:55-56, {ref EWAia} I:775, cf. {ref LIV²} 153).
Continuing Latin aqua 'water' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:46 no. 570), cf. 'water' in /cognate/953/ and 'river' in /cognate/2649/ for further etymological discussion.

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing derivatives of Sanskrit gola- 'ball, round object' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:232 no. 4321), cf. also variant guḍá- (1) m. 'globe, ball' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:223 no. 4181), presumably a Dravidian loanword (cf. {ref KEWA} I:349).

Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Indo-Iranic *gandʰá- 'smell', cf. Vedic gandhá- 'smell', Young Avestan gaiṇti 'bad smell', further connections remain uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:461-462, {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:368-369).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *staina- 'stone', reflecting PIE *stoiH-no- ({ref Kroonen 2013}:472, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:546, {ref Lehmann 1986}:321-322). Further derived from PIE *sti̯eH- 'to become stiff' (following the reconstruction of {ref LIV²} 603).

Pace {ref Kroonen 2013}, the different morphology of the Germanic-Italic lexemes on one hand and the Indo-Iranian, and Baltic lexemes on the other does not favour the view that PIE *h₂ekʷ- and *h₂ep- were variants of one another (Martin Kümmel, p.c.). Likewise it is not clear whether the Germanic and Italic lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (as advocated by {ref Beekes 1998}), but in view of the regular correspondences between Italic and Germanic, gratuitous. Further proposed connections are less certain (cf. {ref EWA 1} 99-103 for a thorough discussion). Less certain is the connection of the Celtic and Anatolian lexemes (cf. discussion in /cognate/1735/). Regarding the Oscan form in this class, an alternative root etymology to PIE *h₂ep- is sometimes considered on the basis of the apparent lengthened root vowel as in the Indo-Iranian forms (e.g. Skt. āp-) cf. {ref Untermann 2000}:42-43, {ref de Vaan 2008}:19), however it is possible that the lengthening of the vowel could be secondary. While it is possible that the Oscan form could preserve an isolated reflex of the root *h₂ep- as found in Indo-Iranian, Baltic, and Tocharian, given that there are no other potential reflexes of the root *h₂ep- in Italic connections with Latin aqua cannot be ruled out, and it seems preferable, on the balance of probability, to connect Oscan aapam with Latin aqua < *h₂ekʷ-(e)h₂ (acknowledged by both Untermann & de Vaan). (NB: In Oscan PIE *kʷ > p).

Baltic and Italic lexemes in the meaning 'red' derived from IE *u̯r̥mi- 'snake, worm' adopted from the use of insects to produce red dye ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 14:288-291, {ref de Vaan 2008}:665, {ref Derksen 2015}:567), cf. also /cognate/1163/. See 'worm' in /cognate/348/ for further etymological discussion.

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ἀληθινός 'true, genuine' ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:25), further perhaps to be derived from PIE *leh₂d-, although the postulated root is based entirely upon internal reconstruction of the Greek evidence (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:65-66, {ref LIV²} 401-402).

Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *kraviya- 'bloody, raw' {ref Turner 1962–1966}:186 no. 3585), cf. Vedic kraviṣ- 'red, bloody flesh', ultimately from PIE *kreu̯h₂-s-, a derivative of *kreu̯h₂- '(clotted) blood, blood outside of the body' ({ref NIL} 444-448, {ref EWAia} I:411).

Extra-Baltic connections uncertain, possibly to PIE *labʰ- if the root is to be reconstructed as such (cf. {ref ALEW} s.v. Lith. lãbas, {ref LIV²} 411-412 s.v. *lembʰ- n1), but such a reconstruction is uncertain, unusually requiring *-a- in the ablaut series. Likewise, the proposed cognates in Greek ἀμφι-λαφής, etc. can be more easily accounted by a zero-grade formation *lm̥bʰ-. {ref Hübschmann 1897}:451 speculatively considered a connection with Armenian law (cf. discussion in /cognate/8081/), but this etymology is not certain and is not even mentioned by {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965} or {ref ALEW}. A lemma for Lithuanian lãbas is lacking in {ref Derksen 2015}. Apart from the as yet uncertain proposal to Vedic rabh- 'seize, grasp', the Baltic lexemes appear to be etymologically isolated.

As though from Sanskrit sajya- 'strung (of bow); prepared, ready', a derivative of Vedic √sa(ñ)j- 'to adhere to' and further to PIE 1. *seg- 'to adhere, to cling to' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:758 no. 13095, {ref KEWA} III:419-420, {ref EWAia} II:688-689, {ref LIV²} 516).

Comment: Parallel loans from Arabic 'carnelian, cornelian, garnet' لَعْل via Persian 'ruby'; also Indo-Iranian surname and given name ('darling'), cf. Persian لعل‎‎, Hindi लाल, Urdu لال‎, Pashto lāl‎, but cf. also ep. Sanskrit lálati , Sanskrit root lal- 'cajole, play, dally, caress' ~ laḍ- cf. Mayrhofer KEWA III, p. 91, Turner 1962-66, p. 633, no. 10922, p. 640, no. 11030; epithet of Agni 'fire' is lālela-, lālilá- (Up+) - Krishna is also called "lalla" लल्ला - some conflation?

Justification: Goidelic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *gelo-, most likely to continue a derivative of PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green' ({ref Lucht 2007}:431-432, {ref Matasović 2009}:156).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √pac- 'to cook' and further derived from PIE 1. *pekʷ- 'to become ripe, make cooked' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:431 no. 7654, {ref EWAia} II:64, cf. {ref LIV²} 468).
Loan from early Scandinavian, cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *gart- 'to turn', a root first attested in Middle Iranic without clear correspondences outside of Iranic. Possibly the same root as Proto-Iranic *gar- 'to turn, wind' in /cognate/8719/ with a dental enlargement possibly under the influence of Proto-Iranic *u̯art- 'to turn', cf. YAv. varət- 'to turn' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:110-111).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 280, no. 5086 s.v. jáṭā f. ʻhair twisted togetherʼ, PārGr̥. ʻfibrous root, rootʼ Bhpr., Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 564 - further source unclear
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic jaṭā- 'hair twisted together', further etymology unclear ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:280 no. 5086, {ref EWAia} I:564).

Nuristani lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *gandʰá- 'smell' in light verb constructions (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:214-215 no. 4014), further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:461-462).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes continuing Indic *rukṣa- 'tree', a metathesised variant of Vedic vr̥kṣá- 'tree', from Proto-Indo-Iranic *u̯r̥ćšá-. Further connections uncertain, perhaps to be connected with Vedic valśa- 'shoot, branch, twig' ({ref EWAia} II:572, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:622 no. 10757).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *rinnan- 'to run', a nasal-infix present stem formed to PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to flow, swirl' ({ref Seebold 1970}:375-377, {ref Kroonen 2013}:413-414, {ref LIV²} 305-306).

Based on an Indic root *kuth- 'to stink' attested only quite late in Sanskrit, further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:169 no. 3282, {ref KEWA} I:228; see {ref EWAia} II:41 for an uncertain Vedic attestation of the root).

Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *hu̯ad- 'to become, make savoury, pleasant', further to PIE *su̯eh₂d- 'to make/become tasty' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:494-495, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:141, {ref EWAia} II:788-789, {ref NIL} 670-675, {ref LIV²} 606-607).

Comment: < Vedic mr̥ṣṭá- 'rubbed, polished, pure', later R. 'prepared, savoury' via Mbh. miṣṭa- 'dainty, sweet, pure, good', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 594f., no. 10299
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing Vedic mr̥ṣṭá- 'rubbed, washed, pure' > Classical Sanskrit 'prepared, savoury', further root etymology outside of Indo-Iranic difficult (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:594-595 no. 10299, {ref EWAia} II:324-325).

Nuristani lexemes as though from Indic rucaka- 'pleasing, sharp, acid', a derivative of Proto-Indo-Iranic *rau̯k/č- 'to shine' and further to PIE *leu̯k- 'to become bright' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:622 no. 10761, {ref EWAia} II:463-464, cf. {ref LIV²} 418-419).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *leu̯k- 'to become bright' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:632-633, {ref Beekes 2010}:851, cf. {ref LIV²} 418-419).

Anatolian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *melh₂- 'to crush, grind' ({ref LIV²} 432-433; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008} 547-548, {ref ALEW} 610-611, {ref Derksen 2015}:302-303, {ref ESSJa} 18:90-91, {ref Derksen 2008}:307}, {ref Kroonen 2013}:351, {ref de Vaan 2008}:386-387, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:58, M:32, {ref Matasović 2009}:255).
A derivative of Latin mola(m) 'millstone' (Giovanni Abete, p.c.), further to PIE *melh₂- 'grind' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:386-387, cf. {ref LIV²} 432-433).

Probably from Proto-Celtic *grau̯ā (cf. Old Irish griän 'gravel', Welsh gro 'gravel, shingle'), postulated for Gaulish on the basis of loanwords attested in Romance ({ref Delamarre 2003}:183-184, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:328 no. 3851). Further etymology uncertain: {ref IEW} 460 suggests a root etymology *gʰreu- 'to crush, grind', {ref Campanile 1974}:131-138 argues for a pre-IE loanword.

Modern Indic lexemes reflecting Sanskrit ākhyāti 'tells' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:47 no. 1041) and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kāzati, both probably to be derived from PIE *kʷek̑- ({ref LIV²} 383-385, cf. {ref EWAia} I:456-457, {ref Derksen 2008}:222, {ref ESSJa} 4:100-101, 9:168-170).
Initial b- in all languages seems to preclude direct derivation from vr̥ddhá- 'grown, increased, large', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:524 no. 9271.

Originally a compound of Proto-Indo-Iranic *u̯r̥ćšá- 'tree' + √*ǰai- 'to win, conquer' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:572). This cognate set is coded for *u̯r̥ćšá- 'tree' as the semantic bearing head, cf. 'tree' in /cognate/2368/ for further discussion. For Proto-Iranic *ǰai- 'to win, conquer' < PIE *gʷei̯- 'to win, conquer' cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:222, {ref LIV²} 206.

Probably a substratum loan in view of the Ancient Greek dialectal variants (Dor. γλέπω) and alternation in final aspiration in related vocabulary (cf. βλέφαρον, γλέφαρον 'eyelid'), cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:219-220 for further discussion. In view of these alternations, possibly borrowed as a root ?*gʷlep⁽ʰ⁾- (cf. note by Scarborough in this set).

Comment: cf. Sanskrit kathayati ʻconverses with, describesʼ (MBh.) (√kath-), derived from kathā- f. 'narration, telling how and why' (MBh.), ultimately derived from kathā 'how, why', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2703f., Mayrhofer KEWA I, p. 148f.
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Sanskrit katháyati 'converses with, describes' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:135 no. 2703), derived from the Vedic interrogative adverb kathā́ 'how?' and further to the interrogative pronoun ká- 'who, which?' < PIE *kʷó-, *kʷí- ({ref EWAia} I:294-295, 284-285, cf. {ref LIPP 2}:452-479).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *kweϸan- 'to say'. Further etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, possibly from PIE *gʷet- if comparable to Arm. kočʻem 'to call, invite', but the comparison is not entirely clear; cf. {ref LIV²} 212, {ref Kroonen 2013}:319, {ref Lehmann 1986}:277-278, {ref Seebold 1970}:318-320, {ref Olsen 1999}:811.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *u̯et-e/o- 'to say, speak', further derived from PIE *u̯eth₂- 'to say' ({ref LIV²} 694-695, {ref Schumacher 2004}:679-680, {ref Matasović 2009}:418, cf. {ref Falileyev 2000}:67).

Comment: < Vedic mantráyate (denominal) 'speaks (*recites mantras)' (RV), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 565, no. 9837
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic mantráyate 'speaks', a denominal formation to Vedic mántra- 'speech, sacred text or speech, a prayer', a nominal derivative from PIE 1. *men- 'to think' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:565 no. 9837, {ref EWAia} II:311, 305-306, cf. {ref LIV²} 435-436).
Ossetic lexemes probably continuing derivatives of a Proto-Iranic root *zag-, without certain etymology outside of Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:460, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:292-293).
Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:418, {ref LIPP 2}:639, cf. {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1149).
Denominal verb, cf. Cuneiform Luvian āaš- 'mouth' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:166-167, cf. {ref NIL} 387-390). For further etymological discussion cf. 'mouth' in /cognate/796/.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11480 s.v. vāṭa- m. 'enclosure, fence' (MhB.): "Early east MIA. < *vārtra-", from 1. var-
Justification: Cf. Sanskrit vāṭa- m. 'enclosure, fence', a formation originating in Middle Indic as though from Sanskrit *vārtra- or Sanskrit *vārta- < PIE *u̯orto- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:670 no. 11480 + addenda; cf. {ref Burrow 1975}:68). For the root, cf. Vedic 2. √var- 'to cover, conceal, hide, surround'. Further root etymology difficult; the Vedic root appears to continue a conflation of several different IE sources that have become homophonous (cf. {ref EWAia} II:512-513, {ref LIV²} 227-228 s.v. *Hu̯er-, 674 s.v. *u̯el- and 684 s.v. 1. u̯er-).

Comment: retra- n. 'perfumed powder', presumably of non-Indic origin (according to Kuiper apud Turner 1962-66, p. 626, no. 10816 "Sanskritization" of a Munda loan)
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit retra- 'perfumed or aromatic powder' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:626 no. 10816). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref KEWA} III:73 for further discussion.

There is no generally accepted etymology for Proto-Germanic *klawō- outside of Germanic ({ref Kluge 2011}:496-497, {ref Kroonen 2013}:292). {ref Adams 2013}:219 suggests a possible connection to with Proto-Tocharian **kolʸ- 'animal's foot'(?) but this remains uncertain.

Comment: < varṇáyati (denominal) 'relates, describes' (MBh.), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 661, no. 11342; from varṇá- m. 'sound, syllable' (AitBr.)
Justification: As though from Sanskrit varṇayati 'relates, describes', a denominal formation to Sanskrit varṇa- 'sound, syllable' and probably a specialised semantic development of Sanskrit várṇa- 'type, kind, colour', a derivative of Vedic √var-² 'to cover, conceal, hide, surround'. Further root etymology difficult; the Vedic root appears to continue a conflation of several different IE sources that have become homophonous (cf. {ref EWAia} II:512-513, {ref LIV²} 227-228 s.v. *Hu̯er-, 674 s.v. *u̯el- and 684 s.v. 1. u̯er-).
Slavic lexemes from PIE *drep- 'to cut off, tear off' ({ref Derksen 2008}:115, {ref LIV²} 128-129, cf. {ref ESSJa} 5:101-102 assuming a basic root *der- with a root extension).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *u̯el-e/o- 'to see', a derivative of PIE 3. *u̯el- 'to see, perceive' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:669-675, {ref Matasović 2009}:412, {ref LIV²} 675).
Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *spek̑- 'to look (at), see' ({ref LIV²} 575-576, {ref EWAia} II:107-108, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:452 no. 8012).

An Indo-Iranic and Albanian lexical isogloss from PIE *dʰei̯H- 'to envisage, contemplate' ({ref LIV²} 141-142, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:969; however doubted by {ref Cheung 2007}:48-50, cf. {ref EWAia} I:777-778 without Albanian).

Nuristani and Modern Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of', cf. Vedic kāś- 'to be visible, appear', Proto-Iranic *kas- 'to look, appear' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:159 no. 3114, {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:40, {ref Cheung 2007}:245-246, {ref EWAia} I:344-345, {ref LIV²} 383-385).
Phonology excludes inheritance

Brythonic lexemes without satisfactory etymology. Proposed to be connected with PIE *g̑enh₁- 'to bear, beget; create' by {ref Pedersen 1913}:544 via the sense 'make, do', although there are formal difficulties with this etymological identification (cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:346). {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} suggests a root *u̯er- 'to turn, spin (wool)' via an nasal-infix stem with an enlargement in *-b⁽ʰ⁾ (after {ref IEW} 1153), but this remains highly speculative. [Not in {ref LIV²}.]

Etymology disputed. Lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *obačiti, traditionally explained as a compound verb *ob-ačiti where *-ačiti is interpreted as a derivative of PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'to catch sight of, behold' (cf. Slavic lexemes for 'eye' in /cognate/211/), although there are some formal issues with this identification (cf. {ref ESSJa} 26:91-92, 32:41-42). Less plausibly it has been suggested that the lexemes were borrowed through East Slavic from Polish (cf. {ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-} 1:337, {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 1:154-155, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 1:138), however, the presence of cognates in many Russian dialects (Smolensk, Kostroma, Pskov, Tver' Novgorod, cf. {ref ESSJa}: 26: 91} makes the hypothesis about an ordinary borrowing from Polish somehow questionable.

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic vī́kṣate 'looks at, sees' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:696 no. 12041), further to Vedic √īkṣ- 'to perceive, view, see' continuing a reduplicated desiderative stem *h₃i-h₃kʷ-s- to PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'to catch sight of, behold' ({ref EWAia} I:203, {ref LIV²} 297-298).

Comment: Cognate with e.g. Russian смотреть 'look at'
Justification: Baltic lexemes generally agreed to be cognate with Proto-Slavic *motriti 'look at, watch' from a Proto-Balto-Slavic stem *mot(r)-, but a further IE root etymology remains disputed (cf. {ref ALEW} 620-621, {ref Derksen 2015}:307, {ref Derksen 2008}:327 for further discussion).

Connections outside of Germanic disputed: the principal hypotheses are (1) an adjectival formation based on a local particle *nē- (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:647) or (2) a lengthened-grade formation to PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, obtain; accomplish' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:387). See {ref Faltings 2010}:409-412 for further discussion (not in {ref Heidermanns 1993}). The Scandinavian and Modern English forms in this class are originally the comparative degree of the adjective which had taken over the meaning of the positive degree, i.e. *'nearer' > 'near' (cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Romance forms from Latin pressē, the adverbial form of Latin pressus, -a, -um 'pressed, straitened' (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 9:365-367, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:559), a past passive participle to Latin premō, -ere 'to press'. Further root etymology difficult (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:487-488 for further discussion).

Generally connected to Germanic words for 'approach, meet', cf. Goth. ga-motjan 'to meet', but a more precise root reconstruction is remains uncertain (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:49-50, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:451-452, {ref Lehmann 1986}:145, {ref Kroonen 2013}:372).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:309, {ref Beekes 2010}:369-370 for various hypotheses.
The precise semantics of the Hittite lexeme are not entirely clear, and therefore the etymology is also uncertain (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:170-171).

Comment: Sanskritism, cf. tīkṣṇa-, Vedic tīkṣṇá-
Justification: Loanword from Sanskrit tīkṣṇa- 'sharp'.
Lexemes as though from Proto-Iranic *ričaka-, cf. Vedic √rekh- 'to scratch', further to PIE *(h₁)rei̯k⁽ʷ⁾h₂- 'to scratch, score' ({ref Bailey 1979}:363, {ref EWAia} II:457, cf. {ref LIV²} 504).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing a derivative of Vedic √vāś- 'to roar, resound' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:675 no. 11586), further to Proto-Indo-Iranic √*u̯āć-, cf. Proto-Iranic *u̯ās- 'to make a noise, roar, shout', but without clear correspondences outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:547-548, {ref Cheung 2007}:432).
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *srau̯- 'to hear, listen', further to PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' ({ref Cheung 2007}:356-357, {ref EWAia} II:666-667, {ref LIV²} 334-335).
Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *gʰrem- 'to roar, rage' ({ref Smoczyński 2005}:164-165, cf. {ref LIV²} 204). For non-target Khwarazmian maγmeda in this set, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:122.

Nuristani lexemes in this set represent a light-verb construction 'to make a song', where cognacy in this set is assigned to the semantic bearing head 'song', as though from Old Indic *lalla- ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:636 no. 10972), probably further of onomatopoeic origin.

Comment: original meaning "to praise"
Justification: Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *fraiH- 'to rejoice? to atone, [med.] please', further from PIE *prei̯H- 'to please, be pleased, enjoy' ({ref Cheung 2007}:87-88, {ref LIV²} 490, cf. {ref Samadi 1986}:69).

Manx lexemes representing a light-verb construction 'to make a song' where for the purposes of cognacy Manx arrane 'song' is encoded as the semantic bearing head (cf. {ref Broaderick 1984b}:12). From Old Irish amrán 'song; a kind of poem', a diminutive of amar 'sorrow, suffering'. Further to Welsh afar 'sadness, lamentation' but of uncertain etymology outside of Celtic ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:65).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √drā- 'to sleep, slumber' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:411 no. 7200, 7201). Further root etymology uncertain, perhaps to ?*dreh₁- 'to sleep' ({ref LIV²} 126-127) if OCS -drěmljǫ is a contamination of this root with PIE 2. *drem- ({ref LIV²} 128), but this remains uncertain (cf. {ref LIV²} 126-128, {ref EWAia} I:757-758 for further discussion).

Comment: cf. Vedic bálbalī́ti (ŚB 2.3.2.11), malmalāyati  (ŚBK), balbalā kar- (Br), Sanskrit barbara- 'stammering' (cf. Greek bárbaros) - thus among the ideophonic roots *bal- ~ *bar- ~ *blV- ~ *mal- ~ *mlV-  vel sim. for 'babble, stammer, say blabla', cf. Vedic brav(i)- 'speak'; remodelled independently due to ideophonic needs, but in one or some forms inherited from PIE, cf. Mayrhofer  EWAia II, p. 217
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5005: "H. chāl f. ʻbark, skin, peelʼ, chālī f. ʻsmall blisterʼ, chālā m. ʻskin, hideʼ (→ P. N. chālā m.)"
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit or Prakrit challī- 'bark' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:274, no. 5005). Of non-IE origin, possibly Dravidian or Munda (cf. {ref KEWA} I:405-406).

Parallel loans from Latin aēr 'air, atmosphere, sky' (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:20-21, {ref Broaderick 1984b}:4, {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:24, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).
Loanword from Arabic جلد 'skin, leather'.

Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives to the same root as Lithuanian deñgti 'to cover', further from PIE *dʰengʰ- 'to cover' ({ref ALEW} 174, 192-193; {ref Derksen 2015}:115, 121-122, cf. {ref IEW} 250 [not in {ref LIV²}]).
Connected to PIE *nebʰ- by {ref van Windekens 1976} and {ref Adams 2013}:70, but this etymology remains uncertain; cf. {ref NIL} 503n21 for further discussion.

Italic lexemes, derived as an instrument noun from a root *bak- whose distribution appears to be an isogloss restricted to Western Indo-European languages. Perhaps a European loanword from an unidentified source ({ref de Vaan 2008}:67, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:64, cf. {ref IEW} 93).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin rīpa 'shore, riverbank' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:605 no. 7328), further from PIE *h₁reip-h₂ 'steep slope' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:524, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:574).

Comment: With prefix ni-, original meaning "to lie down", i.e. "to sleep".
Justification: Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *ni- 'down' + √*pad- 'to fall' via an intermediate sense 'to lie down', further to PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ({ref Cheung 2007}:287-288, cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:46, {ref EWAia} II:77-78, {ref LIV²} 458).

Modern Hellenic lexemes backformed from Ancient Greek (ἀπο-)μύσσομαι 'to blow one's nose, snort' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:906), further to PIE *meu̯k- 'to untie, take off' ({ref LIV²} 443-444, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:726, {ref Beekes 2010}:985-986).
Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *mau̯č- (1) 'to release, let loose/free', further to PIE *meu̯k- 'to untie, take off' ({ref Cheung 2007}:269-270, cf. {ref EWAia} II:382, {ref LIV²} 443-444).
North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *smēha- 'small', further etymology uncertain ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:519, {ref Kroonen 2013}:456, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:519).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8152 s.v. 'slimy, slippery'
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit picchala- 'slimy, slippery' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:460 no. 8152). Further etymology uncertain, probably a loan from a non-Indic source ({ref KEWA} II:271).

Romance lexemes continuing Late Latin flagrāre, Classical Latin fragrāre 'to smell strongly' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:298). Further etymology uncertain, possibly to be connected with OHG braccho 'hound', Middle Irish brén 'putrid, foul' from a root *bʰreh₁g-, in which case the Latin verb would have been deadjectival from an unattested *frag-ro- 'smelling', although this proposal remains quite uncertain (cf. {ref Schrijver 1991}:185-186, {ref Schrijver 1995}:170-171, {ref de Vaan 2008}:238; further to the proposed Celtic comparanda cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:232-233, {ref Zair 2012}:70-71). Alternatively a connection with Sanskrit ghrā́ti, jíghrati 'smells' has been considered but this proposal is formally problematic (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:251, {ref Schrijver 1991}:185-186).
Baltic lexemes continuing a PIE u-stem *lig-u-, further to a PIE root *lei̯g- 'equal, similar, alike' (cf. {ref ALEW} 584-586, {ref Derksen 2015}:286).

Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:68-69, {ref IEW} 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ({ref Matasović 2009}:205, cf. {ref ALEW} 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, {ref EWAia} II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this set).

Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated {ref Smoczyński 2007} and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek {ref Beekes 2010}.

Romance lexemes continuing Latin vivenda 'foodstuffs' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:786 no. 9410, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 14:575), originally a neuter plural gerundive form derived from Latin vivere 'to live' and ultimately to PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:685-686 and further discussion in /cognate/72/).
A derivative of Lithuanian gyvatà 'life', ultimately a derivative of PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' (cf. {ref ALEW} 340, {ref Derksen 2015}:180 for discussion of the nominal derivation).

Comment: from 'creature' via 'any animal of the lowest order, insect, worm', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5110
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic jantú- m. 'offspring, creature, man', via a secondary semantic shift 'any animal of lowest order, insect, worm' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:282 no. 5110). Further from PIE *g̑enh₁-tú-, a derivative of PIE *g̑enh₁- 'to produce, beget' ({ref EWAia} I:570, cf. {ref NIL} 139-153, {ref LIV²} 163-165).

Cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:87 walˈāṛ 'standing' from *awa-darta/i- or *wi-darta/i-, further to Proto-Iranic *dar- 'to hold, keep; dwell', and ultimately PIE *dʰer- 'to stick, fix' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:57-59, {ref LIV²} 145-146).

Comment: < Vedic nāgá- m. 'snake' (ŚB); perhaps cognate with /cognate/1358/ - but later also used for 'elephant', perhaps rather < PIE *nogʷó- 'naked', cf. Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 151 for further suggestions
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic nāgá- 'elephant; snake' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:404 no. 7039). Further etymology not certainly explained, possibly a derivative of PIE 2. *negʷ- 'naked' if the original meaning was 'the hairless, naked animal' (cf. {ref KEWA} II:150-151, {ref EWAia} II:33 {ref NIL} 513-515 for further discussion).

Generally assumed to reflect a derivative of PIE *gʷeh₂- 'to take a step', originally a suppletive aorist stem to PIE *gʷem- 'to go, come' (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:249-250, 344-345, {ref LIV²} 205).

Etymology uncertain. {ref Bailey 1979}:395 proposed *k̑i-es-d- derived to PIE *k̑ei̯h₂- 'to move' (cf. {ref LIV²} 346, {ref IEW} 538-539), but the function of the nominal morphemes ('increments') proposed in order to satisfy the etymology formally remains unclear.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Emmerick & Skjærvø 1997}:146-150 with extensive discussion and rejecting the etymology of {ref Bailey 1979}:404 to Proto-Iranic *aiu̯a- 'one').

Comment: *pa-bim-sta < IE *bʰuh₂-men-
Justification: According to {ref Strand 1998} from *pa-büm-ta- where Kâmviri büm 'earth' < Vedic bhūman- 'earth, world' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:545 no. 9556).

A participle to the Ossetic verb xīlyn | xelun 'to crawl'. Further connected to Sanskrit khelati by {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:201, but the etymology of the compared Sanskrit verb is difficult to ascertain (cf. {ref KEWA} I:312 and cross-references). Ossetic xīlyn | xelun is not listed in {ref Cheung 2007}.
No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic ({ref Derksen 2008}:548, {ref ALEW} 1290-1291, 1301-1302; {ref LIV²} 177 mechanically reconstructs a root ?3. *g̑⁽ʰ⁾er- 'to shine, radiate').

Light verb constructions using verbal nouns of Latin regere 'to guide, direct, govern' as the semantic-bearing head. For Neapolitan all'erta cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:257 no. 2899 Lat. erigere, erēctus 'erheben, aufrichten', 2. *ergere, *erctus; for Old Occitan drech, dreit cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:241 no. 2648 Lat. dīrēctus 'gerade'. Further to PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' ({ref LIV²} 304-305, {ref de Vaan 2008}:517-518)
Loan from Persian ستاره / setāreh 'star'

Anatolian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic derivatives from PIE *steh₂- 'to position (oneself), stand' ({ref LIV²} 590-592, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:879-880, {ref Beekes 2010}:601, {ref EWAia} II:764-766, {ref ALEW} 981-982, {ref Derksen 2015}:430, {ref Derksen 2008}:465-466, 468, {ref Seebold 1970}:464-465, {ref Kroonen 2013}:473, 477, {ref de Vaan 2008}:589-590, {ref Matasović 2009}:338).

Comment: lit. "to stand up"
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *Hrab/f- 'to go'. An etymology to a PIE root *rebʰ- 'to move oneself (boldly)' is tentatively considered by {ref LIV²} 496, but it is by no means assured (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:184).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *laṣṭi- 'stick', perhaps a contamination of Vedic yaṣṭí- 'stick, pole' with lakuṭa- 'club' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:637 no. 10991). Further connections are uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} II:406).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin pālus 'stake, wooden post' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:536-537), continuing an Italic instrument noun *pā̆g-slo- derived from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm', cf. Latin pangō, -ere 'to insert firmly, fix' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:478-479, {ref de Vaan 2008}:442-443, cf. {ref LIV²} 461).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *sfondo- 'stick, staff', further from PIE *sph₂en- 'piece of wood' ({ref Matasović 2009}:334).

Welsh lexemes consisting of a compound  cyn- 'before' + ffon 'stick' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}); the 'stick' compound member, for which cognacy is being encoded in this set, continues Proto-Celtic *sfondo- 'stick, staff', further from PIE *sph₂en- 'piece of wood' ({ref Matasović 2009}:334).

Continuing a nominal derivative from Proto-Germanic *bangōn- 'to beat, hit', if not onomatopoeic possibly further connected to verbs continuing PIE *bʰ-né/n-g- from *bʰeg- 'to break' ({ref Kluge 2011}:109, {ref EWNl} I:265, cf. {ref Orel 2003}:35, not listed in {ref LIV²}).

Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Indo-Iranic *stʰala- 'dry land, ground place; flat surface, roof'. Traditionally connected to the Sanskrit (Dhātupāṭha) root √sthal- 'to stand (firm)', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Strand 1998}, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:793 no. 13744, {ref KEWA} III:525).

Comment: Unknown origin; cf. /lexeme/1878/.
Justification: Of unknown origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:965, cf. {ref HAB} III:596; not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}). [MM: Proto-Armenian *oi̯/u̯łił-o-].

Modern Greek lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ὀρθός 'upright, straight; right, true'. Further etymology disputed, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:818-819 and {ref Beekes 2010}:1101 for various competing proposals.

Similar to Indic *kutta- 'dog', which first appears in Middle Indic. The Indic forms have been hypothesised to be onomatopoeic (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:168, however given similar forms in Uralic (cf. Hungarian kutya 'dog'), it seems more likely to be a Wanderwört. The fact that the Indic and Iranic lexemes only appear in the later languages and are not reconcilable to a common proto-form are suggestive of independent borrowings from a third source. Cf. also {ref ESIJa} IV:413-415 s.v. Proto-Iranian *kuta- 'собака, пёс', *kūtī̆-.

Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek σκύλος 'dog', morphologically transferred into the o-stem declension from Ancient Greek σκύλαξ 'whelp, puppy' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1290). No agreed etymology outside of Greek; cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1023, {ref Beekes 2010}:1361 for various proposals.

Comment: Loan from Persian

Justification: Late loanword from Balkan Romance, showing no trace of rhotacism in Tosk ({ref Huld 1984}:107, {ref Orel 1998}:356). Due to the apparent lateness of the borrowing, this loan is treated as separate loan events in Gheg and Tosk (cf. [Tosk-based] Standard Albanian in /cognate/5925/).

Comment: Loan from Latin.
Justification: Late loanword from Balkan Romance, showing no trace of rhotacism in Tosk ({ref Huld 1984}:107, {ref Orel 1998}:356). Due to the apparent lateness of the borrowing, this loan is treated as separate loan events in Gheg and Tosk (cf. Gheg in /cognate/5505/).
Generally derived from PIE *pleh₂- 'wide, flat' (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:415-416, {ref NIL} 562-564 for further discussion).

Originally a feminine adjectival form of Vedic pr̥thú- 'wide, broad' <*pl̥th₂-ú- as an epithet of the earth, further to PIE *pleth₂- 'to become wide, broad; to spread out' ({ref EWAia} II:161-163, {ref NIL} 564, cf. {ref LIV²} 486-487).

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes from the perfect stem *u̯oi̯d- 'to know' (< *'to have seen') from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to catch sight of' ({ref LIV²} 665-667, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1053, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:211, {ref EWAia} II:579-581, {ref Cheung 2007}:408-409, {ref Derksen 2015}:566, {ref Derksen 2008}:518), Matasović 2009}:422-423).
Parallel loans from Sanskrit sū́rya- 'sun'.

Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑neh₃- 'to perceive, recognise' ({ref LIV²} 168-170, cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:160-161, {ref Malzahn 2010}:609-611, {ref EWAia} I:599-601, {ref Cheung 2007}:466-467, {ref ALEW} 1311-1313, {ref Derksen 2015}:519-520, {ref Derksen 2008}:546, {ref Kroonen 2013}:311-312)

The Modern Greek present stem ξέρω was backformed based on the Ancient Greek aorist stem ἐξεῦρον ({ref Babinotis 2010}:949, cf. ἐξευρίσκω 'find out, discover'). Root ref. form follows {ref LIV²} 698, but cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:482-483 for further discussion.
From Proto-Iranic *u̯ar(H)- 'to choose, convince; (med.) believe' + preverb *u̯i-; root etymology further to PIE *u̯elh₁- 'to choose, select' ({ref Cheung 2007}:420, {ref LIV²} 677-678).

Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *mor-i- 'lake, sea' (ESSJa} 19:227-229, {ref Derksen 2008}:325, {ref Kroonen 2013}:354-355, {ref de Vaan 2008}:365, {ref Matasović 2009}:277; cf. also {ref Derksen 2015}:305-306 for Lithuanian mãrios 'isthmus; (dial.) sea'). Generally considered a western Indo-European isogloss, but cf. a possible further attestation in Iranic via Ossetic mal 'deep standing water' (cf. {ref EIEC} 503-504, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:68-69).

Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rái̯as-, an s-stem noun formed to Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rai̯-'to stretch, extend', cf. Vedic √jray- 'id.', further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:606-607).
Loanword from Turkic, cf. Turkish dengiz 'sea' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:362).
Loanword from Turkic, cf. /cognate/3329/.

No accepted etymology outside of Germanic; cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:292, for the suggestion that Proto-Germanic *saiwi- is a probable non-IE, pre-Gmc. loanword. {ref Kroonen 2013}:423, 435-436 accepts an etymology from IE *sei̯kʷ- without referring to other hypotheses.

North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *watar- ~ *watan- 'water', further from the PIE heteroclite r/n-stem *u̯ód-r̥- ~ *u̯ed-en- 'water', derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ({ref NIL} 706-715, {ref Kroonen 2013}:575-576).

Comment: The Balochi word could be related to *čāt- via *čād- > *čūl (East Iranic) with -ak suffix or borrowed from a Persian form čāh > *čōh > ? *čūh + Turkish -lIK suffix (cf. Rastorgueva/Edelman 2003: 253), cf. Tadjik čalǝk.

Justification: The English word for 'lake' might be inherited from Germanic (cf. OHG lacha 'bog, mire'), but if so in the meaning 'lake' it would appear to be a semantic borrowing from Latin lacus (cf. similarly Greek: Italiot λάκκ̔ο in /cognate/8394/ which might be a semantic calque based on Italian); the cognate Germanic lexemes are unrelated to Lat. lacus, and probably further connected to PIE ?*le⁽g̑⁾- 'drip' (cf. {ref LIV²} 397), otherwise only attested in Celtic ({ref EWA 5}:976-978). If from PIE ?*le⁽g̑⁾- 'drip' then possibly to be connected with Armenian lič in /cognate/607/.
Modern Greek lexemes continuing a diminutive formation of Hellenistic Greek *πούλλο(υ)ς, a loanword from Latin pullus 'young fowl, chicken' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1146).
Hellenic lexemes, ultimately derivatives from PIE *h₃er- 'to set oneself in motion' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1106, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:822-823, {ref LIV²} 299-300).

Anatolian and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ebʰ-. Since {ref Watkins 1973} the Celtic words have been connected to Hittite and Palaic words for 'river' from a PIE n-stem *h₂ebʰ-n-, more recently followed by {ref Willi 2004} and {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:294-295 s.v. Hitt. ḫapa-. A popular alternative analysis reconciles the Celtic words with Indo-Iranic words for 'water' (cf. /cognate/157/) and Baltic and Nuristani lexemes for 'river' (cf. /cognate/7856/) via a derivation using the 'Hoffmann Suffix' *h₂ep-h₃on- (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:23-24 s.v. Proto-Celtic *abon-; {ref NIL} 311-317 tentatively reconstructs for Celtic ?*h₂ep-h₃on-, cf. {ref NIL} with references to further literature), but this analysis must assume an inner-PIE development *-ph₃- > *-b- (e.g. *pi-ph₃-e-ti > Ved. píbati '(s)he drinks'; cf. Lat. bibō with voicing assimilation to the reduplicated syllable). Since the number of examples of *-ph₃- > *-b- are few in number, this must remain a conjectural proposal.  The cognacy in this class therefore follows the etymology of {ref Watkins 1973} to a root *h₂ebʰ-. Cf. also {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:4-5.
Tocharian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *tekʷ- 'to run, flow' ({ref Adams 2013}:267, {ref EWAia} I:610-611, {ref Bailey 1979}:121-122, 182-183, cf. {ref LIV²} 620-621).

Italic lexemes derived from Latin rīpa 'riverbank' from PIE *h₁rei̯p- ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:605, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 10:415-417, {ref de Vaan 2008}:524; cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:574).

Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *dānu-, probably to be further connected with Vedic dā́nu- 'dropping flow, dripping; drops, dew'(?); the possibility of a contamination with Proto-Iranic *dan- < Proto-Indo-Iranic *dʰan- 'to run, flow' (< PIE *dʰenh₂- 'to set in motion; to move off', cf. {ref LIV²} 144-145) is not to be excluded ({ref ESIJa} II:450-451, cf. {ref EWAia} I:719-720, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:366-367).

Although the "Celtic" etymology of OBr. staer figures in the etymological dictionaries, there was never a real discussion of this isolated word, which shares with the Latin and Greek words only the root, not the suffix(es). Bernier, on the other hand, convincingly points out the extensive parallelism in the semantics of staer, ster and estoir, estier and of their use in onomastics.
It seems possible, that Old Breton, being exposes to intense linguistic contace, had several words for river. These were regional varieties or linked to different speaker groups respectively.
Loanword from Old/Middle French riviere 'river' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:629, {ref Favereau 1997a}:641).

Comment: originally name of the river Ganges, cf. Vedic gaṅgā f.
Justification: Continuing Vedic gáṅgā- '(river name), Ganges' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:211 no. 3952), further etymology uncertain. Perhaps a reduplicated nominal formation to Vedic √gam- 'to go' (< PIE *gʷem-) or a pre-IE river name.
Loanword from Indic ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:74, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:774 no. 13415).
Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:210 no. 3943 *khōla- (2) 'cavity, hollow', further etymology uncertain.
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic dhā́ra- 'flow, ray', etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:388 no. 6788, cf. {ref EWAia} I:788-789).

Iranic lexemes, often assumed to be connected with Vedic śákhā- 'limb, branch', although the correspondence of the word-initial sibilants is inexact. Only a reconstructed Proto-Iranic root reference form has therefore been given here, but cf. {ref KEWA} III:321-322, {ref EWAia} II:628 with further discussion.

Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *bando- 'top, peak', as though from Proto-Indo-European *bn̥d-no- which may be further connected to a PIE root *bend-, a root exclusive to Celtic and Germanic (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:54, {ref Delamarre 2003}:66, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:35).

Balto-Slavic lexemes, perhaps to be further connected with PIE *putlo- 'son', but this proposed connection is generally considered to be uncertain ({ref ALEW} 745-746, {ref Derksen 2008}:424-425, {ref Derksen 2015}:375).
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ({ref EWAia} II:370-371, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:593 no. 10265).

Baltic and Nuristani lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ep- 'water, river' ({ref NIL} 311-317, {ref EWAia} I:81-82, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:19, {ref Strand 2011a}, no. 407, {ref ALEW} 1155-1156, {ref Derksen 2015}:483). Perhaps root-cognate with of Anatolian and Celtic lexemes meaning 'river', if the Celtic lexemes are to be analysed as from ?*h₂ep-h₃on- (cf. {ref NIL} 311-317 and further discussion in /cognate/1735/).

This cognate class is coded for Proto-Tocharian *luwā- 'animal'; further connections uncertain. Pace {ref Adams 2013}:606-607, the comparison to Greek λέων is unsatisfactory as this word is likely to be a Near Eastern loanword, cf. Akkadian lābu, Ugaritic lbʾ, Hebrew lābī ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:635, {ref Beekes 2010}:854). Adams's further comparison to OCS lovъ 'the chase' and other Slavic lexemes in the meaning 'hunt' may be possible, but the etymology of these forms are not certainly established (cf. further discussion in /cognate/1145/).

Indic lexemes from Vedic bhadrá- 'fortunate, delightful' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:533, no. 9377). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps from PIE *bʰend- if connected with Germanic *batiza- 'better', but the comparison is uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:244, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:118-119, {ref LIV²} 75). For Assamese and Bengali, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:535 no. 9408.
Etymology outside of Albanian uncertain (cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:268, {ref Orel 1998}:267, {ref Holm 2011}:64) for various proposals).

Extra-Baltic connections uncertain, possibly to PIE *labʰ- if the root is to be reconstructed as such (cf. {ref ALEW} s.v. Lith. lãbas, {ref LIV²} 411-412 s.v. *lembʰ- n1), but such a reconstruction is uncertain, unusually requiring *-a- in the ablaut series. Likewise, the proposed cognates in Greek ἀμφι-λαφής, etc. can be more easily accounted by a zero-grade formation *lm̥bʰ-. {ref Hübschmann 1897}:451 speculatively considered a connection with Armenian law (cf. discussion in /cognate/8081/), but this etymology is not certain and is not even mentioned by {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965} or {ref ALEW}. A lemma for Lithuanian lãbas is lacking in {ref Derksen 2015}. Apart from the as yet uncertain proposal to Vedic rabh- 'seize, grasp', the Baltic lexemes appear to be etymologically isolated.

As through from Sanskrit *rukta- 'bright, liked' to Vedic √roc- 'to shine', further to PIE *leu̯k- 'to be bright' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:621 no. 10755, {ref EWAia} II:463-464, cf. {ref LIV²} 418-419).
Perhaps to be connected to Latin cupiō, -ere 'to desire', but etymology ultimately unclear ({ref Untermann 2000}:405-406, {ref de Vaan 2008}:155).

Comment: < Sanskrit nir-mala- 'spotless, clean' (Up.) ('*having no dirt'), cf. mála-; cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7366; cog. with /cognate/692/
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit nirmala- 'spotless, clean', cf. Vedic mála- 'dirt' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:417 no. 7366). For the further etymology, cf. 'black' in /cognate/1575/, 'dirty' in /cognate/692/.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7150
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic niktá- 'washed, purified' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:409 no. 7150), further derived from PIE *nei̯gʷ- 'to wash' ({ref EWAia} II:54, cf. {ref LIV²} 450).
Etymology outside of Italic unclear ({ref Untermann 2000}:821-822, {ref de Vaan 2008}:651-652).
Cf. Persian javān 'young' from PIE *h₂i̯éu̯-Hon- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:413-414).

Comment: Cf. Ossetic Digoron äxsidzgä "pleasant", Khotanese kṣiṃj- "to desire, long for".

Justification: Iranic words for 'narrow' are better derived from *temk-, cf. already Horn 1893: 89 and Cheung 2007: 377f. Derivation from *tanu-ka- (thus e.g. Korn 2005: 168) might be formally possible but does not really explain the semantic difference found in Persian tang 'narrow' vs. tanuk 'thin'. None of the Iranic forms meaning 'narrow' require *tanu- or *tana-, while there is good evidence for a root *tank-/tanč- 'tp strain, press'.

Hellenic lexemes derived from the adverb πάλαι, probably a fossilised case form of a root noun *pl̥h₂-ei̯ and to be connected with πέλας 'near', πελάζω 'approach, draw near', πίλναμαι 'draw near, approach', πλησίον 'near' (adv.) from *pelh₂-, in the sense *'in the (near, recent) past' > 'old' ({ref Chadwick 1976}, {ref Beekes 2010}:1144-1145). Older etymologies attempting to connect to the same root as Att. τῆλε 'far away' (cf. Aeol. πήλυι) cannot be correct since Mycenaean pa-ra-jo does not contain a labiovelar as one would expect ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:851, {ref Beekes 2010}:1144-1145).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12632 s.v. śodhya- 'be clean(sed)'; cf. LIV, p. 330
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit śodhya- 'to be cleaned' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:733 no. 12632), further derived from a Proto-Indo-Iranic root *ćau̯dʰ- 'to clean, make clean', but further cognates outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:657). {ref LIV²} 330 mechanically reconstructs ?*k̑eu̯dʰ- 'to become clean'.

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic śuddhá- 'clean, bright, white', a derivative of Vedic √śodh- 'to clean, to make clean' and further to Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯dʰ-/*ćudʰ- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:725-726 no. 12520, {ref EWAia} II:657). Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, {ref LIV²} 330 mechanically reconstructs ?*k̑eu̯dʰ- 'to become clean'.
Cf. Latvian maût 'to submerge, swim', Lithuanian máuti, further to PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁- 'to move (oneself)' ({ref ALEW} 621-622, {ref Derksen 2015}:308, 543-544, {ref LIV²} 445-446).

Comment: From the divine name Ahura Mazdā, the principal deity in Zoroastrianism.
Justification: From the divine name Ahura Mazdā, the principal deity in Zoroastrianism ({ref Bailey 1979}:40). The name is often hypothesised to have originally meant 'wise lord' (vel sim.), although the grammatical relations in the noun phrase remain disputed (cf. {ref Encyclopædia Iranica} s.v.). Because of the substantivisation of the noun from a compound theonym, it is difficult to isolate a semantic head for etymological analysis. For etymological discussion of the individual elements of the original compound / noun phrase, cf. {ref EWAia} I:147-148 (~ OAv. ahura-), {ref EWAia} II:378 (~ OAv. mazdā-).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12525 s.v. *śudhya-; from Vedic śúdhyate 'becomes pure, clear; is purified, clear', cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 657; thus ultimately from PIE *k̑eu-dʰ- (from *k̑eu-), cf. LIV, p. 330
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯dʰ- 'to clean, make pure', cf. Vedic √śodh- 'to become clean, pure'. Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:726 no. 12525, {ref EWAia} II:657; {ref LIV²} 330 mechanically reconstructs PIE ?*k̑eu̯dʰ-).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *swellan- 'to swell', without certain connections outside of Germanic ({ref Seebold 1970}:489-490, {ref Kroonen 2013}:499).

Traditionally compared to Proto-Germanic *weϸra- ~ *wedra- 'weather' and further connected with PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- via *h₂uh₁-edʰr-o- or *u̯edʰrom, although there are formal difficulties in the reconstruction of the Germanic comparanda (cf. discussion in /cognate/9440/). The difficulties in the reconstruction of the Germanic form, however, do not preclude the possibility of the derivation of the Slavic form being ultimately derived from PIE **h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow', however the uncertainty over the etymological identity of the proposed Germanic cognates weakens the case somewhat (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:513, {ref Kroonen 2013}:583-584, {ref Snoj 1997-2016} 4:287-288).

Comment: lit. "to make wind"
Justification: Iranic lexemes in light verb constructions, literally 'to make wind'. Cf. {ref EWAia} II:542 and 'wind' in /cognate/342/ for further etymological discussion.
As though from *ā-prus-a- 'bubble up' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:84 no. 1832), further to PIE *preu̯s- 'to spray, spatter' ({ref EWAia} II:192-193, {ref LIV²} 493).

Nuristani lexemes in light verb constructions. Cognacy in this set is coded for 'water', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:19 no. 407 s.v. Vedic áp-, pl. ā́paḥ 'waters'. For further etymological discussion, cf. 'water' in /cognate/157/.

Hellenic, Indic, and Slavic lexemes from PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ({ref LIV²} 487-488, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1208-1209, {ref EWAia} II:194-196). Assignment of the Slavic lexemes to this class follows {ref LIV²} 487-488 and other sources, but cf. reservations of {ref Derksen 1996}:116-117, {ref Derksen 2008}:403.
Middle Indic lexemes continuing a derivative of Vedic √sphā- 'to come fat, plump', further to PIE *sp⁽ʰ⁾eh₁- ({ref EWAia} II:776-777, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:799 no. 13828, cf. {ref LIV²} 584).

Brythonic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *su̯ei̯d-e/o- 'to swell up', generally connected with PIE 1. *su̯ei̯d- 'to break out in sweat' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:610-611, {ref Matasović 2009}:362, cf. {ref LIV²} 607).

Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Old Indic madhurá- 'sweet', a secondary derivative of Old Indic mádhu- 'honey, mead' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:562 no. 9793), further from PIE *medʰu- 'mead, honey; sweet drink; alcoholic drink' ({ref EWAia} II:302-303, cf. {ref EIEC} 271).

Comment: Only non-active forms in Alb. denote 'to swim'
Justification: Albanian lexemes probably continuing PIE *leu̯h₃-e/o- with a present-stem n-suffix ({ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:980, {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}; for the root reconstruction, cf. {ref Melchert 2011}). For older literature, cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:237, {ref Huld 1984}:85, {ref Demiraj 1997}:230-231, {ref Orel 1998}:210.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *sterta- 'tail', possibly a dental-enlarged root *sterd- to PIE *ster- 'stiff' but uncertain, cf. {ref EWNl}, {ref Kluge 2011:877, 883, {ref de Vries 1977}:547, {ref Orel 2003}:376).

North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *halan- 'tail, tip', traditionally further compared variously with Sanskrit śalá- 'staff', Middle Irish cail 'spear', Ancient Greek κῆλον 'shaft, arrow' from a proposed IE root *k̑el- 'to prick, sting' ({ref IEW} 552, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:204, {ref Orel 2003}:156, {ref Kroonen 2013}:203; not in {ref LIV²}), but more sceptically regarding the proposed comparanda cf. {ref EWAia} II:615-616, {ref KEWA} III:306, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:10-11, {ref Beekes 2010}:685.

Comment: Is there any reason to suspect that the Elfdalian is a more recent loanword from Swedish rumpa 'tail' instead of being inherited?

Justification:
See discussion under https://cobl.info/cognate/5697/.  And see also https://cobl.info/cognate/9688/.
Inclusion of Luxembourgish here is questionable, as not directly derived from Middle *High* German, but it is not clear that this loanword appears so early that there was likely little real separation of the Luxembourgish lineage from those that led to the other languages included in this cognate set.
See discussion under https://cobl.info/cognate/5512/

Difficult case to analyse.  The term is known across various North Germanic languages:  Faroese, Swedish, Danish and Riksmal.  Because Riksmal lexicon derives from Danish essentially only in the last few centuries, those can be considered not parallel, whereas the case seems to support more a parallel loan view for the other languages.  The Riksmal and Danish are therefore now to be split off into a separate non-parallel loan cognate set, https://cobl.info/cognate/9687/.  (An alternative analysis is that the loan event was into very early Norse, with a meaning shift in parallel since, but since no Old Norse form is registered here, we do not follow that analysis.)

Germanic lexemes continuing an early loan into West Germanic from Latin cūpa, cuppa 'cup, bowl'. For the semantic development, cf. similarly within Romance: Fr. tête 'head' < Lat. testa 'earthenware vessel, tile, sherd, vessel' in /cognate/3171/.
The loan event is taken here as so early that it would have introduced e lexeme into a very early form of Continental West Germanic, before these three lineages (standard German , Luxembourgish and Bernese) diverged from each other, so this is not a parallel loan.  Only these three would then have made the semantic shift to the 'head' meaning, whether in parallel or still at the stage of a later, narrower common ancestor of theirs.  That this shift is not yet recorded in our Middle High German list, however, supports the idea of parallel semantic shift, but after an original non-parallel loan to enter the Germanic lexicon (with an originally different meaning).

The West Germanic lexemes in this set are parallel loans from Old French. 
The same original Old French source was also loaned into other West Germanic languages. 
 Given the timing of the loans after the basic Dutch/German fragmentation is taken to have already begun, these define separate loan event cognate sets:   
https://cobl.info/cognate/9688/ in Dutch;  https://cobl.info/cognate/9689/ in Upper German. 

A later, follow-on loan-event from Middle Low German into North Germanic languages, is https://cobl.info/cognate/5697/.  

Cf. {ref Den Danske Ordbog}. {ref Kluge 2011}:777-778, {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}, {ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok}).

See discussion under https://cobl.info/cognate/5697/.  And see also https://cobl.info/cognate/9689/.
The loan is so early that it is inconsistent to call it a parallel loan into both Middle and modern Dutch, rather than a loanword event type that at least Modern Dutch did inherit by transmission from Middle Dutch (or a closely related variety).

The North Germanic lexemes in this set are likely to be loans from Middle Low German, of a word originally borrowed from Old French.

See the other loan event cognate sets that also go back to this same Old French source:
https://cobl.info/cognate/9688/ in Dutch;  
https://cobl.info/cognate/9689/ in Upper German, 
https://cobl.info/cognate/9690/ as a parallel loan into English and Frisian

Cf. {ref Den Danske Ordbog}. {ref Kluge 2011}:777-778, {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}, {ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok}).

Loan from Early Low German ({ref de Vries 1977}:368). The inherited lexeme is found in Elfdalian 'smell' /cognate/8301/ and 'sky' in /cognate/2903/.  Since this is present in Old Norse, the case can be made that this is not necessarily a parallel loan, although the inclusion of Faroese in this set suggests the loan must have been particularly early.

The connection of the forms in this class to those from PIE *pstḗn in /cognate/2217/ is disputed, and rest on assuming that it is root-cognate with a gloss στήνιον from Hesychius's Lexicon. The word-formation within Greek is, however, unclear ({ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:795, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1054-1055, {ref Beekes 2010}:1403-1404, cf. {ref IEW} 990).
Parallel loans from Old French.  See also https://cobl.info/cognate/6198/, a further cognate set with the same Old French loan source, but parallel loans into English and Frisian..
Parallel loans from Old French.  See also https://cobl.info/cognate/9691/, a further cognate set with the same Old French loan source, but including inheritance after the initial loan event..

Comment: etymology unknown.
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:135, {ref Holm 2011}:54-55, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:265 for further discussion.

Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *takan- 'to touch; take', probably further to be derived from PIE *teh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'to touch, grasp' ({ref LIV²} 616-617, {ref Kroonen 2013}:507, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:507).
