Modern Greek lexemes continuing Medieval Greek ἐπαίρνω, a remodelled nasal-present stem continuing Ancient Greek ἐπαίρω 'lift up' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1021), except Tsakonian: Peloponnese αζ̌ίκ̔ου < *αρ-ίσκω ({ref Andriotis 1974}:76), both continuing the basic verbal root of Ancient Greek αἴρω ~  ἀείρω 'to raise'. Probably further to a PIE root *h₂u̯er- 'to hang' ({ref LIV²} 290, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:23-24).
Original sense 'female breast' derived from PIE *dʰeh₁(i̯)- 'to suckle' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:875-877).
Loanword from Low German borst 'chest' (cf. Middle Dutch borst 'id.').

Root etymology for the Hellenic lexemes in this class follows {ref LIV²} 535 as though from PIE *sr̥-i̯é- to PIE 3. *ser- 'to take, seize, grasp', but cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} I:43-44, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:38, {ref Beekes 2010}:42 (without reference to new literature in {ref LIV²}).

Lexemes as though continuing Proto-Celtic *kom-ber-e/o- 'bring together', whose basic verbal root *ber- continues PIE *bʰer- 'to carry, bring' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:218-223, {ref Matasović 2009}:214, 62, cf. {ref LIV²} 76-77, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Deshayes 2003}:382-383).
Cf. Old Lithuanian krẽklas 'female breast'; no certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 523).
Old Frisian has berna while the Modern West Frisian variant is baarne, which is not a loanword

Tocharian, Armenian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *pstḗn ({ref IEW} 990, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:386, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:584-585, {ref EWAia} II:752). The potential connection of the Greek forms from Ancient Greek στῆθος (/cognate/8545/) to this class is disputed, and rest on assuming that it is root-cognate with a gloss στήνιον from Hesychius's Lexicon. The word-formation within Greek is, however, unclear ({ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:795, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1054-1055, {ref Beekes 2010}:1403-1404).

Identical to Irish cliabh ({ref Broaderick 1984b}:83-84) from Old Irish clíab 'basket, woven container, hive'. Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:118 for a suggestion to Old Norse hlíf 'shield'.
Italic and Romance lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry (through heat)' ({ref LIV²} 257-258, {ref de Vaan 2008}:53, {ref Untermann 2000}:130-131, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:50 no. 620).

Two possible Indo-European etymologies, either (1) derived to PIE *h₂eh₁- as a denominal verb from *ayr- 'fire' compared to Av. ātar-/āθr- 'fire', Lat. āter 'black, dark', OIr. āith 'furnace', Palaic ḫā- 'be hot' ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:418), or (2) from PIE *h₂ei̯dʰ-, cf. Gk. αἴθω 'to kindle, burn', Skt. edh- 'to set alight, kindle; shine' ({ref Jasanoff 1979}:145, {ref Viredaz 2003}:85). Alternatively {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:98n16 has assumed an Iranian loanword. (Cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:63).

From PIE *u̯erh₁- 'to be hot'; the root reference form for this set follows the reconstruction of {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:923-925, cf. {ref LIV²} 689 reconstructing *u̯erH- with indeterminate final laryngeal.

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic vā́ma- 'left', presumably a euphemistic replacement from Vedic vāmá- 'dear', no further etymology ({ref EWAia} II:543-544, {ref KEWA} III:189, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:672-673, no. 11533).

Root etymology uncertain. Perhaps to *h₂er- 'to fit (together)' (cf. {ref LIV²} 269-270) in the original sense 'more fitting' > 'better' > 'the better side, left' via popular euphemism ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:106-107, {ref Beekes 2010}:128, 131-132).

Ossetic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *čarH- 'to come and go, wander', further to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, to turn' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:303, {ref Cheung 2007}:33-35, {ref EWAia} I:534-535, cf. {ref LIV²} 386-388).

No convincing etymology outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:525). {ref HED L}:97-98 suggests a connection to Armenian leard, but the Armenian forms are more generally considered to be connected to the inherited IE word for 'liver' (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:306-307 and notes to /cognate/718/).

A relationship of this lexeme to PS *trěskati, a lexeme referring to sounds made by splitting or cracking things, seems reasonable. For the semantic development cf. PS *drobŭ *drobŭ (>)'guts' and PS *drobiti 'shatter, crush' (cognate/1153/). However, taking into account ideophonic origin of the PS root(s) and the irregular sound shape of PS *troxa that has to be assumed by accepting this relationship, no reliable further etymology can be found.
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰegʷ- 'to run away, flee' (cf. {ref LIV²} 67, {ref ESSJa} 2:58-60, 92, {ref ALEW} 103-104, {ref Derksen 2008}:40-41, {ref Derksen 2015}:85-86).

Probably from Armenian *əndi (< PIE *h₂ent-i) prefixed to *tʰana- (< PIE ?*pt-n(e)-h₂-) ({ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:114-115, {ref LIV²} 479). Alternatively {ref HAB} II:125-126, {ref IEW} 908 proposes to PIE *sent- 'gehen' but this is phonologically difficult (cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:114).
More archaic is lofts (still part of the written language)..

Baltic and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- are traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from putative PIE *dʰeb- 'thick, firm, solid' ({ref IEW} 239). Due to the rarity of PIE *b and the areal proximity of the languages, however, these cognates might not be of Indo-European date, if they even are cognate at all. Note that because the Leiden school doubts the existence of PIE *b, the Leiden dictionaries reconstruct a *dʰebʰ-. This, however, causes problems for formal correspondences with the Germanic (although cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:89 attempting to save the etymology by invoking analogy with the Germanic iterative stem *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' as though from *dʰobʰ-néh₂-). Cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:97-98, {ref Derksen 2015}:530-531, {ref Kroonen 2013}:89, {ref Kluge 2011}:907 for further discussion.

Root reconstruction difficult. A contamination between two (possibly related) roots *teu̯h₂- and *teu̯k- is a possibility. Cf. discussion in citations to this cognate class. Cf. also Germanic words for 'thigh' in /cognate/6956/.

Comment: cf. Skrt. jaḍa- 'stupid, dumb', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5090

Justification: Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin gurdus 'blockhead, stupid person' ({ref DCECH} III:173, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:333). A root-etymology to a zero-grade form *gʷr̥d-  might be found with the family of lexemes found in Greek βραδύς 'slow', Lithuanian gurdùs 'id.', Latv. gur̃ds 'tired', OCS grьdъ 'haughty, proud' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:275, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:275); in antiquity the grammarian Quintilian considered Latin gurdus a word of Spanish origin.
Frisian doesn't have open syllable lengthening - cannot be Frisian; OFri. liwere

Etymology in this class follows {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1008-1009 to PIE 2. *u̯elH- 'to roll' (cf. {ref LIV²} 677), but cf. {ref Huld 1984}:130, {ref Orel 1998}:511 to 2. *u̯el- 'spin, roll' (cf. Lat. uoluō 'turn', etc.).

Comment: Probably an experiencer construction: "one's heart comes up/beats" with "heart" for the inner part of the body or the inner condition.

Justification: To be connected with lexemes meaning 'to crack' in other Germanic languages (cf. OHG krahhōn, OE cracian), but ultimately of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok} s.v. kräkas, {ref Kluge 2011}:535).
more archaic is libje (still used by a minority of speakers)
the archaic form is tsjok - rarely used nowadays
[frɔu] - likely from Middle Dutch; Also 'person'. AF: mins.
comp. EFri. dialects säie, sii etc.

Considered to be a loanword from Medieval Latin boscus in earlier literature, but given that the Medieval Latin form (and its descendants in modern Romance languages) have no clear etymology from earlier Italic, the Germanic forms are now generally considered to be inherited, although their further etymology is obscure. It remains possible that the Medieval Latin and the Germanic forms are independent borrowings from a third source (cf. {ref EWA 2}:474-476, {ref Kluge 2011}:165).

Comment: some NIA forms may be blends with grāsa m. ʻmouthful', √gras- 'devour', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4379
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic ghāsá- 'food, pasture grass' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:241 no. 4471), a derivative of Vedic √ghas- 'to eat, consume', cf. Young Avestan gah- 'to eat, devour'; further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:514; {ref LIV²} 198-199 mechanically reconstructs ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'to eat, devour, consume').

Cognacy in this set follows {ref Cheung 2007}:93 to Proto-Iranic *gah- 'to devour', but cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:33 suggesting instead to *gaz- 'to bite'. Outside of Iranic further cf. Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰas-, cf. Vedic √ghas- 'to eat, devour, gnaw'. No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic. {ref LIV²} 198-199 mechanically reconstructs  ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'to eat, devour, consume'.

Although also the name of the internal organ 'stomach', in the variety of English targeted here, i.e. standard British English and following majority usage in England, the word 'stomach' has broadened to refer to the abdomen in general, and is has become the default, unmarked word for the target sense here.  The lexeme 'belly' is more marked in register, often with overtones of a protruding 'pot belly'..

See also the independent loan of the same ultimate Greek source lexeme into a variety of Macedonian, at https://cobl.info/cognate/7400.
'sick' is a Germanic root, found also in Dutch and German, for example.

Comment: cf. Avestan gah- and Sanskrit ghas-.
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *gah- 'to gorge, devour', further from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰas-, cf. Vedic √ghas- 'to eat, devour, gnaw'. The Khwarezmian lexeme would contain the preverb *apa- ({ref MacKenzie 1975}:392, {ref Samadi 1986}:17, {ref Cheung 2007}:93), while the Sogdian form probably continues a form with preverb *uz- as though *uz-gahaya- vel sim. (Nicholas Sims-Williams, p.c.). No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic. {ref LIV²} 198-199 mechanically reconstructs  ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'to eat, devour, consume'.

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing an inherited word for 'tooth', widely considered to continue a participle *h₁d-ónt- to the verbal root *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', lexicalised as 'tooth' already in PIE ({ref NIL} 208-220, {ref LIV²} 230-231, {ref EIEC} 594). Under this explanation the original Ancient Greek form would be continued by Aeolic ἔδοντ-, which underwent vowel assimilation in other dialects. The Leiden School of Indo-European reconstruction alternatively reconstructs a distinct root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' following {ref Kortlandt 2003}:77, who argues that it would better account for ὀδών much more straightforwardly, and it would also much better account for the Ancient Greek privative adjective νωδός 'toothless' < *n̥-h₃d-ó-, (expected †νηδός < *n̥-h₃d-ó-); as for Aeolic ἔδοντ-, it only occurs in late grammatical texts and could have itself been created on the basis of an analogy to Greek ἔδ- 'eat'. For individual branches, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:776, {ref Beekes 2010}:1049, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:1049, {ref EWAia} I:693-694, {ref ALEW} 174-175, {ref Derksen 2015}:115, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:169, {ref de Vaan 2008}:166-167, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:62-63 {ref Matasović 2009}:90).
